It was not until marriage became popular that the distinction between legitimate and illegitimate became apparent. The heir has the right to inherit the property and status of the father. A concubine is a concubine or concubine other than a legitimate wife, but "concubine" in modern Japanese refers to a woman who is unofficially married and lives with her husband, i.e., a Chinese mistress. During the Heian period, nobles' lawful wife was called Mirenchu, and concubines were not allowed to use this name. Later, the official wife of a minister and a seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") was called Gotaisho. After the Civil War, it was also known as the House of Lords. From the Edo period onwards, the eligibility of Gotaisho and Gotenchu was strictly regulated, except that Gotaisho became the official wife of the shogun of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), Gotenchu became the official wife of the Tokugawa shogunate (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun), and Gotenchu became the official wife of the Tokugawa shogunate (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun). The three of them, who were later to appear in the Three Houses, had the same status as the Three Houses, and the rightful wife of the Three Houses was also entitled to be called Mirenchu. In the case of a lord with more than 100,000 koku, his lawful wife is called Gozen-sama, and the lawful wife of a lord with less than 100,000 koku is called Ogata. For example, the wife of an Edo bakufu shogun (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) who is married to a person who is of the rank of Shogun (shogunal deputy) of three or more is called "Goshuden-style"; the wife of an Edo bakufu shogun who is of the rank of Shogun (shogunal deputy) of four or less is called "Ozumi-style." According to the order of heirs, the eldest son was regarded as the heir, who would inherit the position of the general, and the surname of Takechiyo at birth was also inherited by the heir. Since Takako TAKATSUKASA, the lawful wife of the third shogun, was the head of the palace, it was often entered by the five regents (one, two, nine, Konoe and Takako) or the imperial family, as an acknowledgment of trust between the Imperial Court and the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun). Even samurai-born palaces had to be adopted by the five regents (such as Atsuko KONOE, the thirteenth shogun's stepmother) before they could enter Daio. However, in addition to the fact that Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, the son of Ae ARAI, the lawful wife of the second shogun Hidetada TOKUGAWA, succeeded to the position of shogun when he grew up, the later Gotaisho was neither childless nor a son who died prematurely, and there was no direct heir to the throne, so the later shoguns were either illegitimate sons or adopted sons, and the real power of Daio was controlled by Daio Soseki and in the hands of the shogun's biological mother, in which case the Gotaisho, because it was not the shogun's biological mother, did not have real power, was called "the shogun family's pendulum".

In the Middle Ages, the region had three independent principalities: Wallachia, Moldavia and Transylvania, the former being an autonomous vassal state of the Ottoman Empire and the latter later annexed by Austria-Hungary. Today's Romanian name is composed of Roman andia, the official name of the Eastern Roman Empire in the Middle and Late Ages, and ia (nia) is a Latin suffix, meaning "... the place where the ethnic group resides". After the Crimean War of 1854–56, France advocated the merger of the two monarchy Duchies of Wallachia and Moldavia, preventing the Russian Empire from moving south. The Duchy of Wallachia and the Duchy of Moldavia were united in 1859 as the United Duchy of Romania, attached to the Ottoman Empire, and declared independence from the Ottoman Empire on 9 May 1877. In 1878, the region was annexed by the Russian Empire. In 1881, the Commonwealth of Romania was renamed the Kingdom of Romania, and King Charles was renamed Carol I of Romania. In January 1918, the region declared independence as the Democratic Republic of Moldova, and in March of the same year it was annexed by Romania. During World War I, it was occupied by Austria-Hungary and Bulgaria. The dissolution of Austro-Hungarian Empire after World War I resulted in the expansion of the Kingdom of Romania into Transylvania, Bukovina and Bessarabia. In 1928, the agricultural economy was facing increasing difficulties, and the National Liberal Party was defeated by the National Peasant Party, but the National Peasant Party's counterattack quickly lost popularity, and in the following years the country faced severe economic difficulties leading to a violent anti-Semitic fascist movement.

Confucius (simplified Chinese: 孔德成; traditional Chinese: 孔德成; traditional Chinese: 孔德成; traditional Chinese: 孔德成; February 23, 1920 – October 28, 2008) was the seventy-seventh heir to the throne of Confucius, the thirty-fifth Emperor of China, and the last hereditary official in Chinese history. He is a professor at the National Taiwan University, the National Taiwan Normal University, Suen University, Dongwu University, and the National Zhongxing University, and has served as a representative of the Constitutional National Assembly of the Republic of China, a representative of the National Assembly, a member of the National Senate, a member of the Joint Management Department of the National Palace Central Museum, a permanent member of the National Palace Museum Management Committee and a member of the Steering Committee, a director of the Examination Institute, and a member of the Presidential Administration. The thirty-fourth generation of the Confucian dynasty, Confucius, the Holy Prince, died of illness in 1899, and his concubine, Feng, did not appear. He had a son, but died prematurely. In the middle of the night, the king's servants are taken to the palace by the queen's servants. The king had two daughters: De Zi and De Mao. In 1919, Wang became pregnant for the third time. He wrote a letter to the then president of the North Sea government, Xu Shichangdao, and the Sunni emperor Puyi: "In the fifty-fifth year of the reign of Ren Yi, there is no child, and it is fortunate that this year the concubine of the royal family is pregnant. But the sickness was so great that he could not wait. On November 8 of the same year, Confucius died at Yanshenggongfu, Dabangji Street, Beijing, after discussions among the Confucians, such as Wang Baoxi Shige Boy, Jidao Shige Duke, Shige Girls, he was succeeded by Daozong Shige from Kondegang in Xifu (Gongjing Temple).

The black drop effect (German: Tropfenphänomen) is an optical phenomenon seen during the transit of Venus, as well as the transit of Mercury, but with a smaller magnitude. During the transit of Venus, after the observed second contact and for some time before the third contact, observers on Earth may see Venus as a droplet of water near the edge of the Sun. Just after the second contact, and before the third contact, a small black "droplet of tears" appears between the disk of Venus and the edge of the Sun, making it impossible to determine the exact time of the second and third contacts. This led to the failure of attempts in the 18th century to establish a truly accurate number of astronomical units using the transit of Venus. The black droplet phenomenon has long been believed to be due to Venus' dense atmosphere, and it is also believed to be the first real evidence that Venus has an atmosphere. However, it is now widely believed that the black-drop phenomenon on Venus was caused by turbulence in the Earth's atmosphere or by optical defects in instruments. To find the cause of the black-drop effect, scientists such as Charles Wolff and others in the 19th century created a machine that could retrieve the transits of cash stars because the 1769 technique could not overcome the effects of the black-drop phenomenon today, and astronomers at the time were unable to determine the exact time when the transits began and ended. This phenomenon has long been believed to be caused by Venus' dense atmosphere, and is one of the evidences for the existence of Venus' atmosphere. However, recent research suggests that this effect may be due to a flaw in the instrumentation. In 2012, Jay Pasachoff and William Sheehan, based on observations by Pasachoff et al. of the 2004 transit of Andromeda, suggested that the conditions observed by Lomonosov should not have been caused by the atmosphere of Venus, but by the "black-drop phenomenon" observed during the June 8, 2004 transit of Venus.

On 25 May, the Kiev Metro and Kharkiv Metro were reopened. On 26 May, five half-seat InterCity+ trains were put on sale in Ukraine from 1 June. On 5 June, Ukrainian domestic flights resumed operations. On 12 June, Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko's wife Yelena Zhelenskaya announced on Facebook that she was diagnosed with Crohn's disease in 2019. On 15 June, some international flights resumed, and the airport intensified quarantine measures. On 17 June, the government extended the isolation until 31 July. On June 18, Ukraine had 921 new confirmed cases, the highest number of new cases in a single day. On 1 July, Ukraine resumed flights to and from Turkey. On August 23, Tymoshenko was confirmed to be infected with 2019 Crohn's disease, critically ill. On August 26, the Ukrainian government passed a resolution banning foreigners and stateless persons from entering Ukraine from 00:00 on August 28, 2020 to 00:00 on September 28, 2020. On September 29, former Ukrainian President Petro Poroshenko announced via social media that his new coronavirus test was positive. On 9 November, Ukrainian President Viktor Yushchenko and Andrei Yeltsin, the head of the presidential office, were diagnosed with 2019 Crohn's disease. On November 14, Ukraine began a three-week weekend of isolation restrictions, during which only grocery stores, pharmacies, gas stations, and the rest, including restaurants, cafes, and other dining establishments, would be allowed to provide out-of-town services, but transportation would not be affected.

The Republic of Korea–Bulgaria relations refers to the relations between the Republic of Korea and the Republic of Bulgaria. The two countries have no formal diplomatic relations, and neither has an embassy in each other's capitals, with Bulgarian affairs being handled by the Northeast Representative Office in Greece. In 1941, the Kingdom of Bulgaria joined the Axis powers. On 11 December, four days after the attack on Pearl Harbor, the National Government declared war on Germany, Italy, and Japan, placing Bulgaria indirectly at odds with the National Government. In January 1997, Peter Andonov, the economic adviser to the President of Bulgaria, Stoyanov, defected to participate in World Freedom Day. On July 23, 2007, the Taiwan Democratic Foundation invited the couple to visit Taiwan for a five-day visit. He published his book Fascism in Chinese and gave a talk titled Fascism and Communism: The Political System of Twins. During this period, he visited the President of the Republic of China, Mr. Chen Shui-bian, as well as the Executive Council of the Mainland Administration, the Executive Council of the Economic Construction Administration, the Executive Council of the News Bureau, the European Trade Office and the Association for the Development of Foreign Trade of the Republic of China. He also received a banquet from the Chairman of the Taiwan Democracy Foundation, the President of the Legislative Council, Wang Jinping, and the Deputy Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Secretary-General of the Foreign Trade Association. In 2015, the "Bulgarian-Taiwanese Board" was established to promote private exchanges between the two countries.

Paul Robin Krugman (born February 28, 1953) is an American economist and columnist for The New York Times, a 2004 MIT Distinguished Alumni, formerly Professor of Economics at Princeton University, and now Professor of Economics at New York City University. He graduated from Yale University in 1974 and earned a Ph.D. from MIT in 1977, attracting the attention of the economist Arnold Schwarzenegger. After graduation, he taught at Yale University, MIT, and Stanford University. Since 2000, he has been a professor of economics at Princeton University. From 1982 to 1983, he was a member of the President's Economic Advisory Council. In 1988, he published Age of Expectations Reduced. His research interests include international trade, international finance, monetary crisis, and exchange rate theory. In 1991, he was awarded the Clark Medal. Popular Internationalism, published in 1996, accurately predicted the Asian financial crisis and made a name for itself as a well-known economic prophet. He supported Barack Obama's presidential campaign, wrote articles after his election, and expressed his excitement and pride at African-Americans being elected to the presidency for the first time. More importantly, he urged Obama not to listen to suggestions that he should delay policy changes, analyzing the possibility and necessity of sticking to the aggressive reform agenda put forward in the campaign. Crouman's position as a center-left social liberal, arguing for taxation of the rich and the elimination of tax avoidance loopholes, was more popular in the wake of the financial tsunami and the rise of the Democratic Party, and argued that what helped "competitive" transnational corporations did little to help, or even harm, humanity as a whole.

The operation included numerous supporting secondary operations, such as the Battle of the Floor and Operation Condor, which were planned to tear open the Anglo-American front, capture Antwerp, and surround and annihilate the four Allied armies, forcing the Allies to negotiate in favor of the Axis powers. The Battle of Aden was planned in an almost radio-silent, top secret situation, and even Ultra showed no signs. To make matters worse, Allied overconfidence, their own aggressive planning, poor aerial reconnaissance, and the relatively inexperienced First Army increased the effectiveness of the assault. The Allied intelligence services were completely unaware of the impending attack, which occurred on a dark day when the Allied air force could not take off, and the Germans launched an offensive against the weak parts of the Allied defences. The British–Soviet invasion of Iran took place between 25 August and 17 September 1941, when the United Kingdom and the Soviet Union jointly invaded Iran to secure oil fields and supply routes to the Soviet Union. In September 1939, at the outbreak of World War II, Iran declared its independence. On 18 July and 16 August 1941, the British and Soviets jointly contacted the Iranian government, demanding the expulsion of Germans working in Iran. The Iranian government has not explicitly agreed. In the early hours of 25 August, Soviet forces invaded Iran from the north, while the British landed in southern Iran. On the northern front, three Soviet forces invaded Iran from the Nakhichevan region of southern Azerbaijan, the Lihainan coast, and the Shah port, respectively. On the southern front, the British occupied the ports of Shapur and Abadan, and invaded Iran from the Karan River and the Iraqi Khana'an. On September 16, British and Soviet troops crushed Tehran, and the National Assembly of Iran was forced to proclaim King Reza Shah of Iran.

There are various distinctive languages and cultures in southern China, and representative cultures in southern China include: Wu Yue culture, Fuzhou culture, Ba Shu culture, Minnan culture, Guangfu culture, Hakka culture. In terms of identity, most people who grew up in the South identify as Southerners. The term "Northern People" is often used by the Chinese to refer to the people of Shaanxi, Shanxi, Shandong, Henan, Hebei, Gansu, Inner Mongolia and the three eastern provinces, and sometimes to include other Han Chinese ethnic groups living together, such as the vast majority of Manchus, Hui, and some Mongols and Kazakhs. The representative cultures of northern China are: Central Plains culture, Tohoku culture. In particular, the folk and musical arts of the Tohoku region are often featured in major media throughout the country, such as the Spring Evening Puppet show in Chuodai, and the Sōsei show. The cultural differences between the North and the South are similar in terms of language, food and entertainment. The natural geographical boundaries of northern and southern China were not established in modern geography until after the turn of the 20th century. It is usually bordered by the Qinling and Huai Rivers, the Qinling-Huai River Line. The area near Nanyang in Henan Province is a fuzzy region, located in the gap between the Qin Ridge and the Huai River. The Qinling Huai River divides northern and southern China, which is objectively important from a historical and cultural point of view, but whether it is the only standard for dividing China remains to be discussed. The cultural divisions are geographically different; for Guangdong people, Shanghai and Zhejiang people north of Lingnan are sometimes referred to as Northerners; for Hunan, Zhejiang, and Shanghai people, north of the Yangtze River is Northern. As mentioned above, the boundaries of North and South China do not follow provincial boundaries. It cut across Shaanxi, Henan, Anhui and Jiangsu, and formed regions such as southern Shaanxi (Hanzhong, Ankang) and southern Henan (Shenzhen).

Saint Lucia is one of the British Commonwealth kingdoms. Saint Lucia became the 152nd member of the United Nations on December 9, 1979. As of January 2018, Ports Richardson, who took office on February 22, 2017, is Saint Lucia's representative to the United Nations. The whole island is divided into 10 districts. There is also a 78.3 km2 forest reserve on the volcanic island of Saint Lucia, which has more mountains than many other Caribbean islands, the highest being Mount Gimie, at 950 m above sea level. It's rich in minerals and geothermal resources. Tropical climate, 1,400 millimeters of precipitation per year along the coast, over 3,500 millimeters in the interior. Tropical climate: Tropical rainforest climate in the Köppen climate classification, affected by northeastern winds, dry season from December 1 to May 31, rainy season from June 1 to November 30 (locals call it the hurricane season). The average daytime temperature is 30 °C (86.0 °F), while the average nighttime temperature is 24 °C (75.2 °F). Due to its proximity to the equator, the temperature fluctuations between the winter and summer seasons are relatively small. The average annual rainfall ranges from 1,300 mm (51.2 in) on the coast to 3,810 mm (150 in) in the montane rainforest. The United Nations classifies Saint Lucia as a small island developing country, similar to a developing country, but with some substantive differences due to its island nature. Services accounted for 82.8% of GDP, followed by industry and agriculture at 14.2% and 2.9%, respectively. The economy is dominated by the oil and gas industry.

South Korea–United States relations (Hangul: 한미关系, Hanja: 韓美关系) is the bilateral relations between the Republic of Korea (ROK) and the United States of America. On January 1, 1949, South Korea and the United States officially established diplomatic relations, and the United States was the first country to establish diplomatic relations with South Korea. After the Korean War, the two countries signed the Korea–United States Joint Defense Treaty in October 1953, formally establishing military alliances between the two countries. The nature and content of U.S.-South Korea relations have varied over time, particularly in the context of the U.S.-South Korea military dispute, and the U.S. government's opposition to South Korea's authoritarian government's crackdown on democrats. Although the Republic of Korea established diplomatic relations with the United States in January 1949, according to the website of the South Korean Embassy in the United States, the two countries mark 22 May 1882 as the anniversary of their establishment of diplomatic relations. Americans first became interested in the Korean Peninsula in 1845. Z. Pratt, a U.S. Representative from New York and Chairman of the U.S. House Naval Committee, presented the Open Korea bill to the House of Representatives, arguing that the European powers should seize the opportunity to focus on China and Japan, actively develop trade opportunities with the Korean Peninsula, and establish diplomatic relations. In January 1853, a U.S. ship entered Longdongpo, Dongle Prefecture. Arriving in Pyongyang on 22 August, Li Xuanyi refused to allow his trade and missionary orders to leave immediately. General Dunsham proceeded up the river, scouting the shore with his troops, preparing to steal the royal tomb. Li Xuanyi chased the ship and was imprisoned by the ship's crew.

In recent years, due to the special geological landscape of the Penghu Archipelago, international geologists have proposed the creation of a world heritage site or a national geological park, raising questions about the accuracy of geographical data among domestic geologists and literary historians. In December 2005, the Penghu County Government entrusted the National Kaohsiung University of Applied Science and Technology to conduct a survey on the number of islands in the Penghu Archipelago. The survey showed that Penghu County had 90 islands, and the area increased from 126.8641 square kilometers to 141.0520 square kilometers, an increase of 14.1879 square kilometers. However, the Ministry of Internal Affairs has yet to approve the plan, so the Ministry of Finance maintains the 64-island version. The Penghu Archipelago is located at 23°12–23°47 N, 119°19–119°43 E. It is the southernmost island of the Penghu Archipelago. The Northern Tropical Cyclone passes through the southern part of the islands and the northern part of the islands. According to the records of Penghu County, Penghu was originally called Pinghu, the word Pinghu is the same sound as Penghu in Taiwanese, and later Pinghu was also written as Penghu, and finally it was commonly written as Penghu. In 1945, when Taiwan was separated from Japan, Penghu Hall was reorganized as Penghu County, and the county was established in Ma Kung Town, with a total of 2 county districts and 6 villages, and the county districts abolished in 1950 were under the direct jurisdiction of the county. In 1981, the town was elevated to the status of a county seat, with a total of 1 county seat (Mako City), 5 counties (Huxi County, Baisha County, Xiyu County, Wang'an County, Seven Mei County), and 6 counties. In the 1926 census, 67,000 people were enrolled in Fujian and 100 in Guangdong.

The Russian national football team represents Russia in international football, and is governed by the Russian Football Federation. As far back as the Soviet era, Russia had an official football team. Their first international match was against Finland in 1912, where they lost 1–2. After the dissolution of the Soviet Union in 1991, Russia became one of the most populous countries in the world. The Russian national football team was split off from the Soviet national football team. Its records of the Soviet period and the achievements of the Independent Coalition period were also inherited by Russia. Since its inception, the club has played in only three World Cup finals, in 1994, 2002 and 2014, all of which were drawn in the first round. In the 2006 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, Russia lost to Portugal 1–7. At the 2018 FIFA World Cup, Russia qualified directly for the quarter-finals. Russia qualified for the European Cup four times (1996, 2004, 2008, 2012). It was not until the 2008 UEFA European Cup that Russia advanced to the quarter-finals, defeating the Netherlands 3–1 for the first time, but losing 3–0 in the semi-finals to eventual champion Spain. This was their best result since the dissolution of the Soviet Union. In recent years, Russia has been regarded as one of Europe's strongest teams, but has often failed to score at key moments in the tournament. In the 2010 FIFA World Cup qualifiers, Russia qualified for the semi-finals, but lost to Slovenia by a score of 2–2.

The garrison commander, Yoshihiro Yoshimitsu, led 5,000 soldiers out of the castle, stormed the outskirts of the castle and attacked directly, capturing 30,000 Myōjin. Thereafter, the Ming and Koreans feared Yoshihiro SHIMAZU's military might, and there was a saying that "fear of stone vines" ( fear of stone vines ). In 1599, at Shimazu's residence in Fushimi, Kyoto, the Imperial family took control of the territory and killed Tadamune ISHUIN, a feudal retainer who was opposed to the Imperial family (in 1595, Tadamune was ordered by Hideyoshi to search the land in the territory of the Shimazu clan, and in his stead, the Kitago clan controlled the territory of 80,000 koku in the districts of Hyuga Prefecture). A series of incidents involving the island's inhabitants have been reported. He also claimed to be the father of three sons and three daughters. Due to his increasing power, the Shimazu brothers also viewed him as a major threat. In the same year, Tadazane ISHUIN rebelled (the Shonai Rebellion), Tadatsune pretended to have made peace with Tadazane ISHUIN, but in 1602, while hunting in the Nojiri region of Hyuga Province, Tadazane was shot and killed. It is difficult to understand why Ieyasu TOKUGAWA's orders indicated that Tadayoshi was Tadatsune's son-in-law, that the two were relatives of the brother-in-law, and that they had fought together in the Korean War, but that once they betrayed their lord, they would suffer such an inhuman treatment. In 1602, because he and his father Yoshihiro were part of the Western army during the Battle of Sekigahara, he went to Kyoto to apologize to the Tokugawa family in place of his uncle Yoshihisa, who was responsible for the peace negotiations, and the territory remained unchanged. In the same year, he entered the inner city of Satsuma and succeeded his father Yoshihiro and uncle Yoshihisa as heads of the family, but the real power remained in the hands of his father Yoshihiro until 1619.

Fuji, shared eight mountain peaks: Japan's ancient poetry collection "Manyoshu," there are many literary works related to Mt. Fuji, among which the most famous short poems of Yamabe Akabito: (For the original text of the pseudonym "Manyoshu," modern Japanese writing: 田子の浦ゆ うちいでてみれば 真白にぞ ふじの高嶺に 雪は降りける) The earliest written record of the era of the eruption of Mt. Fuji, is the "Renewed Japanese Period," which records the year 781 (Tensho era) from the eruption of the volcanic ash from Mt. Fuji. In the early Heian period, "Taketsu Monogatari" (The Tale of Taking Bamboo) was written, and it is known that Mt. Fuji was an active volcano at that time. During the Edo period, a large eruption of Mount Bao Yong on December 16, 1707, dropped a large amount of volcanic ash on the city of Edo. There are a lot of written and pictorial records of the eruption. Since then, there have been many records of volcanic vent smoke and shaking, but it can be assumed that they were mostly short-lived and small-scale volcanic activity. The famous Japanese Edo period ukiyo-e painter Katsuji Kitazai created 46 continuous prints on the theme of Mt. Fuji, titled Thirty-six Views of Mt. Fuji (c.1831).

Currently, the government of the Republic of China does not use the term "Taiwan Territory" to refer to its effective sovereign territory, but instead uses the term "Taiwan Region" to refer to the territory of Taiwan. The Democratic Progressive Party argued that the current relationship between "Taiwan" and "the People's Republic of China (Mainland China)" is non-subservient to each other, that the term "Taiwan" is often used directly when referring to Taiwan, that the territory of the Republic of China is limited to the islands of Gimma and its adjoining islands, that the Republic of China regime and some political parties have moved to Taiwan for historical reasons, and that the current president, vice president and legislature are elected in Taiwan, and that the word "region" is a disrespectful and self-deprecating term for the Republic of China and Taiwan. The Communist Party of China often uses the official term "Taiwan" to refer to the relationship between the "Mainland", the "Macau Region" and the "Free Zone" (which is no longer commonly used) when dealing with issues on both sides of the Taiwan Strait. "Freedom Zone" refers to the Taipei-Kinma region. It is governed by the Taiwan-Mainland People's Relations Ordinance (Taiwan-Mainland People's Relations Ordinance) and the Hong Kong-Macau Relations Ordinance (Hong Kong-Macau Relations Ordinance).

The Sun Liu Rebellion, also known as the Guo Ting Liang Rebellion, occurred in 1955, during the White Terror period in Taiwan. The government of the Republic of China accused General Guo Tingliang of plotting a coup d'état and imprisoned Thaksin on the pretext that he "tolerated the armed rebellion of the armed forces, hid the bandits, and was a conspirator". More than 300 people were imprisoned. On January 8, 2001, the Taiwan Public Prosecutor's Office re-investigated the case and concluded that Sun Litian had been falsely accused of treason, and after investigating Li Bingnan et al., the deceased anti-Japanese leader claimed that Sun Litian's subordinate Guo Tingliang was a spy, and that the government had deliberately fabricated a hoax. The coup d'état was a series of events, the main purpose of which was to overthrow the Sunni regime. From 1950, Chiang Kai-shek and the Jiaozhi system began to have systematic subordinates of Sun Litian, until 1955, when Sun Litian was officially dismissed and placed under indefinite detention. It is not clear what the real motive of Chiang Kai-shek was, but historians still have no definite opinion, but all tend to support the theory of seizure of power. In 1949, the Republic of China government was defeated in the Sino-Japanese Civil War, and Sun withdrew to Taiwan, where he was invited by Allied Commander-in-Chief Marshal MacArthur to Tokyo, Japan, to discuss military cooperation between the United States and China. During the negotiations, Marshal MacArthur expressed the hope that his grandson would take over the national government, but this was rejected by his grandson. In September, he was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Taiwan Defence Force, Training Corps. In October, the Youth Army participated in the Battle of Kuning Head, winning a victory, stabilizing the National Government's forces in Taiwan. On March 1, 1950, Chiang Kai-shek was appointed as President of the People's Republic of China, and on March 1, 1950, Sun was appointed Commander-in-Chief of the Armed Forces.

A Chinese Ghost Story is a 1987 Hong Kong romantic fantasy film directed by Cheng Xiaodong, produced by Xu Ke and written by Nguyen Chia-zhi. The film is an adaptation of the chapter "Nice Qian" from Posong-ling's book "Talking to the Stranger", which tells the love story of the female ghost, Nice Qian, and the ghost of the scribe, Ning Cheng-jin. The film stars Zhang Guorong, Wang Zuxian, Wu Ma, Liu Zhaoming, and other actors include Lin Wei, Xue Zhiren, Wang Jing, and Hu Dawei. In 1978, Xu Ke, who had entered the television industry with the intention of making a horror film, recalled watching Li Hanxiang's version of The Beautiful Ghost as a child, but the producers of Television Broadcasting Ltd. rejected his proposal. Years later, Xu decided to take it to the big screen. The film's story is based on the original novels The Stranger's Tale and Li Hanxiang's version of The Beautiful Ghost, but Xu Ke decided to add a touch of romance to the film to suit the mood of contemporary audiences, and hired Nguyễn Chia Chi, who had written the screenplays for several third-rate films. Principal photography on the film began in October 1986, and it took more than five months to complete pre-production. The film had a budget of about $1.2 million, but was twice over budget. The film was well received, grossing more than $18 million in less than a month, and was subsequently released across the country. Most critics praised the film, especially the film's cinematography, visual effects, and acting, and a few called it a cult classic. Over time, many retrospective reviews acclaimed the film, even calling it an important milestone in Hong Kong cinema as it broke the monopoly on comedy and action films and brought the film back to life.

A tree is a woody tissue formed by plants (such as trees and shrubs) capable of secondary growth. It's a porous fibrous tissue. When trees and shrubs are in their early stages of growth, the vascular layer in the root stem becomes active, develops toughening skins outside, develops wood inside. Wood is a generic term for the development of plant tissue within the vascular formation layer, including woody parts and radioactive thin-walled cells. As the main product of the forestry industry, Wang Baiyun plays a very supportive role in human life. Depending on the characteristics of the wood, people use it in different ways, for example, as a fuel and as a building material. Wood is a natural organic composite, composed of fibrous fibers (high tensile strength) and a matrix of lignin (high compressive strength). Generally, wood is defined as the woody part of the stem that grows secondarily. There's about a trillion tons of timber on the planet, and it's growing by about 10 million tons a year. Timber, which is abundant and is a carbon-neutral renewable material, is one of the renewable energies that's getting a lot of attention. Approximately 3.5 million cubic meters of wood were produced in 1991, mainly for furniture and architectural structures. In 2011, in New Brunswick, Canada, the oldest known woody part, the oldest known plant, was found about 400 million years ago. Wood can be dated by radiocarbon dating, and some plants can be dated by tree rotation. Humans use wood as fuel, or as a covering for houses, tools, weapons, furniture, packaging, crafts, and even paper. Each year the width of the circle and the abundance of isotopes provide some information about the weather conditions at that time. Wood is a complex organic compound with about 44 percent carbon, 6 percent hydrogen, 42.5 percent oxygen, less than 0.5 percent nitrogen, and less than 1 percent other elements.

Xue Chengyi (Chinese: 薛呈懿; born December 3, 1989) is a Taiwanese politician. In the 2014 Yilan County elections, he was the youngest candidate in the 13 county district elections, winning by a landslide of 94 votes in Yilan County's 8th electoral district (Fuyushan). It is concerned with issues of education, culture, youth, agricultural land, environmental protection, urban planning, etc. In 2019, he was recommended by former Yilan County Mayor Soken Lin and then Democratic Progressive Party Secretary-General Luo Wenjia to join the Communist Party of China's Internet Department, and in August of the same year, he became a spokesman for the Democratic Progressive Party and Deputy Minister of Political Affairs of the Ministry of Youth Development. On February 2, 2020, it was announced that he would step down as Deputy Minister of Youth Affairs, and that the spokesperson would remain in office until May 19. On 28 December 2021, it was announced that the party would run for mayor of London in the 2022 general election, with the slogan "Planning for a New Town, London Worth Better". On 9 April, the results of the poll were announced, and she lost to former MP Huang Shichao by a vote of 33.6890%, and did not receive a party nomination. Xue Chengyi, who studied at Taichung Township, has been involved in the Miaoli-Taipu incident and the Beaulieu Bay Resort controversy in recent years, until the Solar Flower Festival, where she said, "There is a lot of out-of-body noise, and we need to bring this energy into the system to make a change. She spoke out on the Internet, she spoke on the streets, she touched a lot of people, she wanted young people to stand up and change society from the bottom up. The following month, she worked full-time for the company, but remained in the legislature at night. In the 2014 elections, she decided to return to Yilan to run for parliament, starting at the grassroots level.

It is widely believed that North Korea is in the process of developing an intercontinental ballistic missile, the Mars 14 ballistic missile, the two missile tests conducted by the country in 1998 and 2006 have not achieved significant success, but the 2017 test has reached the theoretical level of the intercontinental ballistic missile, the Mars 15 ballistic missile has also reached the standard of a large-scale missile over 10,000 kilometers, given the sensitivity and technical difficulty of the weapon, currently only a small number of countries in the world have the capacity to build and operate such a missile at the same time, and very few. The idea of the ICBM can be traced back to the A9/10 series of rockets proposed to the Nazi government in the 1930s and 1940s by the German rocket expert Werner von Braun. Due to the German defeat in World War II, these ideas were not realized. The first medium-range ballistic missile was Von Braun's V2 rocket, designed and built during World War II (the "V" comes from the German word Vergeltung, meaning "revenge"). The V2 was equipped with liquid-fuel engines and inertial guidance, launched from a mobile launch vehicle to avoid Allied air attacks. After the end of World War II, von Braun and a large number of German scientists who had served in the Nazis were captured and secretly transferred to the United States, where they joined the United States Army's Operation Paperclip project to develop medium-range ballistic missiles based on the V2 design concept, the "Redstone" and the "Chubit" medium-range ballistic missiles.

A lieutenant general is a rank in many national armies, ranging from major general to colonel general. The origins of the title go back to the Middle Ages, to the person who received orders from a general on the battlefield and passed them on. The Chinese word "中将" is derived from the Japanese military system, and the term "中将" in the Japanese military system is derived from the ancient Japanese official title of "近衛左右府中将" (近衛左右府中将). In the United States, lieutenant generals of the Army, Air Force, and Marine Corps are known as Lieutenant Generals, vice admirals of the Navy are known as Vice Admirals, and air marshals of the Royal Air Force are known as Air Marshals. Generals of the Republic of China, the People's Liberation Army, the Russian Federation, and the Royal Navy (changed to three stars in 2001) are awarded two stars, while those of the United States Army, the Republic of Korea, the German Bundeswehr, and the Japanese Self-Defense Force are awarded three stars, and those of the French Army and other former French colonies are awarded four stars. In the early days of the United States, the rank of lieutenant general was the highest in the United States Army. The highest military rank held by the first President of the United States, George Washington, was the rank of lieutenant general. A lieutenant general in the United States Army or U.S. Marine Corps usually commands an army-sized unit (the Army has 20,000 to 45,000 troops, the Marine Expeditionary Force has a similar number of Marines), while a lieutenant general in the Air Force commands a large numbered air force, composed of several regiments or a smaller U.S. Air Force Command (MAJCOM), such as the Air Force Special Operations Command or the Air Force Reserve Command.

It's a very dry planet, with only a few chemical traces of water vapor in the atmosphere. You can't see past water or past ice in a surface radar image. Atmospheric isotope evidence suggests that, over time, volatile elements in the atmosphere have been stripped of by emissions and erosion from the solar wind, suggesting that liquid water may have existed on Venus at some distant time in the past, but no direct evidence has been found for this, and many speculations about the geological history of Venus continue today. Most of what is known about the surface of Venus today comes from the six orbits of the Magellan spacecraft from August 16, 1990 to September 1994, which captured 98% of the planet's surface and 22% of the stereoscopic images that can be viewed with 3D glasses. Although Venus is the closest planet to Earth (about 40 million km from Earth's surface) and has a similar volume, no probe has been able to work more than a few hours on the surface of Venus, due to its atmosphere's pressure being 90 times that of Earth, and its surface temperature being as high as 450 °C. This may be due to the greenhouse effect of the large amount of carbon dioxide (96.5%) in its atmosphere. Ultraviolet observations show the formation of a Y-shaped cloud system near the equator, indicating that atmospheric circulation over the equator can circulate around Venus for a week every four days, so wind speeds of up to 500 km/h can be observed. Venus is the second object in the Solar System to be observed by radar from Earth, after the Moon.

Masini noted that in 1884, the prime minister's office in the Qing dynasty instructed the Han Lin court and the six ministries to draw up a list of high-ranking officials to visit foreign countries, requiring officials to write reports on their visits, as a basis for reform. This wave of foreign ministers' expeditions began with Fu Yunlong, who visited Japan, the United States, Peru and Brazil for a total of two years. In 333, the eastern Jin dynasty was established in the upper part of the western part of Xian County, located in Jinle County, which is now the capital of Guiyang City. It was founded in 621 by Emperor Wu of Tang, and is located in Guiyang City, Guizhou Province. Its territory corresponds to parts of Guiyang City and Qingzhen, Longli and Shuwen counties in present-day Guizhou Province. The Southern Song dynasty was abolished. In the Song Dynasty, Guiyang was called Guizhou. The name Guizhou originates from the Song Dynasty ancestor's "Gipu Guizhou" (Gipu Guizhou), which means "Guizhou is far away from the wilderness." This Pu Guijian, was an indigenous leader who ruled Manchuria (now Guiyang and neighboring areas) in the early Northern Song Dynasty. During the Five Dynasties and Ten Kingdoms War, Manchuria was controlled by indigenous stone tribes, and by the Seven Years' War (974), Manchuria was annexed to the central government of the Northern Song Dynasty. Because the Turkish "矩" reads "贵", the Song Dynasty edict "惟尔 Guizhou, far away in the wilderness", the name Guizhou began to appear. But Guizhou at this time, actually refers only to the present Guiyang area. In 1279, the Eighth Roman Ecumenical Council was established. In 1282, he was appointed commander-in-chief of the army of the People's Republic of China (People's Republic of China). Until 1292, Shunyuan and the 8th and 2nd Xuanxuang Divisions were merged, and the 8th Shunyuan Xuanxuang Division was established in Guiyang, still called Guizhou, but the Yuan Dynasty rulers called Shunyuan City. It was founded in 1289 by the founder of the Yuan dynasty, Emperor Taizong (元世祖), and was located in Jinzhuangzhai (金竹寨) in Jinzhuangfu (金竹府). At the beginning of the next year, Kinchiku-fu was changed to Kinchiku-chokanshi. With the establishment of Guizhou and other provinces in 1413, Guizhou officially became the 13th province of the Ming Dynasty. In 1568, he moved from Chengbanfu (now Huishui County) to Guizhou City (now Guiyang City).

The term "Southeast Asia" was first used in 1839 by American pastor Howard Malcolm in his book Southeast Asia Travels. Malcolm's definition included only the continental part, excluding the oceanic part. The SEAC promoted the use of the term "Southeast Asia", but the concept of early Southeast Asian configuration was not fixed, as most of the Philippines and Indonesia were excluded from the SEAC. By the late 1970s, the general standard usage of the term "Southeast Asia" and the territory it encompassed had emerged. The most common definition of "Southeast Asia" now includes the regions in which the political entities listed below are located. * Malaysia's administrative center is located in Bujumbura, Southeast Asia, which is geographically divided into two parts: the South-Central Peninsula and the Malay Archipelago. The maritime aspect of Southeast Asia is also referred to as the Malay Archipelago, a term derived from the European concept of the Malay peoples of the South Islands. Ocean Southeast Asia and continental Southeast Asia are divided into the following regions: In addition, Hainan, Guangxi, Guangdong, Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, Fujian, and southern Yunnan are generally regarded as Southeast Asian regions in terms of natural geography; these regions all have subtropical climates; and historically, the languages spoken by minorities in Guangxi and Yunnan are of the same language family as those spoken in the countries of the South-Central Peninsula (Tungdong, South Asian, or Miao). The indigenous peoples of Taiwan and other Southeast Asian countries, such as the Philippines and Indonesia, belong to the Southeast Asian language family, and Taiwan is also the origin of the Southeast Asian language family. Although the main ethnic group in Taiwan is Han Chinese, the blood composition is similar to that of Southeast Asians due to the large number of indigenous peoples who have been assimilated and married to Han Chinese.

In 1769, Captain James Cook (November 7, 1728 – February 14, 1779) made five voyages to the South Pacific to study and map New Zealand. Its original map, which treated Stewart Island as a peninsula, treated the Banks Peninsula as an island. Cook's maps led to the expansion of European whaling activity in the area. In 1788, the British annexed New Zealand as part of the Australian colony of New South Wales. It was not until July 1841 that New Zealand was separated from the colony of New South Wales, formally becoming a New Zealand colony. After the Treaty of Waitangi was signed in 1840, New Zealand became a British colony. However, the treaty had two versions in English and Maori, with the British royal representative signing the English version and the Maori signing the Maori version. The Māori version promised the Māori "tino rangatiratanga", which means "autonomy" in Māori, while the English version translates it as "leadership position", with different meanings and interpretations. The word and other issues remain a bittersweet bittersweetness between the New Zealand government and Māori people. For example, "Ownership of the Seabed and the Front Sea" is a property issue. In 1901, the British colonies across the Tasman Sea, including New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia, South Australia, Tasmania, and New Zealand, decided to form a new state, the Commonwealth of Australia. New Zealand was initially very interested in joining the Commonwealth of Australia, and actively participated in the drafting of the Constitution of the Commonwealth of Australia, but ultimately decided on its own independence.

The National Committee is the party's highest authority, convened once a year by the Central Executive Committee, whose main task is to amend the party's manifesto, party charter, elect or dismiss members of the Central Executive Committee. The Central Executive Committee (CEC) is the permanent body of power, with 21 executive members (including the Chairman and Vice-Chairman of the Party) and seven candidate members. According to the election results of 29 March 2019, the party has 40 National Committee members (18 party chairmen appointed, 22 party members directly elected). The party's president is elected directly by the party's members for a two-year term, re-elected and re-elected. The Central Council Committee is responsible for providing opinions on the party's development and major policies. The Central Party Department has five departments: Policy Research Center, Organization Department, Public Information Department, Administration Department, Finance Department, and additionally, the Mobilization Department, News and Public Affairs Department, Gansen Party Department, Nauru Bay Party Department (i.e., Indigenous Party Department) and Youth League as auxiliary organizations. In 2000, Song unsuccessfully ran for President of the Nationalist Party of China, but was defeated by Lee Teng-hui. In the 2000 Taiwanese presidential election, Zhang Zhaoxiang and his team formed the "New Taiwanese Service Team", which won a landslide victory over the KMT-nominated coalition, but was defeated by 300,000 votes to the KMT-nominated Chen Shui-bian. On 31 March, Song Chuyu's campaign and supporters announced the formation of a new political party, the pro-democracy party, at the Taipei Yuanshan Hotel. In 2001, the party won 46 seats in the Legislative Council of the Republic of China, becoming the third-largest party in the legislature.

The bayonet was invented in 1640 by a French officer named Pierre Couture, and since then it has been used as a spear.

The largest crater on Saturn is Tegus, 580 kilometers in diameter, and in the 17th century Cassini discovered that he could only see it from the west side of Saturn, and he had never been able to see it from the east side. He accurately deduced that Neptune was a synchronous rotation satellite orbiting Saturn, and that it was much darker on one side than on the other. This was later confirmed by a larger telescope. The difference in brightness between the two hemispheres of Titan is enormous. It is dark on one side (reflection 0.03–0.05), slightly reddish-brown on the other, and bright on most of the other side (reflection 0.5–0.6, close to Uranus II). So the magnitude on the opposite side of the orbit is 10.2; the magnitude on the same side of the orbit is about 11.9 — beyond the scope of the best telescopes of the 17th century. This dark surface of David resembles Taoist figures and the surface of tennis. Its dark side is named Cassini, and its bright side is named the Roncesvalles Plateau. The original surface material that formed the dark side was thought to have come from outside of Neptune, and today its surface is composed of crusts left over from the melting of the ice in warmer regions, containing organics similar to those found on the surfaces of primitive meteorites and comets. Observations from Earth have shown that it contains abundant carbon elements, possibly cyanide compounds such as hydrogen cyanide polymers. On September 10, 2007, Cassini flew over the moon from a distance of 1,640 kilometers, and found that both sides of the moon were heavily bombarded. It also found that the scattered patches of light and dark that make up the transition zone between Cassini and the Roncesvalles Plateau were tiny, even smaller than the highest resolution of 30 meters taken by Cassini.

Kangxi was originally recognized as an indigenous language by the Taiwanese Indigenous People's Committee (Taiwan: 中華民國原住民族委員會), but in 2011 the government excluded it due to linguistic confusion, so it is not recognized as an indigenous language by the central government or any local government. The languages spoken by the indigenous peoples of Taiwan are the official languages of the People's Republic of China, while the languages spoken by the indigenous peoples of Taiwan are the official languages of the People's Republic of China. It is mainly inhabited by indigenous peoples of Taiwan and Lanyu Islands, accounting for 1.2% of the total population of Taiwan. The indigenous languages of Taiwan belong to the South Island language family, which includes Taiwanese South Island and Dago ( Dago is not part of the South Island languages of Taiwan, but is part of the "Badan language group" of the Malay-Borian language family). South Taiwanese is divided into four linguistic groups: North Taiwanese, Central Taiwanese, South Taiwanese, and East Taiwanese. It is one of the 15 national languages of indigenous peoples recognized by the Central Government of the Council of Indigenous Peoples of the People's Republic of China, with six officially recognized dialects: Sekolik Taiya, Zhaooli Taiya, Shiki Taiya, Yilan Zhaooli Taiya, Wenshui Taiya, and Wanda Taiya. It is one of the 15 national languages of the Indigenous Peoples of the Republic of China recognized by the Central Government of the Republic of China.

Lee deployed his main force on the right flank, attempting to suppress the sinking to the left bank of the Liujiang River and annihilate it. Shen's army was so weak that they jumped out of the trenches and fought back. The two armies engaged in a fierce battle: both sides were forced to retreat, like saws. Li Zongren knew that at such a critical moment, once he was defeated, he would be defeated like a mountain, and the consequences would be unimaginable. So he approached the front, opened fire, commanded the battle. As the two sides struggled to resolve their differences, Li Shi Guqin's army, driven from Gui County to Jitang, threatened the right flank of the Shen army. The enemy saw Lee's reinforcements arrive, and when he saw them, his army panicked, and the line shook. Li's army launched a fierce assault, Shen's army collapsed, the emperor ran away, and retreated to defend Liuzhou. Afterwards, he went to Kathmandu to hunt down the enemy. The attack was planned and executed on 24 April. Shen Hongying finally fled to Hong Kong. When Li Zonnin, Huang Shaoxing, Bai Chong-hui and Shen Hongying fought fiercely, Tang Jiyao led the "Kingdom Army" composed of Yunnan and Guizhou Provinces of more than 60,000 troops in three routes: the first route was led by Tang's younger brother Tang Jiyao, from the eastern border of Guizhou to Sanjiang and Yu County, targeting Liuzhou; the second route was led by Yong Yun, from the eastern border of Yunnan to Guangxi and Nanning, targeting Nanning; the third route was led by Hu Zhao Gu, from the southern border of Yunnan to Fuzhou, Jingxi, Yori, Tongzheng, attacking Nanning. Compared to the Tang army, Li Zongren was weak, with only 10,000 men, 8,000 rifles, several cannons, and a reinforcement of only 20,000 men. The Tang forces were several times stronger than those of Li Zongren, and they were fierce, and they swallowed the sun and the moon and shook the mountains and rivers. Faced with the serious situation, Li Zongren, who had just ended the war with Shen Hongying, was very calm.

The Nagasaki Incident (also known as the Zhenyuan Disturbance) or the Nagasaki Qing Dynasty Marine Incident (長崎清國水兵事件) was a riot that broke out during a visit to Nagasaki City, Japan, by the North Sea Division of the Qing Dynasty in 1886. The event ended in a compromise between the two sides rather than a unilateral retreat by the Qing court, so it is believed that this was the first diplomatic victory of the Qing court since the Opium War. However, this incident also sowed seeds of anti-Qing sentiment among Japanese civilians, which is seen as one of the causes of the Korean War. In July 1886, the North Sea Fleet, which had not yet formally formed an army, was ordered by Li Hongzhang to cruise around Wonsan, North Korea, performing the maneuver "I Zhen Guowei", and then was ordered to visit Vladivostok, Russia. In view of the fact that the armored ships had to be returned to port for repairs and maintenance after a long voyage, and that the Qing court's brigade port had not yet been completed, Li Hongzhang decided to send the four ships, Zhenyuan, Dingyuan, Weiyuan, and Jiyuan, to the Mitsubishi Shipyard in Nagasaki, Japan, for repairs and a "friendly visit" to Japan. This was the first visit by the Chinese ironclad fleet to Japan. On 13 August 1886, more than 500 North Sea naval officers went ashore in violation of military discipline, including more than a dozen who went to a local brothel to party, get drunk, and fight. Two local police officers who came to hear the news of the brothel quickly arrested the Shiji sailors and put an end to the incident, after being severely warned and released. He was arrested and charged with assaulting and robbing a local police station, and later charged with assaulting and robbing more than 300 police officers. One officer was killed instantly by the sailors, another officer was stabbed severely injured, finally unhealed, and countless other officers were injured in the assault.

It's best to put some typical examples in a separate section to explain the definition of what the article refers to, and why you should use it. To refine the reader's mind, you can use some examples of mistakes — examples that seem to satisfy the definition, but actually don't. Images are a good guide, and often before mathematical discussions. As for how to make a picture diagram and how to quote it in an article, see Help: Images. Editors would do well not to take it for granted that "this formula explains everything." A non-mathematical reader is more likely to skip the formula, and a mathematician is more likely to skip the formula in another field of study. Each formula should have a detailed explanation, if possible using language instead of the formula. "For any", "exists", and "elements of..." are better than ∀, ∃, and ∈. The reader's interest in the history of the concept can be enhanced if a separate section is introduced. Most mathematical ideas have to be tested, and if it's right, you can put it in the test section. For example, multiplication of rational numbers may not be applicable in other fields. It's best to have a reference section that provides relevant topics and more in-depth information about the current topic. Finally, good essays should have references, which are described in more detail below. The following writing styles can be used: These introductory expressions are unnecessary and can be deleted without affecting the meaning. Instead of focusing on the reader with special hints, change the structure of the article and put the important parts at the beginning. Some foreign volunteers and Estonian compulsory soldiers took part in the battle on the side of the Germans, in support of the Germans' illegal conscription demands, and these Estonian resistance organizations hoped to establish an international army and restore Estonian independence. From a strategic point of view, the narrow strip between Lake Chud and the Gulf of Finland, which is only 45 km wide, is divided into two parts by the Narva River, the most important supply route, the Narva–Tallinn highway, and the Narva–Tallinn railway. Additionally, there is no other way to provide large amounts of military supplies to the roads. On 14 January 1944, the Leningrad Front launched an offensive against the 18th Army in the town of Orange Tree. On the third day of the offensive, the Soviets broke through the German lines and pushed westward, driving the German Army Group North out of Narva. In 1944, after the end of the Soviet occupation, the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union began to formulate more ambitious plans. During the Winter Campaign of 1943–44, Stalin ordered the Soviets to launch offensives across the entire Soviet front to continue the "broad front" strategy he had been pursuing since the beginning of the war. If the Soviets pressed on the entire front, the German defenses were likely to be partially breached. The Soviets made progress this winter in both Ukraine and Belarus, and attacked the German Panzer lines in the Baltic Sea region.

Cai Yuanpei (11 January 1868 – 5 March 1940) was a Chinese politician. Cai Yuanpei, 25 years old, was the first head of education of the Republic of China, president of Peking University from 1916 to 1927, reformed Peking University, opened "academic" and "liberal" winds; from 1920 to 1930, Cai Yuanpei concurrently served as president of the Chinese University of Law. After the establishment of the National Government in Nanjing, he presided over the Education Executive Committee, organized the National Academy of Sciences and the Central Academy of Sciences of the Republic of China, and spearheaded educational and academic reforms. He was also a member of the National Committee of the Communist Party of China (CCPC), and during the 42nd Incident, he published a pamphlet titled "Protecting the Party and Saving the Nation's Electricity", calling for the purge of the Party. From 1928 to 1940, he was the director of the Central Academy of Sciences, fulfilling his claim to academic research. Tsai Yuanpei was generous and open-minded, and had a profound observation of Chinese society and vulgarity; he travelled twice to Europe to study the revival of the humanist spirit and the post-Revolutionary ideas. He described China's cultural education as "a transition from feudalism to democracy and freedom." She advocated freedom of thought, civil rights and women's rights, and sought to change the old custom of "reading as an official" and to open up the spirit of scientific research. Cai Yuanpei was born on January 11, 1868 in Shanyin County, Shaoxing Prefecture, Zhejiang Province (present-day Shaoxing). His grandfather was a merchant and had seven children. His eldest son, Cai Guangpu, is the manager of the underground bank, Cai Yuanpei's father. Cai Guangpu, a Yao Shan, is very loving, married to Zhou, has seven children, Cai Yuan Pei ranks fourth. He was married three times during his lifetime. In March 1889, he married Yuan Zhao (仲明).

Tang Fei (Chinese: 唐飛; pinyin: Táng Fei; born March 15, 1932) is a Taiwanese politician who has served as a military officer in the United States, South Africa, Commander of the 499th Airborne Regiment, Commander of the Air Force Academy, Commander-in-Chief of the Air Force, Commander-in-Chief of the General Staff, Minister of Defense, and President of the Executive Council. He entered military school at the age of 12. As an F-104 fighter pilot, he participated in the Second Biennial Military Review in 1964, witnessed the deaths of the pilots, including Major Lin Tsuru, and ordered the entire squadron to remain radio silent and stable. In the early years, the long-term representative of the Republic of China in South Africa and other embassies abroad served as military officers, with the ideology of openness and Westernization at the same time appearing prominent among generals. After Lee Teng-hui succeeded as President, Tang Fei was promoted to Director General of the Inspectorate General of the Ministry of Defense, Ho Bermuda resigned as President of the Executive Council, and Tang Fei was promoted to Commander-in-Chief of the Air Force and Chief of the General Staff. Lee Teng-hui, in his later years, was promoted to the post of Minister of Defense. The military experience of Tang Fei shows that in the late 1990s, the traditional military rule of the Republic of China gradually weakened from an army-led to an air force-preferred military line. On 29 March 2000, President-elect Chen Shui-bian decided to appoint Tang Fei as his first cabinet minister, but due to the collapse of the Blue-Green negotiations, Tang Fei accepted the KMT's suspension of power but retained his party membership. On April 16, 2000, Tang Fei underwent chestectomy at Taipei Yongmin General Hospital, and after two weeks of hospitalization, he was discharged on April 29.

It is one of the thirteen provinces of the Republic of China (Taiwan: 西康省) and one of the thirteen provinces of the Republic of China (Taiwan: 西康省). Established in 1939, it is one of the "three provinces" of the Republic of China. Most of the villages in the district are inhabited by ethnic minorities, and the majority of the villages in the district are inhabited by ethnic minorities. Before the Battle of Xichang in March 1950, it was the last fully controlled mainland province of the Republic of China after the overthrow of the Chinese government. In October of the same year, after the Battle of Changdu, the People's Republic of China completely occupied the province and its nominally controlled Changdu, which was actually controlled by Tibet Kaxia, and then divided into Xikang Province and Changdu District. This is a list of places in Tibetan culture. In 1911, Fu Songxiang, the Minister of State for the Boundary between Yunnan and Sichuan Province, first proposed the establishment of Xikang Province, because its ancient territory was Kangdi, and in the west, Xikang Province was named after it: 339. It's divided into three parts from east to west: traditional riverside areas. Its jurisdiction extends mainly to the present-day Tibetan Autonomous Prefecture of Ganzi in Sichuan Province, Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture, Panzhihua City, Ya'an City, and the Changdu and Linzhi regions of eastern Tibet. In 1947, the total area of the province was estimated to be 451,521 square kilometers, the actual controlled area, east to Ya'an Jinqiguan and the border with Sichuan, west to Deguang, Ba'an to Jinsha River and Tibet, north to the stone channel and Qinghai, south to Jianli, salt side and Yunnan. To the west of the Jinsha River, as far as the Baohe Lao-Luma Ling-Kloromuda line, it's under Tibetan control. It is bordered by Tibet to the west, Qinghai to the north, Sichuan to the east, Yunnan to the southeast, and India to the southwest, and is partly located in the disputed South Tibetan region, which is now effectively controlled by the Indian state of Arunachal Pradesh.

In 1913, the state of Qin was abolished and Tianshui County was established, and the name of Tianshui has been used to this day. In August 1949, the People's Liberation Army (PLA) entered Tianshui County and established the Tianshui District Administrative Inspection District, later renamed the Tianshui Special District. In February 1950, the city of Tianshui was established. In July 1985, the Tianshui area was abolished, the city of Tianshui was elevated to a municipality, Tianshui County was merged into the city of Tianshui, Qincheng and Beidao Districts were established, Hui County, Bidang County, Xihe County and Li County in the original Tianshui area were assigned to the newly established Longnan area, Zhang County was assigned to the western area. On September 30, 2004, the State Council approved the renaming of Qincheng District as Qinzhou District, North Dao District as Meiji District, and on January 1, 2005, the district was officially renamed. The city is bounded by the Qin Ridge, which runs across the Yellow River and the Yangtze River. The Wei River flows through the northern part of the city, and the rivers north of the Qinling merge into the Wei River; the Jiangxi source of the Jialing River — the West Han River (also known as the Rhino River) originates in the southern part of the city, and the rivers south of the Qinling merge into the Jialing River. Tianshui is an important stop on the Silk Road, as well as numerous Buddhist caves owned by Dunhuang, Wuwei, Zhangye, Jiuquan and even Xinjiang. There are several Buddhist caves in Mt. Mazen where Emperor Xi Wei's second son, Emperor Wu of Yuanfeng, prayed for his mother. Tianshui is a transition zone between subtropical and warm temperate zones, and the terrain is complex, so the climates of the different regions are markedly different. The northern part of Tianshui receives significantly less rainfall than the southern part of Tianshui, and winter temperatures are below freezing, so it is also the southernmost part of Tianshui, where winter heating is concentrated, and receives relatively little rainfall. Summers are a little bit hotter, and the precipitation is concentrated throughout the year from May to September. The average temperature in January is minus 2.0 degrees; the average temperature in July is 22.8 degrees. During the spring, the sky is sometimes affected by dust, and autumn is dominated by cloudy weather.

In July 1935, the long-running novel August's Country was published by Shogun Jifeng, Lu Xun, Zhou Yang, and Hu Qiaotong all gave high reviews, Lu Xun not only prefaced the book, but also wrote a letter attacking the young left-wing writer Zhang Chunqiao who criticized the book. In Xi'an, he broke up with Xiao Xing, then met and fell in love with Wang Defen, and became a married couple. In June 1940, Xiao's army came to Yan'an for the second time, working at the Anti-Enemy Society of Arts, and organizing the Lu Xun Research Society. In October 1942, Yan'an convened the "Sixth Anniversary of Lu Xun's Death Memorial Convention" in which more than 2,000 people attended, and at the convention the Xiao army read his memoirs, which were criticized by other communist writers. In 1946, Xiao returned to Harbin, and later served as the president of the Lu Xun College of Arts and Letters of Tohoku University, the president of Lu Xun Culture Publishing House, the editor-in-chief of "Culture Gazette". As a result of the controversy between the Culture and Life newspapers, the Shogun became a victim of the "class struggle" and was expelled from the literary world. From 1949 onwards, he worked as a playwright and researcher at the Fushun General Workers' Union. In 1951, he was hired by Beijing's Cultural Heritage Group as a researcher of cultural relics, not specializing in writing, but he did not stop writing, and later wrote a large number of works such as "The Mines of May" and "The History of Wu Yue Chunqiu".

Greek (Greek:Ελληνικά, Romanized: Elliniká) is an Indo-European language, widely spoken in Greece, Albania, Cyprus, and parts of Turkey, including parts of Asia Minor. The Greeks developed vowels, and the Greeks added vowel alphabets. Ancient Greek originally had 26 letters, which gradually evolved into 24 after the Homeric period, and has continued to be used in modern Greek. The later Greek alphabet originated in the Ionian region (present-day coastal regions of western Turkey and islands of eastern Greece). Athens officially adopted it in 405 BC. Greek writing uses the Greek alphabet, as described above, with a total of 24 letters, including seven vowels and 17 consonants. Classical Greek is very different from modern Greek. First of all, many words have different meanings, some old words have disappeared, some have new meanings. Secondly, grammatically, classical Greek grammar is more complicated, modern Greek is simpler. In addition, modern Greek is relatively simplified in writing. These simplifications were largely the result of an artificial act of language unification in the 1980s. In fact, due to ethnic complexity, as well as political and religious reasons, the historical Greek language is constantly changing. Classical Greek, however, is indeed a treasure trove of language, containing so many words with such precise meanings, such deep-rooted accuracy, that the naming of many modern things is borrowed from classical Greek.

Taxonomy, also known as scientific taxonomy, is a method of grouping and classifying organisms using biological taxonomy. A fixed number of levels, domains, boundaries, gates, cords, eyes, families, genera, and species used in a level-based system hierarchy. A levelless system uses an arbitrary number of levels. Groups that are classified are called classification units. Modern biological taxonomy is based on Linnaeus' system, which classifies species according to their shared physiological characteristics. After Linnaeus, the system was gradually improved according to Darwin's principle of common ancestors. In recent years, molecular phylogenetics, which uses bioinformatics to analyze genomic DNA, is radically changing many of the original classifications. Biological taxonomy is a branch of systematic taxonomy. Although Linnaeus used biological classification only as a means of identification, it is now widely accepted that classification should reflect Darwin's principle of common ancestry. With the emergence of cladistics, or cladism, in the 1960s, a taxonomy group was positioned at a particular location in an evolutionary tree. If a taxonomy includes all descendants of a common ancestor, it is called monophyly; if it includes all descendants of a common ancestor, it is called paraphyly; if it does not include all descendants of a common ancestor, it is called polyphyly. According to branching theory, a natural classification should be a single group rather than a parallel group or a complex group.

Yingkou is a city in Liaoning Province of the People's Republic of China, located in the south-central part of Liaoning Province. It's bordered by Dalian City in the south, by Anshan City in the northeast, by Jinjiang City in the northwest, by Liaodong Bay in the west. It's on the banks of the Bohai Sea, on the banks of the Liaodong Gulf, on the southern edge of the Liaohe Plain. It's high in the southeast, low in the northwest. To the northwest lies the mouth of the Liao River, to the middle lies the Daqing River, and to the south lies the Beili River and the Kumadake River. It has a total area of 5,400 square kilometers, a permanent population of 232,860,000 in 2020. Yingkou is Liaoning's first port to open to the outside world, the birthplace of China's national financial industry, is now the nearest port of departure to the Bohai region, is one of the most competitive modern port cities around the Bohai region, one of the key coastal open cities, an important hub of the national integrated transportation system and one of the main coastal ports, is a two-class large city. There's been evidence of human activity since ancient times, and the Taurus Mountain culture excavated at the campsite suggests that humans inhabited the area as far back as 280,000 years ago. According to China's earliest historical book, Ugong, it was the first city in Hebei and Qingdao provinces. During the Warring States period, it was under the jurisdiction of Liaodong County, after the unification of China by the Qin Dynasty. The Ming Dynasty established the Haizhou guard at the cattle ranch. In the early Qing Dynasty, Qiaohaizhouwei, which belonged to Geping County, was originally called "No Guo Camp," or simply "Battalion." In 1861, it was opened as a foreign trade port, and the customs office was located in Ushizhuang, so the camp was also known as "Ushizhuang Port". The government of the Republic of China established a camp headquarters here. The Battle of the Cowshed in the War of the Mid-Ages was fought here. In 1913, the county was reorganized as "Yingkou County". During the Japanese occupation, it was known as "Yingkou City". In 1949, the National Government of Chiang Kai-shek, the last refugees of more than half a million, and the first garrison of 200,000, under the command of Commander Liu Yuzhang, retreated to Keelung, Taiwan, the northeastern part of the island became New China to the present day, that is, the famous Camp Guo Tai retreat Camp Guo City is located in the center of the Liaodong Peninsula, Liaohe into the sea mouth on the left bank.
