After the Norman invasion of Ireland, Dublin replaced the Hill of Tara as the capital of Ireland. From the 14th century until the end of the 16th century, Dublin and its surrounding area, known as the Palais, was the only area controlled by the British in Ireland. Beginning in the 17th century, the city expanded rapidly with the help of the Wide Streets Commission. Georgian Dublin was once the second largest city in the British Empire, after London. Many of Dublin's finest buildings were built during this period. The 1916 Easter uprising left the city in a state of instability, and the Anglo-Irish War and the Irish Civil War caused considerable damage to the city, destroying many fine buildings. The Free State of Ireland rebuilt many of the city's buildings and moved the parliament to Leinster House, but did not rebuild the buildings. After World War II, Dublin remained an outdated capital, and modernization was slow to take off until the 1960s. But in the 1970s, there were a lot of bombings in Dublin, and it was terrifying. In recent years, Dublin's urban infrastructure has undergone a major overhaul, with both state and private real estate, transportation and commerce booming. Some of the most famous street architecture in Dublin is still named after the bars and commercial companies that operated there before its closure. Since the 12th century, Dublin has been the capital of Ireland. In 1922, following the breakup of Ireland, Dublin became the capital of the Free State of Ireland (1922–1937).

The MacMahon Line, which was recognized by the British and Indian authorities and the Tibetan authorities, has become a legal boundary, whether China recognizes it or not. A more radical view within the Indian government is that the McMahon Line was originally intended to mark the border between India and China on the highest ridge of the Himalayas. Whereas the established McMahon Line is south of the Himalayan peak, the original McMahon Line should be considered to be the Himalayan peak north of the actual McMahon Line. Following India's independence in 1947, the Nehru government led India into the First Indo-Pakistani War, and concluded military protection treaties with neighbouring Nepal, Bhutan, and Sikkim, striving to fill the power vacuum created by British withdrawal from the South Asian subcontinent and expand India's strategic advantage in South Asia. Because of its strategic importance to India, the Indian government also advocated the policy of inheriting the colonial era, establishing a buffer zone in Tibet, and indirectly controlling Tibet by sending troops to consolidate the security of the Himalayan defences. In 1951, the People's Republic of China entered Tibet through military operations and negotiations. In a letter to the Chinese government, the Indian embassy in China said: "The Chinese army's invasion of Tibet has to be regarded as tragic. In 1959, after the Tibetan uprising, the 14th Dalai Lama fled to India, founded the Tibetan government of exile, advocated Tibetan independence. In 1960, the Premier of the State Council of China, Zhou Enlai, visited India, met with the Prime Minister of Nepal, proposed a negotiated solution to the border issue, no consensus. After 1960, Sino-Soviet relations began to deteriorate, and Sino-US relations were at a standstill because of the Korean War. India has good relations with the Cold War-era Soviet Union and the United States. In August 1962, the Cuban Missile Crisis erupted, causing tensions between the U.S. and the Soviet Union, and involuntary intervention in the Sino-Indian conflict.

If the problems of aging and aging in life, disease, accidental injury, violence between animals and humans, etc., can be completely solved, eternal life can also be hoped for. However, it is now known that when a cell divides, it produces a phenomenon of decreasing replication. As the length of the end of the DNA becomes shorter and shorter, affecting the accuracy of the original DNA, aging occurs. However, once cell aging occurs, this process is irreversible. And there's no way to replenish the end of the DNA. According to Ray Kurzweil, chief futurist at Google, advances in medical technology will extend lifespans by more than one year per person, nanobots will repair and replace cells, tissues and organs, reverse aging processes, and by consciousness transfer, allow people to survive through other bodies without being constrained by physical death, and by 2045, artificial intelligence will outperform humans by a billion times. According to the law of mass conservation (also known as the law of non-extinction of matter), the most basic materials and energies that make up matter cannot be created or extinguished, but can only be reassembled. Thus, from a materialistic perspective, when a human being dies, even if his or her remains are cremated and the ashes scattered over the ocean, they don't really disappear or disappear, but only the basic particles that make up the human body reassemble. According to fear management theory, human beings, fearing the disappearance of the self after death, tend in some way to make themselves symbolically ever present in other people's memories, group life or cultural customs, etc., and those who support the idea that the mind is ever-in-the-mind believe that even if the body has passed away, the mind can survive in such a way that death is not so frightening.

The British Virgin Islands (BVI), officially the Virgin Islands, is a British Overseas Territory located in the Caribbean Sea, east of Puerto Rico. The British Virgin Islands and the adjacent United States Virgin Islands and the Puerto Rican Virgin Islands are known as the Virgin Islands. The British Virgin Islands consist of four main islands: Totola, Virgin Gorda, Anegada, and West Van Dyke, as well as over 50 smaller islands and reefs, of which about 15 are uninhabited. Tortola is the largest island in the British Virgin Islands, about 20 kilometres long and 5 kilometres wide. The islands have a population of 28,000 and its capital, Rhode Island, is located on the island of Tokelau. Approximately 100 BC, the Arawak Indians were the first to migrate from South America to settle on the islands (but there is also evidence that the American Indians were active on the islands before 1500 BC). The Arawak Indians remained on the islands until the 15th century, when they were driven out by the Caribbean from the Lesser Antilles, and the Caribbean Sea was named for them. However, some historians disagree with the claim that "the warring Caribbean drove the peaceful Arawaks out of the Caribbean", arguing that this is a simplistic version of what the Europeans have always said, and that the truth behind it should be more complicated. In 1493, Columbus discovered the Virgin Islands on his second voyage to the Americas, becoming the first European to do so.

In 853 BC, he fought in the Battle of Qarqar against the Allied armies of the Alamanni. In 806 BC, at the time of the reign of Adad-Nirari III, he invaded the Levant and conquered the Aramaic, Phoenician, Philistine, Israelite, Neo-Hittite, and Eastern tribes. In 772 BC, Assyrian king Assyria III became impotent, and during his reign there was a continuous internal rebellion and plague. Tiglath Parashar III was one of the most important monarchs of the New Assyrian Empire, and through his reforms, Assyria once again went from weakness to strength. One of the key elements of the reform was to limit the power of officials. During the reign of Hadrian III, officials were highly empowered, and could even launch battles without the king's knowledge. Local governors tend to form subordinates, some of whom are already independent or are clearly prone to independence. Tigrath Parashar replaced the governor with a chief executive named "Bell-Pahatti" in each province. The chief executive's power was smaller than that of the original governor, but it was still not enough to reassure Tiglath Palashal III. To further reduce the power of the local rulers, he began to reduce the size of the province. The newly conquered provinces were often administered by eunuchs. As a result, the number of provinces increased, and by 738 BC, there were as many as 80 known provinces; and the power of the governors of the provinces diminished, and many more were eunuchs. Tigerpalachar also allowed civilians to write directly to the king, to monitor the bureaucracy at all levels. Other reforms targeted the military. These measures included: the establishment of a standing army, supplied by the government, which encouraged the landless to join the army, thereby strengthening the army; the establishment of an army to guard and act as a backup force outside the main army directly under the king; and the conscription of the inhabitants of the conquered areas to fight for the Assyrians, thereby greatly strengthening the army (foreigners usually served only as infantry, cavalry, and chariot troops, or were recruited by the Assyrians).

Xinjiang was originally called the Western Region, and in the Tang Dynasty it was called the Seishi Region, and the Han Dynasty established the Western Region Dugofu in 60 BC, and the Tang Dynasty established the Anxi Dugofu in the 7th century. Before the Mongol invasion of China in the Middle Ages, the 24th Dynasty of China clearly had a dynastic regime in Xinjiang known as Xilai. It's historically a Silk Road junction. In 1759, the Qing Emperor Qianlong (清乾隆, Qing Qianlong) put an end to the Great and Small Rebellion, united the northern and southern Tianshan Mountains, and the western region was ruled by the generals of Seili. In 1760, Qianlong issued an edict to the governor of Shaanxi, Yang Xueyi, saying, "The newly created territory is as far away from the mainland as Ili, and all matters are difficult to control remotely. In 1877, just before the Qing army invaded and recaptured Xinjiang, the Qing court decided how to deal with the question of Xinjiang's future, and ordered the commander of the Western Expeditionary Force, Zongtang Sa, to make a comprehensive plan. In his report on the overall situation in Xinjiang, Zaozongtang formally proposed to the imperial court the establishment of a province in Xinjiang, and the Qing court issued a decree in 1884, establishing the Xinjiang Bureau of Political Affairs, formally establishing a province in Xinjiang. The meaning of "Xinjiang" before and after Jianxiang is not the same, Jianxiang is derived from the words of the emperor Xiang Zongtang, "The persecution of the other people, the return of the homeland." During the period of geographical discovery, Europeans came into contact with the concept of "Turkistan" from Arab writings, and in the 1722 publication of The Chronicle of Timur, the whole of Siberia was called "North Turkestan", and Xinjiang was called "South Turkestan", but the term was not widely used until the early 19th century. Beginning in the 17th century, the area around the Tarim Basin was commonly referred to by the Russians as "Little Bukhara". For British travellers and English material at the time, they used "Chinese Turkestan", "East Turkestan", "Chinese Central Asia" and "Serindia".

But at the same time, it achieved another strategic goal of the Qing Dynasty, mobilizing the Ming side army. At this time, the immediate strategic objective of the Taijiang Emperor was Jinzhou - the largest military fortress of the Ming army north of Ningyuan, trying to break the strong defensive system of Ningjin, remove the sharp swords against the chin of the Qing Dynasty, and then gradually erode the Ming territory. Consequently, while Dorgon and Leto both broke the barrier, on February 14, Chongzhen 12, the Emperor Taiji quickly mobilized more than 30,000 soldiers of the Eight Banners, carrying more than 20 cannons of the Red barbarians, led Ajig, Daizen, Nikkan, Roto, Kong Yude, Geng Zhongming, Shang Kei, Shi Tingzhu, Ma Guangyuan, Neman and so on to attack the Ming army-controlled Songshan. At that time, the garrison was commanded by Lieutenant General Kim Kuo-feng, with only 3,000 soldiers. The Qing army attacked the castle with artillery, ten days in a row, and the cautious Emperor also believed that Matsuyama Castle was small and could soon be captured. In addition to dispatching some troops to restrain the Ming forces at Anshan, Tashan, and Jinzhou Fortress in the southwest, most of the troops were used to besiege Matsuyama. The Ming army outside Matsuyama had three forts, each containing dozens of soldiers, and Ushinha Cho of Manchuria quickly destroyed these forts with artillery. Early on February 26, the Qing army launched an offensive from four directions against Matsuyama-jo Castle, but was fiercely repulsed by the Ming army, and at noon Zhangjingmen who were fighting for Baturu climbed the ladder, but were repulsed by the Ming army with bows and arrows and firecrackers.

China–Lao People's Democratic Republic relations refer to the relations between the Republic of China and the Lao People's Democratic Republic. From 1958 to 1962, the Republic of China and the Kingdom of Laos had diplomatic relations, but after the breakdown of diplomatic relations, there are no diplomatic missions in each other's capitals. On November 17, 1958, the Republic of China established diplomatic relations with Laos. On January 5, 1959, the Embassy of the Republic of China in Yongjin was established. On Christmas Day 1960, the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) handed over a chartered aircraft to China Airlines for use in northern Burma, and the Air Force Intelligence Directorate (AIAD) requested that the aircraft return to Yongjin to explore the air transport market in the Kingdom of Laos, which was not easily accessible by land. The contractor took delivery of several packaged aircraft, bringing back more than $30,000 in three days. On January 1, 1961, Air Force officer Lin Junping sent a telegram to Kai Hoon reporting that the airline had obtained a contract for two routes. He immediately informed Yang, and dispatched Wu to Yongjin with two C-47 aircraft, 23 airborne personnel, and a "North Tatsun Group" (北辰 Gruppe). In addition to leasing aircraft and crew to Cie Veha Akat to provide air transportation within the Kingdom of Laos, it also transported special forces to the CIA. In 1962, Royal Air Lao (Royal Air Lao) also began to charter crews for the airline.

The Seventh Army of the People's Revolutionary Army is one of the main branches of the People's Army of the Republic of China. He participated in the Unification of Guangxi, the War of Guilin in Yunnan, the Northern Expeditionary War, the War of Ninghan, the War of Chiang Kai-shek, the War of Central Plains, the Civil War of the Communist Party of China, and the War of Resistance against Japan. Finally, in November and December 1949, in the Bo Bai area of Guangxi, it was besieged by the PLA 2nd Field Army Chen Geng 4th Corps and the 4th Field Army 43rd Corps, all of which were destroyed. He was a member of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia's Yugoslav Army, under the command of Lieutenant-Colonel Yugoslavia's Commander-in-Chief of the Yugoslav Armed Forces, Lieutenant-Colonel Yugoslavia's Commander-in-Chief of the Yugoslav Armed Forces and Lieutenant-Colonel Yugoslavia's Commander-in-Chief of the Yugoslav Armed Forces. In 1921, Sun Yat-sen reorganized the 11 regiments of the Genghis Khan Li Zongren's army into the 3rd Guangdong Front, commanded by Li Zongren. Between November 1923 and April 1925, a combined force of 6,000 soldiers from the Jiangxi Thieves (定桂讨贼) exterminated 60,000 former Gui warlords, including Lu Yungang, Lu Rongting, and Shen Hongying. Between February and July 1925, he defeated the Yuan forces of Tang Jiyao with less than 20,000 troops and united Guangxi with 70,000 troops. From early October to December 1925, the entire army entered Guangdong, assisting the Guangdong National Government to eliminate more than 30,000 rebels including Xuan Kewu, Deng Ben Yin, Lin Junting, and Shen Pao. In March 1926, it was reorganized into the Seventh Army of the National Revolutionary Army by the Guangzhou National Government, with Li Zongren as its commander, Huang Shaoxing as its representative, Bai Chonghui as its chief of staff, and a total of 40,000 troops. A member of the Communist Party of China, Huang Jiehui, was once appointed the head of the Political Department of the Seventh Army. In early May 1926, the 7th Army's 7th Brigade ( Brigadier General Zhong Zupei) in Hengyang, northern Hunan, supported the Hunan warlord Tang Shengzhi, who was attacked by the North Sea warlord Wu Pefu, and fired the first shot of the Northern Expedition. On 5 June, the Guangdong National Government formally declared the Northern Expedition. Lee commanded 12 regiments of the 7th Army, formed the Northern Expeditionary Force of more than 20,000 men.

The history of relations between Taiwan and the Philippines (Chinese: 臺灣与菲律宾关系史) refers to the relationship between Taiwan and the Philippines at various stages of history. With the relocation of the Republic of China government to Taiwan in 1949, diplomatic relations with the country virtually overlapped. Between Taiwan and the Bataan Islands in the Philippines, it is separated by the Bay of Biscay. It is bordered by Taiwan's Lanyu Islands to the north and the southern tip of Taiwan's Hengchun Peninsula, and by the Yami Islands and the Bataan Islands to the south. The islands of Taiwan and the indigenous peoples of Bataan Island in the Philippines can be reached by boat. According to ethnographic studies, the indigenous Native Americans of the two islands are closely related. The indigenous languages and traditional songs of Taiwan are also highly similar to those of Fiji, and the two countries have gradually reestablished contact. According to archaeological and linguistic theories, Taiwan is the homeland of the South Islanders, and the South Islanders spread from Taiwan via Lanyu, Bataan, to the Philippines, and then from Southeast Asian islands to Oceania. Among them, the Dago people and the Batan people are linguistically and culturally more similar to the Yami people and the Taiwanese, but genetically, the Yami people are similar to the Taiwanese. Currently, there are more than 1 million Chinese in the Philippines, including more than 20,000 from Taiwan. Most of them are concentrated in the metropolitan area of Oaxaca. In the late 16th century, Spanish officials regarded Taiwan as part of the Philippine Islands, and therefore considered Taiwan to be under Spanish royal jurisdiction. In 1586, the Governor of the Philippines and fifty Spaniards signed a petition to King Philip II of Spain and Portugal, urging him to send troops to the islands of Elmore and the more remote islands of the Philippine archipelago, because "their situation is becoming increasingly corrupt...

Of the four Taiwanese companies, one is located in the Athi River processing export zone near the capital, Nairobi, and three are located in the civilian processing export zone at the Kilindini Harbour in Mombasa, Mombasa's second largest city, mainly for the import of raw materials and accessories and the successful export of garments. On 17 March 2011, the Kenya Taiwan Chamber of Commerce was founded, but the number of members is unknown due to the fact that there are not many Taiwanese businessmen living in Kenya. As of 2020, there are no financial institutions in Taiwan. On November 30, 2014, the Kenya Police cracked down on a telecommunications fraud involving illegal entry and unauthorized use of radio equipment, arresting 77 suspects, 28 of whom were of Taiwanese nationality and the rest of whom were of Chinese nationality. On 5 April 2016, the Kenyan court acquitted 37 of the suspects, 23 of whom were Taiwanese, and released them but restricted their residence and left the country within 21 days. On 7 July, a delegation from the Taipei Liaison Office in the Republic of South Africa arrived in Kenya. Under pressure from the People's Republic of China (PRC), eight Taiwanese were deported to the other side of the Taiwan Strait, the remaining 15 were detained by the police, and on the same day, the Kenyan police cracked down on another fraud case and arrested 22 Taiwanese.

Weather is a chaotic system, and small changes in the system can affect the whole. Throughout human history, humans have sometimes attempted to control the weather, and there is evidence that human activities (such as agriculture and industry) have inadvertently altered weather patterns. Studying the weather on other planets helps us understand the weather on Earth. The famous landmark of the Solar System, Jupiter's Great Red Spot, is an anticyclonic storm that has been known for at least 300 years. However, the weather is not limited to planets. Broadly speaking, weather can include changes in the gas (the gaseous and ionic elements) in the entire galactic space, the continuous ejection of the star's corona, and the creation of an essentially very thin atmosphere throughout the solar system. In other words, the solar wind, the large-scale eruption of the Sun, is also a weather event in the solar system. Meteorology is the science of studying atmospheric motion. The following are the main weather data and phenomena: weather stations, ships, weather balloons, airplanes, buoys, satellites, etc. can collect meteorological data. Weather is a short-lived local, temporary atmospheric phenomenon in an area. Climate is the average physical state of the atmosphere over a long period of time, say 30 years. Weather forecasting uses technology to predict the state of the atmosphere at a given point in time. Mankind tried to predict the weather a million years ago, and it wasn't until the 19th century that formal weather forecasting began. Initially, it relied entirely on manpower to make predictions based on pressure changes, current weather conditions and sky conditions, and weather forecasts had all kinds of end-users. Weather warnings, used to protect lives and property, are important predictions. Every day, people use the weather forecast to decide what to wear on a daily basis.

Uruguay established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China on February 3, 1988, and with the Republic of China on February 4, 1988. In July 1992, the Taipei Economic Office was established in the capital, Montevideo, as an embassy, and the Government of Uruguay will look into it with international organizations. In September 1993, the Permanent Representative of Uruguay to the United Nations, during the general debate of the 48th United Nations General Assembly, proposed the "principle of universal membership", indirectly expressing support for the participation of the Republic of China in the United Nations. In January 1995, a Taiwanese squid struck the South Atlantic Ocean, killing three fishermen suspected of being from the People's Republic of China. Following a preliminary investigation, the Uruguayan government informed the Republic of China Police through the International Criminal Police Organization (Interpol) that the suspects had been detained in accordance with international law, and returned to Taiwan in February to transfer the case. In October 1997, former Uruguayan President Rafael Rivas Posada paid a visit to the country. During this period, he met with Liu Songfan, the President of the Legislative Yuan, Vice-President of the Executive Yuan and Foreign Minister Zhang Xiaoyian, and other government officials. In January 1999, the Speaker of the Uruguayan House of Representatives, Jaime Trobo, paid a visit to the country. He met with Liu Songfan, the head of the Legislative Yuan, Foreign Minister Hu Zhiqiang, and other government officials. In 2015, the president of the Office of the Ombudsman of Uruguay, Mirtha Guianze, paid a visit to Taiwan. In May 2020, 71 Formosa Club MPs from Uruguay and nine other countries in the Americas wrote a letter to Secretary-General of the World Health Organization (WHO) Tan Dece calling on the WHO to address the need and urgency of Taiwan's participation in the world health system.

By the time of the Eastern Han Dynasty, the complete Confucian text had been lost, and Dulin had acquired a lacquered copy of the Book of Ancient Classics in Hexi, which had the same number of volumes as the present-day Book of Ancient Classics, but no more than 16 copies of the Confucian text. From the end of the Eastern Han Dynasty, scholars such as Jia Kui, Ma Yu, and Zheng Xuan actively promoted the writing of lacquer manuscripts, and the number of learners gradually increased and the academic community gradually gained an advantage. In the early days of the Eastern League, he gathered books such as "Legend of the Left," and wrote "102 Books," and he was imprisoned, and the book died. During the reign of Emperor Taizong, the texts of the ancient Chinese classics were lost, and Zheng Xuanzong's commentaries on the ancient Chinese classics became popular. During the reign of Emperor Yuan of the Eastern Jin Dynasty, Meiyi claimed to have obtained the long-lost Confucian Ancient Book (later known as the False Confucian Book), which contained 25 more ancient books than the present one, and the Sui Dynasty Southern Dynasty scripture was introduced to the north, after which the False Confucian Book replaced the Zheng Xuanchuan Book, which had influenced Confucianism for thousands of years, and the genuine Confucian Book (Zheng Xuanchuan Book) was eventually completely lost. However, from the beginning of the Song Dynasty, scholars such as Zhu Xi and Wu Xi doubted Mei's "Fake Confucianism," and by the middle of the Ming Dynasty, Mei's writing of "Shang Shufu" and "Shang Shu Kai" systematically criticized their doubts. It is also said that in the early Qing Dynasty, Huang Zongxi also raised his suspicions, and in thirty years later, he wrote the Book of Confucian Evidence, which lists 128 pieces of evidence, and concluded that the twenty-five pieces of the Book of Confucian Evidence that Mei Cheng presented were forged during the Wei Jin Dynasty. It is now believed to be a forgery. Although most people believe that the "pseudo-ancient scriptures" are not from the ancient scriptures, some of them are better, such as the one mentioned in "The Song of the Five Sons" ("民惟邦本,本固邦寧" in Chinese: 民惟邦本,本固邦寧).

Yongjia Five Years (313 AD) 析永昌, Yunnan two counties 置河阳郡, 治河阳县 (今大理市凤仪镇). In 342, the county was divided into West and East Heyang counties. The southern border of Qijin Province was divided into four counties: Dongheyang, Xiheyang, Xihe, and Yunnan. It belongs to the administrative division of Nanning Prefecture. In the early days of the Tang Dynasty, there were six major tribes inhabiting the Erhai region, called the "six bulls", of which the most powerful was the Monsha bull, which was also called the Nan bull because it was located in the southernmost part of the region. In 738, with the support of the Tang Dynasty, Emperor Pi Luo, the head of the Monshe Zhao, unified the Erhai region, established the Southern Zhao State, and built the capital at Taihe City (present-day Taihe Village, Dali City). In 779, the southern part of the Tang Dynasty was transferred to Dujiangyan. During the Southern Zhao period, the Erhai area was surrounded by "" or "Bye", the northern part belonged to the Jianchuan District, and the western part to the Yongchang District, and the northern part belonged to the Shengxiang District, and the western part to the Yongping County. In 902, Emperor Zhaozong launched a coup d'état against Emperor Zheng of Southern Zhuang, which resulted in the establishment of Greater Changhe Province and the death of Southern Zhuang. Later, in 928, Zhao Zhenzheng usurped the throne and established Da Tianxing Province, the following year, Yang Guanzhen abolished Zhao Zhenzheng's independence and established Da Yining Province. In 937, Tong Hai Festival (通海节度段思平) united the thirty-seven provinces of eastern Yunnan, invaded Dali, overthrew Dai Yining Province, and established Dali Province. In the latter part of the 19th century, the kingdom abolished the military jurisdiction of the nobility and the governor, and replaced it with a prefectural and county government. In addition to the capital of Dali, there are other administrative districts on the border of Ima Prefecture, such as Muromachi (present-day Heqing County), Yichuan (present-day Jianchuan County, which belongs to Muromachi Prefecture), Songxiang County (present-day Yongping County, which belongs to Yongchang Prefecture), and Nanjing County (present-day Nanjing Yi Autonomous County, which belongs to Weichuan Prefecture).

On July 28, 2021, Panzhihua City, in response to the implementation of the three-child policy announced by the Politburo of the Communist Party of China, took the lead in announcing the Sixteen Policy Measures to Promote the Gathering of Human Resources, in which the Panzhihua households with two or three children under the policy were granted 500 yuan per child per month until the child was three years old, making Panzhihua City the first city in the country to grant childcare subsidies. Panzhihua is located in southwestern Sichuan Province, between 26°05′N 27°21′E 102°15′N 108°08′E, with an area of 7,440,398 square kilometers. It crosses the Transcaucasian Mountains to the west, the Dalian Mountains to the east, the Daisetsu Mountains to the north, the Baekje Mountains to the south. It's high northwest, low southeast. Panzhihua City is in the east of the Xiaoxiangling-Haozi Mountains-Lunan Mountains, in the middle of the Yakuz Mountains-Longliang Mountains, in the west of the Jinping Mountains-Berlin Mountains, and the mountains run close to the north and south. Its highest point is at 4195.5 meters above sea level at Ba Lingshan Pass in Yanbian County in the northwest, and its lowest point is at 937 meters above sea level at Jizhuang in Pingdi Town in the southeastern part of the Jinhe District. The urban areas are between 1000 and 1200 m above sea level, while the main agricultural areas are between 1000 and 1800 m above sea level. The Jinsha River, the Yalu River, the Anning River, the Da River, the Sanyuan River and their tributaries are deeply embedded in the mountains, forming a majestic valley zone to the southwest of the river. Panzhihua City is divided into six types: flat dams, plateaus, high hills, low mountains, mountains and plains, with low mountains and mountains dominating, accounting for 88.38 percent of the total area of the city. Panzhihua City lies on the west side of the mid-south section of the Asbestos-Yuanmu quake zone and on the east side of the northern section of the Salt Spring-Eryuan quake zone, largely in the mid-south section of China's north-south quake zone.

On December 25, 2018, he was re-elected Mayor of Taipei, succeeding Liu Yitong as Deputy Spokesperson for the Taipei City Government. In 2019, he was appointed as a member of the House of Representatives for the People's Party, but resigned from his position. In February 2020, he was appointed Deputy Speaker of the Taipei City Government again. In November 2021, Huang left his position as Deputy Mayor of Taipei to become Deputy Spokesperson. On August 6, 2019, the Taiwan People's Party was founded, and Huang was one of the founding members of the party. On November 19, 2019, the Taiwan People's Party (Taiwan People's Party) announced the list of candidates for the Legislative Council of Non-District Territories, Huang was ranked 13th. In March 2019, Huang said on a political talk show, "I just don't know if unification and independence are going to happen in Taiwan every two years, what are they arguing about? She said, "What we care about now is, I'm staying in Taipei, what kind of work can I do, what kind of life can I get in Taipei?" In response to this statement, Lin Feifan, Xu Qiaoxin, Lu Qiyuan, etc., were influenced by the popularity of Huang Tongying's voice, which was originally due to the Internet program. In October 2022, Huang said in front of a political news program, "The anti-China platform is also the DNA of everyone." In response to criticism from the Taiwan People's Party (Taiwan People's Party) candidate, Wong resigned as a spokesperson for the Taipei City Government, and Wang Shiken and Taoyuan City Councillor Wang Haoyu criticized him, saying, "These are fake interviews, a fake process, everything has been fixed." On January 23, 2020, Huang was appointed as Taipei's deputy government spokesman after his visit to Europe.

The Republic of Paraguay (Spanish: República del Paraguay; Guarani: Tavakuairetã Paraguái), commonly known as Paraguay (Spanish: Paraguay; Guarani: Paraguay), is a sovereign state in South America. It is bordered by Argentina to the south, Brazil and Bolivia to the northeast and northwest, and is a member of the Confederation of South American States and the Southern Common Market. Its capital and largest city is Asunción. Although Paraguay is a landlocked country, ships that sail on the Barana and the ports along the Barana can also sail to the Atlantic via the Barana-Baragua waterway. Paraguay is a developing country and a member and founding member of the Common Market of the South, the United Nations, the Organization of American States, the Non-Aligned Movement and the Lima Group. In addition, the city of Luce, in the metropolitan area of Asunción, is the headquarters of the South American Football Association. Paraguay's constitution declares it to be a multicultural and bilingual country, with Spanish and Guaraní as official languages. In that country, 87 percent of the population speak Guaraní. It was discovered by Portuguese explorer Alejo García in 1525, and in 1537 the Spanish colonists founded the city of Asunción. Five years later, Jesuit missionaries also visited the area and taught local farmers and craftsmen. In 1767, the Spanish colonists expelled the Jesuits. In the 18th century, Paraguay was the most densely populated region in South America.

WD withdrew from the national team due to non-injury factors. SUS stopped the race. Scotland played their home match at Hampton Park. Built in 1903 on 33 acres of land in southern Glasgow, Hampton Park was the largest stadium in the world before the opening of the Maracanã Stadium in Rio de Janeiro in 1950. Following the release of the Taylor Report in the 1990s, the stadium was rebuilt for full seating, with the first phase of the project, including improvements to the east and north stands, costing £12 million and completed in February 1994. The second phase of the redevelopment of the West and South Stands was a massive project, costing £59 million (£8 million or 15.7% over budget) when completed in May 1999. With a capacity of 52,000, the stadium was rated by UEFA as one of Scotland's two five-star stadiums. The only remaining amateur club in the Scottish League at present, Division 3's Queensburne, is the owner of Hampton Park, which has been leased to Scottish Football Association (SFA) for a 20-year term beginning in April 2000. Sedna (minor planet 90377), discovered in 2003, is located outside the Kuiper belt, approximately 1,500 km in diameter. However, some astronomers have suggested that these objects may be dwarf planets. It is estimated that there are millions of asteroids, see List of minor planets for details, and the largest asteroids are now beginning to be reclassified, defined as dwarf planets. In 1760, it was conjectured that the distances of planets in the Solar System from the Sun constituted a simple numerical series. According to this series, there is a gap between Mars and Jupiter, and there should also be a planet between the two planets. At the end of the 18th century, many people began to search for this unexplored planet. The famous Titius–Portuguese theorem is one such example. At that time, European astronomers organized the world's first international scientific research project, under the leadership of the Observatory of Gotha, which divided the entire sky into 24 regions, within which European astronomers systematically searched for the planet known as the "ghost". However, the project did not produce any results. On the evening of January 1, 1801, Giuseppe Piazzi discovered a star in the constellation Taurus in Palermo's observatory on Sicily. On June 6, the researchers published a trial scale of the vaccine candidate, reporting that the vaccine induced high levels of neutralizing antibody titer in mice, rats, guinea pigs, rabbits and non-human primates (eating crab monkeys and macaques). On July 16, 2020, the company began Phase III vaccine trials on 31,000 volunteers in the United Arab Emirates. In September 2020, Bahrain participated in a three-stage clinical trial of the vaccine, and Crown Prince Bahrain led the vaccination as a volunteer, with more than 7,700 volunteers participating in the clinical trial. In addition to the United Arab Emirates and Bahrain, Phase III clinical trials have been conducted in Egypt and Jordan. On 9 December 2020, the Ministry of Health of the United Arab Emirates officially approved the registration of the vaccine. On December 13, 2020, after the Bahrain National Health Authority announced that China Pharmaceutical Group's sole distributor in the Middle East and North Africa, G42 Healthcare, had submitted the necessary documentation for listing, it reviewed the results of Phase III clinical trials of 42,299 volunteers, which showed that the vaccine was 86% effective, had a 99% conversion rate of neutralizing antibodies, and was 100% effective in preventing moderate and severe COVID-19, and officially approved the vaccine for listing in the Kingdom of Bahrain. On February 11, 2021, the Bolivian Ministry of Health and China Pharmaceutical Group signed a videoconference signing ceremony to officially approve the launch of the new vaccine.

The third name, or family name, was originally used to distinguish nicknames or personal names of people with the same name, until it appeared in official documents about 100 years ago. Typically, family names are based on physical or personal characteristics, sometimes with ironic connotations: Julius Caesar's third name "Caesar" may have meant "caesaries" and in fact he was bald, while Tacitus's third name "Tacitus" meant "silent", and he himself was a famous orator. By the time of the Republic, however, the third name was no longer used as a nickname, but as a family name passed down from father to son to distinguish between different families within the same clan. Some Roman males have family names ending in -anus, which are derived from clan names, sometimes to honor their maternal ancestors, or if someone is adopted, to honor their real paternal ancestors. For example, Vespasian's clan name Flavius was derived from his father's clan name, while his third name Vespasianus was derived from his mother Vespasia. Others may have used the family name of their mother, such as Caracalla, whose great-grandfather was Julius Bassianus, but Caracalla's third name was not "Julianus" but "Brazilianus". When someone is adopted by another family, they use their adoptive father's name (except for a personal name). If he wanted to, he would change his original clan name to an additional family name and add it after the new one.

A uniform invoice must state the opening number of the store in addition to the water number, the date of the transaction, the name of the goods, the quantity, the unit price, the amount of the goods, the amount of sales, the tax classification, the tax and the total amount of the goods and the address of the store. The number is the individual corporate identity number of the store in the Taiwan For-Profit Corporation, a set of eight digits. Also, because of the unique numbering of the stamps, the invoice is called a "unified invoice". Initially, it was the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance of the Taiwan Province to design and implement the Unified Invoice, and in 1956, after the "Battlefield Political Experiment" was implemented, it was the responsibility of the Ministry of Finance of the Taiwan Province to implement the Unified Invoice, so the two provinces of Kinmen and Mazu were not directly included in the scope of the Unified Invoice. At the time, the Kimma region was the frontline of the Second Sino-Japanese War, and financial management was separated from Taiwan, whether the circulation of new Taiwanese coins, stamp duties or purchases of invoices, and the design of Taiwan Province was different. In the 1950s, the Kimma region used for-profit business invoices, not unified invoices issued by the Taiwan Province. Until January 1960, the Kinma side followed suit with the use of unified ballots, for the Kinmen and Lianjiang county governments to organize and manage separately. In 1980, the Legislative Yuan amended the Business Tax Law, and the Unified Voting was formally supervised by the Ministry of Finance, so it was no longer the responsibility of local governments to organize the Unified Voting, and the Unified Voting was administered by the Taiwan Provincial Government. On January 17, 2002, the Legislative Yuan passed the Outlying Island Construction Ordinance, which granted the Outlying Islands (including Kinmen, Lianjiang, and Penghu) the financial advantages of exemption from business taxes, but still retained the provision of opening a unified invoice and reporting the revenues and expenditures to the local State Tax Bureau.

As of 2018, there are 1,845 border police stations in the country. The Ministry of Public Security will consolidate the responsibilities of the Ministry of Immigration and Border Protection, establish and improve the coordination mechanism for visa management, establish the State Immigration Administration, and affix the license of the Immigration Administration of the People's Republic of China, which will be administered by the Ministry of Public Security. On April 2, 2018, the State Immigration Administration was officially established, and on January 1, 2019, the Public Security Border Guard Force held a collective changeover ceremony, officially transforming it into the People's Police Establishment. To remove Shantou border inspection headquarters, subordinate units were transferred to Shenzhen border inspection headquarters, etc. In this reform, the original nine border police stations along the border provinces were reorganized into border police stations, headed by the territorial border management branch (or battalion), belonged to the system of the State Immigration Administration, and were included in the sequence of central financial budget units.

At 20:51 on 24 August 2010, Henan Airlines Flight 8387 took off from Harbin Taiping International Airport in Heilongjiang Province, carrying 91 passengers and five crew members. At 21:36 hours, a Henan Airlines E190 aircraft, numbered VD8387, landed from Harbin, Heilongjiang Province, in Ichuan, about 690 meters from the head of the runway at Lintou Airport. The plane blew up, the runway broke, some of the passengers were thrown out, and then it exploded. By about midnight on the 25th, the plane had caught fire. Meanwhile, 54 people were rescued by rescue troops and taken to hospitals for treatment. The remains of 42 other victims were also found. Three of the victims were crew members of the aircraft. Accessed 19 October 2010. On 23 July 2011, at 20:30:05, a D301 train from Beijing South Station to Fuzhou Station and a D3115 train from Hangzhou South Station to Fuzhou Station in Wenzhou, Zhejiang Province, China, collided with another D301 train, killing 40 people and injuring 172.

Among them, Ganghe Gap in the southwest of the Changdu region is in the main channel of the Indian Ocean monsoon to transport water vapor to the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, is the southern edge of the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau is the strongest mountain affected by the southwest monsoon of Tibet Autonomous Region, modern glaciers are very developed, and is the mountain with the highest modern glacier coverage on the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. The vast majority of glaciers in this region are formed under the conditions of a monsoonal oceanic climate, oceanic glaciers. Only in the northwest, Mount Tanggula may be a composite transient glacier. There are hundreds of glaciers in Changdu, which is one of the most concentrated glacier areas in the Qinghai-Tibet Plateau. The overall trend of glacier distribution in the area decreased from west to east as the altitude decreased. Not only are the mountains low in elevation, but they are blocked by parallel mountains on both sides, forming a rain shadow region that is difficult for east-west air flows to penetrate, thus becoming the only modern glacial mountain range in the region's mountain ranges. There are eight types of modern glaciers: suspended ice, ice-tubular ice, ice-tubular ice, ice-valley ice, valley ice, canyon ice, slope ice, and ice cap ice. Among them, the valley glacier is the largest of all kinds of glaciers, a large-scale glacier, mainly divided into the highest elevation areas, such as Gangje-Gab, Nengqing Tanggula Mountain-Bishura Mountain, Kangra-Jing, Tanen Taung Mountain in the south, Dami Xue Mountain and Mery Xue Mountain, the length of more than 10 kilometers, the area of several kilometers to dozens of kilometers, are the main types of glaciers in this region. The largest of these valley glaciers is the Lako Glacier (also known as the Yalong Glacier) on the southern side of Lake Erie, which is about 26 kilometers long, 2-4 kilometers wide, and reaches below 4,000 meters at the end. There is also a series of glaciers on the northern slopes of Mt. Nanqing Tanggula in the southern part of Binba County, and the end of the glacier rises to about 4,500 meters above sea level.

The Guangzhou Uprising (Chinese: 广州暴動) was the last major armed uprising of the Communist Party of China (CPC) in Guangzhou in December 1927, and one of the three uprisings Qu Qiu Bai organized with the help of the Communist International, the other two being the Nanchang Uprising and the Autumn Reception Uprising. In April 1927, the Wuhan National Government ordered the pursuit of Zhang Tailei, Tsai and others. In the second half of 1927, Stalin's Chinese policy was criticized by Trotsky, who ordered the Chinese Communist Party to launch a series of armed uprisings in hopes of seizing power in some provinces, thus proving his Chinese policy correct. However, the Nanchang riots in August and the autumn harvest riots in Hunan, Guangdong, Jiangxi, Hubei and other provinces in September failed. However, the Communist International still planned to launch a new, larger-scale armed uprising in one of the provinces. When the Nanchang Insurrectionary Forces withdrew to the south, the Communist International planned to launch an uprising in Guangzhou, in cooperation with the Nanchang Insurrectionary Forces to occupy Guangzhou, establishing a Soviet regime in Guangzhou. In October, after the defeat of Yeltsin's and Holon's forces, plans for the Guangzhou uprising were put on hold for a while, but on 10 November, the Communist International Representative Rominaz convened an expanded meeting of the Provisional Political Bureau of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China in Shanghai, which resolved to carry out a general armed uprising throughout the country and seize power in one or several provinces; among them, Su Zhaozheng, Luo Yannon, and Ron Man (Communist International Representative in China) jointly formulated a plan for the Guangzhou uprising, and established a secret operations headquarters in Guangzhou. After the division of Ninghan in April 1927, Zhang Fukui's 2nd Front supported the Wang Zhenwei government in Wuhan, with Secretary-General Gao Xianghan, Political Department Director Guo Moruo, and 24th Division Commander Ye Ting all public communists, and the 4th Army Chief of Staff Ye Jianying a secret communist.

Badoglio declared that he would not change Italy's policy of fighting alongside Germany in the war, but he did push the Savoy for peace, and in some ways sought a truce with the Allies. Three Italian generals (including General Giuseppe Castellano) arrived in Lisbon to negotiate the surrender with the Allies, but the Allies first learned who had the power to negotiate with the Allies, and General Castellano was finally authorized to negotiate the surrender of Italy. The Allied proposals for Italy's surrender were initially not well received, as the military campaign against the Axis had been successful, and Italy's surrender was only a matter of time, while Germany's surrender was expected, and the Italian ceasefire reduced the Allied gains. Italy's surrender also raised other issues, notably the United States' desire to avoid British control of Italy after the war, as this would give the British complete control of the Mediterranean (including control of the oil trade routes). Castro returned to Italy on 27 August, and three days later, on the advice of the British ambassador to the Vatican, Badoglio met with the Allies in Sicily at the request of the Allies. He ordered Castellano to insist that any surrender of Italy was conditional upon the Allied landing on the Italian mainland (the Allied forces still controlled Sicily and the small islands nearby), and he wanted to know the contents of the Allied military plan, but he knew that it was impossible, as the war was still going on and the Allied personnel could do nothing.

Between 2006 and 2008, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China and Papua New Guinea negotiated the establishment of full diplomatic relations, but after several discussions between the two countries, Papua New Guinea did not intend to establish diplomatic relations, so the Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China, Huang Zhifang, requested the intermediaries Kim Ki-kwok and Wu Si-jin to return the diplomatic funds in the two provisional accounts. These diplomatic contributions were originally intended to provide diplomatic assistance to Papua New Guinea after the establishment of diplomatic relations, but in addition, the aid was seized by Kim and Wu, involving an amount of about $30 million. After the investigation by the Taipei District Prosecutor's Office, it was determined that Huang Zhifang, Qiu Yoshihide, and Ke Cheng Hen were not involved in the invasion of public funds. In the United States, legal action has been taken to compensate for the damages suffered by U.S. citizens as a result of the U.S. invasion and occupation of Kuwait. The Inspector General's Office confirmed that Foreign Minister Huang Zhifang had dealt with the deficiencies and proceeded to impeach him. Papua New Guinea established diplomatic relations with the Republic of China for the first time in 1999, when Taiwan was ruled by President Lee Teng-hui and Foreign Minister Hu Shiqiang. On July 5, 1999, Hu signed a diplomatic declaration in Taipei, formally establishing diplomatic relations between the two countries, but on July 21, 1999, the newly appointed Prime Minister Morota announced the withdrawal of this diplomatic recognition, and the diplomatic relations were maintained for only two weeks. The establishment of diplomatic relations between Papua New Guinea and Taiwan in 1999 was set against the backdrop of a political crisis in which Prime Minister Scott faced a vote of no-confidence by the National Assembly. On July 3, Scutt personally led a delegation to Taipei to meet with Taiwanese Premier Xiao Wan-chung, but negotiations failed due to Scutt's request for up to $2.3 billion in aid.

The Battle of Huaiyin (Chinese: 两淮战) was a series of battles that took place immediately after the end of the Chinese War of Resistance against Japan in 1945, ending with the capture of Huaiyin and Huai'an by the Third Column of the Red Army. This battle is sometimes referred to as the Battle of Huaiyin and the Battle of Huai'an. Like other conflicts between the two Communist parties after World War II, this one stemmed from Chiang Kai-shek’s realization that his Kuomintang regime lacked sufficient troops or transportation capital to deploy its own troops to China’s Japanese-occupied territories. He did not want the Communist Party, which had occupied most of China's rural areas, to further expand its territory by accepting the surrender of Japanese troops and controlling the Japanese occupation zone, so he ordered the Japanese army and the pseudo-army not to surrender to the Communist Party, to maintain their own forces, to "keep order" in the occupation zone, and, if necessary, to fight against the Communist Party, until the National Army finally arrived and completed its deployment. As a result, most members of the pseudo-government and the pseudo-military rejoined the army. However, most of these troops that were converted from the former state army to the pseudo-army were not Chiang Kai-shek's heirs, but were mainly composed of troops of warlords who were nominally under Chiang Kai-shek's rule before World War II, nominally only the Kuomintang, and mostly maintained their own independence or semi-independence. These warlords cared only about maintaining their own power, and when the Japanese invaders promised to keep them in power in exchange for their cooperation, they surrendered to the Japanese. After World War II, these warlords returned to the Kuomintang for the same reason. Chiang Kai-shek clearly found it difficult to eliminate these warlords as soon as they surrendered and returned to the Kuomintang, thus incriminating other factions within the army, and these pseudo-warlords could still help the Kuomintang gain more territory by deploying their own troops to complete the takeover and control.

Longnan City, anciently known as Wutou, is a city in Gansu Province of the People's Republic of China, located in the southeastern part of Gansu Province, at the junction of the three provinces of Shaanxi and Gansu. It borders Tianshui City to the north, Dingxi City to the west, Xipinggan South Province to the south, Aba Province to the south, Mianyang City to the south, Guangyuan City to the east, Hanzhong City to the west, Baoji City to the east. It lies between the southern, northern Qinling Mountains and Minshan Mountains, and in the middle is the Huicheng Basin. The main rivers are Jialing River and its tributaries Xihansui, Bailong River, Baishui River, etc. The city has a total area of 27.839 square kilometers, a population of 25.909 million, and the city's people's government is located in Wutou District. Due to its favorable climate, high forest cover, it is called Longshang Jiangnan. Qin Dynasty put up a stronghold. In the year 111 BC, Emperor Wu of Han (汉武帝元鼎六年(前111年)置武都郡, belonged to the History Department of Liangzhou. At the end of the Han dynasty, Cao Cao divided the provinces into three divisions: Liangzhou, Liangzhou and Yongzhou, and Wutou County was transferred to Yongzhou. During the Three Kingdoms period, Wudu County was the border between Wei and Shu. In 219, Liu Bei captured the Hanzhong County of Cao Cao's army, blocking the connection between Wutou and Yongzhou, so Cao abandoned Wutou County and moved to Ufufeng Xiaokairi. After that, Wei and Shu fought many wars in Wutou, the most famous of which was the "six out of Qishan" invasion of Wei, and in 229, they captured Wutou and Yinping two counties, from which Wutou County became the seat of Shu, until the state of Shu was destroyed by Cao Wei. During the period of the Eastern Jin Dynasty and the Northern and Southern Dynasties, five Hu dynasties were established in Longnan: Yuchi, Tangchang, Wudu, Wuxing and Yinping, and they were called the "Longnan Five Kingdoms". During the Sui and Tang dynasties, the political and economic situation in Longnan region was relatively calm, and the Tang dynasties settled in Longnan, Wu, Cheng, Tei, Tang, Min and other provinces. In 762, Toba invaded Longnan. During the Xiantong years, the Tang recaptured Wuzhou, renamed the state, Xiantong seven years (866) recaptured into a state.

Lucas Papadímos (Greek:Λ aboveas Papadímos; born 11 October 1947) is the former Vice-President of the European Central Bank (ECB) and the 181st Prime Minister of Greece. He earned a degree in physics from MIT in 1970, a master's degree in electrical engineering from MIT in 1972, and a Ph.D. in economics from MIT in 1978. He taught economics at Columbia University from 1975 to 1984 and at the University of Athens from 1988 to 1993. In 1980, he became a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Boston. He was Chief Economist of the Bank of Greece in 1985, and was promoted to Deputy Governor and Governor in 1993 and 1994, respectively, and served as Governor until Greece joined the eurozone on 1 January 2001. From 2002 to 2010, he served as Vice-President of the European Central Bank. After leaving office in 2010, he became the economic adviser to Greek Prime Minister George Papandreou. Since 1998, he has been a member of the Tripartite Commission (a non-governmental social group coordinating economic cooperation between Europe, the United States and Japan). He's a member of the Athens Academy of Sciences. On 11 November 2011, a coalition government was formed under his leadership. The new government’s main task is to enable the European Union’s solution to the Greek debt crisis to be adopted by parliament, and to prepare for the upcoming parliamentary elections on February 19, 2012.

Caesar (Latin: Caesar) was a title in the Roman Empire. After the death of Gaius Julius Caesar (102–44 BC) as dictator, several ancient Roman leaders claimed to have inherited the name of the Caesar family (and its legitimate rule). Thus the word Caesar became one of the many titles of the Roman Emperor. During the reign of the Four Emperors, Descartes formally repositioned the word "Caesar" as "Deputy Emperor", as the deputy and designated heir to the title of "Prince" of Augustus. Caesar's original meaning of "hairy" can be traced back to the early Roman branch of the Iulia clan, the Iulii Caesares, possibly because of his distinctive long hair (or, in other words, the fact that he had no hair on his head). Julius Caesar, a political figure of the late Roman Republic, was assassinated and, in his will, designated his young niece Gaius Jadwiga as his heir. In Roman custom, Octavian was legally adopted by Caesar, and named Gaius Julius Caesar Octavianus. For political and personal reasons, Octavian, after acquiring the sole political authority, emphasized his relationship with Caesar, and adopted the title "Imperator Caesar" in self-proclaimed terms with care and humility—the general representing the actual military power, Caesar representing his legitimate inheritance, the rest of the titles being rejected in public.

The Republic of Mali withdrew from the French Community on 22 September. From its independence to 1991, a series of dictators ruled Mali. Anti-government protests in 1991 led to a coup d'état, a transitional government and a new constitution. In 1992, Alfa Omar Konare was elected President of Mali in the first multi-party, democratic elections, and was re-elected in 1997. He strengthened political and economic reforms and the fight against corruption. In 2002, when Amadou Toumani Touré became President of Mali, Touré was a key figure in the 1991 democracy movement. Presidential elections were held on April 29, 2007. In January 2012, the Tuvaluan rebels launched an armed rebellion in the north, sparking the conflict in northern Mali. On March 21, 2012, a group of soldiers staged a coup d'état in the capital, Bamako, overthrowing the Duel, suspending the constitution, and dissolving state institutions. Under pressure from the international community, the coup plotters signed an agreement with the Economic Community of West African States (ECOWAS) on 6 April, agreeing to cede power and appointing the Speaker of the National Assembly as interim president. On April 8, Duel resigned. At a time of uncertainty in the south, Tuareg separatists, aided by Islamic militants, took advantage of the situation to take control of northern Mali. Later, hardline Islamic militants defeated the Tuareg separatists and took control of northern Mali. In January 2013, the Islamic Republic of Iran launched an armed offensive in the south, France launched Operation Bumblebee, sent troops to assist the Malian government in the war, and quickly recaptured all major cities in the north. On 18 August 2020, a military coup d'état took place in Mali, in which President Ibrahim Boubacar Keita and Prime Minister Bubu Sese were detained by rebels.

Shu Ting (Chinese: 舒婷; born May 25, 1952) is a Chinese poet. She rose to prominence in the Chinese poetry scene in the late 1970s, and along with her contemporaries Kitajima, Gucheng, and Liang Xiaobin, she set off a wave of "shadow poetry" in Chinese poetry. On May 25, 1952, he joined the Xiangxian Internment Corps, returned to the city in 1972 as a worker, began publishing poetry works in 1979, worked for the Fujian Provincial Literature Union from 1980, engaged in professional writing. He is the current Chairman of the Xiamen City Council and Vice-Chairman of the Fujian Province Council of Culture. Husband: Chen Zhongyi (born 1948 in Xiamen), professor at Xiamen City College. Son: Chen Xi (born in Xiamen in 1982), Ph.D. in Modern Chinese Literature, Department of Chinese Studies, Peking University, Research Fellow, Contemporary Room, Institute of Literature, Chinese Academy of Social Sciences. His major works include a collection of poems, "The mast ship", "The iris that sings", "The first ancestor bird", and a collection of essays, "The heart smoke". "To the Oak" is one of the representative works of the wave of obscure poetry. It expresses the spirit and thinking of the women of the time in the unique way of female life experience calligraphy. Shuting excels in introspection of self-emotional rhythms, capturing complex and subtle emotional experiences. Emotional complexity and richness are often expressed through the twists and turns of particular syntactic expressions such as assumptions and concessions. It builds a whole new lyrical image with the self at its core. To express a sweet melancholy, a sad hope, to convey a sad and beautiful feeling. The self-value of human beings — the affirmation and affirmation of dignity, the promotion of personality independence and the pursuit of the ideal of life — constitutes the core idea of all of Shuting's poetry. It has obvious modernist characteristics.

The Chinese Revolutionary League (Chinese: 中國革命同盟会; pinyin: Zhōngxīng Jīngjīng) was the predecessor of the Nationalist Party of China. It was founded in 1905 in Tokyo, Japan, as a revolutionary organization formed in the late Qing Dynasty by a number of groups such as the Xingchu Kai and the Huaxing Kai. Its organization spread across Chinese communities in China and around the world, and launched several attempts to overthrow the Qing dynasty, including the successful overthrow of the Qing dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China's Xinhai Revolution. The alliance was led by Sun Yat-sen, Song Kyo-jin, Huang Xing, Huang Yuan-hui, and Cai Yuan-pei, among others, and as a result of its membership, internal strife has continued since 1906, including personal conflicts, differences of theory, and differences of revolutionary leanings, especially due to a series of failed armed uprisings. After the success of the Xinhai Revolution, the alliance was reorganized into the Kuomintang. After the dissolution of the Kuomintang, some members formed the Chinese Revolutionary Party, which was reorganized into the Kuomintang in 1919. Under the leadership of the Japanese leader Ryohei Uchida, he was elected Prime Minister of the People's Republic of China on the basis of the following organizations: the People's Republic of China Association, the People's Republic of China Association of Huang Hing and Song Kyo-jin, the People's Republic of China Association of Shanghai Cai Yuan-pei, the People's Republic of China Association of Zhang Binglin and Wu Kei-hung, and the People's Republic of China Association of Zhang Jie. The alliance vowed to "eradicate the Tatar POWs, restore China, establish a national state, and establish equal land rights", and the following year issued a "Military Government Declaration", which was listed as the "Four Principles of Revolutionary State-building": 167. The League of China agrees with Sun Yat-sen's idea of a Republic of China government structure: with the Prime Minister as head of the executive, legislative, and judicial branches, which is in fact a principle of separation of powers. On November 26, 1905, the League's organ newspaper, the Minpo, was founded in Tokyo, publishing the words "Promoting the Nation, Civil Rights and Civil Liberties": 169.

Some of the gaps are segments of tiny moons that have been cleared, such as Pan, probably many of which have not yet been discovered, and some of the rings are bound by gravity waves of some Shepherd Dog moons (such as the F-rings maintained by Prometheus and Pandora). Other gaps may be caused by resonance with the orbital periods of the larger moons, the presence of the Cassini node bound to the Milky Way, and more circular structures that produce spiral waves due to periodic perturbations by other moons. Data from the Cassini spacecraft show that Saturn's ring has its own atmosphere, independent of the planet itself. The atmosphere contains oxygen molecules (O2), which are produced by the Sun's ultraviolet rays interacting with the ice in the ring. The bonds between the water molecules are stimulated by ultraviolet light to produce chemical reactions that release and eject gases, especially O2. According to these atmospheric models, there are also H2, O2, and H2 atmospheres that are very sparse, but are strangely condensed around the ring, its thickness being only one atom. Saturn has a complex pattern in its brightness. In 1980, when Voyager 1 flew over Saturn, it was shown that the F-rings were composed of three braided rings with complex structures; it is now known that the outer two rings had protruding tumors, causing the illusion of weaving and clustering, while the third, less luminous, was inside them. The rings of Saturn may be very old, dating back to the formation of Saturn itself, and there are two main theories about the formation of Saturn's rings. One theory, which originated in the 19th century at the Roche limit, suggests that the ring was originally a Saturnian moon that fell into the Roche limit due to a decay in its orbit and was torn apart by tidal forces because it was not tight enough (see Roche limit), and this theory evolved into the theory that the moon collapsed when it was struck by an asteroid or comet.
