Despite heavy losses, the 11th Army pursued the entire army, with Manstein reporting about 100,000 Soviet prisoners and 700 artillery pieces, and the Soviet officials reporting about 68,200 casualties. On 1 November, the 30th Infantry Division captured Sinopheropol; on 4 November, the 42nd Infantry Division captured Feodosiya; and on 16 November, the 42nd Infantry Division captured Kerch. On 30 October 1941, the Germans launched an offensive against Sevastopol, which was defended by about 12,000 Soviet troops, consisting mainly of two battalions of the local infantry regiment, the 2nd and 3rd Marine Corps, and a garrison of permanent fire stations and some artillery detachments with 150 artillery pieces (34 coastal artillery pieces). The main defences were 35 km long, 10–12 km from the city, originating on the east coast of Balaklava, west of Upper and Lower Jorgon, through Mackenzie and Kameshre, to the south of Marmashai, and were initially only 200–300 m in depth and then 2–3 km. The rear defences were three to six kilometers from the city, 19 kilometers long and 300 to 400 meters deep, and were subsequently extended to a total length of 27 kilometers, in which trenches 31.5 kilometers long and 2.8 kilometers deep were dug. In September, a 50-kilometre-long frontier fortification was laid between 16 and 17 kilometres (16 and 17 mi) from the city, but due to time constraints, only four independent fortifications were built at Jogorgon, Cherkdz-Kremyan, Duvankoy and Aranche.

Ye Xiangzhi (Chinese: 葉翔之; September 29, 1912 – January 3, 2001) was a Chinese military commander and a member of the 9th and 10th Central Committees of the Communist Party of China. One of the most important figures in the world of information, Chiang Ching-kuo is one of the most powerful assistants. He is the son of the late lawyer and former Chairman of China Film Corporation, Ye Shiqiao (1937-2013). Born on September 29, 1949 in Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province, he studied in Japan and graduated from the Faculty of Political Economy, Meiji University of Japan. After returning to the country, he joined the Kuomintang, engaged in intelligence work. In 1949, he was appointed Director General of the Second Bureau of Secrecy of the Ministry of Defense, responsible for the assassination of Yang Jiechi in Hong Kong, and the detection of the case of the Deputy Chief of Staff, Wu Shi, and the Working Committee of the Taiwan Province, to Chiang Kai-shek's attention. In 1950, Chiang Kai-shek hoped to establish his own power in the intelligence community by reorganizing the Bureau of Secrecy. He attempted to assassinate Chiang Kai-shek, but was unsuccessful due to Chiang Kai-shek's intervention. Afterwards, he became a member of the Chiang Kai-shek People's Coalition. In 1960, he became director of the Department of Defense Intelligence. From 1973 to 1975, he was director of the Institute of Continental Studies at the Chinese Cultural University. In 1975, after retirement, he was appointed as a state policy adviser. In 1979, Yin'in, the son of Ye Xiang, was involved in the closure of Western department stores and fled abroad. On May 1, 1979, Chiang wrote in his diary: "Recently, the son of Ye Xiang's loans and loans abroad, which had a great impact on the people's hearts, could destroy the government's political achievements, and the hearts of the people and the Party were ashamed of it. Because I used it, I used two spoils, one was Ye Ye, one was Tao Yishan (father of Tao Dawei), and both of them were introduced to Wang Xin Heng, and I myself admitted to be temporarily muddy and guilty, the person should be particularly careful, please note.":161 According to NOWnews, the author of Huang Guangseri's account, when Chiang Ching-guo found the former intelligence director Ye Xiang's house, decorated with gold and glitter, immediately asked him to leave.

In 1645, the Qing army occupied Xining. In 1725, after the reign of Emperor Yongzheng of the Three Kingdoms, it was renamed Xiningwei (西宁卫) and became Xiningfu (西宁府) in Gansu Province. It is situated in the districts of Xining, Renbei and Datongwei. In 1724, he was appointed as the Minister of Banshi Affairs of Qinghai-Mongolia (Chinese: 西寧辦事大臣), and was responsible for the Mongol and Tibetan ministries in Qinghai. In June 1912, he was appointed Minister of Qinghai Affairs as Qinghai Affairs Director, in Xining, Gansu. In April 1913, the North Sea Government reformed the Qing Dynasty establishment, abolished Xining Prefecture, changed the Eastern Sea Route, and Xining was the seat of the province. In June 1914, the east coast road was changed to Sining Road. In October 1915, he was appointed Governor-General of Xining Town, Gansu Province, as well as Governor-General of Ninghai Town, Gansu Province. In 1927, he was appointed to the post of Governor of Xi'anning Province (Chinese: 撤西宁道). In 1929, the National Government established Qinghai Province, with Xining County as the provincial capital. At the end of 1943, Xining County transferred to Wenhua Town (now Rusal Town), in Xining City (officially known as the provincial fence, used until today) set up the provincial fence special district, under the direct control of the Ministry of Civil Affairs, the administration of which was also managed by the Provincial Council Police Bureau. In August 1945, it was reorganized into the Sining Municipal Preparatory Office, with the establishment of the first, second, third, fourth, fifth and fifth districts. In January 1946, Xining County was renamed Huangzhong County. In June 1946, Xining City was officially established, with a total area of 30 square kilometers (3 sq mi) and a total population of over 70,000 (55,564 inhabitants). On September 5, 1949, the People's Liberation Army occupied Xining, and on September 8, 1949, the People's Government of Xining was established. In June 1956, the Qinghai Provincial People's Committee made a decision on the establishment of Xining City, which became the city of the People's Government of the subordinate regions.

In 1999, the following regulations were issued: a seal with a diameter of 4.5 cm, a centrally issued coat of arms, issued by the State Council. The State Food and Materials Reserve Board, abbreviated as the State Food and Materials Reserve Board, is a state bureau under the State Council of the People's Republic of China, which is responsible for the management of the national grain circulation and material reserves and is administered by the ministries and commissions under the State Council. The State Food and Materials Reserve Bureau is mainly responsible for organizing the collection, rotation and management of the national strategy and emergency reserve materials in accordance with the overall development plan of the national reserves and the catalog of varieties, for unified responsibility for the construction and management of the reserve infrastructure, for supervising and inspecting the management of government reserves, enterprise reserves and the implementation of reserve policies, for the management of the grain circulation industry and the administrative management of the central reserves of grain and cotton, etc. On March 17, 2018, the First Session of the Thirteenth National People's Congress adopted the Decision of the First Session of the Thirteenth National People's Congress on the Institutional Reform Programme of the State Council, and ratified the Institutional Reform Programme of the State Council. The program stipulates: "To establish the State Food and Material Reserve Board. Integrate the functions of the State Food Bureau, the organization of the State Development and Reform Commission to carry out the collection, storage, rotation and management of State strategic materials, the management of the State grain, cotton and sugar reserves, and the organization of the Ministry of Civil Affairs, the Ministry of Commerce, the State Energy Bureau and other departments to carry out the collection, storage, rotation and daily management of State strategic and emergency reserves, and form the State Food and Material Reserve Bureau, which shall be administered by the State Development and Reform Commission. It no longer retains the National Food Board. On April 4, 2018, the State Food and Material Reserve Board was officially established. On August 31, 2020, according to the State Development and Reform Commission's "Opinion on Implementation of Decoupling Reforms Between Trade Associations and Administrative Organs" (No.1063 [2019]), one trade association (trade association) such as the Chinese Grain Trade Association, which was formerly under the responsibility of the Food Bureau, and the State Grain and Material Reserve Bureau were separated, registered directly according to law, operated independently, deprived of administrative functions, and no longer set up units in charge of operations.

Emperor Jiaqing (13 November 1760 – 2 September 1820), known as Diệm (Chinese:  ᠠ, transliterated Yong Yan), was the fifth emperor of the Qing Dynasty, reigning from 9 February 1796 to 2 September 1820. The name of the temple is Jinzong (Manchu:, plural:žindzung), and the name of the emperor is Rui (Manchu:  ᠠ, plural:sunggiyen hūwangdi). He was the fifteenth son of Emperor Qianlong, originally known as Diệm, who became the crown prince for sixty years, and changed his name to Diệm to avoid trouble. On 9 February 1796, he accepted the throne of his father Emperor Qianlong, but Emperor Qianlong remained in the position of Grand Emperor. After the death of Emperor Qianlong on February 7, 1799, Emperor Jiaqing succeeded to the throne. On November 13, 1760, Diệm was born, first name Diệm, was the fifteenth son of Emperor Qianlong, mother of Wei Jia. In the thirty-eighth winter solstice, Emperor Qianlong made Diệm the Crown Prince of the Great Qing Dynasty. Previously, Emperor Qianlong had designated heirs to the throne according to the secret system established by his father, Emperor Yongzheng, but he succeeded to the throne twice, designating the choice of princes as early as death; in late Qianlong's third investiture, he was designated as the fifteenth son of Diệm. In 1774, Emperor Qianlong proclaimed the Khitanese dynasty as the legitimate successor to Diệm. In late 1780, Diệm's concubine Liu Jia gave birth to his eldest son. In 1789, Emperor Qianlong appointed Diệm as Prince of Jia.

Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region (Vietnamese; Uyghur pronunciation: ), also known as Xinjiang, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region, Xinjiang Uyg The autonomous region was reorganized by Xinjiang Province, founded in 1955, and its capital is located in Urumqi. Xinjiang has a total area of 1,664,897 square kilometers, roughly one-sixth of China's land area; its land border is 569,142 kilometers, roughly one-quarter of China's total border length. Xinjiang's geomorphology is "three mountains and two basins", that is, it has a unique topographical characteristics of the distribution between the high mountains and the basins. The northern and southern ends are the Kunlun Mountains and the Altai Mountains, while the central Tianshan Mountains divide Xinjiang roughly into the Junggar Basin and the Tarim Basin, or North and South Frontiers. The high summer temperatures, abundant sunshine and wide variations in day and night temperatures make Xinjiang produce all kinds of quality melons, such as tomatoes, pumpkins, pomegranates, grapes, etc. The hot, dry climate and stable irrigation make the southern frontier China's largest production base for high-quality cotton. Xinjiang is also one of China's most oil and gas-rich provinces, accounting for nearly a third of the country's total land reserves, with hundreds of millions of tons of oil reserves. It owns China's strategic oil and gas reserves. It's the largest oil field in the western part of China. Xinjiang is inhabited by 56 ethnic groups and 19 indigenous peoples, including the Uyghur, Han, Kazakh, Hui, Kirgiz, Mongolian, Siberian, Tajik, and Dongxiang ethnic groups.

In 1793, after the invasion of Pingding Gorkha by Fukang'an troops under the governor of Bigang, he sent a petition for the promulgation of Article 29 of the Constitution of Chinding Tibet, which once again confirmed the positions of the Minister for Tibet and Ka Xia. The constitution stipulates that the position of the Tibetan minister is equal to that of the Dalai Lama and the Buddhist monks. The ceremony is presided over by the Dalai Lama, Banchen Dorjee Rinchen Dorjee Rinpoche, the Dalai Lama's funeral pyre, and the Dalai Lama's ordination ceremony. The Dalai Lama and other monks are not allowed to write directly to the emperor, but must be forwarded by the Tibetan minister. In the event of the absence of the chief priest of each temple, the minister in charge of Tibet is elected by the Dalai Lama together with the chief priest. The Governor-General and his subordinates are all members of the House of Representatives. All political matters are to be reported by Karunanidhi and the Dalai Lama to the Tibetan ministers, and may not be disclosed without permission. The emperor is appointed by the Dalai Lama and the minister in charge of Tibetan affairs presents a list of candidates to the emperor. The remaining officers of the front and back of the Tibetan army were appointed by the ministers in charge of Tibet, respectively, together with Dalai Lama and Banchen Chosen. All matters relating to the local borders of Tibet, garrisons, trade (one trip to Karkar in one year, three trips to Kashmir in three years), minting of coins, foreign tribute, etc., are handled by the Minister of State for Tibet. The Minister of State for Tibet also has the power to inspect Tibet's local finances and expenditures; and to supervise the administration of justice, household affairs, and foreign affairs (Ula). In 1846, Qi Zhen, the Tibetan minister in the Qing Dynasty, proposed the "Prohibition of the accumulation of defects in commerce" and approved its implementation, in which he renounced the right of financial audit of commerce, the right to train the Tibetan army, weakened the power of the Tibetan minister in the Qing Dynasty, and said that the Qing Dynasty lost its financial and military rights to Tibet. The Secretary of State for Tibet usually sends the letter to the military, but in times of crisis it is sent on behalf of the Governor-General of Sichuan, as any action against Tibet is handled by the Governor-General of Sichuan.

On November 11, Zhang's grandfather, Zhang Guangzhen, who became a deputy partner of South Korean Yu, officially ran for vice president, and remained a non-party member, was a Tianjin citizen, who served as the station manager at Taipei Station of the Taiwan Railway Administration of the Ministry of Transportation. His father, Zhang Dongwen, graduated from the Department of Civil Engineering of the National Beiyang University, and in 1948, he moved to Taiwan, enrolled in China Petroleum Co., Ltd., and after retirement turned to the private construction industry, as a civil engineering engineer. Her mother is from Taiwan. His wife, Zhang Qiya, studied computer science at the University of San Francisco, and later obtained a PhD in business administration from the National Taipei University School of Commerce. He attended the Northeastern Central Mountains Changchun National School, and graduated with the President's Award. After graduating from high school, he attended the University of North Carolina, where he earned a bachelor's degree and a master's degree from the University of California, Berkeley, graduating with a score of 29 out of 1,300. After graduating from the Department of Civil Engineering at National Taiwan University, he earned a bachelor's degree in engineering, passed the 613-point Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL), and went to Stanford University to study civil and environmental engineering, where he earned a master's degree in 1977. In 1981, he received a Ph.D. in civil and environmental engineering from Cornell University. After earning his Ph.D. from Cornell University, he entered the Computer Graphics Laboratory for postdoctoral research, supplementing the flaws of civil engineering theory with the advantages of computer simulation.

Deng Zhexi (Chinese: 邓哲熙; 1894 – January 10, 1981) was a Chinese politician. Deng Zhexi was a villager of Xibaiyang in Dacheng County, Jiaoling Province. In 1912, Deng entered the North Sea Law School to study law. After graduating in 1917, Deng was sent to study law at Meiji University in Japan. In 1918, he returned to his homeland, where he held various positions, including secretary of the 16th Mixed Brigade, 1st Battalion, 2nd Infantry Regiment, director of the Military Law Department of the Henan Governor's Office, director of the Military Law Department of the Army Inspection Commission, and director of the Military Law Department of the Northwest Frontier Governor's Office. In November 1926, Deng went to Moscow, where he was a representative of Feng Yuxiang's Ministry in the Soviet Union. In June 1927, Deng returned to China and became the head of Henan's Ministry of Justice, and later the president of the Henan High Court. In the winter of 1927, Deng Zhexi was appointed as the head of the Henan Provincial Civil Affairs Office, acting as the chairman of the Henan Provincial Government. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, Deng Zhexi, as a representative of Feng Yuxiang, participated in the enlargement conference convened by Wang Xiewei. After the end of the Second Sino-Japanese War in September 1930, Feng Yuxiangbu was disbanded and Deng Zhexi went to hide in Beiping. In 1933, Feng Yuxiang organized the Zakhar People's Anti-Japanese Allied Forces in Zhangjiakou, and Deng Zhexi went to Zhangjiakou, where he became the head of the Military Law Department at the Allied Forces headquarters. In 1933, he was appointed by Feng Yuxiang as a member of the Legislative Council of the National Government of Nanjing. In 1936, he was appointed a member of the Hebei Administrative Committee and president of the Hebei High Court. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, Deng fled with the Hebei government to Luoyang, Chongqing, and other places in Henan Province. After the victory in the War of Resistance against Japan, Deng Zhexi continued to serve as the president of Hebei High Court, in which he executed the Han traitors Qi Xieyuan, Yin Ruko, Kim Beihui (Kawajima Yoshiko) and others according to law.

However, it was not until 1998 that historians were able to re-examine the Neptune documents in the astronomer Egan's estate (historical documents from the Greenwich Observatory, apparently stolen by Egan nearly thirty years later, were re-examined after his death). For some time after its discovery, Neptune was referred to as either the "planet outside Uranus" or the "planet of Leviathan". Galileo was the first to suggest the name, which he suggested was Janus (the double-faced guardian of the gates in Roman mythology). In the United Kingdom, Charles named it "Oceanus"; in France, Arago suggested calling it "Le Vieux", in response to strong protests outside France. The French astronomical calendar at the time referred to Uranus as Herschel, as opposed to Levier as the newly discovered planet. At the same time, in the case of separation and independence, Adams proposed changing the name of Uranus to "George", while Leviathan, through the Committee on the Longitude of the Moon, proposed "Neptune" as the name of the new planet. Vasily Struvi defended Levey's proposal at the Saint Petersburg Academy of Sciences on 29 December 1846. In Chinese, Korean, Japanese, and Vietnamese, the planet's name is written in Chinese characters as Neptune. In India, the planet is named Varuna, also the sea god in Indian mythology, and has the same meaning as Poseidon/Neptune in Greco-Roman mythology. Neptune looks blue because of the methane in its atmosphere. The atmosphere of Neptune is 85 percent hydrogen, 13 percent helium, two percent methane, plus a small amount of ammonia.

Ming Taizo's tactics for the battle of Pingding and Guangdong were three parallel lines: attacking Fujian's army from the sea heading straight for Guangdong under General Hu Ting Rui of the Southern Expeditionary Force; attacking Guangxi with Jingxiang's army headed by Ping Zhang Yangjing of the Guangdong Expeditionary Force; attacking Deqing Prefecture from Shaoshu (present-day Shaoguan, Guangdong) under the command of Lu Zhong Heng's army under Ganzhou Wei, and then attacking Guangzhou under the Third Route Division. On October 21, 1367, Yang Jing, Zhao Dexing, and Zhang Bing were ordered to lead the guards of Wuchang, Jingzhou, Yiyang, Changde, Yuezhou (present-day Yueyang, Hunan), Hengzhou (present-day Hengyang, Hunan), Lizhou (present-day Li County, Hunan) and so on. At present, the construction of smart cities is a hot issue in the fields of information technology and urban planning. The idea of a smart city originated with the idea of a "smart Earth" proposed by IBM, and similar concepts have existed before, such as digital cities. In November 2008, at the beginning of the global financial crisis of 2007-2012, IBM launched the Smart Earth: The Next Generation Leaders Agenda, a thematic report published in New York that called for the full use of the next generation of information technology in all industries. Specifically, the idea of "intelligence" is to enable mankind to manage the state of production and life in a more subtle and dynamic way through the application of a new generation of information technologies, by embedding and equipping sensors in various objects of the production and life systems such as power systems, water systems, transportation systems, buildings and oil and gas pipelines in every corner of the world, connecting the Internet of Things to the Internet, integrating human society and physical systems, and then integrating the Internet of Things through supercomputers and cloud computing. Since then, this idea has been embraced around the world, as a point of economic growth in response to the financial tsunami. At the same time, the development of smart cities is considered to contribute to promoting the sustainable development of the city economy, society and the environment, coordinating resources, alleviating the "big city disease" and improving the quality of urbanization. Based on international research and practice on smart cities, the concept of "smart" is interpreted as not only intelligence, i.e. the use of a new generation of information technology, but also the full participation of human intelligence. The two forces driving the emergence of smart cities are a new generation of information technology, represented by the Internet of Things, cloud computing, and mobile networks, and an open city innovation ecosystem that is gradually emerging in the context of a knowledge-based society.

The United Nations (UN) is an international intergovernmental organization composed of sovereign states committed to promoting cooperation in international law, international security, economic development, social progress, human rights, civil liberties, political freedoms, democracy and the achievement of lasting world peace. The United Nations was established in 1945 after the end of World War II, replacing the League of Nations to prevent war and provide a platform for dialogue between nations. The United Nations has established a number of subsidiary bodies to implement its purposes. The United Nations is headquartered in Manhattan, New York City, United States, and is mandated to exercise extraterritorial jurisdiction. Other major offices are located in Geneva, Nairobi and Vienna. As of 2018, the United Nations has 193 member states, including all non-contested sovereign states except Vatican City State. In the century before the United Nations was founded, many international treaty bodies and conferences were established to regulate conflicts between nations, such as the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Hague Conventions of 1899 and 1907. The original and complete idea of creating a new world organization dates back to the United States State Department in 1939. U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt first used the word "" United Nations "" to describe allied nations. On 6 January 1946, the first session of the United Nations General Assembly (51 representatives attended. Prior to the completion of the headquarters, the temporary headquarters on Lake Success on Long Island in New York City began operations, even though the Republic of China, which had represented China in 1971, was forced to withdraw on its own, its status being replaced by the People's Republic of China, and the Soviet Union was dissolved in 1991, its status being replaced by the Russian Federation.

A police officer is a professional who is primarily responsible for enforcing the law, maintaining public safety and protecting property. Police forces are generally divided into two systems: patrol police and criminal police, which are then further subdivided into various ranks and categories of work. The London Police Department is the world's first urban police department to use modern policing to maintain law and order, and the Hong Kong Police Department is the first police department in Asia to use modern policing to maintain law and order. Most countries and regions have separate police and military forces, independent of each other, each with its own professionalism. In France and the People's Republic of China, in addition to the police, members of the army or a separate national gendarmerie are also responsible for handling or coordinating security matters. In a few areas, the police became auxiliary armed units of the army. In countries with no army or no military command, the police are the only armed forces that can be directly deployed by the local government or authority, such as Iceland and Panama. In dictatorships and totalitarian states, the police function as an instrument of the dictator to suppress dissent, and there may be police systems such as secret police and religious police. Military police, also known as gendarmes, are those who are responsible for maintaining military order in military camps and areas, and in countries and territories with gendarmes, gendarmes can maintain military order under military law, prosecute military personnel, and assist military prosecutors in military law cases. Some states and territories also have a national constitutional army, stationed in fortresses, borders, important institutions, armed with heavy weapons of infantry rank, and with law enforcement powers over the population. The term "Chinese police" first appeared about 1900 years ago, in October 1894.

Bûgt hôt / Bûût hôt (Mongolian: ོ ᠠ, pronounced ; Chinese: 中蒙通用转写: Buɡutu xota) is a city in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China. It lies on the western border of Bayannur, on the southern border of Ordos, on the eastern border of Khoikhoi and Khoikhoi, on the northern border of Ulaanbaatar, on the northern border of Mongolia. It is located in the middle of the Inner Mongolian Plateau, in the southern part of the border between Mt. Ura and Mt. Daqing, and belongs to the Yin Mountains. Central high, north-south low: the southern part is urban, is the Yellow River floodplain, the river valley plain; the central part is the Yinshan Mountains; the northernmost area is the Mongolian Plateau low mountain range. The Yellow River flows south of the city limits. The city has a total area of 27,571 square kilometers, a population of 282.93 million, a Han population of about 94%, and a Mongolian population of about 3%. The city government is in Jiulong District. Baotou is an important metallurgical, materials and manufacturing base in the country, and an important industrial city in the North China region, where rare earth production is particularly abundant. About the origin of the name of Baotou, it is commonly believed to be the Mongolian "Baoktu" (Mongolian: ོ), which means "deer", officially adopted; the second is the Mongolian "Boto" (Mongolian: ᠠོᠠ, meaning "Baotou", Mongolian "hero" meaning "hero") Baotou was originally an unknown small settlement near the naturalized city of Murte, about 20 to 40 km from the Baotou nomadic settlement Hadamar (now part of the Aganyotae tree ditch Gachahadmengou and the village of Hadmen in the town of Burhantu), and today the main city of Baotou is entirely a nomadic settlement of the Baotou Front Banner (now Baotou City's Baotou Front Banner Settlement formerly part of Ikshaoyu).

Quzhou, also known as Qu City, is a city in western Zhejiang Province of the People's Republic of China. It is bordered by Hangzhou City in the north, Jinhua City in the east, Lishui City in the southeast, Nanping City in the southeast of Fujian Province, Shangrao City in the west of Jiangxi Province, and Huangshan City in the northwest of Anhui Province. It lies in the western part of the Jinkou Basin, surrounded by mountains in the south, west and north, and has a hilly landscape. It belongs to the southeast to the Senxia Mountains, the northwest to the Baiji Mountains, the north to the Chirigang Mountains, and in the middle to the Qujiang Valley. The ports of Changshan and Jiangshan merge in the city, crossing the Qujiang River to the east. The city has a total area of 8,845 square kilometers, a population of 227.6 million, and the city's people's government is located in Kocheng District. Quzhou is a well-known city of national history and culture, with a history of nearly 1400 years, and is known as "the upper right bank of the Yangtze River, the elbow arm of the Poyang River, the throat of the Min Yue River, the voice of the Tong Xue River", and is a member of the Yangtze River Delta City Group and the West Bank City Group of the Strait. Quzhou has a long history, as early as the Neolithic, people lived here. In spring and autumn, it was a place of contempt for the Republic of Vietnam, and in wartime it belonged to Chu. Twenty-five years ago, the Qin Dynasty destroyed Chu, established Ji County, established Taisu County in Quzhou area, and established Jinlong County. The Han–Qin system, from Han to Jin, Quzhou regions all belong to the Yangzhou Historical Bureau Hui County. Two years later, in 1902, the county was divided into three districts, the first of which was established in Qu County, and the second was established in Xin'an County. Wang was closely associated with the outside party at the time, and thus entered politics. In 1978, Wang was registered as a candidate for the Keelung City State Representative, but resigned after the Chiang Kai-shek government announced the suspension of the election. In 1979, Wang participated in Beautiful Island magazine. In 1980, Wang was arrested and sentenced to six years in prison. In 1984, he was released from prison. After his release from prison, Wang founded Wenjie Magazine and became its editor-in-chief, and became acquainted with Chen Yingwei. In 1987, the Chiang Kai-shek government declared martial law, open party ban, proscription and continental exploration, Wang became the first chairman of the Xia Chao Federation, led a delegation to Beijing; and participated in the founding of the Labour Party. In 1989, the Labour Party split, and Wang left the Labour Party to join the Democratic Progressive Party and ran for Mayor of Keelung on behalf of the Communist Party of China, but was defeated by Lin Shui-ming, who was nominated by the Communist Party of China. Between 1990 and 1992, he was a member of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) and chairman of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC). In 1991, the Central People's Representative was re-elected, and Wang was elected to the National Assembly in Keelung City. In 1993, Wang resigned as a representative of the National Congress, representing the Democratic Party to run for mayor of Keelung, still defeated. In 1995, Wang was elected as a member of the National Non-District Legislative Council of the Communist Party of China. In 1998, Wang was elected to the Legislative Council of Keelung City. In 2001 and 2004, Wang was re-elected, becoming an important member of the Communist Party of China's Legislative Assembly. In 2002, Wang joined the Justice League of the Communist Party of China as an executive committee member. At the end of 2004, Wang joined the New Trends. In 2005, the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) called for Wang Tak to run for mayor of Keelung, and after registering as a candidate, changed his name to Chen Jianming, who supported the Taiwan Solidarity Alliance's nomination, but Chen Jianming was ultimately defeated by the Kuomintang's candidate Xu Zhaili.

The Republic of Cuba (Spanish: República de Cuba), commonly known as Cuba, is an island nation in the northern Caribbean Sea of the Americas, located between 19° and 24° N and 74° and 85° W respectively. Located at the entrance to the Gulf of Mexico, it is separated from the Yucatán Strait to the west, from Jamaica and the Cayman Islands to the south, from the Atlantic Ocean to the east, from the Republic of Haiti and the Dominican Republic to the north, from the Bahamas to the northeast, from the Strait of Florida to the United States, and from the southernmost point of Florida, Key West, by land, at a distance of about 145 kilometers. As the largest island in the Caribbean and the second-largest in population, Cuba guards a major maritime artery between the Panama Canal and the east coast of the United States. It's described as the key to the Gulf of Mexico. The Territory comprises the main island of Cuba and its dependent islands and the Isle of Man. Havana is the capital and largest city of Cuba, and Santiago is the second largest city. In 2011, Castro succeeded his brother Fidel Castro as First Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of Cuba, and began a series of reforms, culminating in the normalization of relations with the United States in 2014. In 2018, Miguel Diaz-Canel became the new Chairman of the Cuban State Council, and the National Assembly of the People's Government passed a constitution, including the establishment of a term of office for leaders and the recognition of private property, which was adopted in a referendum in 2019. Under the new constitution, Cuba will establish the offices of President and Prime Minister, replacing the previous offices of Chairman of the State Council and Chairman of the Council of Ministers.

Kerman is the capital and largest city of the Kerman Governorate of the Islamic Republic of Iran, about 1,076 kilometers southeast of Tehran's capital, with an estimated population of 533,799 in 2005. Kierman is derived from Islamic writings, one between Central Asia and the Bahá'í Faith, whose city still exists today, named Kanimekh, Kierman of Liao Shi-Zong Dynasty; another in southern Persia, Kerman, in the Gulf of Persia, near Kerman. Already in the 3rd century BC, the founder of the Persian Sassanid dynasty, Artaxerxes I, built a defensive fortress in what is now the city of Kerman, named after himself, Behdashir, the prototype of what is now the city of Kerman. After the Battle of Nahavand in 642, Persia was conquered by the Arab Empire, and the city fell to the Muslims. Initially, the city was isolated from the outside world, allowing only the Wahhabis and Zoroastrians to settle, but in 698 the Wahhabis disappeared, and by 725 most of the city's inhabitants were Muslims. In the 8th century, the city was famous for Kashmiri wool scarves and other textiles. After the decline of the Abbasid dynasty in the late 9th and early 20th centuries, the city came under the control of the Tahrir, Safavid, Ottoman, and Byzantine dynasties, and was conquered by the Mahmoud Sultan of Ghazni in the late 10th century. According to some accounts, in the 10th century Behdahir was renamed Kerman.

Lin Hwang-sun (Chinese: 林弘宣; pinyin: Lin Hwang-sun; born 25 September 1942 in Taichung, Taiwan) is a Taiwanese politician who served as a government adviser to President Chen Shui-bian. On September 18, 2015, Lin was found unconscious in his bathroom after falling; he died at 1:38 a.m. on September 25, at the age of 73. In 1978, the United States and the Republic of China broke off relations, and he decided that Taiwan might be sold to the Chiang Kai-shek regime in the midst of the internal and external crisis, resolutely abandoned his studies to return to Taiwan, became a pastor of the Taiwanese Christian Presbyterian Church, and served as an editor of the Taiwan Church Communiqué, targeting members of the Presbyterian Church's minor faction clergy, organized work, and actively participated in the out-of-party movement. In 1979, Hayashi was appointed General Manager of Beauty Island Magazine. After the "Beautiful Island Incident", Lin and Lu Xiu Ren, Shi Ming-de, Huang Shin-suke, Lin Yoshio, Yao Jiao-wen, Chen Qiu, and Zhang Shun-hong jointly claimed that the "eight pirates" were prosecuted for insurrection, Lin's defense lawyers at the time were Zhang Shun-o and Li Katsu-o, and Lin was sentenced to 12 years in prison. In 1986, Lin was released from prison on parole because of lymphatic cancer; after his release, he did not go to politics like other victims of Beautiful Island, but hid in the Hakka village of Nepu village in Pingtung County, sometimes living on the basis of translation books, and spent his days with crude tea and rice. Lin was invited by the chairman of the Communist Party of China, Jiang Peng Keng, to serve as a member of the Communist Party's arbitration committee (not required to be a member of the party) for two years; the leader of the New Trend Party, Qiu Yoshihide, also invited Lin to join the Communist Party, but Lin never joined the Communist Party because of his lack of political intentions. In July 2005, Lin accepted an offer from then-President Chen Shui-bian to serve as a state policy adviser to the President's Office.

Aji (Ryukyu:首里那霸方言:アジ orアンジ; Shinto:先島方言:アズ) was a local administrative unit in the history of the Ryukyu Kingdom, and later became a name for the nobility and local ruling families of the Ryukyu Kingdom. Since the Second Shang Dynasty, only members of the royal family were allowed to take office. The family was a branch of the royal family, comparable to the Imperial Family of Japan, the domains of China, and ranked second only to princes in the aristocracy. The female heir (Oninushi) may also be called Azikanashi (阿ジカナシ orアンジカナシ), while the female heir is called Azikanashi (按司加那志) (阿ジカナシ orアンジカナシ). According to the Chronicle of the Sun Yat-sen, the Ryukyu people were descendants of the Emperor. God sent the goddess Amamikiyo and the male god Shinerikiyo to humanity, bearing three sons and two daughters, as the ancestors of the Ryukyu people. The eldest son is the descendant of the heavens; the second son is the ancestor of the princes; the third son is the ancestor of the people. In fact, in early Ryukyu, there was no concept of a king, and the heads of the various regions called themselves priests, and were sometimes honored with the titles "Lord of the World" and "Lord of the World". According to the Okinawan scholar Ipopuyu, "Aji" is a transliteration of "Lord" (alji) in the Ryukyu language. The first settlers in the area came in the 12th century, and they built several castles and fought against each other. Afterwards, the king unified Ryukyu. However, he was still in power, and participated in the coup d'état in Ryukyu. It was not until the reign of King Shōshin that the Ryukyu court ordered the capture of weapons from all over the country, summoned the chief priests to live in Shuri-jo Castle, and the chief priests were weakened by force. Afterwards, the prince turned from a local ruler to a city nobleman, and sent an official named "Aziutch" to administer his territory.

These volcanoes are usually composed of basalt magma and are highly fluid, so they can be distributed over large areas to form broad mountains. The most famous example is the Hawaiian Islands, each of which is a giant shield volcano. Alta Area, in the Rift Valley of Africa, is also a shield volcano, with a crater with a very rare and long-lived lava lake, like Mount Kilauea in Hawaii. A lava dome, commonly found in volcanic vents or on the sides of volcanoes, is a dome-shaped protrusion that resembles the bulb of some plants.

Sino-Austrian relations (German: Sino-Österreichische Beziehung) refers to the historical bilateral relations between China and Austria, to the present day between the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Austria. Austria's first trade with China began in 1781. In 1869, the Austro-Hungarian Empire and the Qing dynasty concluded a treaty establishing diplomatic relations, which were formally implemented in 1871. During the Eight Nations Campaign of 1900, Austria-Hungary was one of the participating nations. On October 6, 1913, the Austro-Hungarian Empire recognized the Republic of China, and the only Chinese ambassador to the Austro-Hungarian Empire at that time was Shen Ruilin. In 1938, Nazi Germany annexed Austria, and the Republic of China and Austria again broke off diplomatic relations. After World War II, the Republic of China and Austria briefly established diplomatic missions. After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Austrian embassy in Taiwan was closed. Diplomatic relations between the Republic of China and Austria were not interrupted until the establishment of diplomatic relations between the People's Republic of China and Austria on 28 May 1971. In 1964, the People's Republic of China and Austria signed an exchange of letters, the Mutual Commercial Representative Office. On 28 May 1971, the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Austria established diplomatic relations at the ambassadorial level. The two countries began sending ambassadors in September of the same year. Since the establishment of diplomatic relations between the People's Republic of China and Austria, relations between the two countries have shown good momentum, and cooperation in various fields has accelerated. On September 20, 2007, then-Austrian Prime Minister Alfred Gusenbauer met with the Dalai Lama. Austrian exports to China In October 1972, the People's Republic of China and the Republic of Austria signed the Trade and Payment Agreement, which upgraded the bilateral private-sector trade relationship to an intergovernmental one.

In astronomy, interstellar matter (ISM) is matter and radiation in space that exists outside the star system of a galaxy. The forms of these materials include ionized gases, atoms, and molecules, as well as cosmic dust and cosmic rays. They fill the intergalactic space, and they successfully integrate into the surrounding intergalactic space. Energy in the form of electromagnetic radiation occupies an interstellar radiation field of the same volume. Interstellar matter, whether it's atoms, molecules, or ions, has different phases depending on the temperature and density of the material. Interstellar matter consists primarily of hydrogen, followed by helium, and is composed of trace amounts of carbon, oxygen, and nitrogen relative to hydrogen. The thermal pressures of these phases are roughly in equilibrium with each other. Magnetic fields and turbulent motions also provide pressure for interstellar matter, which is usually more important than thermal pressure. By Earth's standards, all phases of interstellar matter are extremely fragile. Cold, dense interstellar matter, the main components of which appear in the form of molecules, has a density of 106 molecules per cubic millimeter (1 million molecules per cubic millimeter). Thermal, diffuse interstellar matter is mainly ionized atoms, with densities as low as 10–4 ions per cubic millimeter. Relative to the Earth's sea level, about 1019 molecules per cubic centimetre, and 1010 molecules per cubic centimetre (10 billion molecules) in the Highly Vacuum Laboratory, are the densities of extreme vacuum. By mass, 99% of interstellar matter is of various types of gas, and only 1% of it is dust particles, known in astronomical terms as metals. By mass, 70 percent is hydrogen, 28 percent is helium, 1.5 percent is heavy elements. In interstellar matter, hydrogen and helium are mainly the result of protonuclear synthesis, while heavy elements are the result of quenching during stellar evolution.

To the east, the Usuri River is bordered by the Russian city of Bikin, to the south by the cities of Torin, Mishan, and Biran, to the west by the cities of Jiamusi and Shitaihe, and to the north by the cities of Fujin, Dongjiang, Fuyuan, and Biran. The city is located at the foot of Mount Wanda, on the banks of the River Ambon. It is divided into four districts: Shuxian, Baoqing, Friendship, Raohe, and Senshan, Lingdong, Shifangtai and Baoshan. It has 12 state farms, 40 state forests. It has a total area of 22,483 square kilometers, of which the urban area is 1,767 square kilometers, and the population is 1.5 million. Of these, 1,192 square kilometers (67,45%) were covered by mangrove forests; 4 square kilometers (0.23%) by water; 291 square kilometers (16.47%) by arable land; 66 square kilometers (3.74%) by construction land; and 214 square kilometers (12.11%) by other land. About 50 kinds of minerals have been found in Shuangqiao City, accounting for 37% of 135 kinds of minerals found in the province. Of these, 12 kinds of resource reserves have been identified, including coal, iron ore, tungsten ore, peat, graphite, etc. Dushanbe is rich in forest resources, has a forest cover of 40 percent, is a national forest city. The total area of forest in the city is 154.6 million hectares, of which 110.6 million hectares are forested, and the total forested area is 1004.97 million cubic meters. Dushanbe is rich in wetlands, and the total area of the city's wetlands is 21.52 million hectares, 9.5% of the total land area, and it's a typical inland wetlands. It has 47.98 million hectares of natural wetlands. The municipality is divided into four districts and four counties.

The Small Solar System Body (SSSB) is a new category of objects created by the International Astronomical Union (IAU) in 2006 when it reinterpreted planets and dwarf planets in the Solar System. All other objects orbiting the Sun would fall into this category: Solar System minor planets..., which currently includes most of the planets in the Solar System, most of the extrasolar planets (TNOs), comets, and other small objects. This includes: It is unclear whether there is a minimum threshold for small objects in the Solar System, whether they are small enough to include meteorites; the upper limit is unclear, but it is certain that planets do not fall into this category. The moons have different orbits, but not around the Sun, but around planets and other objects in the Solar System, such as dwarf planets. Some of the larger Solar System minor planets may be reclassified as dwarf planets, requiring further confirmation as to whether they are in fluid static equilibrium. Most of the asteroids in the Solar System are distributed in two distinct regions, the asteroid belt and the Kuiper belt. However, the boundaries of these regions are still obscure, and there may be smaller internal structures caused by perturbations from the equatorial planets of Jupiter and Neptune. There are also small objects scattered throughout the rest of the Solar System, such as near-Earth asteroids, semi-major planets, and comets. It is necessary to pay attention to the eccentricity and semi-major axis of these objects' orbits in order to know where they come from outside the main regions of the Solar System. An object less than 50 meters in diameter in a near-Earth object (NEO) is called a meteor, so a meteor is just a piece of debris scattered in space.

Li believed that the relationship between the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China had long been "state-to-state", or "at least a special state-to-state relationship", rather than "a legitimate government, a rebel group", or "a central government, a local government", so there was no need to declare independence. In April 1993, the Sea Foundation held its first meeting with the Association for Relations between the Two Sides of the Strait. However, in 1995, after Lee Teng-hui visited the United States as President of the Republic of China, the definition of "one China" was tightened, and relations between the two sides fell into low tide, triggering the Taiwan Strait Missile Crisis. In March 1996, the first direct presidential elections were held in the Republic of China, and Lee Teng-hui was re-elected. Hong Kong's sovereignty was transferred to the People's Republic of China on 1 July 1997, and Macao's sovereignty was transferred to the People's Republic of China on 20 December 1999. In response to the growing pressure on Taiwan from the one-state-two propaganda of the People's Republic of China, the U.S. has repeatedly argued that the two sides should sign a mediation agreement, so Lee has instructed the establishment of a "Strengthening the Sovereignty of the Republic of China Project Group" to study countermeasures. In May 1999, the group discussed the positioning of the two sides in terms of "special state and state relations". In August 1998, the "Strengthening the Sovereignty of the Republic of China" Group was formed, bringing together several young legal and political scholars to participate in the study. The main direction of the research was "How to delink the sovereignty of the Republic of China with a Chinese one", and the research report was completed in May 1999. The report, in its preamble, discusses the constitutional foundations of the Republic of China as a sovereign state, and proposes a step-by-step plan for the preservation of Taiwanese sovereignty, including constitutional amendments, amendments to laws, and the abolition of statehood.

Chinese history books, including the Three Kingdoms, Wu Zhi, Sui Shu, and Ryukyuan, and the Commentaries on Chinese Literature, all contained descriptions of Taiwan. For example, the Sui Dynasty's Sui Sui Chuan (流求傳) states: "Sui Chuan is in the sea, when Jian'an County is east, the water runs for five days. According to historical records, the Penghu Islands were under the control of the Yuan Dynasty, and the mainland of Taiwan was included in the map of the Qing Dynasty during the Qing Dynasty. Since the Muromachi period, the Japanese began to call Taiwan Takasago, Takasagokuni, Takayamakuni. In 1593, Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI sent an envoy to pay tribute to Takayama Province, but the envoy was unable to find a person who could deliver the document to Takayama Province and returned unsuccessfully. In 1609, Ieyasu TOKUGAWA appointed Harunobu ARIMA as Toban no gon. In 1616, Ieyasu Tokugawa appointed Tsutomu MURAYAMA, Nagasaki's deputy governor, to conquer Taiwan, and Tsutomu and Akian MURAYAMA, Tsutomu's second daughter, led the expedition of 2,300 men, which was the largest in scale, but was unsuccessful due to a windstorm. In 1641, with the completion of the seclusion system, exchanges gradually diminished. In 1895, the Qing Dynasty was defeated in the Sino-Japanese War, and Taiwan was ceded to Japan. In 1684, the Qing dynasty established Taiwan Road, Taiwan Prefecture and other administrative divisions or local governments in Taiwan. Due to the isolationist policies of the Qing Dynasty, Taiwan's frequent trade with foreign countries such as Japan, France, and the United Kingdom was interrupted, and at this stage all of Taiwan's trade came from its provinces. In the middle of the nineteenth century, China's declining power, its policy of isolation, was challenged by the Western powers. After several defeats, China signed multilateral trade treaties.

The Yangtze River, anciently known as the Jiangsui or the Dajiang River, is Asia's first and the world's third longest river, and also the world's longest river entirely within a single country. It is 6,300 kilometers long, and its dry flow originates in the eastern Qinghai-Tibet Plateau, the Tanggula Mountains and the Ladan winter peaks, crosses southwest China (Qinghai, Tibet, Yunnan, Sichuan, Chongqing), central China ( Hubei, Hunan, Jiangxi), eastern China (Anhui, Jiangsu), and flows into the East China Sea in Shanghai. The Yangtze River basin covers one-fifth of China's land area, feeding one-third of its population. The Yangtze River Economic Zone is also one of the largest economic zones in China. The Yangtze River and the Yellow River, as the mother rivers of Chinese culture, gave birth to the Yangtze and Yellow River civilizations. The Yangtze River basin is rich in ecological diversity and aquatic life, and it's home to endangered species like the crocodile and the sturgeon. For thousands of years, people have used the Yangtze River for water, irrigation, sewage, transportation, industrial development, as a boundary. Since the industrialization of the People's Republic of China, the Yangtze River has been threatened by industrial pollution, agricultural runoff, river sedimentation, and reduced wetlands and lakes, leading to increased seasonal flooding. Some parts of the Yangtze River have been designated as protected areas. The Yunnan Sanjiang Confluence Protected Area is listed as a UNESCO World Natural Heritage Site because of its rich natural and cultural resources. The word "river" is often used to refer to the Yangtze River. With regard to the origin of the Chinese character "Jiang", Rogery and Mazorin proposed in 1976 that the ancient Chinese fifth syllable of "Jiang" is similar to the "river" of some South Asian languages. Each section of the Yangtze River from its source to Yibin has an independent name.

The Johan Cruijff Arena (Dutch pronunciation: ), formerly known as the Amsterdam Arena (Dutch pronunciation: ), is a football stadium in Amsterdam, Netherlands. Construction of the stadium began in 1993, costing €1.4 million, and was designed with an open-topped roof. The stadium was opened on August 14, 1996, and can be used for football, American football and concerts. The stadium holds 51,628 seats for matches and 68,000 seats for concerts. The stadium has been the home of the traditional Dutch team Ajax since 1996, and was one of the venues for the 2000 European Cup. Many artists from the Netherlands and other countries perform at the stadium. Amsterdam was one of six cities to bid for the 1992 Summer Olympics. Therefore, in 1986, the government made plans to build a new stadium with a capacity of 55,000 people, including new grasslands and runways. In the end, however, Amsterdam was unable to secure bids, and plans for a new stadium were put on hold. In 1990, the government reintroduced the concept of a new stadium. At the same time, Ajax hoped to acquire a new stadium, as the old stadium was no longer meeting the needs of the fans. Another stadium design was also developed at this time, which had no runway, became a dedicated football pitch, and reduced capacity to 50,000. In 1993, the government of Amsterdam authorized the start of the project. The stadium was opened in 1994 and completed in 1996.
