It is necessary to discuss the meaning of "enthronement" in the book of Spring and Autumn, and the following characteristics can be derived from the preliminary analysis. First, the Eight Enthronements of Spring and Autumn are recorded seven times in the Spring and Autumn Equinox, the first spring of the new reign of Lu. The exception is the Spring and Autumn Chronicle: "Summer, June, July, the death of the Duke (of the previous year's death, Duke Lu Zhao) until the end of the reign of Emperor Qianhu. Pentecost, the emperor ascends the throne. The jubilee of the accession of Louis was a special occasion. It can be seen that there is a close relationship between the Enthronement and the Neolithic, that the beginning of the Neolithic and the Enthronement coincide in time. Secondly, there are the Four Kings of Lu, who are absent from the Book of Spring and Autumn, and the year of Spring and Autumn is the year of their accession to the throne. For example, the enthronement of Ruin was not recorded, but the Spring and Autumn Chronicle was chronicled in the form of "a certain year of Ruin" during his reign. Thirdly, the "enthronement" time of the new emperor recorded in Spring and Autumn is not the time when the new emperor is established or when the new emperor actually begins to reign. The old man died, the new man was confirmed, and he was actually in power. However, the next year, the first January of the new millennium, he was "appointed" to the throne.

The Battle of Andong (Chinese: 安东会战; pinyin: 安东会战; October 1946 – November 1946) was a battle fought by the Northeastern Front against the Liaodong Liberation Zone of the People's Republic of China. In late August 1946, the National Army launched the He River Offensive, the thirteenth army successively captured Chengdu (August 29), Longhua (August 31), Siegefield (October 8), Red Peak (October 11), Doren (October 12), and Fu Shaoyi's forces struck Jincha Hebei District capital Zhangjiakou, achieving strategic coordination. The thirteenth army even advanced to the Red City, Chongli, and the Fu Shaoyi Division meeting with Zhang Jiakou. The party's military units retreated to the base of Taihangshan Lao; the party's military units in Hebei Province retreated to Linxi. The army of the Northeast and the army of the North China were completely united. According to Chiang Kai-shek's orders, "The bandits who repeatedly commit crimes against the eastern side of the Yangtze River should be crushed by concentrating the main force, and as far as possible, they should be suppressed and annihilated," the commander-in-chief of the Northeast Security Command, I. M. Du, formulated the strategy of the Army of the People's Republic of China in the northeast, "first south, then north, then south, then north." After a four-month demobilization and disarmament, the Northeast Army began its offensive against South Manchuria in early October 1946 with the deployment of heavy troops. Du's strategic plan consisted of three steps: the first step was the New Sixth Army and the 52nd Army in southern Liaoning, taking advantage of the weakness of the Communist army in front of them, and rapidly taking the city of Andong. Then the whole vast area of southern Liaoning was adjacent to the garrison of the brigade of the Soviet Union, the east to the coast of the Yellow Sea did not need military defence, the duck-green river and the confrontation with North Korea, could greatly save military forces; in the second step, with the forces of the new sixth army, the 52nd army, the Youth Army 207th division together with the forces of three armies occupied Jian and Linjiang, thoroughly eliminated the communists in Nanchang; finally, the new army of Changchun, the 60th army of Yongji, the 71st army of Shiping, and other units to withdraw troops, with the forces of five armies from Jilin City to bypass right hook and bypass to capture Harbin.

This is a topical homepage for wiki users interested in computer science and information technology. We hope to help make it easier for people to find articles that are related to computers and also to find places that can help Wikipedia improve in this area. Information technology (IT) is a general term used to describe the various technologies used to manage and process information. It mainly uses computer science and communications technology to design, develop, install and implement information systems and application software. It's also often called information and communications technology (ICT). OpenBSD is a Unix-like operating system derived from BSD, which was spun off from NetBSD in 1995 by project founder Theo de Raadt. OpenBSD is known for its commitment to open source, high-quality files, robust software licenses, and a focus on system security and code quality. OpenBSD uses dolphins as project mascots. OpenBSD contains some security features that are lacking or listed as optional on other operating systems, as well as a strong emphasis on code review, a tradition maintained by developers to this day. Floppy disks are the earliest and most portable media storage devices for personal computers. The first floppy disk was developed by IBM in 1971, 8 inches in diameter. With the development and use of hardware technology, a 5.25-inch floppy disk was developed, which was widely used in the Apple II, IBM PC, and compatible computers.

The city is divided into two districts, six counties, and one county-level city. In addition to the official administrative divisions, Changde City also established the following economic management zones: the Changde National Economic and Technological Development Zone, the West Dongting Management Zone, the West Lake Management Zone (all of which were established at the county level by the reform of state-run farms), and the Liuye Lake Tourism and Holiday Zone. Preliminary results of the Sixth Population Census in 2010 showed that Changde had a permanent population of 5,717,218, ranking fourth in Hunan Province with an 8.70% population density of 314 people per square kilometer, and a male-female sex ratio of 101.66 to 100. In terms of educational attainment, college-level and above make up 6.27 percent of the population, junior high-level and above make up 62.80 percent of the population, and the illiteracy rate is just 3.20 percent. The district has 1,701,408 family households, the family household population is 5,358,077 people, accounting for 93.72% of the total population; the average family size is 3.15 people. In terms of age composition, the population aged 14 and under was 756,743, representing 13.24% of the total population; the population aged 15-64 was 4,306,767, representing 75.33%; and the population aged 65 and over was 653,708, representing 11.43% of the total population. Changde is the second largest settlement of Uyghurs in China, as well as the Hunan Hui settlement. The majority of the population is ethnic Han, the minorities are largely dispersed and small settlements, the seated minorities are Tujia, Hui and Uyghurs. According to the fifth census in 2000, Changde had a total Han population of 5,740,875, accounting for 91.98% of the district's population; 460,499 ethnic minorities, accounting for 7.18 percent of the province's ethnic minorities, ranked fifth; 8,02 percent of the district's population; and 47 ethnic distributions among China's 55 ethnic minorities.

Some thirty volumes of the play have been handed down to this day, all of them beloved by the Tuen Mun people: Xue, Yang, Yue, Di, Sankoku, and Wagangzhai. It's a single story, the story of the conquest of King Gordian the Great, the story of the absence of the genius, the story of the pursuit of justice, the story of the green forest rebellion, the myth of the fairy tale, the story of the praise of loyalty, the story of the loyalty of the patriots. It's reflective from the dawn of time to the end of the week, to the dawn of tomorrow. It is distributed in Pingba, Puding, Zhenning, Guanling, Ziyun, Zhejiang Development Zone, and neighboring Qingcheng, Huaxi, Changshun, etc., centered on Xixiu District, Anshun City, Guizhou Province. Of the 300 theatres in the district, more than 190 are located in the West Theater District alone. Like many local plays, it has been struck by the multifaceted impact of contemporary economics and culture, and has gradually shrunk. On May 20, 2006, the Anshun Ji Theatre was included in the list of the first national intangible cultural heritage with the approval of the State Council of the People's Republic of China. In Zhang Yimou's 2005 film A Thousand Miles on a Bike, it tells the story of a Japanese father, Takada Gokaichi (played by Japanese actor Takakura Ken), who travels to Lijiang, Yunnan, China, to shoot a masked drama (subtitled "Yunnan Masked Drama"). On the morning of May 11, 2010, the "Anshun Ji Theater Case" was heard in the Beijing City West District Court. During the trial, witnesses for the Anshun Cultural Bureau alleged that, during the filming of "A Thousand Miles on a Unicycle," the actors of Anshun's Jianjiatun were invited to Lijiang, performing "Battle of Tongguan" and "A Thousand Miles on a Unicycle" from the traditional drama "Anshun Jiao" and were clipped into the film. But the Yunnan Masked Circus promoted by the film is actually the Anshun Jiao Circus, and the Anshun Jiao Circus was listed as a national intangible cultural heritage in 2006.

Zhang Shenghe (Chinese: 張盛和; born September 1, 1949) is a Taiwanese politician who graduated from Tainan Elementary School, Department of Commerce, National Taiwan University, National Political University, Institute of Finance and Taxation, and Institute of Economics, Iowa University. He also served as a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, and was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, where he was also a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, and the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, and the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, where he was a member of the Board of Trustees of the University of California, Berkeley, Berkeley, and the Board of Trust He was the Minister of Finance of the Republic of China. In June 2008, the then-Deputy Minister of Finance, Zhang Sheng, said in an interview with the Legislative Yuan: "Before the tax purse was abolished, every director of the State Tax Bureau could receive one million yuan, and now it's about 700,000 yuan." In November 2012, the Legislative Assembly proposed the removal of the Ministry of Finance's tax allowance of about 100 million yuan, which the then Minister of Finance Zhang Sheng and strongly opposed, on the grounds that "the treatment is not good enough to maintain a decent standard of living", while the former Minister of Finance Wang Jianhui was the only one to donate all of his tax allowance of tens of millions of yuan at the time of his resignation, allotted to the Ministry of Finance officials, and did not receive a receipt. In December 2013, Mr. Zhang said that the price of the house had risen to a record high, and that if young people wanted to buy a house, they could buy it if they didn't want to buy it. In 2014, Chong was voted one of the 10 worst people on the Internet, saying, "I've done so many financially sound programs, 101 franchises, won the Silver Jubilee election, it's all good, which one of the hardships is bad for society?" In 2015, he was named by The Banker as the "Best Finance Minister in the World and Asia-Pacific", the second Finance Minister in Taiwan after Peng Huainan, and the first Finance Minister in Taiwan.

During the reign of Emperor Qin, it belonged to the areas of Jolu County, Handan County, Hengshan County, Qi County, Jibei County, Kamiya County, Dae County, Yuyang County, and Ubeiping County. During the two Han dynasties, Yuzhou and Jizhou were established in Hebei, and Cao Wei and Cao Cao Cao built the "Copper Canopy" on the banks of the Zhang River, and ordered his son Cao to plant the famous poem "Copper Canopy Fu". During the Jin dynasty, it belonged to Hezhou, and was successively ruled by the Later Zhao, the Former Yan, the Former Qin, the Later Qin, the Western Yan, the Northern Yan, the Southern Yan, the Northern Wei, the Eastern Wei, the Northern Qi, and the Northern Zhou. During the Sui Dynasty, he was a provincial governor of Hebei Province, and was responsible for the construction of the Yongji Canal, the Nanda River, and the northern Tongzhu County. During the Jin Dynasty, it belonged to Hebei East Road and Hebei West Road, and Central Capital Road, and became the capital of Gyeonggi Province. Hebei was a centrally administered central province in Yuan Dynasty. It is the northernmost municipality in the state, and is under the direct control of the central government. At the beginning of the Ming Dynasty, large numbers of immigrants from Shanxi and Shandong were introduced, and cotton cultivation was widely promoted. Late in the morning, Xu Guangqiang began transplanting rice from the south to the coast of Hebei, beginning the history of rice cultivation in northern China. It is named after the provincial capital. Since the eighth year of Yongzheng, the direct subordinate governor in Baoding Prefecture (now Baoding City), there is a direct subordinate governor's office at that time, the office is the only provincial office in China, has a very high cultural relics preservation research value. In the late Qing Dynasty, Tangshan built China's first railway, the first modern coal mine. Beijing Zhang Railway is the railway from Beijing to Zhangjiakou, is the first railway that the Chinese themselves designed and built, chief engineer Zhang Tianyu many inventions have been adopted by railways around the world. It was renamed Hebei Province in 1928. Hebei was divided into three provinces: Hebei Province, Hebei Province, and Hebei Province.

Traveling through the Bahamas requires a passport. Bahamian citizens holding a Bahamian passport can enter the Republic of China with an electronic visa for up to 30 days and not be delayed for international conferences, sporting events, and trade fairs. On 30 September 1992, the Bahamas granted visa-free entry to citizens of the Republic of China for 60 days. The main items of trade between the two countries in 2020 are as follows: The main items of exports to the Bahamas are as follows: Passenger cars and other motor vehicles principally designed for passenger carriage, freight carriage; Telephones and other apparatus for transmitting or receiving sound, images or other data; Refrigerators, freezers and other refrigerating or freezing equipment; Parts and accessories used in motor vehicles; Goods and equipment for sports or outdoor games, swimming pools and mini-swimming pools; Exports of small bills of exchange of not more than NT$50,000 and other trifle goods, unlisted prepared glue and other prepared adhesives; Radiographs, spectrometers and other instruments and apparatus for measuring or checking electricity, instruments and apparatus for measuring or detecting X-rays, alpha, beta, gamma, cosmic or other ionizing radiation; Sugars, syrup, artificial honey and sugar cane; Separate reagents or preparation reagents for diagnosis or experimentation, aluminium tubes, other plastic products and The main items imported from the Bahamas are as follows: iron waste, remeltable waste steel cast iron tablets; aluminum waste; automatic data processing machines and their associated units, magnetic or optical readers; books, pamphlets, leaflets and similar printed matter; electric motors and generators; imports of small bills of lading and other trivial items, box-and-bag containers, and other vulcanized rubber products other than hard rubber.

After the death of ancient East Asian monarchs, princes, ministers, empresses, dignitaries, monks, etc., the government lived according to their merits and cultivated their virtues. This custom is found in China, Korea, Vietnam, and Japan, but there are exceptions: for example, during the Spring and Autumn War, the monarchs of the Wu, Yue, and Qin dynasties did not use the  symbol. According to an archaeological study of the Bronze Age inscriptions of the Western Zhou Dynasty, this custom was popular around the time of King Zhou Mu. It is commonly used to honor ancient emperors, ministers, scholars, and nobles; some famous names, such as Zhugewu (諸葛武侯), Hanwu (韓文公), Zeng Wenzheng (曾文正), and Zeng Wu Mu (岳武穆), are almost synonymous. The emperor's throne is usually proclaimed by a decree of the royal court, followed by the approval of the emperor who succeeds to the throne, and the throne of his subjects is granted by the imperial court. In later times, the power of the emperor was encumbered, determined by the "sanctification". ,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,  According to Liu Kei-six, a renowned Chinese genealogist, "" is a colloquial praise for ordinary Buddhist practices, and "" is a praise for government institutions. According to the interpretation of the origins of the system of oppression in the Yi Zhou Book of Laws, it was established by the Emperor Zhou and Emperor Taigong in the middle of the Zhou Dynasty in order to accurately reflect the events of the deceased's life and achievements after the unification of the six kingdoms of the Qin Dynasty, because the seizure of the "Zhou" would form a situation of "child, father, and subject," so the law was abolished. It is believed to have been reintroduced at the end of the Han dynasty, at the end of the Qing dynasty. In later times, due to variations in the application of some of the characters, there were inherently other interpretations of some of the scriptures, such as that of Su-yeung of Song Dynasty, which partly explained the standards of the Song Dynasty.

On 31 August, General Castellano flew to the city of Termeni Imerese in Sicily, and then to the town of Cassibile in Syracuse, where the negotiations began to diverge, and Castellano requested that the Allies defend themselves, as Italy might be retaliated by the Germans after the signing, but received only vague promises, including the dispatch of an airborne division to land in Rome, and that these actions would take place simultaneously with the signing of the Armistice Agreement, rather than, as Italy had intended, before it was signed. The next day, after Castellano returned to Italy, he was greeted by Badoglio and his companions, with Foreign Minister Raffaele Guariglia stating that the terms of the alliance were acceptable, while the other generals had reservations, as the army near Rome lacked fuel and equipment, and the truce was to be delayed. A confirmation telegram was sent to the Allies, but the contents of the telegram were intercepted by the Germans, the Germans suspected that their closest ally, Italy, was seeking a ceasefire on its own, the Germans implicated Badoglio, who reaffirmed Italy's loyalty to the alliance with Germany, his reassurances could not be trusted by the Germans, so the Wehrmacht formulated a plan (Axis Action), in case the Italian government really turned against the Allies, the Germans immediately occupied Italy southwards. On 2 September, Castellano, having received the conditions for accepting the Allies, set off for Cassibilee, without a written authorization from the head of government, Bardoglio, who hoped to rescue his country from the brink of defeat.

The formation and evolution of the Solar System began 4.6 billion years ago with the gravitational collapse of a tiny chunk of a giant molecular cloud. Most of the collapsed mass concentrated in the center, forming the Sun, the rest flattened and formed a protoplanetary disk, followed by planets, satellites, meteors, and other small solar system bodies. This is a widely accepted model of the nebula hypothesis, first proposed in the 18th century by Emanuel Swedenborg, Emanuel Kant, and Pierre Simon, Marquis of Lapland. Its subsequent development was intertwined with many other scientific fields, including astronomy, physics, geology, and planetary science. Since the advent of the space age in the 1950s, and the discovery of extrasolar planets in the 1990s, this model has been challenged and refined in the process of explaining new discoveries. Since its formation, the Solar System has undergone considerable change. Many moons are formed from a disk of gas and dust surrounding their parent stars, while others are believed to have been captured, or from massive collisions (e.g., Earth's moon). Interstellar collisions continue to occur today, and are at the center of the evolution of the Solar System. The positions of the planets are constantly shifting, and some of the planets are already aligned with each other. Thought about the origin and fate of the world can be traced back to the earliest known writings; however, for most of that time no one attempted to link such a theory to the existence of the Solar System, for the simple reason that people at the time generally did not believe that the Solar System as we now know it existed. The first step toward the theory of evolutionary formation of the Solar System was the widespread acceptance of the Sun's center, which puts the Sun at the center of the system, putting the Earth in orbit around it.

Ge Tan (Chinese: 葛覃; pinyin: Gǔ Tǎn; 1899–1958) was a Chinese politician who served as a deputy to the Central Committee of the Kuomintang, head of the Qingdao City Party Department of the Kuomintang, a member of the Legislative Council of the Kuomintang, and a member of the Constituent Assembly of the People's Republic of China. In 1899, he was born in Donghuaxiang Southwest Village, Laiyang County, Dezhou Prefecture, Shandong Province (now Donghuaxiang Southwest Village, Laixi City, Qingdao City, Shandong Province). In 1913, he graduated from Luxi County Secondary School, entered Jinan Provincial First Middle School, and joined the Nationalist Party of China. Enrolled at Peking University in 1919, he was arrested and detained for 80 days for his participation in the May Fourth Movement. After graduation, he served as a member of the Shandong Provincial Party Committee and Minister of Organization of the Kuomintang. In 1926, he was involved in the formation of the Laiyang County Provisional Party Department, and in 1930 he went to the University of Edinburgh to study economics. In 1935, he was recalled to Nantong, where he was appointed as a commissioner and security commander of Jiangsu's 7th District Administrative Inspectorate. In March 1938, due to the occupation of Nantong and Tiansheng Port by the Japanese army, he was dismissed from his post and ordered to investigate, at the end of April, organized a failed counter-attack on Nantong City, then recaptured Tiansheng Port, the order was revoked, on October 4, 1945, he went to Qingdao, served as a director of the Qingdao Party Department of the Kuomintang, vice mayor of Qingdao City, social secretary of Qingdao City, on the eve of the liberation army takeover of Qingdao in June 1949, he went to Shanghai. After the Liberation Army occupied Shanghai, he and dozens of other members of the Legislative Council who remained in Shanghai issued the "Declaration of the Former KMT Legislative Council Members Separated from the Kuomintang Resistance". In 1950, he was arrested by the Hong Kong Governor's Office for his anti-Chiang Kai-shek statements and was released on bail for $10,000. He lived in Japan, died in 1958.

Southern Europe is bordered by the Mediterranean, where summers are dry and winters are rainy, where subtropical highs dominate in summer, and we have a westerly wind in winter. And the Arctic coastal region has a tundra climate. Two or three hundred years of archaeological excavations have confirmed that there was human activity in Europe, including Britain, during the Paleolithic. From 4000 B.C. to the 26th century B.C., the Celts in Western Europe developed a megalithic culture, and there are now European megalithic monuments. The Aegean Sea in the eastern Mediterranean is considered the birthplace of European civilization. Around 2000 BC, the ancestors of the ancient Greeks settled on the Aegean island of Crete, which also became the birthplace of ancient Greek civilization, and gradually developed a city-state culture. In the 5th century BC, after the Peloponnesian War, the ancient Greek mainland gradually declined, but its cultural influence continued to expand, and in the 3rd century BC, Alexander the Great conquered Egypt and Persia, established a great empire across Eurasia and Africa, spreading Greek culture to Asia and Africa. In 27 B.C., ancient Rome arose, formed the Roman Empire, became a great empire that ruled Europe, Western Asia and North Africa, and the Mediterranean became its inland sea. The Apennine Peninsula was the political and economic center of Europe at the time. After the 1st century, Christianity began to spread in Rome. In 313, Christianity was declared a Roman state, gaining dominance in Europe. In the late 3rd century, the Roman Empire gradually weakened. In 376, when the Huns defeated the Eastern Goths, the Goths were forced to cross the Danube into the Western Roman Empire. In 395, it was divided into two empires, East and West.

Wang Zhigang (Chinese: 王志剛; born 7 September 1942) is a Taiwanese politician. He graduated from the Department of Agricultural Economics, Taiwan University, and received a Ph.D. in Business Administration from the Texas Institute of Agriculture and Technology. After returning to Taiwan, he taught at the University of Taiwan, the Political University, and was the head of the Department of International Trade at the University of Taiwan. During his tenure, prominent entrepreneurs such as Guo Taiming, Yin Yanliang, Yin Kaitai, and Lin Xinyi were his students, and Taiwan University was the first university in history to have a full-time lecture in the Law School auditorium, with no seats on the floors or on the floors, and students crowded around the doors of the classrooms to listen to his lectures. In 1984, as a scholar, he was invited to serve as the executive secretary of the Investment Advisory Committee of the Ministry of Economy, cooperating with the government in implementing the policy of great openness to the outside world, actively attracting foreign investment, overseas investment and technical cooperation projects. In 1989, he was appointed Director of the Commercial Department, promoted commercial automation, promoted commercial upgrading; promoted the liberalization of commercial regulations, provided a convenient business environment, and achieved outstanding service to the public.In 1990, the Executive Council held an evaluation of service to the public of about 2,000 administrative agencies under its jurisdiction, the Commercial Department was rated as the first, by the then President Lee Hwan personally awarded the prize. In 1990, he was appointed Deputy Director General of the Ministry of Economy, which promoted Taiwanese business to invest in the continent, supplemented the registration system, and laid the foundation for bilateral trade and investment activities. From November 12 to 14, 1991, the Minister of Economy Xiao Wancheng led a delegation to Hancheng, South Korea to participate in the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) ministerial meeting, which was Taiwan's first participation in APEC, Vice President Wang Zhigang accompanied as a speaker, witnessed our country under the name of Chinese Taipei, and China and Hong Kong became official members of APEC at the same time.

The Salt City (Chinese: 盐市; pinyin: Zhānfu; ancient Chinese: 盐渎; pinyin: Zhānfu) is a city in Jiangsu Province of the People's Republic of China, located along the coast of central and eastern Jiangsu Province. The coastline is 582 kilometers long, 61% of the total length of the coastline of the province. It's bordered by Nantong City to the south, Taizhou City to the west, Yangzhou City to the west, Huai'an City to the northwest, Yungang City to the northwest, and the Yellow Sea to the east. It is located in the northern part of the Yangtze River Delta, the northern part of the Subei irrigation canal is the Huang Huai Plain, the southern part is divided into two parts — the Kushan River in the west is the Lishui River Plain, in the east is the coastal plain, the terrain is flat, the canals are horizontal. Irrigation networks such as irrigation canals, waste Yellow River, Subei irrigation canals, Jiayang River, Xinyang Port, Tongyu Canal, Kushan River and others run through the city. With a total area of 16.931 square kilometers, it is the largest city in Jiangsu Province, with an area of 824.7 million inhabitants. With its long coastline and extensive coastal wetlands and beaches, Salt City is an ideal bird sanctuary, and the Yellow Sea bird sanctuary is a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The area where Salt City was located was formerly Huaiyi territory; Kyushu was divided into Qingzhou at the time, Wu at the time of Spring and Autumn, and Yue at the time of Later. The warring states belonged to Chu. It belonged to the Eastern Kai County in the Qin Dynasty; the western Han Dynasty was initially the territory of the Sun Yat-sen Marquis Liu Wanfeng. In the Western Han Dynasty, Salt City was still a seaport on the coastline, and was named for its major industry, which was the smelting of seawater for salt. In the fourth year of Emperor Hanwu's reign (119 BC), the county was established, which was the beginning of the establishment of the county of Salt City, and Sun Jian was appointed as the secretary of the county of Salt City. The three provinces belonged to the Wei, abolished the county system; the West Jin again re-established the county system; the East Jin Yixi seven years (411) renamed Salt City, this is the beginning of the present name; the Northern and Southern Dynasties called Salt City County; the Sui Dynasty was still a county, belonged to Jiangdu County; at the end of the Sui Dynasty, Weiche, according to Salt King, was divided into two counties, Xin'an and An'le, the Tang Dynasty re-established Salt City County; the Song Dynasty belonged to Chu Prefecture.

The Battle of Handan (also known as the Battle of Pinghan) was fought between October and November 1945, when the Chinese National Army surrendered to the Japanese along Pinghan Road, south of Handan, Hebei Province, in a clash with the forces of the 8th Army of the Jinhe-Luyuan Military District, and the 8th Army called it "the self-defense counterattack against the National Revolutionary Army". In September 1945, the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) accepted the surrender of the Japanese army and dispatched troops to the Communist Party of China (CPC) liberated areas, but the Eighth Route Army did not allow the NRA to enter the liberated areas, believing that this was an invasion of them; at the same time, the Eighth Route Army actively accepted the surrender of the Japanese army to expand the liberated areas. On the Shanxi side, the Eighth Route Army launched a counterattack to prevent the surrender of the National Army. On 10 October, the two sides signed the Bi-Ten Agreement in Chongqing, but the substantive issues remained unresolved. The battle was nearing its end, but by the time it was fully over, most of the main army of the 8th Route was in southeastern Jin, and it was difficult to reach Handan at once. Liu Beisheng and Deng Xiaoping, during the Battle of Shanghai, deliberately left the Jilu Yu column, which had been stationed near Handan, to monitor the northern section of the Pyongyang Railway, and took on the task of blockading it. On October 10, Liu Beisheng and Deng Xiaoping sent a telegram: "He Lu Yu and He Nan should relax the secondary direction, pull out the army used in the decisive direction of the Pyongyang Line, no worries, dispersed troops, everywhere powerless. In mid-October, the First Ladder of the 30th Army, 40th Army and the newly formed 8th Army, composed of seven divisions and 40,000 men under the command of General Sun Lianzhong, the commander of the 11th Army, started from Xinxiang and moved northeast along the Pinghan Line under the command of Deputy Commander of the 11th Army, General Takashi Kōshū; the 32nd Army and the newly formed 4th Route Army, commanded by General Sun Daebu, continued to follow the First Ladder as the Second Ladder.

At the age of 24, he enrolled at Beiping Chinese University, where he taught political science, English and American law, as well as German and French, and The New York Times described him as "a living encyclopedia". In 1911, the Guangdong Provincial Assembly held a banquet in Hongkou Hongyuan Garden in Shanghai for Sun Yat-sen's upcoming visit to Beijing as the Provisional President, Wang Yun-fi's speech on behalf of the Assembly was praised by Sun Yat-sen, and in 1912 he was appointed Secretary of the Office of the Provisional President of Sun Yat-sen, and joined the Kuomintang. In 1921, on the recommendation of Hu Shi, Wang Yun-fi was appointed Director of the Compilation Department of the Commercial Printing House and later General Manager. During Wang's tenure, he published a variety of dictionaries, encyclopedias, and collections, with the aim of promoting education and academic independence, and was instrumental in the spread of knowledge in China. Wang also studied the invention of the square number retrieval method, known as Wang Yuan Five, and printed the Five Dictionaries of Wang Yuan using this method. Wang also reformed commerce with scientific management methods, increasing the number of publications. In 1932, during the Second Sino-Japanese War, the Commercial Printing House and the Oriental Library were almost completely destroyed by the Japanese, and more than 3,700 employees were made redundant and unemployed. After two years of struggle, he not only completely restored the operation of the building, but also doubled the original capacity by half. Under the auspices of Emperor Wu, Commerce was able to continue publishing during the Sino-Japanese War, and continued to do so for 40 years. After the war, Wang retired from the Nationalist Party in 1927, but became an active outsider as a senator.

Hispanic Americans, Latin Americans, Latin Americans, or Latinos are immigrants from Latin America to the United States, many of whom speak Spanish as their mother tongue and English as a second language. Americans referred to as "Hispanic" or "Latino" are, in fact, often European whites, or mixed-race people whose ancestors were married to Native Americans (the Mestizos), not true Spaniards, and sometimes include immigrants and ethnic groups who actually emigrated from Spain to the United States. As a result of the North American Free Trade Agreement, Mexican immigrants (including illegal immigrants) migrated to the United States in the 1980s and 1990s, becoming the largest ethnic minority in the country, surpassing African Americans. Latin Americans are generally settled in the southwestern United States, near the Mexican–American border, so in American schools, although the traditional middle school foreign language instruction is to learn French, in many states, the middle school foreign language instruction is to learn Spanish. The emergence of the Latinos, beginning with the Spanish conquest of the Americas in the Age of the Navigator, and the large number of Western conquerors who began to marry indigenous women, led to the birth of a mixed-blooded Latin population known as the Mestizos, which spread from southern Argentina to northern New Spain to California, and became the dominant ethnic group in Latin America. After the American Revolution of 1789, the United States emerged as the only nation in North America capable of competing with British North America, Canada, and Mexico, which had just gained independence from the Spanish Empire.

They were accompanied by several KC-135 coaxial gasoline tankers. Farther out in the Pacific, the U.S. Navy's aircraft carrier USS Lincoln, the Wasp-class amphibious assault ship USS Essex and 36 other warships, as well as three submarines, are participating in RIMPAC in Hawaii. The U.S. Marine Corps' first F-35 Lightning II fighter squadron was also deployed on Lincoln. In addition, in Hong Kong and Macau, except in cases involving history, the term "Three Domains City" is commonly used, as opposed to Mainland China and Taiwan. The Chinese-language media in the area are generally referred to as "San Francisco" (Cantonese) and "San Francisco" (Chinese/Putonghua) depending on the dialect habits of the readers, viewers or listeners. The Chinese version of the official website of the City of San Francisco and its subordinate municipal units uses the two different translations of "San Francisco" respectively, without unifying them into a single translation. Older Chinese Americans often refer to San Francisco as the "Big Harbor" (whereas the "Second Harbor" and "Three Harbors" refer to the California capitals of Sacramento and Stackton, respectively), but this name has been used less frequently by new immigrants in recent years. Native Americans arrived in Northern California 3,000 years ago. Evidence suggests that the indigenous Ohlone people inhabited the San Francisco Bay Area as early as the sixth century, and that "Ohlone" means "Western" in their own language. Europeans arrived in the San Francisco Bay Area in 1542, and the San Francisco area became part of Spain's Upper California Territory in the 16th century. The Spanish general Don Gaspar de Portola led his men to explore the San Francisco Bay Area in 1769. On 28 March 1776, the Spanish explorer Juan Bautista de Anza selected two building sites, one for military purposes and the other for missionary purposes, but the actual construction was supervised by two of Anza's companions, Lieutenant José Joaquin Moraga and Francisco Palóu, a Franciscan priest.

Initially, volunteers temporarily recruited by the government and volunteers enrolled on a voluntary basis were separated from the regular United States Army, separately known as the "History of the United States Army", but in 1918 (within a year of entering the war), the Department of War abolished this division, declaring all former National Army units to be part of the United States Army. After the end of World War I, the isolationist United States began to reduce the size of its federal army. Congress passed the National Defense Act of 1920, which reorganized the U.S. Army, defining its three components: the Regular Army (the Army's reserve force), the Army National Guard, and the Army Reserve. The United States began using aircraft after 1910, initially under the command of the Army. In 1947, after World War II, the United States Army Air Forces formally separated from the United States Army and became the independent United States Air Force. The U.S. Army also participated in the Korean War and the Vietnam War. With U.S. involvement in the Vietnam War no longer supported by the people, the Volunteer Army Project (VOLAR) began in the late 1970s, seeking to abolish the compulsory military service. After the end of the Vietnam War, the U.S. Army became a fully volunteer army, consisting entirely of volunteers. In the early 1990s, the end of the Cold War prompted the United States to pursue a policy of disarmament.

Buddhism in Japan was introduced in the Asuka period, and began to develop in the Nara and Heian periods, as one of the Han Buddhist traditions, with Mahayana Buddhism as the mainstream. Chinese Buddhist sects that have disappeared, such as Shingon Buddhism and Hosso Buddhism, have been handed down to this day in Japan. According to the United States Central Intelligence Agency (CIA), Buddhism accounts for 70.4% of Japan's population and Buddhism for 69.8%. According to the Religion Statistics Survey conducted annually by the Japan Agency for Cultural Affairs, as of December 31, 2016, there are 84.74 million believers in Shinto (about 68 percent of the population) and 87.70 million Buddhists (about 70 percent of the population), i.e. most Japanese believe in both Shinto and Buddhism. Many Japanese do not participate in any religious organizations, only participate in traditional religious ceremonies such as weddings and funerals; and many young people even participate in religious ceremonies, but consider themselves agnostic or atheist. There are about 75,000 Japanese Buddhist temples and over 300,000 Buddha statues in Japan. According to the Japanese Buddhist calendar compiled by the Ministry of Culture, the majority of Buddhists in Japan today belong to the Taishu-Kamakura period sect. According to a 2010 survey of Eastern Hongan-ji Buddhist monks, the majority of sects in the Pure Land Sect (including Pure Land Shintoism) comprise about 47%; the Nichiren Sect (including Confucianism) comprises about 21%; the Zen Sect comprises about 16%; and the Esoteric Sect (including Taoism and Eastern Buddhism) comprises about 12%, with the remaining 4%. The following is a list of Buddhist temples in Japan. Although the "temple petition system," "honmatsu system," and "tatto system" have been abolished, they still influence Japanese Buddhism today.

The eastern part of the island is under the jurisdiction of the West Butekha Governorate, which has four flags: Busi, Bahiko and others. In 1907, the province of Heilongjiang (黑龍江省) was established, and the area was under the jurisdiction of the province. In the early days of the Republic of China, the Mongolian independence movement called for the establishment of an autonomous government of the province under the name of the Deputy Governor-General of the province. In 1919, the Beijing government appointed Xu Shuzhen as the Northwest Expeditionary Commissioner, led the Mongol army into Outer Mongolia, Outer Mongolia was forced to abolish "independence" and "autonomy", and Hulunberg lost a major pillar. On 21 December 1919, Guifu, the deputy governor of Nursing Province of Hulunber, called on the Beijing government to abolish the Hulunber Special Region. On 28 January 1920, the Beijing government announced that it would abolish the Hunanbel Special Zone and the conditions set by China and Russia, placing the Hunanbel region under the jurisdiction of Heilongjiang Province. In February 1920, Xu appointed Zhong Yu as interim governor and mediator in the aftermath of Huron Rebellion. At the same time, the Hunan Hall established in the late Qing Dynasty was renamed Hunan County, the Haman Prefecture was renamed Haman County, the Jilaling County was renamed Murwe County, and the Qiqian County was added, and the following year it was renamed Qiqian County. The Heilongjiang Provincial Department promulgated the provisional regulations of the Office of the Governor-General of Hulunber, which placed all the judicial, administrative, educational, industrial, financial, police, and Karen affairs under the jurisdiction of the Governor-General. In March 1920, Zhang Kuiwu was appointed as the garrison commander of Hulunber, and his army was divided into the 2nd Mixed Brigade and the 1st Cavalry Regiment of Heilongjiang Army, which was stationed in the areas of Hulunber, Murwe and Zaleinor, and was responsible for border defense and road protection. Eastern (continental) Scandinavian: Western (island) Scandinavian: The Scandinavian or Northern Germanic branch is a branch of the Indo-Germanic language family, including languages spoken in Scandinavia, parts of Finland, and the Faroe Islands and Iceland. The North Germanic languages are more widely used in comparative linguistics, while the Scandinavian languages are mainly used in the study of contemporary dialect continuum on the peninsula. The language is spoken by about 20 million native speakers, of whom about 5% live as a minority in the non-Northern Germanic-speaking country of Finland. There are also a number of speakers of the language in Greenland and North America. North Germanic is the official language of Denmark, Iceland, Norway and Sweden. Within the Nordic Council, written material is usually translated into three versions: Finnish, Icelandic, and one of three: Danish, Norwegian, and Swedish. In Northern Europe, apart from Finland, Greenland also uses a non-Northern Germanic language, Greenlandic, which is the only official language of Greenland. There are some German minorities (also known as North Schleswig Germans) in the southern part of Denmark's Jutland Peninsula, and German is the official minority language of the region. Conversely, in the German state of Schleswig-Holstein, a group of German-speaking Danish minorities settled in the Ruhr. Both groups are highly Danish-Lower German bilingual. Traditionally, German and Danish are the official languages of the United Kingdom of Denmark and Norway. Written languages in Denmark and Norway use Danish, while the Duchy of Schleswig and Holstein use German.

Pingliang is a city in Gansu Province, China, located in the eastern part of Gansu Province, at the intersection of the three provinces of Shaanxi and Ganning. It's bordered by Baiyin City to the northwest, Xilinding City to the west, Da Tianshui City to the southwest, Baoji City to the southeast, Xianyang City to the east, Linqingyang City to the northeast, Guyuan City to the northeast of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region. It's in the western Longdong Loess Plateau, high in the middle, low on both sides. To the east are the loess plateau gullies, to the middle are the hexagonal mountain ranges, and to the west are the Liangshan Hills. The western two counties belong to the Weihe River system, the eastern five counties belong to the Jinghe River system, the Jinghe flows from the west to the east across the middle. It has a total area of 11,171 square kilometers, a population of 209,800, and the city's people's government is located in Dongdong District. Plain is an ancient Silk Road must-visit town, called "dry dock" and "the first city west of Chang'an." The Buddhist name Mt. Dongdong is located in the precinct. In 572, he was appointed governor of Pingliang County, Longcheng County, Liyuan Province. In 742, the county was reorganized into a county, and the original county was reorganized into Pingliang County. In 788, Pingliang County was re-established. In 803, the exiles from Gyeongwon Province, located in Baili-jo Castle in Lingtai County, moved to Pingli-jo Castle. In 809, Wei was established in Pingliang, Pingliang County. In 880, the Tibetans occupied Pingliang Castle. After the Tang Dynasty of Qingtai II (935), Pingliang County was re-established, first belonged to Jingzhou, then to Weizhou. In the Northern Song Dynasty (1117), Weizhou was elevated to the rank of Pingliang army commander. In 1331, he changed Weizhou to Pingliang Prefecture. It was renamed Weizhou in 1139. In 1787, he was appointed governor of Liangliang (平凉府) in Liangliang Province.

Although the introduction of the wartime economic system slowed the pace of Japan's financial bankruptcy, it was not a long-term solution, coupled with concerns about Soviet military might, and the Japanese were eager to quickly overthrow the national government in order to accumulate more resources for both northern and southern policies. As Emperor Hirohito of Japan said at a pre-war conference in Wuhan, he wanted to give the national government a final and deadly blow, to force China to surrender, and not to see another "million imperial divisions subdued in China." Therefore, Japan's war against Wuhan was also a throwing away of the nation's strength, a throwing away of its own. After the war, it was discovered in Japanese documents that "the army devoted all its efforts to the Battle of Hankou, and there was no room for maneuver," and even the only remaining Japanese Home Guard division was on standby ready to reinforce Wuhan. Wuhan was the second-largest city in China at the time, with a population of more than two million, and on December 13, 1937, the National Government Military Committee formulated a plan to defend Wuhan. After the defeat of Xuzhou, he reorganized the deployment, mobilized about 50 army 130 divisions and 200 aircraft of various types, 40 ships of various types and minelaying boats, a total of more than 1 million people, took advantage of the favorable terrain on both sides of the Dabie Mountain, Poyang Lake and Yangtze River, organized defense, defended Wuhan. Lieutenant General Li Zongren, Commander-in-Chief of the Fifth War Area (from mid-July to mid-September, acting on behalf of Bai Chong-hui), commanded 23 army divisions in charge of the defense of the North River; Lieutenant General Chen Cheng, Commander-in-Chief of the Ninth War Area (from mid-July to mid-September, acting on behalf of Bai Chong-hui), commanded 27 army divisions in charge of the defense of the South River. In addition, the 1st War Area was in the area west of the Zhengzhou to Xinyang section of the Pinghan Railway (now Beijing 1 Hankou) to defend the Japanese forces south of China; the 3rd War Area was in the area east of the Yangtze River between Anhui Wuhu, Anqing and Nanchang in Jiangxi to defend the Japanese forces bypassing the Zhejiang and Gansu Railway (Hangzhou 1 Zhuzhou) to the Guangdong and Han Railway (Guangzhou 1 Wuchang).

Battlefield is a series of first-person shooter computers, home consoles, and Mac games developed by Electronic Arts. It was first published in 1942 by Digital Illusions CE. The Battlefield series is characterized by large maps, a wide variety of vehicles, and extensive network combat, while recent Battlefield games also have environmentally damaging features. Battlefield 1942 is the first installment in the Battlefield series, released for PC on September 10, 2002, and for Mac in 2004. The game recreates the battlefield of World War II, with an abundance of land, sea and airborne vehicles, and supports up to 64 simultaneous online battles. DICE's self-developed Refractor engine was first used in Battlefield 1942. The game has sold over three million copies. Battlefield: Vietnam is the second installment in the Battlefield series, released for PC on March 15, 2004. The game recreates the Vietnam War, adding jets and helicopters. The game incorporates nearly 20 1960s pop songs to give it a sense of the times. Battlefield 2, the third installment in the Battlefield series, was released for PC on June 21, 2005, and is set against the backdrop of a fictitious modern military war. The game uses a much improved Refractor 2 engine, which makes great improvements in graphics and sound effects.

Wang Zhang meeting refers to the 2014 meeting of the Taiwan Provincial Committee Chairman Wang Yuqi and the head of the Mainland National Taiwan Zhang Zhijun. The meeting between the two leaders was promoted on the premise of equality and dignity. The main purpose of establishing this institutional platform is twofold: firstly, to deal with important issues on both sides and to fight for the welfare of the people; secondly, to clarify the current situation of the separation of the two sides of the sea, and the objective facts of the existence of the Republic of China, and to clarify the pluralistic values of Taiwanese society. February 11–14, 2014. Wang Yuqi was invited to visit Nanjing and Shanghai, and on the afternoon of February 11, he held the first meeting of the heads of the two sides of affairs in Zhang Zhijun and Zhang Jinshanzhuang in Nanjing. At 2 p.m. on February 11, Wang held talks with Zhang Zhijun in Shijingshanzhuang, Nanjing. On the morning of February 12, Wang visited the Mausoleum of Nanjing Zhongshan, and issued a dedication, notable for the fact that the wreath was signed by the chairman of the Mainland Commission, Wang Yuqi, and all his colleagues, without mentioning the Executive Council. On 13 February, he arrived in Shanghai in the morning and in the afternoon went to the Shanghai Academy of Social Sciences, where he had a meeting with experts from Shanghai's important think tanks; he also visited the Shanghai Radio and Television; in the evening, the Sports Committee and the National Television hosted a party at the Peace Hotel for a closed-door tea ceremony. In the morning of 14 February, he visited the Shanghai Taiwan Children's School, and in the afternoon he boarded the plane back to Taiwan. The full text of Wang Yuqi's Mausoleum of the Father of the Nation is as follows: Great Father of the Nation, the Leader of the Revolution, the Founder of the People's Republic, the Rising of the Sun. The sun is shining in the sky, the sky is shining, the year is coming, the firewood is spreading. It's three-party democracy, five-power constitution, one-size-fits-all, based on the people. Treasure Island, Taiwan, Ippon Chosheng, Ji Zhi Suji, Shao Cheng Rui Xian. Cross-Strait divides, cross-border divides, cross-border divides, cross-border divides, cross-border divides. Face the reality, live in harmony, develop peacefully, create win-win.

According to the Constitution of the People's Republic of China, the People's Republic of China is the supervisory organ of the People's Republic of China, is the state organ that performs the functions of state supervision, was established from 2017 to 2018 successively, is elected and appointed by the people's congress at the same level, accepts the supervision of the people's congress at the same level and the state supervisory organ at the higher level, is a parallel state organ other than "one government and two courts", and co-operates with the CCP's disciplinary and inspection organs at the same level. This system is a reorganization and optimization of the disciplinary inspection organs, administrative supervision organs and anti-corruption departments at the four levels of the state, province, city, and county, and is regarded as a major reform of the system of disciplinary inspection and supervision of the Party and the State under the leadership of President Xi Jinping. The thirteenth session of the National People's Congress, held in March 2018, adopted the Constitutional Amendment and the Law of the People's Republic of China on Supervision, and elected the first members of the National Supervisory Commission of the People's Republic of China. On October 27, 2016, the Communist Party of China's Sixth Plenary Meeting of the Eighteenth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China merged the "supervisory organ" with power organs (the People's Congress and its Standing Committee), administrative organs (the People's Government), judicial organs (the People's Court and the People's Procuratorate) for the first time, and upgraded it from a constituent department of the People's Government to a parallel state organ. For this reason, the CPC Central Committee decided to establish the Leading Group for the Pilot Work on the Deepening of the National Supervisory System Reform, and Wang Qishan, Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, served as the head of the group. On November 7, 2016, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued "On the Pilot Program for the Development of the State Supervisory System Reform in Beijing, Shanxi and Zhejiang Provinces", which determined the thinking of the supervisory system reform.

Since taking office in 2017, US President Donald Trump has repeatedly criticized the North American Free Trade Agreement for the loss of manufacturing jobs in the United States. The North American Free Trade Agreement reopened negotiations, and the first round of negotiations officially kicked off in August 2017. On August 27, 2018, the United States and Mexico reached a preliminary agreement in principle to renew the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA): On September 30, 2018, the United States and Canada announced that they had reached a consensus on a new agreement: Agriculture has been a contentious issue since the original NAFTA negotiations, and any free trade agreement signed under the World Trade Organization framework raises similar issues. Agriculture is the only part not to have been negotiated in tripartite consultations, with three separate agreements being negotiated bilaterally. Agreements between Canada and the United States contained restrictions on agricultural products and tariff quotas, mainly sugar, dairy products, and poultry; agreements between Mexico and the United States allowed phased trade liberalization. The overall effect of the Mexico–Mexico Agricultural Agreement is controversial, as Mexico does not have the infrastructure investment needed to compete, such as a complete rail and road transportation system, which puts the country's poor in a more difficult environment. In fact, Mexico's agricultural exports increased by an average of 9.4 percentage points annually from 1994 to 2001, compared to imports which increased by only 6.9 percent. Mexico's corn production increased after the NATFA was implemented, but the domestic demand for corn exceeded what was available, making imports more urgent than Mexico's initially agreed agricultural quotas.

Between 1822 and the 1860s, the main settlers were freed slaves, and a portion of the black population of the United States was transferred to Monrovia, which was renamed Liberia in 1824, then expanded inland, and in 1838 the settlements were combined to form the Liberian Federation. Liberia declared its independence on 26 July 1847, the earliest independent modern sovereign state in Africa. The Abyssinian Empire was an independent state prior to the colonial era of the African continent. Since 1878, the party has been in power for 102 consecutive years, banning all opposition party activities, becoming the longest-running party since the establishment of the modern party system. In 1885, Liberia was defeated by Britain, which ceded land north of the Mano River; in 1892, it was defeated by France, which ceded most of the colony. Afterwards, land was ceded several times to the United Kingdom and France. After 1908, the existing boundaries were basically defined. From 1944 to 1971, William W. S. Doberman served as President of the United States for 27 years, progressively elevating the status of indigenous Africans, proposing an agenda for national integration, and working to bridge the gap between black Americans and indigenous peoples. In 1971, Du Bois died and was succeeded as President by William Richard T. Tolbert. In 1979, the opposition rioted and was suppressed by the armed forces. In April 1980, 17 soldiers, led by Colonel Samuel Canyon Doy of the Clan Presidential Guard, staged a coup d'état that overthrew and killed Albert, ending the long-held monopoly of American-Liberians on state power and becoming the first black head of state.

The first Chinese People's Liberation Army naval fleet to cross the Taiwan Strait occurred in late January 1974, after the outbreak of the war in the Western Sahara, the Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy Eastern Sea Fleet escort ships of the 18th Battalion South Division in the Fuzhou Military District fully counterattacked, from the evening of 21 to the morning of 22 smoothly sailing through the Taiwan Strait, supporting the South China Sea Fleet. The Chinese People's Liberation Army Navy used the voyage to break the military blockade of the Republic of China — the policy of closure, to restore the fleet to the Taiwan Strait. Tens of thousands of soldiers in Fuzhou Military District. In October 1949, the People's Republic of China was founded, divided on both sides. To oppose the new government of the People's Republic of China, the Republic of China imposed a military blockade of China's territorial waters — a policy of closure. Although the People's Republic of China gradually broke through the military blockade in other areas of the Taiwan Strait, the Republic of China was able to maintain its closure policy for a long time because of US support and the Republic of China's military superiority over the People's Republic of China. PLA surface ships, like civilian ships, didn't cross the Taiwan Strait until 1974. When small ships — torpedo boats — are moved north and south of mainland China, they are usually transported by train. The Southern Submarine Group, the 18th Battalion, 6th Marine Guards Squadron of the Eastern Sea Fleet of the People's Liberation Army in Zhejiang Province, was the main fighting force at the time. The 18th Battalion was originally composed of four Type 6601 frigates of the Riga class, namely the Kunming (505), Chengdu (506), Guiyang (507) and Hengyang (508). On 19 January 1974, the Battle of the Western Sahara broke out. Prior to this, Zhang Yuanpei, commander of the South China Sea Fleet, had asked the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the People's Liberation Army Navy for support for the East China Sea Fleet.

The French Liberation of Paris (French: Liberation de Paris) was a battle fought by the Allies to regain control of Paris from the Germans during World War II. The battle lasted from 19 August 1944 until the surrender of the German garrison on 25 August 1944. After the Battle of France in 1940, France fell into Nazi Germany's military occupation, and Western Europe fell into Nazi Germany's rule. The Allied forces launched a counterattack on Western Europe in 1944, and on 6 June 1944 the Allied forces successfully landed in Normandy. Allied military operations in Normandy progressed smoothly, and by early August they had achieved the objectives of the Grand Duchy's campaign, gaining control of much of the Normandy region. Following the fall of Normandy to the Allies, Allied troops approached the original French capital, Paris. On 19 August, the French Resistance in Paris responded by launching an uprising to drive out German troops stationed in Paris. Among them, the former Vichy France, which had a police force of 10,000, also joined the uprising under the banner of the Resistance. The Germans, on the other hand, had about 20,000 regular troops stationed in Paris, 5,000 of whom were in the city. The two armies fought fiercely in the streets. Due to the heavy casualties of the French resistance, the insurgents' fighting power and weaponry were far inferior to those of the trained regular German forces, as well as inadequate supplies and ammunition, the insurgents sent envoys to the regular Allied forces to seek help. However, according to the Allied plan, the Allied forces intended to bypass Paris after the Normandy landings and attack Germany directly, avoiding entering the city for street fighting, so the Allied generals in command of the front refused to seek the help of the French guerrillas. However, under the influence of Charles de Gaulle, the supreme decision-maker of the Allied forces, the plan was changed, and the French 2nd Armoured Division was sent to attack Paris; on 24 April, the leading elements of the L'Aquilae Division entered Paris and engaged the Germans; on 25 April, the French issued an ultimatum to the German commander of the garrison, Lieutenant General Dietrich von Kurtitz.

Plastics can also be classified according to their physical properties, such as density, tensile strength, and glass conversion temperature. There are also specialty plastics for special purposes, like medical plastics, conductive plastics, high-temperature plastics, etc. Biodegradable plastics degrade naturally when exposed to certain environmental or biological conditions in nature. Specific conditions may include exposure to the sun, exposure to water or moisture, bacteria, enzymes, wind abrasion and other environmental conditions (environmental decomposition), or biological conditions such as predators, pests or insect attacks. Some types of plastic decomposition require that the plastic be exposed to sunlight, and some decompose in landfills or compost. Starch particles have been added to plastics to accelerate their decomposition, but they are still unable to completely decompose the plastic. Some researchers have used genetic engineering to modify a bacterium to make plastics that are completely biodegradable, but this material (polyhydroxybutyrate) is still very expensive by 2013. There are also companies that have developed biodegradable additives to accelerate the decomposition of plastics. Natural plastics include natural rubber, latex (which can be used to make gum), insecticides, and nitrified fibers, but most of today's plastics are produced by the petrochemical industry. The limited availability of oil and the problem of global warming have led to the development of bioplastics, plastics made from renewable sources of biomass, such as vegetable oil, corn starch, peas starch, etc. The world's annual consumption of soft packaging is estimated at 12.3 million tons, of which 32.7 million tons are bio-based. Some plastics are semi-crystalline polymers with half crystalline and half amorphous chemical structures, so they have both melting points (the temperature at which intermolecular forces are overcome) and one or more glass conversion temperatures (the temperature at which local molecular elasticity is significantly increased).
