The court-martial jurisdiction of military courts differs from court-martial jurisdiction to court-martial jurisdiction: some incorporate military criminal law into court-martial jurisdiction, some retain military courts only during wartime, some distinguish between court-martial jurisdiction and court-martial jurisdiction on the basis of crimes committed by military personnel, and some make court-martial jurisdiction independent of court-martial jurisdiction; and some include members of the military family or civilians who may be transferred to court-martial jurisdiction if they violate military law. Some military courts, based on confidentiality requirements, may choose not to hold public hearings, or not to appoint a jury; in some cases, military convictions are preceded by discharge, discharge orders, and deprivation of liberty. Western military law originated in Roman law, when it was common law and there was no clear distinction between civilian and military crimes; after the conquest of England by William I in 1066, the establishment of the Constable's Court provided an independent tribunal to deal with crimes committed by non-citizens, separate from the civilian population; in 1523, the Holy Roman Emperor Charles V enacted the Military Penal Code, which was pushed to Europe as the military expanded; in 1642, the British formally established a military court to replace the constable's court; and in 1689, the British Parliament passed the Rebellion Act, which later became the basis of the U.S. military law.

The southern expedition of the Golden Soldiers, Huai'an often suffered from war, people fainted, so the Huai'an army was changed to Huai'an State, the Yuan Dynasty was changed to Huai'an Road, the capital was still Xianyang. During the Ming and Qing dynasties, Huai'an was the hub of the three great powers of the southeast: the river, the paddle and the salt; the imperial court appointed two governors of the southern river and the paddle; the city flourished at its peak; Fucheng, Kawashima, Banzhao, and Qingjiangpu formed dozens of miles of huge belt cities; along with Yangzhou, Suzhou, and Hangzhou, they were called the "four great cities" along the Beijing-Hangzhou Grand Canal. Huai'an Prefecture was one of only two prefectures north of the Yangtze River in present-day Jiangsu Province, and its jurisdiction extended to the four cities of Huai'an, Salt City, Shuqian, Lianyungang, and the eastern part of Xuzhou. In the Qing Dynasty, Huai'an Province was divided into Haizhou and Jilin Province, and Xu'an Province was divided into the newly established Xu'an Province, the scope of which was reduced, and six counties were under its jurisdiction: Shanyang (now Huai'an District), Qinghe (now Huaiyin District), Andong (now Lishui), Moyuan (now Sabian), Salt City, and Funing (division of Shanyang County east of the newly established Xu'an Province). In 1761, when the city of Qinghe was destroyed by a flood, the town of Qingjiangpu in Shanyang County was transferred to Qinghe as a new county seat. In 1914, several counties in the area were renamed because of their importance: Shanyang County was renamed Huai'an County, Qinghe County was renamed Huaiyin County, Andong County was renamed Lishui County, and Taoyuan County was renamed Sabian County. After the establishment of the Republic, the prefectural administration was abolished, and the road was retained. It was the seat of Huaiyang Road, and from then on it officially replaced Huai'an Prefecture as the administrative center. Huaiyang Road includes the former Huai'an Prefecture and Yangzhou Prefecture, and is administered by 13 counties: Huaiyin County, Huai'an County (now Huai'an District), Liansu County, Yancheng County, Funing County, Sabian County, Jiangdu County, Dongtai County, Gaopu County, Yixi County, Baoxiang County, Tai County, and Xinghua County.

The Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous-Shoemaker is a NASA spacecraft named in honor of astronomer Eugene M. Shoemaker. The main objective of the Soyuz-Shumek program was to study the inner structure, composition, mineralogy, mass distribution, and magnetic field of the star for more than a year. The secondary objectives include studying the characteristics of the weathering layer, the interaction between asteroids and solar winds, possible geological activity (e.g. dust or gas) on the surface of the asteroid, and the state of rotation of the asteroid. These data will help scientists understand the general characteristics of asteroids, the relationship between meteorites and comets, and the early history of the Solar System. To achieve these objectives, the spacecraft was equipped with an X-ray/gamma ray spectrometer, a near-infrared imaging spectrometer, a multispectral camera with a CCD imaging detector, a laser rangefinder, and a magnetometer. Scientists have also used the Near Field Tracking System to conduct radio science experiments to estimate the asteroid's gravitational field. The instrument weighs 56 kilograms and requires 81 watts of power to operate. The Soyuz-Shumek was also the first spacecraft to land on an asteroid. The main mission of the Soyuz-Shumek spacecraft was to study the structure of Uranus by orbiting it for nearly a year. Aishin is an S-type asteroid, 13 × 13 × 33 km in size, the second-largest of the near-Earth asteroids. Its initial orbital radius was 200 km, then gradually reduced to 50 × 50 km on April 30, 2000, and then to 35 × 35 km on July 14, 2000.

Swedish (Swedish: svenska 帮助·信息) is a North Germanic language (also known as Scandinavian) spoken mainly in Sweden and Finland (especially the Åland Islands) by more than nine million people. It communicates with two other Scandinavian languages, Danish and Norwegian. Like other North Germanic languages, Swedish is derived from Old Norse. Old Norse was a common language in Scandinavia during the Viking Age. Adult literacy in Sweden is 99 percent. Standard Swedish is the official language of Sweden, derived from the dialect of central Sweden in the 19th century, and established in the early 20th century. Standard Swedish spoken and written is unified and standardized. Other language variants that have evolved from older, more remote dialects still exist, some of which differ greatly in grammar and vocabulary from Standard Swedish and cannot be called the same language. These dialects are spoken only in very remote areas, in very small numbers, and these people have very little social mobility. Although there are no signs that these languages are going to be dead, many scholars are studying these dialects seriously, and local governments are encouraging people to use them, but the number of people using them has been decreasing since the last century. Swedish Standard Grammar is a predicate structure, sometimes changing the order to emphasize certain words. Swedish is similar in construction to English, with relatively little variation in word form; there are two types of lexical lattice, no grammatical lattice (previous studies have suggested that there are two types of lattice, main and subordinate); and there are differences between singular and plural. Adjectives vary according to their lexical, quantitative, and restrictive categories.

On March 15, 2017, the Fifth Session of the Twelfth National People's Congress adopted the General Provisions of the Civil Law of the People's Republic of China, which entered into force on October 1, 2017. However, the Civil Code has not been repealed and may continue to be applied. If the provisions of the Civil Code are inconsistent with the provisions of the Civil Code, the provisions of the Civil Code shall be applied in accordance with the principle that the new law is superior to the old law. In February 2019, Xi Jinping, General Secretary of the Communist Party of China (CPC), said at the first meeting of the CPC's Central Committee for the Comprehensive Rule of Law, "We must start from China's national situation and reality, take the road of the rule of law that suits us, never copy the models and practices of other countries, never follow the path of the West's 'constitutional government', 'three powers' and 'independence of the judiciary'." The law of the People's Republic of China includes the basic laws formulated and amended by the National People's Congress and other laws formulated and amended by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress. In some cases, "law" is broadly equivalent to "constitution and law", but the Constitution is outside the scope of this article. The laws of the People's Republic of China must comply with the Constitution of the People's Republic of China, and the legal effect of the Constitution is superior to administrative regulations, local regulations, autonomy regulations and unilateral regulations, the regulations of the departments under the State Council of the People's Republic of China, the regulations of local governments, and judicial interpretations. The legal system of the People's Republic of China has changed over the centuries, but since the founding of the country, it has adopted the written legal system, with legal origins expressed as enacted laws, not including case law. In accordance with the Constitution of the Communist Party of China, the Regulations on the Work of the Basic Organization of the Communist Party and Party Organs of the Communist Party of China, and other regulations, the Political and Law Committee of the Communist Party of China has been established from the central to the local Party Committees at the county level, and exercises leadership over the judicial, procuratorial, public security and national security organs.

As a historical term, it usually refers to the introduction of Western ideas into Europe and parts of the pre-British colonies during the late Ming and early Qing dynasties and the late Qing dynasties. During this period, Chinese attitudes toward Western studies ranged from initial rejection and resistance to gradual acceptance, and even calls for "comprehensive Westernization." Western philosophy, astronomy, physics, chemistry, medicine, biology, applied sciences, technology, geography, politics, sociology, economics, law, history, literature, and the arts were introduced to China in large numbers through the media of Chinese immigrants, Chinese emigrants, various newspapers, books, and modern education, with Macau, Hong Kong, other trading ports, and Japan as important windows. The evolution of Western scholarship discussed in this article can be roughly divided into two phases: the Ming and Wan eras, with the arrival of Jesuit missionaries, touched upon the academic thought of China. By this time, Western science and technology was beginning to develop rapidly, while the development of science and technology in China was relatively slow, falling somewhat behind that of Europe at the same time. At the same time as spreading Catholic doctrine, missionaries also introduced a great deal of Western science and technology. Some Chinese physicians and emperors accepted scientific and technological knowledge, but were largely unaffected by it. This phase of Western studies was interrupted by a change in the Roman Church's missionary policy towards China (abolition of the Rima rule, prohibition of priests), which provoked antipathy from the Yongzheng dynasty and the people, but the smaller-scale introduction of Western studies was not completely stopped.

1662), general of the late Ming Dynasty, military figure of the Southern Ming Dynasty. He was an officer in the Ming Dynasty. Between the spring of 1641 and the autumn of 1643, he surrendered to Li Zhicheng. In February 1645, when the Taishun regime collapsed, Ho Jian, Luo Dai, Meng An, and Guo Teng surrendered to the Qing dynasty in the middle of Han, and Prince A Jig of England appointed him as the commander-in-chief of Han forces. In the northern Shaanxi Province and other places, the Daishun army led by Li Qiao, Gao Yigong, Li Yu, Tian Hu and so on captured Daohan and entered Sichuan, but Ho Jian's army was blockaded and defeated by Li Qiao, Gao Yigong and so on. Around June 1645, Taixi Zhang Chengzhong's army of 30,000 troops attacked Hanzhong, Gao Zhen intercepted the enemy, Taixi soldiers knew nothing, and retreated back to Sichuan. In September, he was promoted to the rank of Major General. At that time, the main Qing army led by Dodo and Aziz was already far away from Shaanxi, and in early December 1645, Gao Zhen raised an army in Hanzhong against the Qing. Praise be to the Lord Almighty. In mid-December 1645, he led an attack on Fengxiang County. On the evening of the 17th, the city's deputy defense commander, General Wu Dading, and the headquarters of Shi Guo Shi responded by occupying Fengxiang County for a time. In response, Ho Jian attacked Longzhou, Guyuan, and other places, killing General Ho Shiyuan. Immediately, peaceful uprisings took place in Shining, Lingtai, and Guanzhong. In the aftermath of the Qing rebellion, Sun Shufa, Hu Xuanxin, and other local armed leaders came to contact with the Qing army and fought against it. Sun Shufa called for the sons of the Qin king of the Ming Dynasty to fight in Goro Mountain. In late December, Gen. Ho Jian and his troops attacked Xi'an with 70,000 infantry. In 1646, the Qing army of Shaanxi was continuously strengthened, and the provinces of Hechin, Wudaiding, and Sun Shufa were transferred to the Xing'an area.

If the general died sooner than the palace itself, the palace would have to be decorated along with the concubines, but only the palace itself could remain in Dao Zhong, and even participate in the government of the bakufu with its influence. In addition, to avoid confusion with the name of the successor general's palace, the former palace is revered as the Great Palace. On the Korean Peninsula, discrimination against legitimate and illegitimate children during the Joseon Dynasty was severe, with men and women of different classes not allowed to marry, and lower-ranking men who married higher-ranking women were guilty of kidnapping and the marriage was null and void. Females of lower ranks, if married to males of higher ranks, are generally only concubines, not wives, and are not legally assisted after the death of their husbands, with very few exceptions. After the death of her elder brother, Yoon Yuan-hyun's concubine, Cheng Lan-jeong, she was permitted to be raised to the status of a legitimate wife, and she was given the title of Join Join-jeong-woman. At that time, there was a "mother-law" in which children inherited their mother's social class, with the exception of royalty or the children of the royal family. If a child is born out of wedlock to a non-royal family, his or her father, his or her lawful wife, and his or her legitimate brothers or sisters shall be regarded as servants of the Lord, and if his or her mother is of noble birth, he or she shall be regarded as servants of the Lord. The king's heirs are called princes, his daughters are called princes, his daughters are called princesses, and his sons are called princesses. The king's daughter-in-law is called the countess, and the daughter-in-law is called the countess. The legal spouse other than a legitimate wife is an illegitimate wife, often called a concubine or concubine. In the Zhou Dynasty, noblewomen married, requiring sisters or nieces of the same family to marry, called  (正妻的同族陪嫁女子), rarely seen in later times. A concubine is usually a man who marries a woman who is inferior to him, without going through the rites of Sanskrit, and takes her as his concubine in a simpler ceremony known as a concubineship.

His paternal family came from Venice, 40 kilometers from Rome. On September 23, 63 BC, Octavian was born in a small place called "the head of the ox" on Mount Palatine in Rome, near the Piazzale Roma. He inherited his father's name Gaius Octavius. In September 45 BC, Caesar the Great adopted Jadwiga and designated her heir by will. In March 44 BC, when Caesar was assassinated, Octavian was in the army of Albania. He was eighteen years old, often underestimated by his opponents. However, he repeatedly emphasizes himself as Caesar's son to arouse people's affection for him (so much so that he deliberately omits Octavian to call himself Gaius Julius). Anthony accuses Housewife of being a child molester and of killing Caesar in order to have him adopted. The Roman historian Suetonius analyzed Antony's accusation that he was trying to throw dirty water at Octavian, because Antony had also insulted Octavian's relatives' ancestors. After Caesar's death, Octavian marched to Italy, where he recruited and expanded Caesar's old army. After arriving in Rome, he discovered that the capital was in the hands of the republicans Marcus Junius Brutus and Cassius, who had murdered Caesar. After a tense standoff, he formed a military dictatorship with Marc Antony and Caesar's important colleague Marcus Emilios Rebida, known as the "Third Coalition". They then began to clean up the Senate, enslaving the property of 300 senators and 3,000 knights, which was not only "cleansing" the place, but a large portion of the unclaimed property was used to expand the army.

In November 1956, as deputy commander of the National People's Congress delegation to visit the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries led by the commander Pengzhi, Zhang suddenly stood up and said: "I am very happy to see Comrade Khrushchev, and I want to say a few words to Comrade Khrushchev. I would like to say a few words that have been on my mind for many years, and I have not had the opportunity in the past. I am very happy to have heard Comrade Khrushchev speak today, and I would like to take this opportunity to speak. I used to be a member of the Communist Party of China, because my views on the Chinese revolution were different from those of some of my comrades, and I was rejected. And then I left the Communist Party. On April 30, 1957, Zhang was very excited to hear Mao Zedong speak at the Supreme Council of State. Mao Zedong believed that the introduction of the concept of "internal contradictions of the people," the general principle that "the problem of productivity and productive relations will be solved mainly in the future," and the establishment of the principles of "one hundred flowers, one hundred families," and "long-term coexistence and mutual supervision" represented a breakthrough in Mao Zedong's theory of himself. And that breakthrough would benefit his social practice. "The first generation of leaders is the leader who is determined to hold the future of the country in his own hands; the second generation of leaders is the leader who is able to satisfy the people's desire for life, and life is not so easy to satisfy. Mao Zedong, who proposed internal contradictions and solutions for the people, is likely to complete the task of two generations of leaders. "The Ministry of the Central War of the People's Republic of China came to hold a symposium, the Minister of the Central War of the People's Republic of China Li Weihan personally called to urge Zhang to attend the symposium, to make some criticisms. According to Zhang, "For the past 20 days, people all over the country have been talking about internal contradictions, helping the Communist Party to clear the air, putting forward a lot of ideas, and it seems normal.

In British units used in the United States, burning the equivalent of one cubic foot of natural gas produces 1031 British Units of Heat (BTUs). In the U.S., natural gas is often retailed as "" sam "" (Therm, abbreviated as th,1 Therm = 100,000 BTU). Wholesale transactions typically use "Decatherms" (Dth) or "Thousand decatherms" (MDth) or "Million decatherms" (MMDth) as units. One million tenths of a gram is roughly equivalent to one billion cubic feet of natural gas. As the main fuel for gas turbine engines and steam turbine power generation, natural gas is very important. In the gas turbine, steam turbine, combined cycle model of power generation, energy efficiency is particularly high. In terms of the natural environment, burning natural gas is cleaner and produces fewer greenhouse gases than fossil fuels like oil and coal. To get the same amount of heat, burning natural gas produces 30 percent less carbon dioxide than burning oil, 45 percent less than burning coal. Combined cycle electricity using natural gas is the cleanest fossil fuel energy available. This technology is being widely adopted where gas can be obtained at a reasonable cost. Fuel cell technology may eventually provide a cleaner alternative to converting natural gas into electricity, but it is not yet price-competitive. Similarly, natural gas is said to peak around 2030, 20 years later than oil. Global gas supplies will run out in the mid-1980s.

"The Island of Hong Kong, to be possessed in perpetuity by Her Britannic Majesty, Her Heirs and Successors, and to be governed by such Laws and Regulations as Her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain, etc., shall see fit to direct." Between 1842 and 1898, Hong Kong Island, the Kowloon Peninsula, and the New Territories were ceded to the British by the Qing dynasty. The island of Hong Kong, far from the mainland, has been complained of by the British as "poor, unsanitary, and worthless", and Hong Kong's annexation has often been described as the first in the history of modern China. (In 1842, the Treaty of Nanjing was signed, Macau was not ceded, but was granted to Portuguese merchants in the Ming dynasty.) "Wait a minute." As a follow-up to the Treaty of Nanjing, the Sino-British Five Points of Commerce (July 22, 1843) and the Five Points of Commerce (October 8, 1843) were signed. The British subsequently gained diplomatic rights such as tariff agreements, foreign law enforcement (similar to the Treaty of Xiamen and Beijing, claimed consular jurisdiction, Chinese and foreign people's lawsuits were each governed by their own laws), demarcation of the territory, one-sided most-favored-nation treatment, ports of embarkation of warships, and enjoyed more advantages in trade with the Qing Dynasty, the Qing Dynasty also opened its gates due to pressure from the British, accelerated modernization, and indirectly led to the overthrow of the Qing Dynasty and the establishment of the Republic of China.

As the school became a university, the word "A&M" was no longer an abbreviation, becoming the official school name, and the school was founded when the U.S. government sought to develop the economy by establishing schools of agriculture and machinery throughout the country, with the "Texas Farmer" as its ancestor. The school's students are collectively referred to as "Aggies," an evolution of the word "agriculture," which is not an official word, and because of Texas oil production and the state's booming finances, the school's low tuition, $105.2 billion in donations, made it the richest public school in the United States, and ranked sixth among the wealthiest public and private universities in the country. In Texas, the Texas Agricultural University and the University of Texas-Austin are the two flagship universities in the state. In the U.S. News & World Report rankings, the school ranked first and fourth in the U.S. in oil and agricultural engineering, respectively, and was ranked in the top 20 in many engineering fields, including aviation, mechanical engineering, civil engineering, and industrial engineering. According to a Texas proverb, "A graduate of an agricultural college can fly across the state like a bullet." Former U.S. Secretary of Defense Robert Gates was the school's principal. It's a very important part of American culture, a very important part of American culture, and it has a lot of alumni. Two-time World Series champion second baseman Chuck Norbrooke of the Minnesota Twins and the New York Yankees, American soccer coach Gary Kubiak of the Houston Astros, and Olympic gold medalist and men's world record-holder Randy Barnes were among the players.

Hirofumi Ito (伊藤博文, Ito Hirofumi, October 16, 1841 – October 26, 1909) was a Japanese nobleman who lived from October 16, 1841 to October 26, 1909. Japan's modern politician, the Meiji Restoration Emperor, was one of the five great leaders of Choshu who went to the United Kingdom to study, led Japan to the completion of the Westernization, became the first prime minister of Japan's cabinet, plotted the Sino-Japanese War at noon, and was Japan's first Korean governor-general. On 26 October 1909, while negotiating with Russia, he was assassinated by Anzhigen at Harbin Railway Station. Catalogue 1 Childhood 2 Studying in England 3 Respecting the Emperor and expelling foreigners 4 Visiting the Emperor four times 5 Commander-in-Chief of Korea and assassination 6 Various positions 7 Peerage 8 Honour 8.1 Rank 8.2 Order of Japan 8.3 Foreign Orders 9 Ratings 10 Generations 11 Works appearing 12 Related Articles 13 Sources Born on October 16, 1841, Hirobumi ITO was the eldest son of Tenzo YAMAMURA, a poor farmer, and the eldest daughter of Chozaemon AKIYAMA. His real name is Lin. The Hayashi clan was a descendant of Emperor Ko Rin, the seventh ruler of Japan, and a branch of the Kawano clan (河野氏) with the surname of Ochi no Sukune (越智宿). His father was adopted by Takehei MIZUI, who was employed as a buke bugonin (a court noble) of the Choshu Domain, and changed his name to "Juzo MIZUI", while Takehei MIZUI was adopted by Yaemon ITO, who was employed as a buke bugonin (a court noble) of the Genshu Domain, and changed his name to "Naoemon ITO," so that "Juzo MIZUI" was also changed to "Ito," and inherited the family. In 1853, he lodged in a temple, and later worked as a servant in the family of feudal retainers such as Fukuhara, usually doing miscellaneous duties, leisurely studying literature and reading.

A prime minister (Chief Minister, Chancellor, etc.) is the head of government of a country or region who is responsible for the administration of the government. Most modern parliamentary, bicameral, monarchical, and other quasi-presidential governments have prime ministers or similar positions, and some prime ministers are formally called presidents of the Council of Ministers, but in some presidential countries (such as the United States, Brazil, and Indonesia), the head of state is also the head of government, so there is no need to create a separate government headquarters. The term "Prime Minister" is used in Chinese to refer to the head of government of a monarchy, such as the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, but there are many exceptions to this usage. The titles of heads of state in Chinese are more often based on traditional translations, and can sometimes be used interchangeably. For example, the Prime Minister of Thailand under the Constitution of Thailand is often referred to as the "Prime Minister of Thailand" in Chinese; the Prime Minister of Japan under the Constitution of Japan may also be referred to as the "Prime Minister" or "Prime Minister" in Japanese; and the "Prime Minister" (head of government under the Constitution of Thailand) may also be referred to as the "Prime Minister" in Chinese. Both prime ministers and prime ministers can use the term "uprising" broadly, this usage comes from the ancient Chinese to distinguish the prime minister from the "uprising", the Ming Dynasty also called the cabinet chief "uprising", "Ming Dynasty Zhaofu calendar 1": "In Zhaofu, especially the uprising is important.

Zhang Zongchang (張宗昌; February 13, 1881 – September 3, 1932) was a provincial governor of Shandong Province. He was a military commander in the government of the Republic of China in Beijing. Zhang Zongchang broke through Guandong as a teenager, as a lumberjack, as a railroad worker, and in Russia, as a butcher, and later organized as a laborer's friend, became a bandit. In 1911, during the Revolution of 1911, he led the Green Line brothers into the hands of Huei, the governor of the Shandong Revolutionary Army, and then moved to Shanghai, where he became the commander of the Guangfu Army under Chen Qimei, the governor of the Shanghai Military Governorate. In 1913, he was appointed commander of the 3rd Division of the Jiangsu Army. In the same year, during the Second Revolution, Zhang Zongchang was ordered to Xuzhou to resist the attack of Yuan Shikai's North Korean army, and fell before the battle, becoming a subordinate of Feng Guozhang's North Korean army. In the spring of 1916, during the Shanghai Uprising, Chen Qimei was assassinated by Zhang Zongchang. As a result of his efforts, he was promoted to the rank of lieutenant colonel. In November of the same year, he was appointed deputy commander-in-chief, and Zhang Zongchang was appointed military commander. After the outbreak of the Civil War in 1918, Zhang Zongchang was appointed as the commander of the 6th mixed brigade brigade of the Soviet army (Jiangsu army), along with Zhang Huaizhi went to Hunan to participate in the battle with the Southern government forces, but was defeated. In 1921, Zhang Zongchang's headquarters in Ji'an, Jiangxi, was disbanded by Jiangxi Governor Chen Guangyuan. Zhang Zongchang fled to the north. Since then, the direct leader Cao Cao had hoped to appoint Zhang Zongchang, but failed due to opposition from Wu Pefu. Zhang Zongchang then relied on Zhang Shaolin, who was a vassal of Zhang. In 1922, Zhang defeated the loyalist rebels and gathered the remnants of the rebels into his own army. In the winter of the same year, Zhang absorbed the Russian White Army, which had fled from Russia to China.

Organ transplantation is the process of transferring an individual's organ, in whole or in part, to another body (or to another part of the body, such as an autologous skin graft). The aim is to replace damaged or dysfunctional organs with healthy organs from the donor. The donor is the "" donor "" of an organ transplant, whether it's a living person or a recently deceased person. The organs provided by the living are called living organs, and the organs of the deceased are called dead organs. One of the recipients of the organ is the recipient of the transplant. However, organs that have been infected or depleted cannot be transplanted. According to Auschwitz survivor Yitzhak Ganon, he had successfully removed a kidney from a concentration camp medic, Joseph Mengler, without the use of narcotics, but this was inhumane, so that under normal conditions, anesthesia was used before the organ was removed or the donor was confirmed to be brain dead. In addition to the above-mentioned technical issues, organ transplantation in some places may also raise ethical controversies because of the source of the organ donor, so as noted above, in general, if the patient is not dead or suspected to be dead, it must be performed after the legal examination has been completed, and after the prosecutor has determined that no further examination is necessary. Since the People's Republic of China has long used capital punishment organs, there is considerable possibility of using imprisoned Falun Gong practitioners' organs without prior consent.

On July 19, 1994, the National Health Insurance Act was passed by the Legislative Assembly for the third reading, and the National Health Insurance was officially authorized by the people. The Executive Council's war plan was expected to be formally implemented on January 1, 1995. However, due to concerns and protests from labor and other groups, the legislature did not pass the "Organization Ordinance of the Central Health Insurance Bureau" until December 23, 1994, and it was promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui's decree on December 30, 1994. Due to the late completion of the legislative process, the original implementation date had to be postponed. On January 1, 1995, the Health Department of the Executive Yuan was officially established as the "Central Health Insurance Bureau", with the position of "General Manager". On March 1, 1995, the "National Health Insurance" was fully implemented. In 2003, the Department of Health and Social Services implemented a fully integrated health card, integrating all medical records into a single card chip, and uploading them to a cloud server for each visit. On January 23, 2009, the "Organization Law of the Central Health Insurance Bureau of the Executive Yuan Health Department" was enacted, which contains nine articles. On January 1, 2010, the "Organization Act of the Central Health Insurance Bureau of the Executive Yuan" was enacted, renamed the "Central Health Insurance Bureau of the Executive Yuan", and the position of the head of the Central Health Insurance Bureau was changed from "General Manager" to "Director General". On January 1, 2013, the second generation of healthcare was officially implemented. On 19 June, the Ministry of Health and Welfare's "Organization Act" was enacted, and on 23 July, with the establishment of the Ministry of Health and Welfare, it was reorganized into the Ministry of Health and Welfare's "Central Health Insurance Agency". In July, the Department of Health set up a patient-centered "Healthcare Cloud Pharmaceutical History System", which provides physicians of the contract medical service organizations with immediate access to the patient's medication records of the past three months, avoiding the occurrence of overdose, enhancing the safety and quality of medication when prescribing, opening prescriptions and consulting with pharmacists.

In 920, it was renamed Jinlingfu, in 937, it was renamed Jiangningfu, in 975, in 1018, it was renamed Jiangningfu, and in 1129, it was renamed Jiankangfu. In 903, Yang Wu's regime moved Liyang County to the new Liyang City (now Liyang City), which has been the administrative center of Liyang for more than 1,100 years. In 1277, he was elevated to Lizhou, and was appointed to the post of Xuanzong of Jiangdong Province, and in the following year he was elevated to Liyang Prefecture. In 1279, it was elevated to Liyang Road, under the jurisdiction of Liyang County and Liyang City Records Bureau. Until 1291, Liyang Road was abolished, but remained Liyang County, and was renamed Jiankang Road (in 1329, it was renamed Jiqing Road, in 1356, after the Ming army occupied it, it was renamed Tianfu). In 1296, it was renamed Liyang Province. In 1369, the county was abolished, and it remained under the jurisdiction of Tianfu. In 1730, he was transferred to Jinjiang Prefecture, Jiangsu Province. In 1912, the temporary government of Nanjing withdrew, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province, Jinling Province became Jiangsu Province (1914–1927), Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1932, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1933, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1936, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1939, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1945, Jiangsu Province became Jiangsu Province in 1948. On April 25, 1949, Liyang was occupied by the People's Liberation Army, and on May 7, 1949, the county people's government was formed, which belonged to the Southern Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China.

January 23, 1368 – April 25, 1644. The first emperor was Zhu Yuanzhang, the second Zhu Yuanzhang, and the third Zhu Yuanzhang. In the final years of the Yuan Dynasty, political corruption, unremitting natural disasters, unremitting civil unrest, the civilian Zhu Yuanzhang joined the Red Scarf Army, and rose to prominence among them, following the occupation of Hozhou by Guo Zhixing. After the death of Guo Zi-Xing, Zhu Yuanzhang was promoted to the rank of deputy commander-in-chief of the left by Han Lin, the then rebellious King of the Koming Dynasty, and his troops occupied Chuzhou, Wazhou, etc., and eventually captured Jiuqing (now Nanjing City), adopting the policy of "high walls, plentiful food, loosely called the king" suggested by Zhu Liang. In 1364, Zhu Yuanzhang proclaimed himself King of Wu, establishing the Western Wu Dynasty. In 1368, Zhu Yuanzhang ascended the throne as Emperor on the fourth day of the first month of the lunar calendar, and became known as Daimyo (大明), uniting the whole country. At the beginning of the new millennium, the world was stable, the national power was growing rapidly, and history called the reign of Hongwu. After Zhu Yuanzhang's death, his grandson Zhu Yunzhang succeeded to the throne, but he was defeated in the Siege of Yanjing by Zhu Yuanzhang's fourth son, Zhu Di, who had been stationed in Yanjing. After Zhu Di ascended the throne, he moved the capital to Juntianfu (present-day Beijing), changed the bureaucratic post of Beiping to Beizhi, and the former bureaucratic post of Beijing to Tianfu, and renamed Nanjing. After the Three Great Conquests of the Han Dynasty, to settle internal and external problems, Japan destroyed the enlightened plan of Hideyoshi TOYOTOMI to invade Korea by crossing the sea, however, because of the dispute over the country, the emperor gradually neglected the dynasty, the history called the Wanren neglected the government, while the Donglin Party dispute also brought political chaos, and the real power of women began to rise. The day is marked by a turning point in the day-to-day life of the village. The Ming Dynasty encompassed the Han Dynasty. The prosperity of the Ming Dynasty and the port trade after the opening of the Longqing trade led to the emergence of the Chinese heat in Europe, the emergence of commercial centers in China, and the secularization of handicrafts and the arts.

Plutonium is also lighter than air, allowing it to escape from the Earth's atmosphere. Under low-voltage fluorescent lamps, high-voltage discharge tubes, and neon lights, it emits a distinctive reddish-orange color. Plutonium is also used in plasma tubes and refrigeration equipment, with few commercial applications. Its commercial sources are mainly distilled from liquid air. Because air is the only source, plutonium is more valuable than helium. Plutonium is the second lightest inert gas, after helium. It emits orange-red light in a vacuum tube. It also has the smallest liquid temperature range of any element: 24.55 K to 27.05 K (-248.45 °C to-245.95 °C, or 415.21 °F to 410.71 °F). On a unit volume basis, it has a cooling capacity that's 40 times higher than liquid helium, three times higher than liquid hydrogen. Of all inert gases, plutonium discharge is most intense at equal voltages and currents. The color of plutonium in vacuum discharge tubes is orange-red, visible to the naked eye, due to the presence of many radionuclides within this range. It also has a bright green spectral line, but is generally not recognizable, and can only be detected by spectrophotometry. There are two common applications of fluorescent lighting in everyday life. The bulbs are generally smaller and operate at voltages between 100 and 250 volts. Lamps are often molded into various shapes and characters as signs, and are used in architecture and the arts. It is often used in advertisements for neon lights, emitting bright orange-red light. Although neon lights of other colors are often referred to as fluorescents, they use different types of inert gases or fluorescents of different colors. Other applications include: liquid and gaseous plutonium are relatively expensive, and the price of liquid plutonium can exceed 55 times that of liquid helium.

At the beginning of the Qing Dynasty, the government of the Qing Dynasty and the government of the Russian tsar signed the Treaty of Nebuchadnezzar, which China called the Treaty of Equality, and Russia (including the Soviet period) called the Treaty of Inequality (Russians believed that the Treaty of Aihui recovered the lost land that had been occupied by the Chinese). It is believed that the treaty marked the beginning of normalized Chinese diplomacy, but in fact, until the establishment of the prime minister's office, the Qing dynasty treated foreign affairs with the concept of feudal lordship, and endeavored to seek foreign submission in exchanges (e.g., with Machiavelli), unlike diplomacy in the modern sense. With the decline of the Qing dynasty and the corruption of the government, as well as foreign aggression, starting with the Treaty of Nanjing, the Qing dynasty began to sign a series of unequal treaties with foreign countries. These unequal treaties, either demanding land expropriation or demanding compensation, led the Qing dynasty from a powerful Eastern empire gradually to a semi-colonial state, which, in the face of repeated blows, ultimately led to the overthrow of the Qing dynasty. Nearly 200 treaties were signed by more than fifty republics before, during and after the Qing Dynasty. Although a considerable part of them were treaties degrading the state (such as the Sino-British Treaty of Tianjin), there were also treaties that promoted the dignity of the state at the time of its glory (such as the Treaty of Nebuchadnezzar). But from the beginning to the end, the Qing dynasty government never forgot its prestige as a "heavenly dynasty great power." Even when they sign some unequal treaties, they don't forget to hang their heads, to see themselves as heavenly, to see each other as little countries that are inspired by heavenly morality and dignity, that owe a debt of gratitude to heaven. The Great Purge Law, compiled in 1646, retained the provisions of the Great Ming Law relating to "the smuggling of foreigners and the violation of the law of the sea".

Wang Liping (Chinese: 王麗萍; pinyin: Wáng Liping; born August 6, 1962) is a Taiwanese politician who was born in Yunlin County, Taiwan Province, and graduated from the Chinese Department of the National Political University. Wang Liping was elected to the 11th, 12th and 13th Yulin County Legislative Assembly at the age of 23, and subsequently served as a member of the 4th National Non-District Legislative Committee of the Communist Party of China. In 2006, he was dismissed from the Communist Party of China (CPC) as deputy leader of the Million People's Mutiny Movement, and remains a non-party member. For many years, she has spoken out for women's rights, serving as the president of the Yunlin County Women's Youth Business Association, the chairman of the Yunlin County Women's Rights Promotion Association, the chairman of the Taiwan Women's Senate Association, and the current chairman of the Sister Sirius Radio Station. In 1979, when the United States broke off relations with the Republic of China, Wang was a second-year student at Hongren Girls Middle and High School, and called for the whole class to write a large-scale poster on Zhongshan Road in Chiayi City, protesting the U.S. government's rejection of Taiwan. In 1983, Wang was listed as an out-of-party activist student and was interviewed by a political unit. After graduating from the National University of Political Science in 1985, he was appointed editor of Zheng Nanrong's "Liberty Times Weekly". In 1986, at the age of 23, he was elected to Yunlin County Council, the youngest county councillor in Taiwan's history, and served three terms. In 1987, he supported the "Egaishidai Dokkan Island March". In 1988, he joined the Taiwan Agricultural Rights Association as an executive. After the 520 farmers' movement, the parliament organized a support group, demanding the innocence of the detained farmers Lin Guohua, Qiu Hongxue, and so on, and asked the Lee Teng-hui government to respond to the five petitions, to the farmers' change.

Zhu Baede (Chinese: 朱培德; October 6, 1889 – February 17, 1937), also known as Yunnan Lufeng or Yunnan Lufeng, was a general of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA), the commander of the Guangzhou Guards, the commander of the Third Army of the National Revolutionary Army (NRA), the president of Jiangxi Province (February 1927), the chief of staff, the fifth Central Executive Committee of the Kuomintang (KMT), and a member of the Central Political Committee (CPC). He died on February 17, 1937, in a medical accident. His ancestor, Zhu Huafu (朱化孚), was an envoy to Guangzhou in the Ming Dynasty, and his father, Zhu Bingkun (朱秉坤), was a senior official in the Qing Dynasty, serving as the head of Guantong (now part of Lufeng County) Monkey Salt Well Mountain, accompanied by his family. He graduated from the first class of Kunming Military Academy in Yunnan, and Zhu De, who later became the Marshal of the People's Republic of China, was one of his classmates. In 1917, he joined Sun Yat-sen's defense of the law, becoming one of the main forces of the Guangdong faction: 171. After the establishment of the National Government in July 1925, the department was reorganized into the Third Army of the National Revolutionary Army, with the rank of commander: 171. During the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army, he served as Chairman of the Jiangxi Provincial Government. After the national reunification, he served as a member of the National Government, Chief of Staff of the General Staff Headquarters, Director of the Office of the Military Committee, Director of the Department of Training, Director of the Department of Training, etc.: 171. On January 1, 1937, Chiang Kai-shek met in Nanjing with Zhu Baede, the head of the Military Commission Office, Gu Zhutong, the head of the Chongqing Camp, Xiong Shihui, the head of the Jiangxi Provincial Government, Zhu Shaolin, the head of the Gansu Suijing Public Administration, and Lin Ul, the head of the General Staff Headquarters.

The Battle of Imphal was a battle fought by the Imperial Japanese Army against British India during World War II, which lasted from March 1944 to July 1944. During this operation, the Japanese army, commanded by Lieutenant General Yasuo Mutaguchi, aimed to capture the northeastern Indian town of Inpal. Of the remaining 90,000 soldiers, only about 10,000 survived, of whom 32,000 were killed, and most of the remaining tens of thousands died of starvation or disease during the retreat. The main cause of such heavy losses was the departure from reality and irresponsible operational planning and evasion of command responsibilities of Commander Mutaguchi, which is still regarded as a standard military disaster; in Japan, the use of the Inpal to describe someone doing something has become synonymous with "recklessness". In August 1942, the South Vietnamese Army launched an offensive against India, known as Operation 21 in addition to recruiting supporters in Burma and elsewhere who hoped to use the opportunity of the Great East Asia War to achieve Indian independence. The initial plan for Operation 21 was to use the main force of the 15th Army's 18th Division, with a combined strength of about two divisions, to bring troops to India and Burma, with the main task of cutting off the Allies' Chiang Kai-shek route and weakening the country's war capabilities. In October 1942, the British launched an exploratory offensive from the western coast of Burma, the Arakan Campaign 1942–43, followed by the airborne infiltration of the Chindits on the eastern bank of the Chindit River in central Burma.

However, Bahrain's economy is not solely dependent on oil; it has invested heavily in the development of finance and tourism since the late 20th century. The capital, Manama, is home to major financial institutions both within and outside the country. Bahrain has a high Human Development Index, ranked 44th in the world, and is recognized as a high-income economy by the World Bank. In 2001, Bahrain became a major non-NATO ally, and the U.S. Navy's Fifth Fleet Command was based in Manama, monitoring the Gulf and Indian Oceans at all times. Bahraini Bahrayn is the binary form of Bahr (sea), so al-Bahrayn means "both seas". The word appears five times in the Qur'an, but originally did not refer to the island of Bahrain, but to the Arabian Peninsula. Today, however, the two seas are generally referred to as the bays to the east and west of Bahrain. On 15 August 1971, the Grand Duchy of Bahrain, which had been ruled by the Al Khalifa family, declared its independence from the United Kingdom. The city was founded 3,000 years ago. The Phoenicians came here in 1000 BC. In the 7th century it became part of the province of Basra in the Arab Empire. Influenced by Arab culture, forming the current Muslim customs. It was occupied by the Portuguese in 1507–1602, and later by the Persian Empire. In 1783, he overthrew the Persian Empire and declared independence. The British invaded in 1820, and in 1892 it became a protectorate of the United Kingdom. In October 1940, during World War II, the Italian Air Force bombed Bahrain. In 1957, the British government declared Bahrain "an independent emirate under British protection". On 14 August 1971, Bahrain gained its independence from the United Arab Emirates.

The main reason for the zoning adjustment was the construction of the Huanglong Zi Zi Project in March 1990 in Gaoqing County to drain the Huanglong River. According to the literature, the Shandong region, centered on Zibo, was the main base of silk supply at that time, was one of the origins of the Silk Road. Today Zibo, as a producer of silk and light textiles, still occupies an important position in China. Zibo's agriculture is relatively small but has distinctive characteristics, and has now been built ten characteristic economic zones such as high-quality special grains, vegetables, fruit, mulberry silkworms, animal husbandry, freshwater aquaculture. The level of agricultural modernization is high, the level of integrated mechanization is 78%. Kantai County was the first "two thousand counties" in northern China (acreage producing 1,000 kilograms of grain, per acre earning 1,000 yuan); Gaoqing and Yiyuan respectively entered the national ranks of "hundred strong counties" of cotton and fruit production. The whole countryside is basically well-off. Since modern times Zibo has been an important industrial city in Shandong Province and even in China. In 1992 Zibo was selected as one of the "China's Top 50 Cities of Comprehensive Strength", and was ranked 47th on the list of "China's Top 100 Cities of Comprehensive Strength" published by the China Bureau of Statistics in 2005, and was rated as one of the "China's 50 Best Cities for Investment Environment". Its industry is dominated by petrochemicals, pharmaceuticals, building materials, textiles, ceramics and mechanical metallurgy. Famous enterprises include Qilu Petrochemical, Xinhua Medical, Xinhua Pharmaceutical, Hua Guang Ceramics, Wanjie Group, Lutai Company, Kokto Group, etc. Zibo is one of China's five porcelain capitals, Zibo porcelain was honored as "the third generation of national porcelain," entered the South China Sea, People's Assembly Hall, Diaoyutai National Hotel. At present, there are 332 ceramics manufacturing enterprises in the city, employing nearly 100,000 people. In 2003, Zibo's exports of ceramics reached more than 60 percent.

He said that, in the process of social movement reform, the most important thing is for the majority of the people to take control of the government, "by the people." He said that society doesn't need superheroes, that every citizen should be a superhero of his own, that "citizens' eyes are colorless, and they watch governments from time to time." Another coalition spokesman, Mr. Chen, said that the two events far exceeded expectations, except for thanks and appreciation, "This is a new page in the history of Taiwan's social development, a new page in the protests, a new page for all of us to write together. "I hope to awaken the consciousness of Taiwanese citizens, which is a great progress of Taiwanese society. "The Alliance hopes to blossom everywhere, through the power of the Internet, so that anyone can be the initiator, the spokesman, everyone can speak out for social injustice, everyone can stand up together against injustice. The Alliance hopes that by arousing a sense of citizenship and spirit, a model that goes beyond the traditional path, one can imagine one's own, based on how one defends the spirit of citizenship, and one's adherence to the principles of free democracy and human rights.

As a reward for his service to the Crown Prince, Prince Bao Bao was appointed Taifu (太傅) and Sajo (左丞相). In response to the rising power of Southern Zhu Yuanzhang, Yuan Hui Zong (元惠宗下) proclaimed Bao Bao as the king of Henan, the head of the army and horses. The king then ordered the four generals, including Li Shiqi, to surrender Guanzhong and confront Zhu Yuanzhang. However, because Li Shiqi and others were of the same rank as Khamenei's peers, they were older than Bao Bao Bao and had deeper qualifications, despised Bao Bao Bao and refused to obey his orders. The king sent his younger brother Dein Temur to defend Shandong against Zhu Yuanzhang, he himself went into Shaanxi to attack Li Siqi, the two sides fought for years, the Yuan Dynasty's attitude was uncertain, first supported the king, then supported Li Siqi, finally Yuan Huizong in the year of Hongwu (until 1368) ordered the removal of all official positions of the king, ordered all generals to attack the king. By this time, Zhu Yuanzhang had ascended to the throne, established the Ming Dynasty, changed Yuan Hongwu, Xu Da, and the Northern Expeditionary Army of Changchun had already approached the capital, and finally conquered the capital on September 14, 1368. In October of that year, Yuan Huizong, who fled to Kaiping (present-day Inner Mongolian County), re-appointed Wang Bao Bao as Qiang, ordered him to take back the capital from his base in northern Taiyuan, bypassing Ganmen Pass and Kuyong Pass (then renamed Beiping by Zhu Yuanzhang), Xu Da took advantage of Wang Bao Bao's opportunity to attack the capital, attacked Shanxi, defeated Wang Bao Bao under Taiyuan City, rescued Wang Bao Bao, and Wang Bao Bao left Taiyuan, and further withdrew from Siege. On May 23, 1370, Yuan Huizong died of illness, and Emperor Aiyu succeeded to the throne as Emperor Zhaozong, and Zhaozong proclaimed 1371 to be Xuan Guang, continuing the confrontation with the Ming Dynasty.

Although the secret clauses in the Treaty of Non-Aggression of the Soviet Union were exposed at the Nuremberg Trials after World War II, the Soviet Union denied the existence of these clauses. On the 50th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Non-Aggression of the Soviet Union, relations between the Baltic states and Moscow became increasingly strained. Ramos-Horta launched a two-million-strong joint protest in Lithuania, demanding the withdrawal of Soviet troops from the country. On 15 August, in response to the Estonian strike, the official Soviet media, Pravda, strongly condemned the "radicalists" for ignoring the overall interests of the Soviet Union, indulging in self-serving "narrow nationalism", and provoking "hysterical" mass actions. On 18 August, the Pravda newspaper published the views of Alexander Yakovlev, a member of the Politburo and secretary of the Central Secretariat of the Soviet Union, on documents such as the Soviet Treaty. Yakovlev was the chairman of the 26th Committee of the National Congress of the Soviet Union, which investigated the Soviet Treaty and secret documents. Inspired by the opening policies and economic reforms of Mikhail Gorbachev, General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, street demonstrations became increasingly popular and supported. On August 23, 1986, 21 Western cities (including London, Stockholm, Seattle, Los Angeles, Perth, and Washington, D.C.) held Black Ribbon Day marches, demanding that the world condemn the Soviet Union's human rights violations. On Black Ribbon Day 1987, 36 cities held demonstrations, including Vilnius, Lithuania. In the same year, Estonian Tallinn and Latvian Riga also held demonstrations against the Treaty of Non-Aggression of the Soviet Union. In 1988, for the first time, the Soviet government approved these demonstrations, without arresting the demonstrators.

The parliament is divided into two chambers, the Senate and the National Assembly, both of which have legislative powers. The Senate has 66 seats, 60 of which are indirectly elected by district electoral commissions, six of which are reserved for the Prüm region, for a six-year term, re-elected by lot every three years; the National Assembly has 153 seats, directly elected, for a five-year term, re-electable. The president and both houses of parliament share the power to legislate, but the president has no power to dissolve parliament, nor does the National Assembly have the power to remove the president or impeach the government. If there is a vacancy in the presidency, the Speaker of the Senate fills the vacancy. The current president is Denis Sassou-Nguesso. The current constitution was adopted in a referendum on January 20, 2002, making it the eighth constitution in the country's history. The party was founded on 31 December 1969 by the late President Marion Ngongi as the Communist Party of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. In 1990, Marxism-Leninism was abandoned and the Open Party was banned. The party withdrew from the opposition between the 1992 multi-party elections and the end of the civil war in October 1997. The country is divided into 12 provinces and one city: Congo is in the Midwest of Africa. To the east and south, it is bordered by the Congo River and its tributaries, the Ubangi River, and is adjacent to the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It borders Gabon in the west and Cameroon and the Central African Republic in the north. Southwest is Angola. The Atlantic coastline is shorter. The capital, Brazzaville, is on the Congo River, adjacent to Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of the Congo. It's in the Congo Basin in the north, about 200 to 300 meters above sea level, a marshland; in the south it's a plateau, 500 to 1,000 meters above sea level, with narrow lowlands along the coast.

Specific deployment: To ensure the smooth conduct of the operation, the Field Command, under the auspices of Liu and Deng, convened a meeting of operations to determine the plan for the three-stage implementation of the Yubei Campaign. The first step was to destroy the Yellow River railway bridge and the Zhengxin section of the Han–Chinese Railway, to destroy the army's defense system, and then to march into Xinxiang, to mobilize the support of the enemy's Wang Zhonglian, and to destroy the army's vital force in the campaign. The second step, avoiding the advantageous national army, bypassed the northern Tangyin, Anyang area, occupied the Pinghan Road Anyang and Qi county sections and vast areas west of the Wei River, opened the battlefield here, lured Wang Zhonglian northward, in the campaign to destroy the national army. The third step is to conquer Tangyin and destroy Sun Temple. On 30 March, the Liberation Army began to advance towards Qi County, attacking the garrisoned National Army 32nd Division. On 2 April, the Liberation Army launched an attack on the enemy garrison in Qi County, capturing Dongguan and the outer perimeter on the same day, killing more than 5,000 defenders. At this time, Gu Zhuo sent a telegram to Wang Zhonglian, a brigade from Wuhan to the 9th Division, from Huang Henan to the 66th Division, from Qi County to the 41st Division, from Jiao Zhao to the 3rd Division and so on, and quickly reinforced Qi County. On April 3, the Liberation Army withdrew from the Qi County area. After the Liberation Army withdrew from the county, they attacked from the north on the same day. By April 10, they had occupied Qi County, Zhucun, Yigou, Hebei, and Chuwang, and annihilated the 1st, 2nd, and 3rd armies of the Henan province, destroying about 10,000 people, and destroying the Anyang to Qi County section of Pinghan Road, and the west side of Pinghan Road to the west of the Wei River were occupied by the Jin Jiluo and Jin Jiluo field armies, and their forerunners pushed against Anyang. After being severely reprimanded, Wang led two brigades of the 66th Division, one brigade of the 41st Division, one regiment of the 40th Division and the 2nd Rapid Brigade (i.e., the 49th Brigade) and the 32nd Rapid Northern Infantry Division, but was soon repulsed by the PLA.

The game uses a new generation of Frost 1.0 engine developed by EA DICE, which significantly improves graphics while also supporting larger-scale destruction—most buildings, items, and trees can be destroyed in the game. It is a single-player action-adventure game that tells the story of a group of soldiers fleeing the battlefield in search of gold. The game sold 1.6 million copies in one month. Battlefield: Heroes is the seventh installment in the Battlefield series, released on June 25, 2009. The game is the first web game in the series, and the only third-person shooter with a highly cartoonized graphic style. The game only supports up to 16 simultaneous online battles. With Battlefield: Heroes, the total number of registered players has grown to over two million. Battlefield: Heroes blocked IP in Hong Kong, Macau and China, where players could only play through agents. Battlefield 1943, the eighth installment in the Battlefield series, was released for the Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 on July 8, 2009, but was delayed until 2011. The game is the first paid downloadable minigame in the series, with maps and weapons all ported from Battlefield 1942, but recreated using the brand-new Frost 1.5 engine. The game broke the record for "first-day sales" and "first-week sales" for Xbox 360 and PS3 downloads, surpassing one million copies six weeks after its release.

Suffering (Sanskrit:दु:ख, Romanized:duḥkha, Pali:dukkha) is a Buddhist term meaning pain, anxiety, dissatisfaction, etc. It's one of the most fundamental teachings of Buddhism, one of the four truths. The Sanskrit word duḥkha, commonly translated as "pain", or "pain meaning" (as one of the four meanings), from Sanskrit semantics, means "anxious" or "unsettled". It can correspond to modern descriptions of such emotions as "pain," "sadness," "anxiety," "discontent," and "depression." To suffer means to suffer, to be unhappy, or to be miserable. The dissatisfaction of the heart is because of the circle of the heart, the circle without end, the thought without end, the thought of the past, the thought of the future, the thought of the present, and so on. Thoughts are stirred up by dissatisfaction, and at the same time, just like dissatisfaction, they often repeatedly feel what is lacking in life, that there are always places that are not right, that are not enough, and so they always want to make up for the shortcomings, to tidy up the situation so that they can have a little more comfort. Continuing to struggle and to concentrate is very annoying and painful; when one enjoys pleasure, one is afraid of losing it, and strives to seek more pleasure, or to preserve it; when one suffers, one strives to escape from suffering; and one is always dissatisfied, so that all one's activities do not always contain the components of dissatisfaction and pain. Buddhism believes that all existence is suffering. Life is full of suffering and joy, but what makes it hard to endure are the irregularities. Life, old age, and sickness are what all beings have to do, and the "I" is made up of five substances and spirits, but is a short-lived and accidental product, not a lasting, abiding, eternal thing. The truth of suffering is that when we turn around in the three realms, we see that there is suffering in the three realms, and that there is pain in the outer and in the inner.

Taiwan–Gambia relations refers to the relations between the Republic of China and the Republic of Gambia. The two countries had formal diplomatic relations between 1968 and 1974, and between 1995 and 2013, but after the break-up of diplomatic relations, there are no diplomatic missions in each other's capitals. It is administered by the Northeastern Trade Office of the Federal Republic of Nigeria. Contacts between the Republic of China and the Gambia began in 1960. On November 12, 1968, Gambia and the Republic of China established diplomatic relations. On November 5, 1969, the Embassy of the Republic of China in Bangkok was established. On 14 December 1974, the Gambia and the People's Republic of China signed the Communiqué of Establishment. On 28 December, the Republic of China broke off relations with the Gambia. On December 30, the embassy in Gambia closed. On 13 July 1995, after the 1994 Gambian coup d'état, Yahya Jammeh became the ruler of the Republic of China. The Embassy of the Republic of the Gambia in Taipei was reopened on 21 July 1996, and the Embassy of the Republic of the Gambia in the Republic of China opened in Taipei in June 1996. On November 14, 2013, Gambia's President Mwai Kibaki announced a unilateral decision to sever ties with the Republic of China based on "national strategic interests", stating that "I feel that Taiwan no longer needs us". On 18 November, the Government of the Republic of China decided to terminate diplomatic relations with the Gambia on the grounds of preserving the dignity of the country and the principle of diplomatic life, and to remove the embassy, technical staff and all bilateral cooperation projects.

Proterozoic comes from the Greek root protero-, meaning earlier; and zoic-, meaning animal. The oxygen content of the atmosphere gradually increased in the early Paleozoic, but it was not very high until the depletion of surface reductive substances such as iron and sulfur oxides. Two and a half billion years ago, there was only one to two percent oxygen in the atmosphere. This process continued until the barbed-iron deposition stopped, and it wasn't until the crust oxidized 850 million years ago that the oxygen content in the atmosphere began to rise dramatically. This period has seen the discovery of many mycorrhizal, algal and ancient microbial fossils, hence the term mycorrhizal age. At the end of the Eocene, the Ediacaran bioburst, the emergence of large numbers of soft-bodied multicellular organisms, the emergence of gastropods, linked animals and arthropods, but these animals didn't have hard bones, so the fossils left only marks and things like that. There was a global Great Ice Age in the middle of the Pleistocene, and glacial remains have been found all over the world, like the Ice Age in the late Pleistocene to the Ice Age in the Ice Age of Snowball Earth. There were at least four global ice ages in Neolithic times, such as the Marinean glaciation and the Stewart glaciation. Extensive crustal movements also occurred in prehistoric times, when the Earth was undergoing major mountain building.

James Bradley first attempted to measure stellar parallax in 1729. He used telescopes to prove that the motion of the stars was negligible, but he found aberrations in the path of light, the motion of the Earth's axis, and he edited a table of 3222 stars. The most common measure of stellar parallax is the annual parallax, defined as the difference in angle between the positions of stars seen from Earth and the Sun, i.e., the difference in the diagonal of the average radius of a star in Earth's orbit around the Sun. One parsec (3.26 light-years) is defined as a distance of one arcsecond from the annual parallax. Annual parallax is a measurement of the position of a star that is observed at different times of the year, moving through Earth's orbit. Annual parallax measurements were the first reliable measurement of the closest distance to a star. The first successful measurement of stellar parallax was that of 61 Cygnus by Berserl in 1838. Due to the difficulty of measurement, by the end of the 19th century only about 60 stellar aberrations had been observed, and most of them were using filament microscopes. In the early 20th century, astronomical cameras using astronomical photographic plates accelerated this process. Automatic film measurements and more sophisticated computer technology in the 1960s made the pairing of stars more efficient. In the 1980s, photosensitive coupled components (CCDs) replaced photographic film, reducing uncertainty to a thousandth of an arcsecond. Stellar parallax is still the standard for calibrating other measurements (see Cosmic Distance Scale). Distance calculations based on stellar parallax require very precise measurements of the distance between the Earth and the Sun, now based on radar reflections from the planet's surface.

The Channel Islands (French: Îles de la Manche, English: Channel Islands), also known as the Anglo-Norman Islands (French: Îles Anglo-Normandes), are an archipelago in the English Channel, about 10 nautical miles (10 km) from Normandy in northern France. The entire archipelago is divided into two administrative regions: the Kansai Region and the Jersey Region. Although often misunderstood as British (United Kingdom) territory, the Channel Islands are actually British royal territory, with sovereignty vested directly in the British Crown rather than part of the United Kingdom. The origins of the Channel Islands can be traced back to the 10th and 12th centuries, when the Duchy of Normandy ruled northern France and William I of Normandy conquered England and became King of England in 1066. Following the invasion of Normandy by King Philip II of France in 1204, the Channel Islands were not reclaimed by France, but continued to be controlled by the British. In 933, the islands were annexed by the Duchy of Normandy. In 1066, William the Conqueror of Normandy invaded and conquered England, becoming King of England. From 1204 onwards, the king of England lost part of the Norman continent to the Hundred Years' War. This meant that the Channel Islands were separated from the Duchy of Normandy and ruled by the King of England. The entire archipelago is divided into two administrative regions: the Kansai Region and the Jersey Region. The two administrative regions have been separated from each other since the late 13th century. Those who are unfamiliar with these islands may think that they belong to the same administrative unit.

For a long time, a large population of speakers, combined with global popularity, made English an international language. Today, English is indispensable for cultural exchange, information dissemination, commercial activities, and international diplomacy. Modern English originated in England during the Elizabethan era, during the creation of the British poet William Shakespeare. Under British colonial rule, English was used throughout the world, for example in the United States, India and Australia. As Britain established colonies in North America, Asia, and Africa, English language, customs, and ideas spread throughout the world. It is part of the Columbian Exchange. Early modern English did not have a unified spelling, and by 1755, Dr. Samuel Johnson had published a dictionary in England, defining the key word standard spelling. In addition, Noah Webster published a dictionary in the United States in 1828. In the 19th century, as public education and public libraries became more widespread, people had more opportunities to read books, and to interact in standard languages. Through trade and settlement, many people were exposed to foreign cultures, and with the influx of immigrants to the United States, foreign languages were introduced into English. After World War I and World War II, people from different backgrounds assembled in a short space of time, and social mobility intensified, invisibly narrowing the differences in social accents, particularly in the United States. In the early 20th century, radio broadcasting developed, and people became more familiar with foreign accents and vocabulary, some of which they had never heard before. This phenomenon is still seen today in film and television.

In terms of religious population, Taiwanese folk religion is the largest religious population in Taiwan. Buddhism and Taoism are the two major religions of Taiwan. According to the U.S. Department of State's 2003 International Religious Freedom Report, there are 454.6 million Taoists in Taiwan, most of whom belong to the Taiwanese folk faith, which is recognized as " Taoism". The report even states at the end of the page, "If the worship of ancestors, witchcraft, ghosts and other deities and animal worship were included in this belief, the number of Taiwanese folk beliefs would be as high as 80% of the nation's population." Most Taiwanese believe in both Buddhism and Taoism. This fusion of Buddhist and Taoist civil religions has maintained a strong influence on social life, and various sacred festivals are held throughout the country. Each of these festivals had many folk activities, and the attendance was up to two or three days, or even longer. In Taiwan, there is a saying, "March mad mother, April meets the king," and other local Shinto beliefs are as follows: the moon, moon, stars, wind, rain, lightning, four squares, four colors, four days, four nights, mountains, rivers, lakes, flowers, trees, dragon, fox, snake, and ancient stone. There are few other religious saints in the region, such as Moses, Jesus, Muhammad, and other saints of the Abrahamic religions. Few temples, however, worship these monotheistic gods or saints, because their monotheistic beliefs can only believe in one god, and cannot accommodate or accept polytheistic beliefs.

Jin opera is an important genre of drama in northern China, and is found in northern central Shanxi, central Inner Mongolia, northern Shaanxi, and western Hebei provinces, mostly in the Jin dialect of Yuzhou, Lüliang, Zhanghui, and parts of Dabao and Wutai. Because it originated in the middle of Shanxi Province, it is also called Zhonglu Bangzi, also called Shanxi Bangzi, in addition, Jin opera in the Zhangjiakou area is also called "mouth Bangzi." It originated in the middle and late Qing dynasties in the Jinzhong area. It was founded by the Puzhou Bangzi, which combined the folk songs of the Jin Dynasty, seedling songs of the middle road, skin shadows and other forms of music. It's divided into five rows: red, black, green, brown, and ugly. The melody is gentle, flowing, the melody is graceful, smooth, affectionate, clear, with a strong rural flavor of the Jinzhong region and its own unique style. It's not easy to distinguish them, but I'll just mention the influential figures: Wang Zhengkai, Kim Se-yao, Hao Tei, Zhang Jia-sheng, Feng Jizhong, Li Shangguang, Wang Chunkai, and so on. "Dai Jinzhi", "Lingtong Mountain", "King Kun Belt", "Sada Guo", "Bai Wan City", "Bai Sui Beach", "King Sui Bridge", "Fire foal", "Van Wang Palace" Zhang Bao Kai, Ding Guo Xian, Zhang Meiqin, Gui Gui Gui Ying, Guo Feng Ying, Ji Meilin, Cheng Yue Ying, Hua Yanjun, Liang Xiaoyun, Guo Lan Ying, Yan Hui Zhen, Wu Zhong, Liu Baozhun, Ma Yu Lou, Wang Ai Ai Ai, Wang Wanmei, Cheng Guilin, Tian Gui Lan, She Tao, Hu Chang'e, Miao Jie, Song Chang Chang, Chen Chang Ying, Wang Xiaoping, Zhang Mingqin, Li Yue Xian, Guo Caiping, Yan Fei Yu, Jia Hua, etc. See: Inner Mongolia intangible cultural heritage representative list See: Hebei intangible cultural heritage representative list See: Shanxi intangible cultural heritage representative list.

Linfen City, formerly known as Pingyang and Jinzhou, is a city in Shanxi Province of the People's Republic of China, located in the southwestern part of the province, on the eastern bank of the Yellow River, named for its proximity to the Fen River. The city borders the southern junction city, the southeastern neighboring Jin City, the northeastern border Changzhi City, the northern Da Jinzhong City, Lüliang City, the western boundary of the Yellow River and Yan'an City, Weinan City in Shaanxi Province. It lies to the southeast of the Loess Plateau, to the east of Mt. Taidake and Mt. Chujo, to the middle of the Fen River Basin and to the west of Mt. Lüliang. From north to south, the Fen River runs through the entire province, and the Qin River flows through the eastern part of the province. The city has a total area of 20,302 square kilometers, a population of 443,57 million, and the city's people's government is located in Yaotou District. Linfen has a long history, is an important birthplace of Chinese people and the cradle of the Yellow River civilization, has been called "China's first capital." Linfen is an important grain and cotton production base in northern China, rich in wheat, cotton, etc., has the reputation of "the town of cotton and wheat" and "the land of plum blossoms"; the city has formed a multi-industry system, is an important component of the construction of new energy and industrial base in Shanxi Province; the city is rich in natural resources, is one of the three major coking coal bases of high quality in China; the city has a variety of intangible cultures, there are many folk art forms such as Puzhou Bangzi, Weifeng Causeway Drum, and is known as "the town of plum blossoms", "the town of paper cutting" and "the town of causeway drum". Linfen is one of the birthplaces of the Huaxia ethnic group, and the Emperor's Century calls it "Yao Tu Pingyang", which is now Linfen. "Ugon" divides the land into Kyushu and Pingyang into Hezhou. It is located in the center of Kyushu, hence the name "China," from which the word "China" is derived. In the West Zhou period, Zhou Chengwang's younger brother, Shugyu in Tang (present-day Wing City), because there is a Jin River in Tang, Shugyu's son Xiefa "yi Tang for Jin".

With the gradual siltation of the Great Lakes region recorded by the Iwo Jima in 1697, these submerged civilizations and crops, which had not yet been reclaimed by the people of Kedah, were regarded as landless, leading to the settlement of the Zhangzhou immigrants of the Qing Dynasty. The conflict escalated. Along the waterfront, settlers from Zhangzhou and the Kaida clan gradually formed Han-style Kaida clan chiefdoms through conflict and cooperation, such as Azui in Banqiao Harbor (now Jiangsu Province), Sashi Island in Sashi Province, Shilan Castle (also translated into Zhangzhou as "Chinatown" for Kaida clans), Shipai clan (石牌庄, 里岸社) and so on. From 1745 to 1748, he was a member of the Board of the Freshwater Hall, where he said that in order to avoid disputes and determine the boundaries of the two sides, he had established the Hangban Boundary Monument (漢番界碑). Even in 1859, the old forest of Shiran Castle was destroyed by fire, and today's old forest, the new forest, is an area that has flourished with the reclaiming of water. Nowadays, apart from Chengdu Road, the expropriated land belonging to the original Banqiao Forest lineage has also gradually developed away from the agricultural type of fields.
