Heian (14th century? – 1409), Xiaoji Bao, a southern direct vassal of Fengyangfu Chuzhou (now Chuzhou City, Anhui Province), a general of the Ming Dynasty Emperor Jianwen, had repeatedly assaulted Zhu Di at the Battle of Jingning, Zhu Di pardoned Heian after his accession, and was also appointed as "the governor of the affairs", but a few years later he remembered Heian, and forced him to die. His father's name was Pingding, and he joined the army of the great ancestor of the Ming Dynasty, Zhu Yuanzhang, and commanded Jiningwei, and died in the Battle of Beiyuandu in the spring. Heian was a son of Ming Dynasty ancestors, succeeded his father, was promoted to Miyun commander, and was promoted to the right-wing military governor. In 1399, Pingan was the vanguard of Li Jinglong's army, ambushed Zhu Di, King of Yan, and the two sides fought until dusk, killing each other. In the middle of the night, both sides withdraw their troops. Chu Di lost his way, only three followers, and went down to the east and west to find the camp. The next day, the battle resumed, and Ping defeated Fan Guang and Chen Hengbu. Zhu Di sees the situation urgently, personally engages in a stone warfare, after the horse's arrows are exhausted, the sword can not be attacked. On the embankment, he pretended to whip the rear horse to confuse the South Central Army. At this point, just in time for Zhu's rescue, Zhu Difang escaped the danger and was forced to return to the north. Later, Zhu Di again went south, besieged Jinan City, camped Heian at a single bridge, and plotted to attack Yan's boats, and besieged Texas, eventually resolving the siege of Jinan, and then with Wu Jie in Dingzhou to station troops. The next year, the Yan troops defeated the Song Yong, and the retreating troops attacked a single bridge. The enemy attacked and captured the town. Then, on the Yellow River, the Yan army was defeated again. In the ensuing skirmish, the enemy fired heavy artillery rounds at the enemy positions, killing and wounding the enemy soldiers. After the defeat of the Ottoman army by the Ottomans and the capture of the city by the Ottomans, the Ottomans were forced to retreat.

The National Rural Revitalization Administration (Chinese: 国家乡村振兴局; pinyin: Zhōngxīn Zhōngxīn Zhōngxīn) is a state agency under the State Council of the People's Republic of China that is responsible for rural revitalization, and is currently administered by the Ministry of Agriculture and Rural Development. On December 22, 1982, in order to accelerate the construction of the Gansu Hexi Corridor commodity and grain base, to change the poverty face of the Gansu Dingxi and Ningxia West Haikou regions, the State Council decided to establish the Leading Group for Agricultural Construction in the Three West (Hexi, Dingxi, West Haikou) regions. The headquarters of the group is located in the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries of the People's Republic of China, which is responsible for day-to-day operations. On May 16, 1986, the State Council established the Leading Group for the Economic Development of Poverty-stricken Areas under the State Council's Leading Group for the Economic Development of Poverty-stricken Areas (Development Office), responsible for day-to-day work, located in the Ministry of Agriculture, Livestock and Fisheries of the People's Republic of China. On July 18, 1988, the State Council decided to merge the Leading Group for Economic Development of Poverty-stricken Areas of the State Council with the Leading Group for Agricultural Construction of the "Three Wests" Area into the Leading Group for Economic Development of Poverty-stricken Areas of the State Council. The Office of the Leading Group for Economic Development of Poverty-stricken Areas of the State Council (Development Office) is located in the Ministry of Agriculture of the People's Republic of China. At the same time, it retained the "Three West" district office, and the offices of the Development Office.

On the left, the British army uncle Colonel with the 26th Cameronian Regiment of Foot, 55th Regiment of Foot, landed from Chenshanzui, Tangjiawan, encountered the Qing army Chiang Ching Li Ting Gui, Zhang Huai Sabi with 376 soldiers.

Xidan Theater is one of the old theaters in the western district of Beijing, which has a history of eighty years. Its predecessor was the Hall Fei Grand Theater, Zuiyuan Teahouse, Great Light Cinema, which was famous for the earthquake in Beijing. After 1949, it was converted into the present Xidan Theater by public-private partnership. The company was founded on September 14, 1930, and took its name from the English word "Happy", which was misspelled "Haipy" by the manager. It was the first semi-circular theatre in the city, the stage and auditorium lighting were all lit, and there were services such as an audience lounge, a vending machine, etc. It was the most westernized and most advanced theatre in the city at the time. It was the only theatre in the western part of Beijing, and was one of the most violent theatres in Beijing from its opening until the Lugou Bridge Incident in 1937. Halfey performed mainly at Peking Opera, interspersed with other theaters, to suit the audience's tastes. Many renowned pear gardeners such as Ma Liang, Zhou Xinfang, Mei Lanfang, Yang Xiaolou, Cheng Yanqiu, Shang Xiaoyun, Xun Huijun, Gao Qingqiu, Li Taoqiu, Du Liyun, Diamond, White Jade Frost and so on have long or short cooperation with Hal Fei. In addition to traditional drama programs, modern performing arts such as drama and dance are also frequently performed in Halfei. At that time, the more famous Yitzchi Baihua New Theatre Company and Shanghai Mingzhen Opera and Ballet Company performed in Halfei. Most of the performances were newly composed dramas, musicals and dance programs that responded to the spirit of science and democracy, and caused a stir in society.

Moktar Ould Daddah (Arabic:مختار ولد داداه ; 25 December 1924 – 14 October 2003) was the first President of Mauritania after independence from France in 1960. Dadakh came from a wealthy family, and his father was the head of the Muslim Archdiocese of Butilimet. He studied at the École des Beaux-Arts and the École des Beaux-Arts in Saint-Louis, Senegal, where he worked as a translator for six years. In 1948, he went to France to study law in Nice, where he graduated from the University of Paris School of Law and the National School of Oriental Languages, receiving a bachelor's degree. After returning to the country in the 1950s, he joined the Progressive Union of the Centre-Left, was elected to the territorial legislature in 1957, and was appointed deputy prime minister of the "semi-autonomous republic" and minister of youth, sports and education. In 1958, the Progressive Alliance merged with the Consultative Party to form the United Party of Mauritania, with Dadakh as General Secretary. He was in a relationship with his wife Mariam Dadakh. In 1959, the Union Party was reorganized as the Mauritanian People's Party, and he became party leader. In the elections of the same year, the People's Party became the first parliamentary party, and Dadakh was nominated as Prime Minister and Minister of the Interior of the Autonomous Government. Following Mauritania's independence from France in 1960, Dadakh served as Prime Minister of Mauritania and as Minister of Defence and Foreign Affairs. In August 1961, Dadakh was elected as the first president. During this period, the failure of the war in Western Sahara was widely questioned. In July 1978, the army's chief of staff, General Mustafa al-Salek, staged a military coup d'état, in which he was overthrown and arrested.

In astronomical dynamics, any orbit of an architecture under the standard hypothesis must be the shape of a conical tangent. The eccentricity of the cone section, the orbital eccentricity, is an important parameter in defining the orbital shape, and it defines the absolute shape. The eccentricity can be explained by the degree to which the shape deviates from the circle. Under the standard hypothesis, the eccentricity ( eccentricity, e {\displaystyle e\,\!} ) is a strict definition of circles, ellipses, parabolas, and hyperbolas, and has the following values: the eccentricity e {\displaystyle e} of an ellipse is the angle projection of the circle. For example, the eccentricity of Mercury is (0.2056), and a simple calculation of the inverse function of the sine yields a projection angle of 11.86 degrees, and then if you look at any circular object (such as a coffee cup seen from above) from that angle of inclination, the ellipse you see in your eye will have the same eccentricity. For example, Earth's current orbital eccentricity is 0.0167, but due to gravitational attraction between planets, it slowly becomes closer to zero over time, with a maximum value of about 0.05. (Please refer to (back up the page, in the Internet Archive)). In other measurements, Mercury's eccentricity (0.2056) is the highest of any planet in the Solar System. In the 2006 redefinition of the planet, the dwarf planet Pluto had a larger eccentricity of about 0.248, and the Moon had a remarkable eccentricity of 0.0554.

There are also Chinese words for "class", "class", and "social class", according to Marxist theory, that refer to social groups with the same or similar economic levels and social identities. The term "class" is used in many historical or political contexts to refer to "multiple social groups with different identities, different statuses, wealth, forms of work, lifestyles, or other social, economic, or cultural factors, of different ideologies, etc." Most theories of class are based on the notion that societies are divided and antagonistic groups, and that the antagonisms between groups place societies in perpetual conflict. Marxism-Leninism holds that class has never existed, as the earliest primitive societies did not have the underlying factors for the emergence of class because of their excessively low productivity. It is generally assumed that the emergence of a class occurs after a certain degree of productivity has been attained, such as when a slightly larger society begins to have a division of labor phenomenon, and that it will inevitably die out in another extremely productive society (e.g., a capitalist society extinguishes a feudal society). The earliest classes occurred during the slavery era — the slaveholder class and the slave class. Marxism's most classical definition of class comes from Lenin: class, that is, such large groups as these, which have different positions in a certain historical system of social production, different relations of occupation of the means of production (which are largely prescribed by law), different functions in the organization of social labour, and thus different ways and quantities of the social wealth which they control.

Yuncheng, anciently known as Hedong, is a city in Shanxi Province of the People's Republic of China, located in the southwestern part of Shanxi Province, in the Qin, Jin and Yu Yellow River Golden Delta. It is bordered by Linfen City in the north, Jincheng City in the east, Jiyuan City in Henan Province, Luoyang City in the south, Sanmenxia City in Henan Province, and Weinan City in Shaanxi Province on the west. It's located in the southeastern part of the Loess Plateau, in the Yuncheng Basin between Mt. Lüliang, Mt. Taidake and Mt. Chujo. The Fen River flows into the Yellow River in the northern part of the city limits, and the Xishui River runs from the northeast to the southwest across the city limits. The total area of the city is 14,183 square kilometers, the permanent population is 473.32 people, the city's people's government in the Salt Lake District. It is an important birthplace of the Huaxia civilization, and in the study of history, Sun's capital Buhan and U's capital Yangcheng are considered to be in the present-day Yuncheng territory. Archaeological finds suggest that the city may have been the site of a battle between the Yellow Emperor and the Flaming Emperor Hanquan. About 1.8 million years ago, there was human activity here. Shunto Pozaka, Utsunomiya-jo Castle, and the capital of the summer are all here. In the spring and autumn period, it belonged to the state of Jin, and the state of Jin was established in Jiang (present-day Jiang County) in 669 BC. Qin Shi Huang reunified China, She 36 county, Yuncheng belonged to Hedong county, Jisho Anhui county. For more than two thousand years, it was frequently built, but it has always been known as the "East River." Ming and Qing dynasties, for Shanxi. At the end of the Yuan Dynasty, due to the government's operation of the salt industry, the Department of Shipping Shipments was established. For administrative purposes, the settlement was moved from the city of Liuzhou to Lu Village (or Road Village). At the end of the year, the village was renamed St. Mary's. In 1356, when Nahedin was appointed as a salt envoy, he began to build the city, first named Phoenix City, because it was the seat of the salt shipping division, and later renamed Shipping City.

Suzhou has a written history of more than 4,000 years, and the officially recognized founding history of more than 2,500 years, is one of the oldest existing cities in China, one of the birthplaces of Jiangnan Wu culture. Suzhou is one of the largest cities in the country with the approval of the State Council to enjoy local legislation, the most important economic center in the northern wing of the Yangtze River Delta Economic Circle, and the most developed and modern city in Jiangsu Province. Suzhou is rich in culture, one of the first 24 national historic and cultural capitals of the People's Republic of China, one of the 10 key scenic tourism cities of the country, one of the first excellent tourism cities of China. Suzhou is one of the origins of Wu culture, in the spring and autumn period was the second capital of Wu, the economic, political and cultural center, during the Qin and Han dynasties has the nickname of "Jiangdong metropolis." At the foot of the Lingyan Mountain in the east of the Yangtze River, Xu built the "Huxu City" (located in the present-day Wuzhong District, Suzhou City). Yang Wai-nyo (Chinese: 楊蕙如; pinyin: Yáng Wai-nyo; born January 15, 1978) is a Taiwanese Internet activist, politician, and member of the Democratic Progressive Party. She graduated from the Department of History, National Success University, Taito City, Taito Prefecture. He is credited as "The God of Cards" due to his use of credit card bonuses. A former sports agent, he became closely involved in politics after the 2008 presidential election. In May 2018, the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka was shut down by Typhoon Yanzi, and Yang was sentenced to a fine of 150,000 yuan by the Taiwan High Court for insulting civil servants. After graduating from high school, Yang Hui earned a fortune from China Trust Commercial Bank by using credit cards, online auctions, and TV shopping vouchers, which caused controversy, and was even labeled "card god" by the media.In 2004, he ordered a "one-yuan luxury suite" that was promoted by a hotel company over the Internet, and let his mother and uncle spend an unforgettable white Valentine's Day. In 2006, she became the host of the popular Chinese entertainment program "People's Hot Pot" (中天 Entertainment台 popularity program "全民大悶鍋") as well as the stock market celebrity "Zhang Guozhi" (張國志), and expressed her dissatisfaction to the media. However, the China Trust Commercial Bank, on the one hand, phoned her in a negotiating posture, and on the other hand, suspended her and her family's credit cards.

After the French Revolution, as one of the acts of abolishing the privileges of the nobility, the republican government imposed a right-of-way for vehicles and horses. Napoleon conquered many countries in Europe through war, and thus also introduced the right-handed custom to the Netherlands, Belgium, Luxembourg, Spain, Italy, Prussia (then unified Germany) and the Austrian Empire. But Britain, Portugal, the Russian Empire, Sweden, and others, which Napoleon had not conquered, still maintained a leftist tradition. For more than 100 years, that's what Europe's road rules have been like. In the English thirteen states of North America, the original rules of the road were left-hand drive, and after American independence, right-hand drive. A lorry driver, driven by up to 20 livestock, likes to drive on the right side of the road. In 1792, Pennsylvania passed a right-hand drive statute, and New York and New Jersey passed similar statutes in 1804 and 1813. The earliest car driver's seats were located in the center of the vehicle, and soon afterwards some car manufacturers placed driver's seats on the side of the centerline of the road in order to observe traffic on the opposite side of the road, while others placed driver's seats on the side of the road in order to avoid collisions with roadside fences, hedges, ditches, and other obstacles. Practical testing found that the former approach was more conducive to maintaining road safety, and thus became the norm for automobile manufacturers. This makes the difference between a left-hand drive (the driver's seat is in the left front of the vehicle) and a right-hand drive (the driver's seat is in the right front of the vehicle). Which side of the road the vehicle is on depends on the country's long-established traffic rules, which result in more detailed and strict road traffic regulations, and many countries determine the direction of the vehicle in the form of laws.

A medical officer is a member of the military who is responsible for the health, disease and accident prevention of members of the armed forces. Military doctors are trained to be able to accompany general troops and perform medical duties as soldiers at any time during the war. Military doctors in different countries have their own official special names. The Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) refers to itself as the Sanitary Corps or Sanitary Corps. In the Republic of China, military doctors are referred to as "medical officers", "medical nurses", "medical paramedics" or "medical paramedics". In the United States Army, medical personnel have been referred to as "68W" since December 2005. In the United States Navy and U.S. Marine Corps, it is known as the Marine Corps Medical Corps. In the British Army, medical officers are known as Combat Medical Technicians and are attached to the Royal Army Medical Corps. In the Japanese Self-Defense Forces, it's called "Eiseika." In the Republic of Korea, it is known as "Medical Corps" (의무병). According to the Geneva Conventions, all personnel on duty in combat rescue missions, including medical personnel, are required to wear a waterproof armband with the Red Cross or Red Crescent symbol on their left arm to protect their safety (see First Geneva Convention of 12 August 1949—Article 40 of the Geneva Convention for the Amelioration of the Condition of Wounded and Sick Persons in Armed Forces in the Field). Prior to the signing of the Geneva Conventions, in the European theatre of World War II, the Allies and the Nazis had an unwritten etiquette that neither side intentionally opened fire on medical personnel undergoing medical treatment.

When a patient dies with the help of a doctor, the term assisted suicide is often used. In Switzerland and the U.S. states of California, Oregon, Washington, Montana, and Vermont, assisted suicide is legal. Non-voluntary euthanasia is performed without the consent of the patient. Child euthanasia is illegal throughout the world, but the Netherlands has decriminalized it under the Groningen Protocol in certain specific circumstances. Passive forms of involuntary euthanasia (i.e., euthanasia) are legal in some countries under certain conditions. Involuntary euthanasia is against the wishes of the patient. Voluntary, non-voluntary, and non-voluntary euthanasia can be further divided into active and passive. In the Netherlands, for example, euthanasia must be performed at the individual request of the patient, and a doctor must prove that the patient is experiencing pain that cannot be alleviated or tolerated, and a consensus must first be reached between the doctor and the patient, confirming that euthanasia is their only option. Countries and territories that have legislation allowing for active euthanasia: Countries and territories that have legislation allowing for passive euthanasia: Countries and territories that have legislation allowing for assisted suicide Denmark passed the Provision of Wills Act in 1992, administered by the University of Copenhagen School of Medicine, and the Patients' Rights Act in 1998, confirming its binding nature.

The establishment of the Communist Party of Vietnam (Maoist) was facilitated by the Communist International Representative Ho Chi Minh (the leader of the Communist Party of Vietnam), at the time Ho Chi Minh (real name Nguyễn Bến Tông) called himself "阮愛國". Shortly after the establishment of the Communist Party of China, a trio of spies, known as the Communist International Representatives, were recruited and elected General Secretary. During the Japanese invasion of Malaya in December 1941, the Malayan People's Anti-Japanese Army was formed by the Malayan Communist Party under the auspices of the British Army, and the Malayan People's Anti-Japanese Army fought guerrilla warfare in the rear of the Japanese army, becoming one of the main anti-Japanese forces of the Japanese occupation of the Malayan Peninsula. The Communist Party of Malaya adopted the U.N. anti-Japanese policy, and the People's Anti-Japanese Army, led by the Communist Party of Malaya, grew to over 10,000 men, and controlled half of Malaya. After the Japanese surrender in 1945, the Communist Party of China began to engage in anti-colonial activities, strikes, strikes, increasingly strained relations with the British colonial government. In June 1948, three European heads of plantations in Perak and Phnom Penh were murdered, and the British colonial government declared several left-wing political parties, including the Communist Party of Malaya, illegal and banned them. Faced with the suppression of the British colonial government, the Communist Party of China decided to armed itself and launch a forest guerrilla war, and the Sixth World War broke out, and the whole country went into a state of emergency. In 1949, the Malayan National Liberation Army (later renamed the Malayan People's Army) was formed, and guerrilla warfare on the peninsula continued into the 1960s. In order to continue the armed struggle, the Communist Party of China was forced to relocate to the Thai border and established revolutionary bases in Budong, Sukhothai, Banglang and Yenha, respectively. In addition, the CPN(M) would occasionally send raiders south to search for food, and ambush the Malaysian government armed forces (at the time considered a puppet regime backed by the British colonists). In 1955, for the first time under British rule, the Commonwealth of Malaya was elected as a self-governing state, and negotiations were held between representatives of the Commonwealth of Malaya and the Commonwealth of Independent States in Walling County, North Majiddah, known historically as the Walling Negotiations.

As the 15-day truce came to an end, all sides called for an end to the civil war. In Chongqing, more than 4,000 people from all walks of life called on Chiang Kai-shek to "extend the negotiating period and achieve lasting peace." Seventeen Shanghai economic circles sent a joint telegram to Chiang Kai-shek, saying: "Eight years of resistance, renewed fighting in October, national economy, exhaustion. Desolate farmland is palpable, and industrial production is half-empty. Issuance skyrocketed, prices skyrocketed. Famine is everywhere, death is everywhere. On 21 June, under pressure from all sides, Chiang Kai-shek announced that the ceasefire would be extended for eight days, until 30 June. This failed to meet the demands of many for an end to the civil war. Following Chiang Kai-shek's announcement that the ceasefire would be extended for eight days, the Shanghai People's Organization Federation immediately decided to hold a general assembly on June 23 at Shanghai North Station in Shanghai Gate, welcoming the peace delegates of the Shanghai People's Organization delegation to Nanjing to petition for peace. At 7 a.m. on June 23, people gathered at Shanghai North Station to attend the conference and greet the peace delegates. Participating in the congress were "more than 150 people's organizations in Shanghai launched [to] about 100,000 people from all walks of life," the people were filled with slogans, cartoons, as well as the flag of the Republic of China, the school flags of all schools, the flags of all professional groups and trade unions, and all kinds of colorful flags. The walls and the bodies of the trains were filled with Chinese and English slogans: "For peace, for democracy," "For peace, against civil war," "Welcome to the Beijing petitioners," "If the civil war does not stop, the whole country will end!" "The civil war does not stop, the telephone is not working!" Journalists from the United States, the Soviet Union and other countries, as well as journalists from China, were interviewed at the conference.

Examples include Emperor Wei and Emperor Wei, Emperor Jin and Emperor Jin, Emperor Wei, Emperor Song, Emperor Liang and Emperor Liang, Emperor Chen, Emperor Sui, Emperor Tang and Emperor Taizong, Emperor Qing and Emperor Qing. The Battle of Penghu Sea, also known as the Siege of Shandong, was a key battle in the Qing Dynasty that destroyed Ming Zheng, one of the Four Great Battles of Penghu. In 1683, Admiral Shlong of the Fujian Naval Division fought against the Ming Zheng naval forces in Penghu, defeating Qing's army first and winning afterwards. After the defeat of Liu Guo-ken, Ming Zheng's internal unwillingness to resist the Qing army, and the defeat of King Cheng Kai-shek of Ping County, the Southern Ming Zheng regime collapsed, ending 22 years of rule in Taiwan. During the Three Domains Disturbance, the Qing Dynasty, which had entered the Central Plains shortly afterwards, had an unstable foundation and was constantly engaged in warfare with various Southern Ming forces, so Ming Zheng, who was on the side of Fujian Province, basically adopted a strategy of peaceful negotiation. In 1667, the Qing court sent General Kong Yuanzhang to Taiwan to mediate. He promised that if Zheng Zhen returned, he could seal the "Eight Min Kingdoms" and continue to rule the territory of Mintai, but Zheng Zhen refused. In 1669, Emperor Kangxi expelled Obai and began a pro-government policy. He then ordered the Ministry of Justice to make a major concession, allowing the Zheng clan to seize the territory, and to protect Taiwan for the rest of his life. Zheng Zhen compared himself to the king of North Korea, and said, "If you can follow the example of North Korea, do not shave, call your servants tribute, honor great deeds, then you will be able to do so." Kangxi replied: "If Zheng Jing remains in love with Taiwan, he can leave without thinking. As for not shaving more than North Korea, I wish to pay tribute, it is not acceptable. The North Koreans were never all foreigners, Zheng Xing was a Chinese," at which point Emperor Kangxi objected to Taiwan being a part of China, and effectively rejected the peace talks. On April 21, 1674, King Kangxi of the Qing Dynasty, Geng Jingzhong, raised an army against the Qing Dynasty and invited Cheng Jingzei to the expedition. He defeated Geng Jingzhong, and captured Zhangzhou, Quanzhou, Chaozhou, Huizhou, and Tingzhou.

Born into a middle-class family in Putney, London, on 3 January 1883, he was educated at Norfolk School, Holyrood and Imperial Service College and Oxford University College, graduating as a lawyer in 1904. Early in his life, he served children in the poorer parts of London's East End, and as a result, he became increasingly pro-socialist. He joined the Independent Labour Party in 1908 and became a lecturer at the London School of Economics in 1913, but was drafted into the army after the outbreak of World War I in 1914. During World War I, he served in Gallipoli and Mesopotamia, and after being badly wounded in action was sent back to England to recuperate, returning to France in 1918 for the Western Front, but the war was nearing its end and he returned home as a major at the end of the war. After the war, he returned to the London School of Economics as a lecturer, and began to become involved in politics. He was first elected mayor of the London Borough of Stafford in 1919, and in 1922 was elected to the London House of Commons in Stafford's Leamhouse constituency. After being elected to Parliament, he served briefly as Parliamentary Private Secretary to Ramsay MacDonald during the 1922 session. He joined the government for the first time in 1924, serving as Under Secretary of War in Ramsay MacDonald's "First Labour Government", but resigned shortly afterwards. In 1926, Edwards actively supported the National Strike, but in 1927 he reluctantly joined the Royal Simon Commission to study the feasibility of self-government for British India.

The Māori War of 1845–1872 was the first land dispute in the history of New Zealand, and was first referred to as the "New Zealand War" by New Zealand historian James in 1987. The most intense fighting took place in the 1860s, with the main battlefield in the central part of the North Island. In 1864, the British army totalled 18,000 men (including infantry, cavalry and artillery), against 4,000 Māori. The Māori used fortifications to fend off shells, and successfully defeated the infantry. 1,800 Māori and 800 European soldiers were killed. More than 2,100 people died during the war. About 16,000 square kilometres (16,000 sq mi) of the North Island was confiscated by the British, most of which was later paid or returned to the Māori (many of which were not original Māori tribes), but had a profound impact on the social and economic development of the local tribes. New Zealand is a constitutional monarchy, Westminster parliamentary democracy, and therefore has no written constitution. The head of state of New Zealand is King Charles III of New Zealand, who is also the British monarch, and retains only symbolic powers; since he has not been in the country for many years, the Governor-General is the monarch's representative in the country. Executive power is exercised by a prime minister who is trusted by an elected assembly, and the economist ranks fourth in the world on the Global Democracy Index, and first in the Asia-Pacific region. New Zealand's parliament is a unicameral, 120-seat, three-year-old legislature, with a single-seat, two-member, mixed-member proportional representation (MMP) system introduced in 1996.

Wang Xuefeng (Chinese: 王雪峰; born 26 August 1964) is a Taiwanese politician. He was born in Taipei. Wang Xuefeng was the daughter of Wang Kunwa, an important member of the Outside Party Movement, and was educated in the Political Department of the National Taiwan University before transferring to the Law Department of the National Taiwan University. During his time at the university, Wang was involved in student activism, served as vice president of the Taiwan University Students' Representative Union, and was one of the founders of the Association for the Promotion of University Law Reform; Wang was also attacked and detained by the military and police in 520 incidents. He then went to Cornell University, where he earned a master's degree in law, and then went on to study law at Harvard Law School. After returning to Taiwan in 1991, Wang was elected as a representative of the Democratic Progressive Party to the Second National Assembly in Taipei, and was subsequently appointed Deputy Director of the Social Movement Department of the Central Party Department of the Democratic Progressive Party, elected to the Third Legislative Council in 1995, and re-elected in 1998 and 2001. In 2002, Wang Xuefeng married fellow student Wang Sakuryo, and left politics. In April 2009, Taiwanese media reported that Wang Xuefeng and Wang Chengliang were picking up Visheng near their mountain home in Xindian City, Taipei County; Wang Xuefeng said that there was nothing wrong with picking up Visheng, and that she didn't mind being recognized, but she also hoped that the outside world would help her find a job. On October 15, 2009, Wang Xuefeng was rushed to the hospital in an ambulance after being injured by police officers, and Wang Xuefeng's brother Wang Bo-yu claimed that Wang Xuefeng had been assaulted by Wang since 2007. On October 16, 2009, Wang said that they had only argued on the 15th, that he had not beaten Wang Xuefeng, and that Wang Xuefeng occasionally waved at him; he said that he had indeed beaten Wang Xuefeng at the end of 2007, that Wang Xuefeng had gone to the hospital for an examination and to the police station, but that Wang Xuefeng had chosen to forgive and decided not to report; he said that, based on Christian belief, he would not divorce Wang Xuefeng, and that he would also take good care of Wang Xuefeng who was in poor health.

Brandess alumni are also famous in politics, including heads of state, congressmen, governors, diplomats, and so on. Brandeis University was founded in 1948. Because of widespread discrimination and exclusion, Jews, women, and other minorities were unable to access higher education on an equal footing, and the American Jewish community funded the establishment of a non-religious university, accepting faculty from all backgrounds and faiths. Its mission is to maintain excellence in university education and research innovation. It was founded on the site of Middlesex University. Middlesex University is a medical school located in Waltham, Massachusetts, and is the only medical school in the United States that does not allocate a quota to Jews. The founder, John Smith, died in 1944, and his will provided for the establishment of a non-sectarian university. Dr. Smith's son, C. Ruggles Smith, desperately wanted to save the University of Middlesex. He learned that a New York committee led by Dr. Israel Goldstein was seeking to establish a secular university funded by Jews. Smith sought Goldstein's help and made a proposal to hand over the Middlesex campus and licensing rights to the Goldstein Commission, in the hope that his commission "would have the evident ability to rebuild the medical school on the basis of approval". Goldstein feared that his medical school vision would fail, but eventually secured a 100-acre campus. So he was very excited. It's not far from one of the world's largest Jewish communities, New York City, and it's only nine miles from one of the most important Jewish population centers, Boston.

Finally, Allied leaders decided to launch a major offensive against France in early 1944, but U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt wanted to keep Italy out of the war. As a result, the Allies decided to conduct military operations against Italy without affecting the main fronts, thereby giving the Royal Navy complete control of the Mediterranean, and greatly improving Britain's ability to communicate with Egypt, the Far East, the Middle East, and India. At the same time, the Germans forced the Soviets to withdraw their troops from the war to defend Italy and southern France, in favor of the Soviets' war against Germany. At the time, the Allies had even hoped that Italy's surrender would force the Germans to abandon Italy and retreat to the north. In September 1943, the Allies successfully landed on the Italian mainland from Sicily, and Italy surrendered to the Allies. The Allied success in capturing large numbers of German troops in Italy prevented the Germans from mobilizing additional troops to support Northwestern Europe. On July 10, 1943, a combined force of British, Canadian, and U.S. forces landed in Gela Bay and Syracuse, Sicily, with amphibious assault vehicles and paratroopers. Although the Germans were unable to stop the Allied occupation of Sicily, they managed to evacuate almost all German forces back to Italy. On 17 August, the last German troops from Sicily withdrew to Italy. Nonetheless, the Allies at least learned to land. On 3 September 1943, the Eighth Army launched Operation Bay City, landing in Calabria, Italy, and the Italian government surrendered to the British on 8 September. However, the Germans did not withdraw and decided to fight alone. On 9 September, the U.S. Fifth Army launched a major campaign of avalanches, but encountered a German heavy artillery counterattack when it landed at Salerno.

Intel Corporation was the world's second-largest semiconductor company, initially developing SRAM and DRAM memory chips, which were Intel's primary business until the 1990s. In the 1990s, Intel invested heavily in new microprocessor designs and nurtured the fast-growing PC industry. During this period, Intel became the supply leader for PC microprocessors, and market orientation was dominated by aggressive and sometimes controversial marketing strategies, much like Microsoft dominated the development of the PC industry. The main competitors are Apple, AMD, NVIDIA, Samsung Electronics and TSMC. Intel's growth history can be divided into several distinct phases, described in the following sections. In 1955, "Father of Transistors" William Shockley left Bell Labs to found the Shockley Semiconductor Laboratory, which attracted many talented young scientists to join it. Soon, however, Shockley's management methods and eccentric behavior caused employee discontent. Among them, Robert Noyes, Gordon Moore, Julius Blank, Eugene Clay, Kim Hurney, Jay Laster, Sherton Roberts, and Victor Glick resigned, and in October 1957, they co-founded Sendo Semiconductor. Hungarian Andy Grove, who later made Intel a dominant player in the 1990s, joined the company in 1963 at the invitation of Gordon Moore. Due to the rapid development of Sendo semiconductor, internal organizational management and product issues have become increasingly imbalanced.

Kyzylorda Kyrgyz Autonomous Oblast (Kyrgyz: Кызылсуу Кыргыз aвтономиялуу oбласты; Uighur: قىزىلښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښهښه, Latin: QizilsuÉSZhiz Aptonom Oblasti), also known as Kyzylorda Suzhou or Kyzylorda, is an autonomous prefecture of the Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region of the People's Republic of China, located in western Xinjiang. It's bordered on the east by the Aksu region, on the south by the Kashgar region, on the west by Tajikistan, on the north by Tajikistan. It's on the southern edge of the Tianshan Mountains, on the eastern side of the Pamir Plateau, on the northwestern side of the Tarim Basin, on the northern slope of Mount Kunlun, and it's surrounded by mountain ranges. The main rivers are the Toshgan River, the Budani River, the Chukmak River, the Kuzlesu River, the Gezi River, the Kushan River, the Yelqiang River, and other lakes, such as Lake Brenkur and Lake Karakur. It has a total area of 72,468 square kilometers, a population of 59,610,000, a Kurdish population of about 27%, a Uyghur population of about 65%, and the autonomous city of Atush. Kizilsu (Kizil Su) is a name derived from the Kizi River, which means "red water" in Kyrgyz. "Kizil" (Russian: Кири́ль, "red") can be found in the villages of Kizil, Kizil Caves, Kizilto, and the capital of the Tuva Republic of Russia, Kyzyl.

Geographers study phenomena, processes, features, and the interrelationships between humans and the natural environment, their spatial and temporal distributions. Spatial and temporal themes are ubiquitous, such as climate, ecology, and economics, so geography is a cross-disciplinary discipline. Geography can be divided into two parts: natural geography and human geography. Natural geography focuses on natural environments, such as the formation processes of landforms, phenomena related to climate, soil, water, ecology, and vegetation, and their interrelationships. Human geography focuses on man-made environments, such as how humans colonize, manage, and view space.Natural geography is a natural science that specializes in exploring patterns of change in nature (rock, atmosphere, hydrology, and biosphere), and can be classified into the following categories: Biogeography and landscape ecology Climate and prehistoric climateology Oceanography and coastal geography Environmental geography and environmental management Geodesy Landforms Paleogeography and Quaternary science Hydrology and hydrology Soil and soil geography Climate glaciology and frozen soil Chemical geography Seismology and volcanology Human geography deals with the interactions between humans and the environment, and studies the relationship between humans and communities, culture, and economics, thus falling into the category of social sciences. Although there is little mention of human geography and landforms (see natural geography), human activity is certainly mountainous and riverous, with regional climates (such as deserts unsuitable for cultivation). Therefore, when discussing human geography and not neglecting natural factors such as landforms and climate, environmental geography connects the two.

In Roosevelt's conception, the Secretary-General of the United Nations should be a "world moderator", a position defined by the United Nations Charter as the "head of administration" of the organization. The Secretary-General is nominated by the Security Council and appointed by the General Assembly as the principal judicial organ of the United Nations. It was established in 1945 under the Charter of the United Nations, and replaced the Permanent International Court of Justice the following year. Similar to its predecessor, the Statute of the International Court of Justice is the principal constitutional document establishing and regulating the operation of the Court. The International Court of Justice is housed in the Peace Palace in The Hague, Netherlands, in a building shared with the Hague Academy of International Law, a private research center for international law. Some of the current judges of the International Court of Justice are also alumni or former faculty members of the Academy. The purpose of the International Court of Justice is to settle disputes between nations. The International Court of Justice has dealt with war crimes, illegal state interference and ethnic cleansing. Among them, there are still cases pending. In 2002, following a series of international discussions initiated by the United Nations, the International Criminal Court became operational: it was the first permanent international court to try the most serious crimes under international law, including war crimes and genocide. The International Criminal Court operates independently of the United Nations, both personnel and financially. However, some meetings of the governing bodies of the International Criminal Court, such as the Assembly of States Parties to the Rome Statute of the International Criminal Court, are held under the auspices of the United Nations.

Established in 1928 in Nanjing, China, the Central Academy of Sciences (Chinese: 中央研究院; pinyin: Zhongren-in) is the national academy and the highest academic hall of the Republic of China, directly subordinate to the President's Office. It is located in the southern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the southern part of the city, in the northern part of the city, in the southern part of the Researchers, associate researchers, and assistant researchers at the Central Research Institute are equivalent to university professors, associate professors, and assistant professors, and Taiwan's top universities often hire researchers from the Central Research Institute to fill their faculty and supervise graduate students. Members of the Central Academy of Sciences are the highest honors in the academic world of the Republic of China, many of them are elected as full-time researchers at the Central Academy of Sciences, or after being elected as full-time researchers or communications researchers, so there is a relatively large proportion of members who are also researchers in the Academy. On April 17, 1927, at the 74th session of the Central Political Conference of the Kuomintang in Nanjing, Li Shisheng proposed the establishment of the Central Academy of Sciences, and the resolution recommended that Li Shisheng, Cai Yuanpei, and Zhang Jinjie jointly draft the Law on the Organization of the Central Academy of Sciences. On May 9, the 90th meeting of the Central Political Conference of the Kuomintang established the Preparatory Office of the Central Research Institute, and appointed Cai Yuanpei, Li Yuying, Zhang Jinjie, Chu Minyi, Xu Chongqing, and Jin Xiangfan as the Preparatory Committee members. On July 4, the "Organization Ordinance of the University of the Republic of China" was promulgated, renumbering the Central Research Institute as one of the affiliated institutions of the University of the Republic of China. On November 9, the "Organization Law of the Central Research Institute" was promulgated, stating that "the Central Research Institute is directly subordinate to the National Government of the Republic of China and is the highest academic research institution of the Republic of China", establishing fourteen institutes: physics, chemistry, engineering, geology, astronomy, meteorology, historical language, national literature, archaeology, psychology, education, social sciences, animals and plants.

Judges are national judges who are elected and appointed by the people. The President of the Supreme People's Court is elected and removed by the National People's Congress. Local courts are elected and dismissed by the local people's congress. The other judges were appointed by delegation. Currently, the People's Republic of China is divided into 12 levels, the President of the Supreme People's Court is the Chief Justice, the others are the Chief Justice, the Senior Judge and the Judges. According to the Law of the People's Republic of China on Judges and the Measures for the Implementation of the State Judicial Examination, a person who has not passed the judicial qualification examination and obtained the judicial qualification shall not be appointed as a judge. Under the People's Republic of China's Law on People's Jurors, the system of People's Jurors is implemented in some trials, with the participation of people's jurors and judges. The current Constitution of the People's Republic of China and the Organization Law of the People's Procuratorate of the People's Republic of China stipulate that the People's Procuratorate is the legal supervisory organ of the state. It shall have the exclusive right to exercise public prosecution, at the same time exercise the right to approve arrests, arrests and appeals, and shall have the right to investigate on its own specific crimes involving corruption, neglect of duty and violation of the elections of the people. The Procuratorate shall be under the dual leadership of the People's Congress at the same level and the Procuratorate at the higher level. Although the Constitution does not explicitly state whether the Prosecutor's Office is a judicial organ, China has always regarded the Prosecutor's Office as a judicial organ that is independent of the government and inseparable from the courts. The People's Procuratorate shall be established in accordance with the level of comparison of the people's courts, and all levels shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate, except for the branch of the People's Procuratorate of the Municipality directly under the Central Government, which shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate of the Municipality directly under the Central Government, which shall be referred to as the People's Procuratorate of the Intermediate People's Court. It also established specialized prosecutor's offices, such as the Military Prosecutor's Office and the Railway Transport Prosecutor's Office. In Xinjiang, the Production and Construction Corps also set up procuratorates by regiments, divisions and regiments.

The stars in other clusters are also composed of a single constellation, but not a traditional model. Like seasonal clusters, some other clusters are composed of stars in more than one constellation. In addition to large-scale clusters, there are also small, well-adapted clusters of stars. The southern constellation is a special case. Early in his career, he was one of the largest constellations created by Ptolemy, and in his Coelum Australe Stelliferum (1763), when Lacaille reconstructed the southern constellation, he divided it into several parts of a ship: the bottom, the stern, and the sails. In 1930, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) also considered the constellation to be too large, so these old clusters were formally recognized as three constellations: Constellation Taurus, Constellation Canis Major, and Constellation Taurus Minor, while the original constellation was regarded as a single cluster. The Cross of the South is not a star cluster, but rather a real constellation: the constellation of the Southern Cross, although it is still a star cluster in the rear leg of Centaurus in Byrd's Uranometria (1603), it was not separated from Centaurus until 1930. Prior to this, the equinox had been reduced once, and Lupus was originally only part of this group, being considered a strange beast in the hands of the equinox, separated by the Iberian valley around 200 BC, and had existed independently on the list of Ptolemy. In the original design, the tail of Leo had some faint stars forming like waves after a flattened body, vividly depicting the tail. Probably before Ptolemy, Alexander the Great called the constellation "the hair of Berenice" in 243 BC in memory of his queen, and it was later accepted by Diocletian as a constellation, and Bayreuth recorded this result and re-drawn the lion's figure; the International Astronomical Union also recognized it as a constellation.

In 2008, the State Council of the People's Republic of China approved the construction of Hainan as an international tourist island, and in 2018 it approved the construction of Hainan as a free trade port. In the Western Han period, the Hanwu Emperor Yuanfeng Dynasty (110 BC) established Pearl Cliff County (now Hainan Qianshan) and Danlu County in Hainan Island. In the 5th year of Emperor Hanzong's reign (82 BC), Danlu County was annexed to Pearl Cliff County. At the end of the Western Han Dynasty, Zhuhai County was abolished. In 43 AD, Emperor Han Guangwu of the Eastern Han Dynasty dispatched the generals of Fubo (伏波將軍馬援平定交, 撫定珠崖, 設珠崖縣). During the Three Kingdoms period, between 238 and 251, Shezhu Cliff County (now Xu Wen, Guangdong). In the year 280, the western Jin Dynasty Emperor Taikang (西晋武帝太康元年), the provincial cliff county, and joined the Hyupo county. During the Southern Dynasty, Song Dynasty Yuanjia eight years (431 years) re-established Zhuhai County, Ji Xu Wen, soon abolished. During the reign of Emperor Liangwu (r. 535–546), the island of Hainan was ruled directly by the central government for the first time after the abolition of the Zhuhai County in 580. In the first year of Emperor Sui's reign, the Sui dynasty officially included Hainan in the map. It was founded in 631 by Emperor Tang Taizong in the province of Qiangcheng, hence the abbreviation "Qing" in Hainan. Five generations, ten countries, Hainan belongs to the Southern Han. In the Song Dynasty, Hainan Island, along with most of today's Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region, belonged to Guangxi Southwest Road. In the Yuan Dynasty, the former Guangxi Road was assigned to the province of Huanglong, and Hainan Island was also assigned to the province of Huanglong. In the Ming Dynasty, Qiangzhou was part of Guangdong Province, and Ji was located in Qiangshan County (now Jiangshan City and Town), which governed the entire island. The West and South Sands Islands are officially under the jurisdiction of the Joongju Governorate. The Qing Dynasty basically followed the Ming system, and by the end of the Qing Dynasty, Hainan had one province, two states and 11 counties.

2019 Coronavirus disease 2019, abbreviated COVID-19. Common symptoms include fever, cough, fatigue, shortness of breath, and loss of sense of smell. The virus is transmitted mainly through oral and nasal secretions, including cough. Several diagnostic methods have been developed to diagnose the disease. The standard diagnostic methods are reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (rRT-PCR), transcription-mediated amplification (RMA), or reverse transcription loop-mediated isothermal amplification (RT-LAMP) to detect viral nucleic acid. Chest CT scans can also help diagnose individuals who are highly suspected of infection based on symptoms and risk factors. Precautions include frequent hand washing, keeping social distance, quarantine, indoor ventilation, covering your nose and mouth when coughing, and avoiding touching your face with unwashed hands. Antiviral drugs are being developed for 2019 coronary artery disease, and some vaccines have been approved and are being distributed in countries that have subsequently launched large-scale vaccination campaigns. The main treatment is symptomatic therapy. On January 30, 2020, the World Health Organization declared the 2019 coronary heart disease outbreak a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC). In early January 2020, due to the unknown cause of pneumonia cases, and the preliminary investigation of the pathogen identification and traceability of the cause, the Wuhan City Health and Health Commission called it "unknown cause of pneumonia".
