The Sumerians believed that the entrance to Kur was in the eastern part of the Zagros Mountains, and that every soul needed to pass through the seven gates of Kur. Ancient Egyptian religions believed that man was composed of various elements, some of which were physical, some of which were spiritual. There are similar ideas in the religions of Ancient Assyria and Babylon. The Kottamuwa Stele, a burial stone of 8th-century BC royal officials of the Sam'al dynasty, describes how the Kottamuwa asked his burial attendants to hold a banquet to commemorate his life and afterlife, "for the sake of my soul on this stone," so that the stone could serve as one of the earliest references to the idea that the soul could be separated from the body. It's made of basalt, three feet high, two feet wide. It was discovered during the third excavation of the Neubauer Expedition at the University of Chicago Oriental Institute. The Bahá'í Faith holds that the soul is the symbol of God, the jewel of heaven, and that the most learned cannot grasp its trueness, and that no matter how acute its mystery may be, no one can hope to unravel it.

Under construction, the Kunming City Area Railway will connect Anning City, Kunming City District and Songming County. Anning is the largest metallurgical, salt and phosphorus chemical base in Yunnan Province, the site of the largest Yunnan iron and steel enterprise Kungang Group, and the main production base of Yunnan's largest chemical enterprise Yun Tianhua Group. With PetroChina Yunnan's 10 million-tonne refinery project in the grasslands of the Anning Industrial Park, Anning will become the center of Yunnan's petrochemical industry. However, due to concerns that the project might contain PX, an anti-PX incident broke out in Kunming in 2013. In 2016, regional GDP reached 272.87 billion yuan, an increase of 0.8 percent over the previous year. The GDP per capita, per capita, is 7,3810, which is 4.6 percent more than last year. In terms of regional GDP, the value of the first industry grew by 13.31 billion yuan, or 5.9 percent, compared with the previous year, driving GDP growth by 0.3 percentage points; the value of the second industry grew by 109.38 billion yuan, or 0.9 percent, compared with the previous year, driving GDP growth by 0.4 percentage points, of which the value of the industry grew by 90.50 billion yuan, or 1.1 percent, compared with the previous year; the value of the third industry grew by 150.18 billion yuan, or 14.8 percent, compared with the previous year, driving GDP growth by 7.3 percentage points; and the value of the first, second and third industries grew by 4.9 percent, 41.1% and 55.0%, respectively. The non-public economy achieved an increase in value of 111.1 billion yuan, an increase of 8.9 percent, accounting for 40.4 percent of the total GDP of the entire city. In 2016, the city's total local revenues were 39.39 billion yuan, up 3.9 percent from the previous year.

Shoko Shō Kō (尚, Shoko Shō Kō; 14 July 1787 – 5 July 1834) was the 17th King of the Second Shogunate of the Ryukyu Kingdom, reigning from 1804 to 1834. His name was Satsuma Shang, and he was nicknamed Satsuma Ryokin. He is the fourth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fourth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fourth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fifth son of the emperor, and the fi However, in 1803, King Shang of Ryukyu died at the age of three. As the king had only one son, and only one of the sons of the king's father, Shang Mu, was still alive, the princes conspired to appoint Shang as king. He was only allowed to return to the royal family, and was still considered the son of King Shangmu. He sent messengers to demand a seal of the Qing Dynasty. In 1808, Emperor Qing Jiaqing dispatched Shusen Ziyang, and gave him the title of "Senior Viceroy" (正副冊封使) and the title of "King" (冊封尚). During his reign, Ryukyu suffered frequent disasters. Due to long-term overdevelopment, desertification and deforestation in all parts of Ryukyu gradually atrophied. The sudden onset of an unusual climate, the corruption of officials, and the exploitation of the Satsuma clan further exacerbated the difficulties of people's lives, with famine and pestilence repeatedly occurring in Ryukyu. In order to stabilize the situation, the Shang dynasty dispatched governors, prosecutors, and other officials to various areas of poverty, instructing and encouraging the cultivation of the people; and on many occasions awarded people's official positions or objects as prizes. In 1810 and 1814, he sent additional doctors to Miyako and the Yaeyama area to teach the locals how to treat diseases. In addition, Dutch and British warships also came to the Ryukyu Islands, demanding trade, but being rejected by the Ryukyu Islands. Although he hoped to restore the situation of poverty in Ryukyu, the situation did not improve.

In preparation for the opening of the mine, Tang also proposed to build a railway from Kaiping mining area to Beitang estuary, so that coal could be transported to Beitang estuary by sea to Shanghai, Tianjin, etc. At the same time as the construction of the railway, the Kaiping Mining Bureau also established the Xikouzhuang Repair Works in Fengrun County (now Fengnan County), the first railway factory in China. When the factory was first built, it belonged to the Kaiping Mining Bureau, and was very small, with only a few dozen workers and a rudimentary workshop, with a total of about a dozen small machines, most of which were hand-rolling machines, a few of which were steam-powered. In 1883, the Hu Xiaozhuang Automobile Works, imitating the European model, built a first-class passenger car for the officials of the Kaiping Mining Bureau, beginning the history of the factory's production of railway passenger cars. With the expansion of coal mining in Kailuan, the Tangxi railway continued to develop. In August 1885, Lieutenant Governor Li Hongzhang accepted the proposal of the Kaiping Bureau of Mines to "divide mining and railway" and sent a letter to the Qing government for approval, and in 1886 organized the Kaiping Railway Company, also known as the Kaiping Railway Bureau, with Wu Tingfang as the general manager, overseeing the Tangxi Railway and the Huxing-Kozhuang Railway Factory, becoming the beginning of independent railway operations in China. In February 1887, the Qing government placed railway affairs under the jurisdiction of the Prime Minister's Office of Naval Affairs, and the railway became one of the national priorities. In August 1888, the Tangxi Railway was extended to Tianjin, renamed the Tangjin Railway, and passenger trains began to run. Due to the increasing volume of transportation, the Xiqiao Zhuang workshop was no longer able to meet the needs, while, due to the establishment of the Kaiping Mining Bureau in Tangshan, many of the coal wagons needed to be repaired were in the Tangshan mining area, and the factory's coal had to be transported from Tangshan, so as to facilitate the operation of the factory, the Xiqiao Zhuang workshop was moved to No. 23 Shanxi Road in 1888, separated from the Kaiping Mining Bureau, renamed the Tangshan workshop, and the scale was expanded.

It spans 106°39′45′′E — 108°32′11′′N, 30°19′40′′N — 32°20′15′′E, has a length of 177.5 km from east to west and 223.8 km from north to south. Mountains, hills, valleys and dams are all covered, with mountains and hills dominating the topography, accounting for 98.8% of the territory's area, the topography is high in the northeast and low in the southwest, and the topographical complexity is highly varied. The city has an average temperature of 14.7 degrees Fahrenheit to 17.6 degrees Fahrenheit, an average annual rainfall of about 1,100 millimeters, a frost-free period of 258 to 300 days. The city is divided into two districts, four counties, and one county-level city. According to the Sixth National Population Census of 2010, the city's resident population was 54,680,922, down 32,5052 from the Fifth National Population Census in the same decade, down 5.61%, down 0.58% on average per year. Among them, the male population was 27,953,538, or 51.12 percent; the female population was 2,672,554, or 48.88 percent. The sex ratio of the resident population (100 females) was 104.60. The population aged 0-14 was 1,113,344, or 20.36%; the population aged 15-64 was 375,824, or 68.73%; and the population aged 65 and over was 596,506, or 10.91%. The town population was 1788418, or 32.7%; the village population was 367,9674, or 67.3%. Dazhou is located in the center of the four major cities of Chengdu, Chongqing, Xi'an and Wuhan, and has been a center of merchandise distribution and trade of the Chuan-Yue-Shaan Joint Department. It is one of the 179 major national highway transportation hubs and one of the 12 secondary integrated transportation hubs planned in Sichuan.

Although it was suggested that an international conference be convened to resolve the problem, the United States unexpectedly declared an immediate end to the leasing program in August 1945. On September 2, 1945, U.S. lending support to Britain was abruptly withdrawn, causing a severe blow to the new government's plans. It wasn't until July 15, 1946, that the U.S. completed the Anglo-American loan agreement with Britain, that the economy recovered to some degree of stability. The loan, however, was intended primarily to support British overseas spending shortly after the war, rather than to implement the Labour government’s domestic welfare reforms and the nationalization of key industries. Although the loans were made under reasonable conditions, they included conditions that proved to be unfavourable to the pound's finances. Between 1946 and 1948, Britain introduced a system of bread rations that it had never implemented before during the war. The Soviet Union suffered heavy losses in the war against Germany. The Soviet Union's population declined by about 27 million during the war. Of these, 8.7 million died in combat. Nineteen million non-combatants died of various causes, including starvation during the Siege of Leningrad, imprisonment in German prisons and concentration camps, mass shootings of civilians, forced labour in German industry, famine and disease, the harsh conditions in Soviet camps, and service in German or German-controlled military units fighting the Soviet Union. Soviet prisoners of war and civilians deported from abroad were suspected of collaborating with the Nazis, of whom 226,127 were sent to concentration camps under Soviet censorship. Many former prisoners of war and young civilians were also drafted into the Red Army. Others worked in labor camps to rebuild infrastructure that had been destroyed during the war.

It belongs to Han, Wei, Chu. 230 BC), Qin Yingchuan County, Jiyang Zhai (音狄, present-day Uzhou City). The county is divided into twelve counties: Xu County (present-day Xuchang County), Yang Zhai County (present-day Uzhou City), Changsha County (present-day Changge City), Xiangling County, and Xiangcheng County. It was founded in 201 B.C., and is located in Xihan Gaozu (西汉高祖六年, before 201 B.C.), Diaxu County, and Qiyingyin County (治今魏都区). The counties of Xu County, Yingyin County, Yang Zhai County, Changsha County (治今长葛市老城), Xingling County (治今陵县彭店乡古城村) and Xiangcheng County all belong to Yingchuan County. On October 7, 1906, Emperor Han relocated the capital to Xiu, and Xiu became the nominal capital of the country until 220. During the Three Kingdoms period, Wei called Yingchuan County, which belonged to Yuzhou, Xuchang County, Yingyin County, Xuling County, Changsha County, etc. all belonged to Yingchuan County. Xuchang is one of the five capitals of Wei. In 221, Emperor Wen of China changed Xu County to Xuchang County (Chinese: 许昌县; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; RR: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; RR: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎichang yuxu; pinyin: Wánggǎ It is located in the southern part of the county, in the county seat of Changsha, Changge and Xiangcheng counties. The palace is open to the public. In 1368, it was abolished as Changsha County, and was incorporated into Xuzhou, the four counties, Changge, and Xiangcheng. Xuzhou and Junzhou were all subordinate to Kaifeng. In 1575, Junzhou was renamed Uzhou. At the end of the month, Li Zhengcheng's insurgents changed Yuzhou to Hwangpyeongfu. In the early Qing Dynasty, Xuzhou and Uzhou belonged to Henan Province. In 1724, Xuzhou was elevated to the status of a direct vassal state, and it belonged to Chang Gu. The palace is open to the public. In 1735, Xuzhou was elevated to Xuzhou Prefecture, Linying, Xiangcheng, Xiangcheng, Changge, Mi County (now New Mi City), New Zheng Province, and in 1741, Xuzhou was restored to Zhili Province, and all of the counties belonged to it.

The United Nations General Assembly has 65 observers. It consists of two observer states, five observer entities, and 58 observer organizations. In addition to its member states, the United Nations also has an observer system, inviting international organizations, non-governmental organizations and entities to participate in United Nations affairs. Observers have the right to speak at the United Nations General Assembly, but are not allowed to vote in the Assembly. The United Nations also has a permanent observer system, which allows non-members to qualify as members of any United Nations specialized agency. The following is a list in alphabetical order. The United Nations General Assembly may invite non-member entities that are not formally members to participate in the United Nations, and this has happened many times. Such participants are described as observers, some of whom are more clearly interpreted as observers of unofficial member states. The majority of former non-member observer states accept observer status because they have applied for membership but have not been granted, either because of actual or threatened rejection by one or more permanent members of the Council. The right of observers is granted only by the United Nations General Assembly and is not vetoed by the Security Council. An observer state is a sovereign political entity that can apply for membership in the United Nations on a voluntary basis at any time; for example, Switzerland was a permanent observer from 1948 to 2002, before becoming a full member on 10 September 2002. It should be noted that the United Nations considers the Knights of Malta to be a sovereign entity, not a sovereign state. Sixteen former non-members were also granted observer status. Most former non-member observer States accepted such status when applying for membership, but were unable to obtain membership because of the veto power of one or more permanent members of the United Nations Security Council.

The Forest Brothers (Estonian: metsavennad, Latvian: mežabrāļi, Lithuanian: miško broliai) referred to the guerrilla warfare of the three Baltic States against the Soviet occupation of the Baltic States during and after World War II in Estonia, Latvia, and Lithuania. Similarly to the Cold War, anti-Soviet organizations in Eastern Europe also fought against Soviet rule in Bulgaria, Poland, Romania, Croatia, and Western Ukraine. In 1940–41, the Soviet Red Army occupied the independent Baltic states, and after Germany occupied them in 1941–44, they occupied them again in 1944–45. As Stalinist oppression intensified, 50,000 people in these countries began to use rural forests as natural barriers and bases for armed resistance to Soviet rule. Resistance organizations ranged from individuals with basic self-defense capabilities to well-organized, large-scale units capable of fighting large numbers of Soviet armed forces. The name Forest Brothers first appeared in the Baltic Sea region during the Russian Revolution of 1905. The term forest brothers sometimes refers to farmers rebelling in the forest during this period. After the collapse of the Russian Empire, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania gained independence. For Estonia and Latvia, it was the first time since the 13th century that they had become independent, and so the idea of nationalism and national self-determination was gradually gaining ground. At the same time, Lithuania regained its sovereignty: it was the largest country in 14th-century Europe, but it was occupied by the Russian Empire in 1795.

The page can be divided into different chapters using the chapter title syntax. You can create chapters with titles, see the code below, see also Help: Editing Pages. Don't use a single equalizer (=Heading=), which will make the chapter title the same font size as the page name. Registered users can set parameters for automatic title numbering, so that each chapter title has its own unique tag. Chapter titles (including subtitles) should have only one in the same page, and using the same title name raises the following problem: one or more chapter content can come from a separate page (or template) that contains it, without altering the appearance of the page. Reference: Help: Template#Composite_pages. This method actually provides a chapter-independent editing history. You can also split up custody. The chapter of a template page, its chapter number depends on the position of the presentation page. For example, if the template is in the third section of the article, then the first section of the template becomes the fourth section of the article. Any text that appears in the first section of the template becomes the text of the section in which the template is located, and the text behind the article becomes the text of the last section of the template. This may be deliberate, but it is generally best to avoid it. In MediaWiki software, chapter titles written in wiki-style are defined as regular expressions, /(^={1,6}.*?={1,6}\s*?$)/m (m stands for multi-threaded mode). As long as each article has more than three chapter titles, it automatically generates a table of contents (TOC) based on those titles, except in the following cases: __FORCETOC__ or __TOC__ code can be used to force the display of a directory with fewer than four chapter titles.

Vanuatu recognizes the sovereignty of the Arab Democratic Republic of the Sahara and the sovereignty of Kosovo. Abkhazia had established diplomatic relations with Vanuatu in 2011, but in 2013, after Russia stopped providing economic assistance to Vanuatu, Vanuatu and Abkhazia broke off diplomatic relations, instead establishing relations with Georgia, and recognizing Abkhazia as part of Georgia. The majority of Vanuatu's people are engaged in primary production, mainly agriculture, whose crops provide about 65% of Vanuatu's needs; fishing and livestock farming are also one of Vanuatu's major economic activities. Tourism is also important in Vanuatu, and is a major source of revenue for the government. Due to high prices and production costs, Vanuatu's industry lacks export competitiveness, with major industrial products imported from abroad and sold domestically in Vanuatu. Vanuatu has small factories for coconut processing, food processing, timber processing, butchery, soap. Vanuatu's road system is undeveloped, with less than 100 miles of paved roads, mostly muddy and only suitable for four-wheel drive. Each island has a small harbour or wharf that allows small cargo ships and boats to dock regularly. In Vanuatu, cycling is a popular alternative. There are a number of taxis and small buses in Port Vila and Luhanville. According to the 1999 Census of Vanuatu, there were 95,682 males and 90,996 females. Official statistics show that infant mortality declined in the second half of the twentieth century, from 123 deaths per 1,000 population in 1967 to 25 deaths per 1,000 population in 1999. However, the CIA estimated in 2011 that 46.85 babies died per 1,000 live births.

Zhu De (Chinese: 朱德; pinyin: Zhu De; December 1, 1886 – July 6, 1976), also known as Zhu De (Chinese: 朱代珍; traditional Chinese: 朱代珍; pinyin: Zhu De; pinyin: Zhu De), was a citizen of Yilong County, Sichuan Province, China. He was one of the founders and leaders of the People's Liberation Army and the People's Republic of China, and one of the early leaders of the Communist Party of China. Zhu De is an important revolutionary and military figure in modern Chinese history, and the head of the Ten Commanders-in-Chief of the People's Republic of China. Zhu De graduated from Yunnan Military Academy, participated in the Xinhai Revolution, the War for the Protection of the State, the War for the Protection of the Law, and served as the head of the Yunnan Provincial Police Department. In 1922, while studying in Germany, he joined the Communist Party of China, and later studied at Zhongshan University in Moscow. On August 1, 1927, he participated in the Nanchang Uprising, after which he led the Mao Zedong faction to Jinggangshan, and successively served as the commander of the Fourth Red Army, the commander of the First Red Army Corps, the commander of the Red Army of the One Party, the commander of the Chinese Workers' and Peasants' Red Army, and the chairman of the China Revolutionary Army Commission, participating in the Long March. During World War II, he served as Vice-Chairman of the Central Military Commission, Commander-in-Chief of the Eighteenth Army Group and Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Second Military District. During the Second Sino-Japanese War, he served as the commander-in-chief of the Chinese People's Liberation Army, along with Mao Zedong. After the founding of the People's Republic of China, Zhu De successively served as vice-chairman of the Central People's Government, secretary of the CPC Disciplinary Inspection Committee, vice-chairman of the People's Republic of China, and vice-chairman of the CPC Central Committee. In 1959, he was elected chairman of the National People's Congress. During the Cultural Revolution, Jude was shocked. On July 6, 1976, Zhu died in Beijing. During his time in the North Sea government, Zhude was awarded the Order of the Fifth Order, the Order of the Silver Tiger, and the rank of Lieutenant General of the Army. He was awarded the title of General of the National Revolutionary Army by the National Government during the War of Resistance against Japan and the Medal of Victory in the War of Resistance after the war.

Sagittarius is a small southern constellation near the South Pole, one of the 14 constellations identified by the French astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille in the 18th century. The constellation's original name, Mensa, is Latin for "" table, "" originally meaning "" Mons Mensae, "" or "" Table Mountain. "" The constellation is one of 88 modern constellations designated by the International Astronomical Union (IAU), covering 153.5 square degrees of night sky. Apart from Antarctica, which is the southernmost constellation, Saturn is the southernmost constellation, and the northern hemisphere is only visible south of the 5th parallel. The constellation is at the base of 88 modern constellations, has no bright stars at all, and its brightest star, Alpha Centauri, is barely visible in the night sky of ideal weather in the suburbs. With so many clusters and quasars in the constellation Cassiopeia, at least three galaxies have discovered extrasolar planets. The French astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille spent two years at the Cape of Good Hope observing and cataloging 10,000 southern stars, 14 constellations in Europe's unobserved southern sky, and 13 other constellations named after scientific instruments from the Enlightenment, with the exception of the constellation Sagittarius, which represents Table Mountain. It faces Scorpio to the north, Hydra to the northwest and west, Antarctica to the south, Taurus to the east, and is adjacent to Pisces to the northeast, covering 153.5 square degrees of night sky, 0.372 percent of the total, 75th in 88 modern constellations. Lacaille allocated ten Greek letters (except κ) from α to λ for the constellation, using the Bayer nomenclature, and Benjamin Apsoop Gould later added κ, μ, ν, ξ and π. Usually these faint stars don't deserve to be named in the Greek alphabet, but Gould felt they needed to be named because they were so close to the South Pole.

On March 2, 1945, the Commander-in-Chief of the Chinese Army ordered the withdrawal of the Commander-in-Chief of the Expeditionary Force, the Commander-in-Chief of the Fourth War Area, the Commander-in-Chief of the Gui Guizhou-Guiangxiang Border Area, the Commander-in-Chief of the Yunnan-Vietnam Border Area, and the numbers of the 1st, 9th, 11th, 16th, 20th, 24th, and 35th Army Groups and the Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the 1st Army Group, appointed Wei Lihuang as the Deputy Commander-in-Chief of the Chinese Army, Lu Han, Zhang Fukui, Yun Bo, Wang Yaowu as the Commander-in-Chief of the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, and 4th Fronts, and Chiang Kai-shek ordered Cho Yuzi as the Commander-in-Chief of the 36th Army Group: 7673. In March, the Maoists opened the China-India highway, praising China and abroad. The stance of Wei Lihuang toward the problem of the Communist Party was more oriented to the problem of political negotiation, and the main war colors of Chiang Kai-shek and others were extremely unacceptable; funding allowed him to remain in the West. In November 1946, Wei Lihuang stepped down as commander of the Expeditionary Force, a four-man expedition from Shanghai to the United States via Japan. In the spring of 1947, Wei left for Europe. Upon arriving in Britain, Mrs. Han wrote to her French niece in Paris, Li Huiwen, and her nephew's son-in-law, Wang De Zhao, asking them to contact the Communist Party of China as soon as possible. Wang de Zhao contacted the Soviet embassy in France through his friend, the Communist Party of France, and reported the matter to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union through the Northeast Bureau of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union secretly between July and August 1947. In October 1947, Chiang Kai-shek returned to China. In January 1948, Chiang Kai-shek appointed Wei Lihuang to replace Chen Cheng as the commander-in-chief of the Northeast Anti-Banditry Command: 555. In April 1948, Wang and his wife returned to their homeland after 15 years in exile, and Wang was appointed by Wei Lihuang as Deputy General Secretary and Chief of the General Staff.

In 1931, the Tibetan army again attacked the Qinghai Yushu area, was defeated by the Qinghai army of the Republic of China, the Republic of China Kawan Army also took the opportunity to launch a counterattack in Kang District, the Tibetan army had to retreat to the west of Jinsha River. In 1932, the two sides signed a ceasefire agreement, agreeing to use the Jinsha River as the boundary, pending a negotiated settlement between the Republic of China and the Tibetan authorities. On July 22, 1935, the Nanjing National Government established the West Kangding Provincial Committee in Ya'an, which was relocated to Kangding the following year. At the time, the committee nominally controlled 20 counties in the Kangding region, and 13 counties already controlled by the Tibetan Karkha. On March 14, 1938, the Nanjing National Government reorganized the Xikang Jian Provincial Committee, and on September 1, it divided the former provinces of Ning (now Xichang) and Ya (now Ya'an, except for Meishan County) into two administrative bureaus of 14 counties under the jurisdiction of the Xikang Jian Provincial Committee. With the abolition of the Sikang Provincial Committee, it was reorganized into the Sikang Provincial Government, established the Sikang Province, and implemented the Sichuan and Sikang Separation. On January 1, 1939, Xikang Provincial Government was officially established, and Liu Wenhui was appointed as the chairman of the province. The provincial government of Western Kangxi actually only manages Kang District east of Jinsha River. In 1941, the Banzen Kambu Conference Hall recognized the ninth Banzen Erdeni as a reincarnated child, but the Kakha never recognized his status, claiming that he was "a substitute child", and also recognized the tenth Banzen Erdeni as a legitimate Banzen Erdeni, allowing him to live in Lhasa, and declaring that he had been approved by the Tibetan independence state. It was not until 3 June 1949 that the Government of the Republic of China "specially authorized the succession to the tenth Panchen Dorjee Rinchen Dorjee Rinpoche," and on 10 August the ceremony was held.

In 1918, the Ottoman Empire was defeated in World War I, withdrew from the region, and Arab tribes clashed. In 1922, the League of Nations entrusted Britain with the administration. Influenced by the rise of Jewish nationalism and anti-Semitism, after World War II, large numbers of Jewish immigrants moved in. On 29 November 1947, the United Nations General Assembly adopted Resolution 181, in which it declared its support for the partition of Palestine, the establishment of an independent State of Palestine and the international administration of Jerusalem and its environs. On May 14, 1948, David Ben-Gurion, president of the World Organization for the Restoration of Judaism and the Jewish Association for Israel, declared that "a Jewish state shall be established in the homeland of Israel, called the State of Israel", and that it would begin to function at the end of the Mandate. Jordan occupied the area from the Green Line to the Jordan River, and in 1950 annexed it to the Kingdom of Jordan, recognizing all Arabs there as Jordanian nationals. Israel gradually gained control of the West Bank (1967–present), the Sinai Peninsula (1956–1957, 1967–1982), parts of Southern Lebanon (1982–2000), the Gaza Strip (1967–2005; still considered occupied after the withdrawal in 2005), and the Golan Heights. Israel extended its jurisdiction to the Golan Heights and East Jerusalem. Under the Oslo Accords of 1993, Israel exercises partial or total jurisdiction over Areas B and C of the West Bank, while Area A is under full Arab autonomy.

On November 30, 1946, a demonstration of stall vendors in Shanghai ended with the release of the arrested stall vendors and an apology. In July 1946, the Shanghai Municipal Government ordered stalls to be allowed only at designated locations on the grounds that stalls obstructed public space and traffic; on August 2, it ordered stalls to be banned in Shanghai's 1st District in August, September and October; in August, the 1st District Police began arresting stall vendors and confiscating goods; as a result, 16 stall vendors headed by Wang Zhenhui, a member of the Communist Party of China, formed the 1st District stall vendors committee, wrote to the Shanghai Municipal Government, demanding that the ban on stalls be reinstated, and released the stall vendors in custody, returning the confiscated goods. The city government ignored it. On August 28, 15,000 stall vendors gathered on Hankou Road to petition the city government, stopped by the military police, turned to the city's public stadium, decided to send a separate petition representative, and then disbanded. On the 27th of November, the First District Police Department went out and arrested the vendors. On the 30th, more than 3,000 hawkers and their families gathered at the 1st District Police Station to demand the release of people and a physical confrontation. It wasn't until eight o'clock in the evening that they were all released, handcuffed, and then scattered. But the Shanghai government didn't keep its promise, and on December 1, the city went under martial law. More than 5,000 hawkers gathered again to besiege the first ward, and clashed fiercely with the army and police. On December 2, representatives of the stall vendors again petitioned the city government, the city government was forced to take back the life of the stall vendors, the police chief Xuan Tieguo publicly apologized to the injured, and promised to replace the post of the director of the first division, announced the release of the arrested stall vendors, and issued the goods that had not been collected.

Du Xun-woo (April 6, 1900 – February 10, 1977) was a Chinese character. He was born in Gyeongcheng County, Heilongjiang Province, Hebei Province, and died in Qingcheng Province two years ago. In 1948, he was elected to the First Legislative Council of Heilongjiang Province, and after graduation, he was appointed to the Provincial High School of Heilongjiang Province, and after graduation, he was appointed to the Provincial Secondary School of Heilongjiang Province, and after graduation, he was appointed to the Special School of Legislative Affairs of Heilongjiang Province. Emperor Yongle (永历帝朱由榔; November 1, 1623 – June 1, 1662), also known as Emperor Zhaozong, was the fourth and last Emperor of the Southern Ming dynasty (December 24, 1646 – June 1, 1662). In 1646, Emperor Longwu of the Southern Ming Dynasty was captured, and Emperor Gui of Guizhou named himself Qing. Shortly thereafter, Emperor Longwu's younger brother, Emperor Tang, succeeded to the throne in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, and the following year, the year of Shaowu, was designated as "Shaowu Emperor". A few days later, Emperor Gui of Guangdong Zhaoqing also ascended the throne, the year of the eternal calendar, is called the "Eternal Calendar Emperor". In the end, the two armies were defeated, and the war was declared a war of attrition, resulting in the defeat of the Allies. The following year, the Qing army captured Guangzhou, Shaowu Emperor's troops were defeated and martyred, and Emperor Yongzheng became the sole ruler of the Southern Ming Dynasty. In 1659, after the Qing army captured Kunming, Emperor Yongzheng was exiled to Burma by the Dong Xu dynasty. In 1661, on the third day of the first month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the sixth month of the seventh month of the seventh month of the eighth month of the ninth month of the ninth month of the tenth month of the eleventh month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the tenth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the ninth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the twelfth month of the On June 1, 1662, the Emperor's father and son were hanged in Kunming. After his death, the Zheng dynasty in Taiwan continued to use the epoch-making date until 1683, when the Qing dynasty occupied Taiwan and Zheng Keqiang surrendered. Zhu Yuhao was the grandson of the Myojin sect, a disciple of the Ming Xi sect, the Myoshu sect, and the Myoan sect, and was born on November 1, 1623. He was the seventh son of Emperor Ming of the Ming Dynasty, and the seventh son of Emperor Hengyang of Hunan, and he entered the domain on September 26, 1645, and died of illness in Wuzhou on November 4, 1645.

The Bering Strait (Croatian:Эʼрвытгыр, Russian:Бе́рингов проли́в) is a strait in the Pacific Ocean between Cape Tejenev (169°43' W) at the easternmost point of Asia and Cape Prince of Wales (168°05' W) at the westernmost point of the Americas. This strait connects the Chukotka Sea (part of the Arctic Ocean) and the Bering Sea (part of the Pacific Ocean), between Russia and Alaska. It's named after the Danish explorer Vitus Berring. Right in the middle of the Bering Strait are the Aomed Islands. The narrowest point of the Bering Strait is about 82 kilometers, and the water is between 30 and 50 meters deep. The strait connects the Chukotka Sea (part of the Arctic Ocean) with the Bering Sea. The International Date Change Line is located between the islands of Grand Omid and Lesser Omid, so although the two islands are only about three kilometers apart, the time zone is not the same, so you can see "Tomorrow" Russia on the side of Lesser Omid. The Bering Strait is sparsely populated. The towns of Nome (3,788 people) and Teller Village (228 people) on the eastern coast of U.S. Alaska. The western coast is occupied by the Chukotka Autonomous Oblast in the Far Eastern region of the Russian Federation, along with the strait towns of Lorino (1,267 inhabitants) and Lavrentya (1,459 inhabitants). During the Cold War, the Bering Strait was the boundary between the Soviet Union and the United States, with the Soviet Union's Grand Omid Island only 3.9 kilometres (3.1 mi) from the United States' Grand Omid Island.

Mongolia On December 4, 2022, large-scale protests and riots broke out in the Mongolian capital Ulaanbaatar. Thousands of people gathered in Sukhbato Square in front of the National Palace, home of Mongolia's central government, to protest government corruption and high inflation, and to demand the dissolution of the parliament, as well as the government's joint investigation into coal corruption involving about 44 trillion kroons ($12.8 billion). As a neighbour and largest trading partner, Mongolia exports 86% of its total exports to China, more than half of which are coal. In the nine months to 2022, Mongolia's coal exports jumped to $4.5 billion. Even during the winter, mass protests erupted in the Mongolian capital Ulaanbaatar. Protesters gathered outside Ulaanbaatar's government palace on December 4 to ask for the names of officials who allegedly stole 44 trillion Mongolian Tugrik coal export earnings over the past two years. Several protesters held up flags and slogans such as "Working together, punishing bandits," "Don't just eat, think about my future." Hundreds of protesters decided to continue protesting on December 5th, saying they would "" go all the way. "" In the third largest city of Mongolia, Darkhan, protesters also demanded the publication of the names of the coal thieves and the confiscation of their property. On Sunday, protesters marched through the city, arguing that citizens' constitutional rights and freedoms were being increasingly curtailed, and that their lives were deteriorating every day. On December 5, protesters attempted to break into the government palace in Ulaanbaatar. Christmas trees were burned in Sukhbatar Square, and protesters blockaded the capital's Avenue of Peace. The Mongolian authorities say they have set up a working group to talk to the protesters.

λ Cusa is an optical binary star composed of λ1 and λ2, which are very distant in real time, but seen from Earth's perspective are essentially overlapping. λ1 Rhododendron is an 186-light-year-old binary star with a magnitude of 6.22 and a spectral classification of F7IV-V. The seven bills represent the left leg of the big-billed bird. Theta Tucana is an A-type star about 423 light-years from Earth. Bird bill VI is a yellow-white main sequence star with a spectral magnitude of F9.5V, 4.2, about 28 light-years from Earth. There are five known planets in the constellation Cuckoo, four of which have been discovered by Chile's high-precision radial velocity planetary search engine. HD 4308 is about 72 light-years from Earth, about 83 times the mass of the Sun, has a planet called Super-Earth, and it orbits for about 15 days. Located to the west of the Milky Way, 47 Cancri is the second-brightest globular cluster in the night sky, behind ω Centauri, about 1.47 million light-years away, and an estimated 12 billion years old, 2.77 million light-years away. NGC 362's orbit passes about 3,000 light-years from the center of the Milky Way, very rarely close to a globular cluster. James Dunlop discovered NGC 362 in the 1920s. The Milky Way lies at the southernmost tip of the constellation cuckoo, and it's a dwarf galaxy about 210,000 light years from the Milky Way, closer than most other known galaxies. The Milky Way is probably a disk, but it's distorted by the massive tidal force of the Milky Way. The Magellanic Stream is a giant gas cloud that encloses the Milky Way and the Large Magellanic Cloud.

The Red Wall is a place name, famous for the Battle of Red Wall in 208 C.E., as well as the famous phrase "Red Wall" by the great writer Su Shi. In 1998, the name was changed to the former city of Akabe in Hubei Province. The Battle of the Red Wall occurred at the end of the Three Kingdoms period, is one of the three battles, at that time basically controlled the northern China Cao Cao led a large army in the Yangtze River along the Red Wall, the Uling Line and Liu Bei, Sun Quan's coalition of the battle, resulting in the weakened Sun Liu coalition of the army launched a fire attack, Cao's army was defeated, lost the opportunity to unite in the sea, also roughly determined the situation of the Three Kingdoms era three-legged and divided the world. The battle of the Red Wall not only had a profound impact on the history of the time, the main characters of both sides of the war such as Cao Cao, Zhou Yu, Zhuge Liang and so on are known and admired by future generations, and a large number of vivid stories, such as the Anglo-Saxon League, grass boat borrowing arrows, borrowing the east wind, ring counter, etc., "Fire burned the Red Wall" became one of the most famous battles in Chinese history. For hundreds of years, historians have debated the location of the "Red Wall" war, often referred to as the "New Red Wall War" by the media. General statistics show that there are at least seven kinds of "Akabeki-Say" (赤壁說): Bugan-Say, Huangzhou-Say, Zhongxiang-Say, Wuchang-Say, Hanyang-Say, Hanchuan-Say, Jiao-Say. From a contemporary point of view, the controversy centers on the distinction between the Putonghua and Jiao dialects, while historical publications and the evidence of found artifacts are more biased towards the Putonghua dialects. In the Ancient Commentary on Chinese Literature by Yin Falu, he wrote: "That red wall is in the northwest of Pohang County, in present-day Hubei Province, on the south bank of the Yangtze River. It is also said that "Akabe Mountain lies 120 miles west of Pohang County, on the northern bank of the Linjiang River, on the northern bank of which is Urin, which is the place where Zhou Yu burned his boat and fled.

Nantou County (Chinese: Nantou  Nantou; pinyin: Lâm-tâu-kuān; Buno: Nantu; Hakka: Nàm-thèu-yen) is a county in the Taiwan Province of the People's Republic of China. It is the largest, most densely populated, and most transportation-intensive city in Nantou County. The indigenous peoples of the county include the Taiya, Sadek, Buno, Zou, and the Zou of Sun Moon Lake. Taiwan's highest peak, Mount Tama, the largest natural lake, Sun Moon Lake, the source of the longest river, and Taiwan's geographical center are all located in the county. Specialties include blue plum, banana, sugarcane, frozen oolong tea, Shaoxing wine, bamboo handicrafts, Nantou pottery, flowers. The name Nantou is derived from the Arikun word for "Ramtau", which means "Nautou" in Taiwanese. It is located in the northern part of the city of Nantou, east of Nantou Mountain, south of Nantou River, north of Nantou River and north of Nantou River, hence the name Nantou. It is located in the northern part of the township of Northumberland (formerly Northumberland Township). It is located in the northern part of the city of Nantou (modern-day Nantou County) and is adjacent to the northern part of the city of Nantou (modern-day Nantou County). In 1683, it belonged to the Zoro County of Fujian Province. In 1723, it was added to Changhua County, which belonged to the county. In 1759, he was appointed governor of Nantou County, which marked the beginning of Nantou County's political and religious life. In 1887, Fujian and Taiwan were divided into two provinces, and Taiwan was reorganized into Taiwan Province, which at that time was part of Taiwan Prefecture's Taiwan Prefecture (present-day Taichung South District).

A dirty bomb is a radioactive weapon that combines radioactive materials (usually uranium) with conventional explosives. Dirty bombs are not like nuclear weapons. The radiation cloud may extend tens to hundreds of square miles (about 26 to 259 square kilometers), and the radiation scope of a dirty bomb may be confined to a few blocks or miles from the site of the explosion. One of the simplest dirty bombs even needs to leave the radioactive material there for its radiation to spread, without having to be explosive. Sources of radioactive waste include medical isotopes and waste, radioactive drugs (iodine-131, iodine-123, yttrium-99, yttrium-201, xenon-133), nuclear power plant fuel rods (uranium 235), universities, laboratories, X-ray inspection and measurement ( cobalt-60, caesium-137, yttrium-192, radium-226), and so on. Radioactive materials can be released in a variety of ways, including destruction of facilities or containers containing radioactive materials, detonation of cargo or remotely controlled devices, placing of radioactive materials in facilities such as water treatment plants, use of aircraft, missiles, and rockets, and contamination of livestock, fish, and food crops. Most dirty bullets do not release enough radiation to cause death, which leads directly to serious disease. Depending on the circumstances, however, dirty bomb explosions can cause public fear and panic, pollute property, and require extensive clean-up costs.

A battalion is a modern army formation of about 300 to 1,000 men, composed of several companies, usually of the same type, with another battalion regiment or other combat support units. The commander of a battalion is an officer, called a "battalion commander", and is usually a lieutenant colonel or major. In modern army formations, a battalion is a battle tactical unit that belongs to a regiment, group, or brigade and has more than one supply source, allowing it to sustain more than a few days of operations. In Japanese and Korean, this unit is called a "battalion", and in some countries a "cavalry squadron" is roughly equivalent to a battalion. In addition to battalions and air squadrons, an infantry battalion usually has one battalion regiment, three infantry regiments, one artillery regiment, a mechanized infantry battalion with one battalion regiment and three mechanized infantry regiments, a tank battalion with one battalion regiment and three tank regiments, and an artillery battalion with one battalion regiment and three artillery regiments. The battalion commander is a lieutenant colonel, and there is also a deputy battalion commander and a battalion counselor. In order to increase the combat capability of the Combined Armoured Brigade, the Republic of China Army began in 2019 to subordinate each armoured brigade and mechanized infantry brigade to the "Composite Battalion", where the armoured battalion is equipped with two tank regiments, one mechanized infantry regiment, one fire support regiment, one combat support regiment, infantry battalion is equipped with two mechanized infantry regiments, one tank regiment, one fire support regiment, one combat support regiment, in order to adapt to future ground defense operations. In the early years of the Civil War, the U.S. Army did not have a fixed battalion structure, as long as it consisted of several regiments.

The term "Four Policemen" was coined by President Franklin D. Roosevelt to refer to the four major Allied powers and founding members of the United Nations: the British Empire, the United States of America, the League of Soviet Socialist Republics, and the Republic of China. The phrase symbolizes Roosevelt Jr.'s conception of the post-World War II world order. After the end of World War II, these four countries would become the "police of the world", meaning that they would need to maintain world peace together, but after Roosevelt's death, this idea was not realized until the Declaration of the United Nations was signed and the United Nations was established. In the middle of World War II, it was generally understood that there were three superpowers in the world: Britain, the United States, and the Soviet Union. China was also considered a superpower at the time, but due to its low level of economic development and instability, it was generally not recognized as a superpower. Until the end of World War II, when the Allies achieved a decisive victory, President Roosevelt proposed the concept of a "trustee of world power" to describe the four countries, later known as the "Four Policemen". He believed that the four countries would become the superpowers of the world and form an alliance. However, the Chinese Civil War continued and the Communist Party of China gained leadership. Since then, China has not become a superpower. At the same time, the widespread independence movement led to the disintegration of the British Empire and the loss of Britain's superpower status shortly after the war. This left only two superpowers in the world: the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. Then came the Cold War. After the end of the Cold War, the Soviet Union, as a superpower, withdrew from the Union for various reasons, thus dissolving the Soviet Union.

The Jutland Peninsula (German: Jütland; Danish: Jylland; Low German: Jötlann) is a peninsula in northern Europe, on the northern tip of the North European Plain, between the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, that forms the bulk of Denmark's territory. To the west and north are the North Sea and the Skagerrak, and to the east are the Kattegat and the Little Belt. It's about 2.35 million people. In ancient geography, it was known as the Siberian Peninsula. Broadly speaking, it includes Schleswig-Holstein in Germany. On 31 May and 1 June 1916, the only war between the British and German navies — the Battle of Jutland — took place in the Skagerrak Strait to the north of the peninsula. The peninsula and nearby islands were completely covered by glaciers in the 4th century, leaving behind ice shelves that formed low, rolling ice shelves and ice lakes. After the end of the ice age, sea levels rose, and with the partial subsidence of the land, the original land was divided into peninsula and island. In the eastern part of the peninsula, the polygonal bay, the curved coastline, is conducive to shipping and development of fisheries. Minerals were scarce, only a small amount of lignite and kaolin. The peninsula has historically been part of Danish territory along with the Scandinavian region and the Isle of Wight. Prior to this, according to Ptolemy, it was the home of the Jodonians, the Symbri, and the Charudes. The Danes built a wall in southern Jutland that extended from the North Sea to the Baltic Sea to resist the Christian Frankish invasion. Charlemagne drove out the pagan Saxons at the southern end of the peninsula (later the Halstein region), and moved the Christian Obots (a group of Slavs who spoke German) there.

Huili City (Chinese: 会理市; Northern Yi dialect:  or  nyi ddix shyp or hop li shyp) is a county-level city in Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture, Sichuan Province, China. It has a total area of 4,527 square kilometers, 440,000 inhabitants in 2004. It was designated a National Historic and Cultural Landmark in November 2011. On September 26, 2021, the county council was officially dissolved and the county council city was established. In 111 BC, the Hanwu Emperor established a government here, called Kaiwu County, belonged to Yeoshu County (present-day Xichang), belonged to the northern part of present-day Kairi County and the eastern part, Ningnan, Meiyi, etc.; in 675, the name of Kaichuan County was changed to Kaichuan County, meaning "Kawahara and Kai, the place where the chiefs listen to each other"; from 1277 to 1277, it was called Kaichuan Road, Taiwuan, Yongchang, Laixi, Kairi, Malong, Tong'an, Jiangzhou, etc., seven provinces; in 1392, the Ming Dynasty ancestor Hongwu 25th year of the Heian Dynasty, the rebellion of Ruetsumil, was changed to the commander of the people of Kaichuan Guards; in 1729, the Qing Dynasty Emperor Yongzheng, the people of Kaichuan Guards, guarded Kaichuan State, transferred to the eastern part of the Kairi State in Weizhou (the seat of present-day In May 1935, the Red Army's Long March passed through Kairi, and because of the high walls, the county seat was not attacked for a long time, becoming one of the few county seats not to be attacked on the way to the Long March. On the 12th, a famous conference was held on the outskirts of the city. It is located in southern Sichuan, the southernmost tip of Liangshan province, 184 km north of the provincial capital Xichang, adjacent to Panzhihua in the west, and bordering Yunnan in the south. The city is about 1,800 meters above sea level, surrounded by mountains.

Beijing Imperial Palace is located outside the Forbidden City of Beijing in the Ming and Qing Dynasties, inside the inner city of Beijing. It is surrounded by walls and has a gate, known as the Royal Gate. Beijing's Imperial Palace is located in what is now Beijing's Eastern and Western Districts. It extends south to Dong Cheung An Street, West Cheung An Street and Chairman Mao Memorial Hall; north to Jianmen West Street, Jianmen East Street; west to Fu Uk Street, Ling Shan Hotong, West Yellowstone South Street, West Yellowstone North Street; east to Morning Street, East Yellowstone South Street, East Yellowstone North Street. It has an area of about 6,87 square kilometers. Its predecessor was the Sui Dynasty's Sui Goryeo Gyogu (高麗行宮臨朔宫宫城) and Beiyuan (北苑), the Liao Dynasty's Yongyu Gyogu (姚嶼行宮), the Jin Dynasty's Daning Gyogu (大寧宮), and the Jin Dynasty's Dadu Gyogu (金中都離宮大寧宮). In 1368, the Ming Dynasty troops captured the capital, the Yuan Shun Emperor fled north, the capital was renamed Beiping. Due to the lack of warfare, the capital and the Yuan dynasty palace were completely preserved, but were demolished by order of Zhu Yuanzhang in 1369. In 1370, Zhu Yuanzhang placed his fourth son, Zhu Di, in the northern domain, and ordered him to build a royal palace at Longfeng Palace inside the Yuan imperial palace. In 1379, Yan's palace was completed, and in 1380, Chu Di ascended the throne. In 1399, Emperor Zhu launched the Siege of Jingning, won the throne in 1402, and changed the northern plain to Beijing in 1403. In 1406, plans were made to relocate the capital to Beijing, and it was built on the site of Yan Wang's palace in the west. In 1416, the Beijing Palace was built in imitation of the Nanjing Palace. In 1416, the expansion work moved the southern wall of Beijing to the south about 0.8 kilometers, so the Beijing palace was moved southwards on the base of the Yuan Forbidden City, while the axis of the central axis of the Yuan Forbidden City was shifted to the east about 150 meters, so that the central axis of the Yuan Forbidden City was placed on the so-called "white tiger throne" or "killing throne" of the west.

American English (abbreviated AE, AmEng, UES, en-US) is a form of English used in the United States. It's the dominant language of the United States. According to the 1990 census, 97 percent of Americans could use English "good" or "good," while only 0.8 percent did not use English at all, compared to 3.6 percent in 1890. By 2005, more than two-thirds of native English speakers were using American English. During the British colonization of North America, English was introduced to North America. The first emigration of native English speakers to the United States occurred in the 17th century. At the same time, Dutch, French, Spanish and Swedish are spoken in North America. In contrast to English, many aspects of American English tend to be phonologically conservative. Some people think that some of the North American accents are the same as Elizabethan English, which is still under discussion. Standard American English in the Midwestern and Northern United States is more pronounced than 17th-century English in comparison to contemporary English indigenous tones. The main reason for the conservative pronunciation of American English is that it is a mixture of various dialects from the British Isles. Due to its close relationship with England, the East Coast of the United States remained predominantly British at the time, and the tone of the East Coast of the United States changed with the development of English-speaking America. With relatively little contact between the interior of the United States and the United Kingdom, the original tone was largely preserved. Most contemporary North American English has a curl (also known as a curl), and the letter r is pronounced before the consonant; although English today does not have a curl, this was the case throughout England in the 17th century.

Both sides of the river are gently sloping to the northeast in the middle, and the mountains in the south are descending towards the river. The Wuling Mountains branch off from Guizhou Yunmiang Mountain into this city, and three branches. The northern branch comes from Hubei to Fenglong Mountain and enters Xianshan, Guiyingshan and Qinglong Mountains in Sangyou County in this city; the central branch along Lisui River north of there are Tianxishan, Hongxishan, Chaotianshan, Qingyanshan and Maohuakai. The southern branch runs between Lishui and Yuansui, has seven stars, Chongshan, Tianmen Mountain, extends into Jili County, Dalongshan, Tianhe Mountain. All three branches flowed east to Lake Dongting and disappeared into the plateau. The highest point is 1890.4 meters above sea level and the lowest point is 75 meters above sea level. The city has an average elevation of 183 meters, and the area has an average elevation of 1,000 meters. The municipality is divided into two districts and two counties. At present, Yongding District, Wulingyuan District and Sangfeng County enjoy the policy treatment of ethnic autonomous areas, while Jili County enjoys the treatment of more than half of the province's ethnic minorities. Preliminary results of the 6th census of 2010 showed that Zhangjiajie had a resident population of 1,476,521, 2.25% of Hunan's population, ranked 14th, population density of 155 people/km2, and gender ratio of 104.38/100. In terms of educational attainment, higher education accounted for 6.47 percent of the total population, lower education for 55.37 percent of the total population, and illiteracy for 4.74 percent. The district has 438,419 households and 1,388,420 households, accounting for 94.03 percent of the total population; the average household size is 3.17 persons. In terms of age composition, 262,085 persons aged 14 and under accounted for 17.75% of the total population; 1,049,596 persons aged 15-64 accounted for 71.09%; and 164,840 persons aged 65 and over accounted for 11.16 percent of the total population.

Shortly after the Japanese took control of Taiwan, they launched an invasion of Fujian as a base. In the early days of Japanese rule in Taiwan, the Japanese did not need a passport to travel through Taiwan to Qing. However, as Japanese rogues appeared in Fujian and engaged in illegal activities, the Governor-General of Taiwan promulgated the Foreign Travel Pass Rules in January 1897. Initially targeted at Japanese travelers to the Qing Dynasty, it expanded to Taiwanese and Taiwanese living in Taiwan and traveling to China and other countries in May of the same year. Around 1896, the then-Japanese governor of Taiwan, Yugentaro Yu, sent the then-chief priest of Yilang Lanyang Temple in Taiwan, the late Gao Su Guang, to Xiamen for missionary work. Later, the monks of the Eastern Voodoo Monastery, such as Mizutani Kaiyo, built the "Xiamen Eastern Voodoo Monastery". On August 24, 1900, the cathedral was burned down. On the 25th, the Japanese governor of Taiwan sent an army overseas to seize Xiamen. The Western powers reacted strongly, and the British, Germans, Americans, and Russians launched their warships into Xiamen harbor, and the British landed on British soil, and the Japanese were forced to retreat. "The Xiamen Incident of 1900". In February 1934, Chen Yi was appointed as the President of Fujian Province. On August 15, 1945, Japan declared its surrender. On 29 August, Chiang Kai-shek appointed Chen Yi, then President of Fujian Province, as Taiwan's Chief Executive. On October 25, the Republic of China took over Taiwan and Penghu. In 1949, the Central Committee of the Republic of China government moved to Taipei after losing the Chinese Civil War. Fujian and Taiwan faced a long-term civil war. In 1979, at the beginning of the reform and opening-up, the Mainland issued the Letter to the Taiwan Compatriots. In November 1980, the first small-scale trade transactions were concluded between Fujian and Taiwan, and the first Taiwanese-owned enterprise was established in Fuzhou in 1981.

Li Bin ordered the assassination of Hong Nongwei Chido Chen An, and was prosecuted by Chen An's family, Zhu Qi was handed over to the court for re-trial, and Shi Hen was ordered to mitigate Li Bin's crimes. One of the officers said: "Li Bin always hid a book of demons, saying that his brother Li Keng should have a great throne, and wanted to secretly plot revenge for Shi Heng. He was sentenced to life imprisonment, and Li Bing was convicted of treason and conspiracy to commit treason. Zhu Qian twice ordered his retainers to go to court, but they were afraid of persecution and did not dare to take revenge on him. The Li Bin brothers were executed by hanging, with twenty-eight people taken to their deaths. At the beginning of 1946, of the 38 seats in the political consultations involving the People's Coalition, the Communist Party of China, the Chinese National Party and non-partisans, the People's Coalition occupied nine seats, more than any other party at the time; combined with its alliance with other parties, the People's Coalition became an important force in balancing the two parties. In November 1946, the KMT decided to convene a constitutional national assembly, but the Communist Party of China refused to participate. Within the People's Alliance, the Chinese Youth Party and the Chinese Democratic Social Party participated separately in the Nanjing Constituent National Congress, but were expelled by the People's Alliance, leading to a rapid deterioration of the People's Alliance's relations with the Kuomintang. In October 1947, the Kuomintang government of the Republic of China declared the League an "illegal group" and imposed sanctions. In November of the same year, the National Assembly of the People's Republic of China held elections for deputies, and both the Communist Party of China and the People's Alliance boycotted the elections. The Kuomintang's suppression of the League led directly to the League's open declaration of cooperation with the Communist Party of China at its January 1948 Third Plenary Session, and the League's alliance with the Communist Party of China since then. Following the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Communist Party of China became the ruling party, and Mao Zedong proposed that eight other democratic parties, including the People's Alliance, remain. The Communist Party of China (CPC) exercises political leadership over the League, but promises to guarantee the organization's independence and legal equality, without interfering with the independence and day-to-day affairs of the Democratic Party. At the first plenary session of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), Zhang Lan was elected Vice-Chairman of the Central People's Government, Shen Jun-ju was elected Vice-Chairman of the National People's Political Consultative Conference (NPCPCC), Zhang Beijun was elected President of the Supreme People's Court, and Zhang Beijun, Shi Liang, and Hu Yuzhi were elected Ministers of the Administrative Council, respectively.

Yang Qiu Xing (Chinese: 楊秋興; born May 15, 1956) is a Taiwanese politician who served as a member of the Legislative Council of Kaohsiung Prefecture. He was promoted to the Democratic Progressive Party (DP) by Kaohsiung County Governor Chen Yueying, and returned to his hometown to represent the blacks of Kaohsiung County, participated in the National Assembly, and ran for mayor of Fengshan City, but was unfortunately defeated. He was re-elected to the Legislative Council of Taiwan in 2001 and succeeded in becoming the governor of Kaohsiung Prefecture, where he was highly regarded as a "small giant of the South". In the 2010 municipal election, he was defeated in the first round by the Democratic Party of Kaohsiung mayor Chen Qiu, and was defeated in the second round by the Democratic Party of Kaohsiung mayor Chen Qiu. In the 2012 presidential election, he was elected as a member of the Political Affairs Committee and Director of the Southern United Service Center of the Executive Yuan, and in 2013 he joined the Kuomintang again, winning the nomination for mayor again defeated. He resigned from the National Party in 2019. After leaving politics, he worked as a construction worker. Yang Qiu Xing was born in 1956, the birthplace of the rolling water tribe (now Kaohsiung Kaohsiung's Yanzhao District's Yanzhao Village). He graduated from the National Tainan First Senior High School in 1974, and joined the National Taiwan University in March 1975. In 1979, he graduated from the Faculty of Civil Engineering of the National Taiwan University, then entered the engineering department as an engineer. He graduated from the Institute of Civil Engineering, Taiwan University in 1985, and returned to Chungding Engineering Service, where he married his wife Lin Shufeng at the beginning of the year, and his eldest daughter was born in the same year. In 1986, while serving as the governor of Kaohsiung Prefecture, he joined the government of Kaohsiung Prefecture, joined the Communist Party of China, and became one of the first members of the Communist Party of China.

The Solar System contains the Sun and other bodies bound by its gravitational pull: eight planets, 165 known moons, five confirmed dwarf planets (including Pluto) and their moons, and billions of small bodies. Small objects in the Solar System include asteroids, Kuiper belt objects, comets, meteors, and interstellar dust. Broadly speaking, the region diagram of the Solar System includes the Sun, four terrestrial planets classified as inner planets, a belt of asteroids containing some small rocky objects, four gas giants classified as exoplanets, and a second band of ice-packed objects called the Kuiper Belt. Above the Kuiper belt are the Disc, the Solar System, and the hypothesized limiting Oort cloud. The planets are arranged in order of distance from the Sun: Mercury, Venus, Earth, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Six of the eight planets have natural satellites, usually named after the Earth's moon, or the Moon, and each is surrounded by a planet made up of dust and other particles. All planets except Earth are named after gods or goddesses in Greek and Roman mythology. The five confirmed dwarf planets are Pluto, Ceres (the largest object in the asteroid belt), and the largest known objects in the Kuiper belt: Orion and Haumea, and Eris, the largest object in the Disc. The Earth is home to millions of creatures, including humans, and the Earth is the only known body of life in the universe today. The Earth was born 4.54 billion years ago, and life was born within a billion years. Since then, the Earth's biosphere has altered the atmosphere and other environments, giving rise to oxygen-demanding organisms and creating the ozone layer.

Taiwanese subjectivity, also known as Taiwanese subjective consciousness, is a political and cultural discourse in Taiwan. After the democratization of Taiwan in the 1990s, it became one of the mainstream ideologies. "Taiwan's subjectivity" is based on the idea of Taiwan as the center, through the power of multiculturalism and Taiwan nationalism, to break through Chinese centralism, Chinese nationalism or Great Han nationalism, to establish Taiwan as an "independent country" democratic system and cultural identity. Taiwanese subjective consciousness, along with the concepts of promoting Taiwanese independence, anti-authority, anti-colonialism, and anti-middle class often form a collection. However, because the ethnic history of the South Islands, European heritage, Chinese traditions, and Japanese Taiwan are all part of Taiwan's history, there is actually a difference. Supporters of Taiwan's subjectivity, such as law and politics scholar Peng Mingmin (Declaration of the Taiwan Self-Defense Movement), historian Cao Yonghe (The History of Taiwan Island), Lin Mazli (The Composition of Taiwanese Blood and the Origin of Taiwanese Ethnic Groups), former president Lee Teng-hui (Special Binationalism), former vice president Lu Xiu-ren (The consensus of '96'), Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan Solidarity Alliance, Time Force, even musician Xiao Tai-ren, singer Cai Zhen-nan, director Wei De-sheng, all supported or actually participated in the Taiwanization movement, forming a subjective consciousness centered on Taiwan, and developing Taiwan's own culture. Taiwan's subjectivity emphasizes multiculturalism and democratic thought. In the view of Taiwan's subjectivity, the influences of non-Chinese Taiwanese indigenous culture, European culture, Chinese culture (Chinese culture), Japanese culture, American culture, and globalization are all part of Taiwan's historical heritage and modern civilization, hence the criticism that Taiwan's subjectivity is a de-Chineseization. In a speech at an academic conference titled "New Thinking in the Study of History and Culture", the Minister of Education of the time of the Communist Party of China, Du Zhengchuan, proposed "turning 90°", "Taiwan's view map", emphasizing "Taiwan must find its own central point".

Huizhou was an area of terrestrial marshes 70 million years ago, suitable for dinosaurs to survive, and in recent years, four sets of 38 dinosaur eggs and some dinosaur footprints have been found all over Huizhou. About 10,000 to 4,000 years ago, in the late Neolithic Age, primitive humans began to thrive in Huizhou, engaged in fishing and primitive agriculture. Today, 28 ancient sites such as hills and caves have been found throughout Huizhou, including Borohu Ling, Su Yagang, Ho Yagang and other hillside sites, excavated a large number of stone tools and pottery pieces. During the Spring and Autumn Warring States period, there was an ancient kingdom called Banlu in the Boro County of Huizhou, and it is recorded in the Lu Spring and Autumn: "Banlu, Yaoyu, Shokoku no kuni, do no kimi." In 1993, during the construction of the Guanghui Expressway, more than 300 ancient tombs were discovered in Mt. Yooling in Boro County, mostly belonging to the Zhou Dynasty. In 214 BC (Qin Shi Huang thirty-three years ago), after the Qin Shi Huang Pingding Ling southern area of Baekcheng territory, in Huizhou established Boro County, which belonged to Nanhai County. At the end of the Qin Dynasty, Zhao Tuo founded the Republic of South Vietnam, and Huizhou belonged to the territory of the Republic of South Vietnam. In 111 BC, after the death of Emperor Hanwu of South Vietnam, the county was divided into nine counties, and Huizhou belonged to Boro County, Nanhai County. During the Three Kingdoms period, Huizhou belonged to the territory of Eastern Wu. In 326, Nankai County was divided into Dongguan County and Boro County was transferred to Dongguan County. Between 326 and 334, Ge Hong, a famous Taoist monk, retired to Mount Lo Wu in Huizhou to seek medicine, refine, and create four Taoist temples on the mountain, making Mount Lo Wu one of the most famous Taoist temples in China.

In 1597 or 1598, Peter the Great collaborated with Jodocus Claudius in Amsterdam to print the Twelve Constellations on a 35-centimeter telescope. In 1603, the German astrographer Johann Bayer published the Astronomical Survey, the first astronomical atlas of the constellation. Both Francis and Bayer painted the cuckoo as a big-billed bird. The cuckoo is irregularly shaped, with Hydra to the east, Crane and Phoenix to the north, Indian to the west, and Antarctica to the south. The constellation covers 295 square degrees of the night sky, ranked 48th out of 88 modern constellations. In 1922, the International Astronomical Union (IAU) determined that the three-letter abbreviation "Tuc" represented the constellation. In 1756, the French explorer and astronomer Nicolas Louis Lacaille allocated the Greek letters "α" to "ρ", omitting the letters "ο" and "ξ", and assigned the two nearest stars to "λ" and the three stars to "β". In 1879, the American astronomer Benjamin A. Good described Lacaille as a nebula in the constellation Xi Cuckoo, which is now known as the globular cluster 47 Cuckoo. According to Francis Bailey, Cuckoo was too faint to be assigned the Greek alphabet, so the original name was dropped, and two bodies, now called κ1 and κ2, formed Cuckoo Kappa. The cuckoo's brighter stars are arranged like kites. Beak 4, Beak 2, and Kappa Cuckoo are multiple star systems, containing six, two, and four stars, respectively. The beak is around the tail of the bird.

The Original Geometry (Ancient Greek: Σλιοχεῖα, Stoicheia) is a 13-volume work by the ancient Greek mathematician Euclid. This book is the foundation of modern mathematics and is estimated to be the second most widely published book in the West after the Bible. In all four books, he was assigned to the Department of Astronomical Algorithms. Euclid's Original Geometry consists of 13 volumes. Volumes 1 through 6 deal mainly with planar geometry. The seventh to ninth chapters of the book deal mainly with number theory. Volume 10 discusses unreasonable numbers. Volumes 11 through 13 deal mainly with stereogeometry. Geometry was originally considered by many scholars to be the work of Euclid, who gathered together the principles proved by many of his predecessors and some of his own original proofs, according to an ancient Greek historian Proculus. Euclid wrote the original geometry in 300 BC. It was translated into Arabic, then re-translated into Latin. The first printed book appeared in 1482. The Greek version still exists in various places, such as the Vatican Library or the Bodleian Library at Oxford University. It is regrettable that these existing manuscripts vary in quality and are incomplete. The earliest Chinese translation was the Latin text of Origen (15 volumes), compiled in 1607 by the Italian missionary Limazzo and the Chinese scholar Xu Guangqi, and revised and supplemented by the German priest Christopher Kravius, and named Origen Geometry, from which the Chinese name of geometry is derived. They translated only the first six volumes, and the last nine volumes were translated by the Englishman Weir Yale and the Chinese scientist Li Zhenlan in 1857.

The Military Police Training Center (MPTC), formerly known as the Military Police School (MPS), is a military professional training center located in New Taipei City, Taiwan. On October 31, 1948, the 1st Regiment was transferred to the Huangpu River Shipyard in Shanghai and conducted 12 drills in Jian, Hualien County. In September 1956, the new South Battalion was formed in Taipei City as the "Constabulary Training Battalion". In 1958, the regiment was reorganized as the "New Military Training Battalion" (憲兵新兵訓練大隊). On May 16, 1961, the unit was expanded to six battalions and renamed the Military Police Training Center. In 1965, he was transferred to Taishan District, Tai'an District, Taipei Prefecture. In July 1983, he was transferred to the Linkou-Huimin camp. On November 2, 2004, it was merged into the Military Police School (憲兵学校) as the "林口校區" (林口校區). On 27 November 1924, the second phase of the Huangpu Military School was expanded to include a gendarmerie section, "Department of Administration Director Gu Zhutong organized the gendarmerie", located at the old site of the army lecture hall in the northern campus of the provincial city of Huangpu Military School "provincial branch school". The gendarmerie department opened in April 1925, ten months of training, graduating in February 1926. In February 1925, the National Government established the Military Police Training School in Huangpu, Guangzhou.

Pingjin District (Chinese: 平鎮區; pin: ziin: kiʹ; pin: zhin: kiʹ; Taiwanese: Pîng-tìn-khu) is a district of Taoyuan City in Taiwan, located in the northern Linjiang District, the western Yangmei District, the eastern Daxi District, the northeastern Linjiang District, and the southern Yuelongtan District. The core of Pingcheng District's original development was in the Anping Township, Nansei, and Shanzitop areas, and later, due to the influence of the Nine Districts of the nearby city, its development was more restricted and it was more likely to become the peripheral zone of the city. It is known for the development of a highly tight-knit Middle-Level, as well as the nationally known High School Baseball Strength Plains High School Baseball Team. Archaeologically, the early Plains Town belonged to a 3,500-year-old plough head system culture group, and three sites have been found, including the Songya site, the Futang Palace site, and the Zhuang Cuo site, but there is no clear record of it, possibly because the inhabitants moved elsewhere at the time, and the area has not been culturally preserved. During the Qing Dynasty, Pingcheng was part of the Mokan Fort, and at that time the administrative division could be divided into Yabo-zhuang, Anping-zhuang, Doulian-po-zhuang, Song-ya-zhuang, Northern-zhuang, Southern-zhuang, Shanchai-cho-zhuang, Eastern-zhuang, and Shachai-zhuang. The name of the town was originally derived from the fact that in order to protect the safety of traveling troops from the mouth of the Great Lake to Zhongli, Taoyuan, it was established Zhang Luliang (present-day Puxin District, Yangmei District), Wang Luliang (present-day Nansei District), and the area between the two places was called Xisei (present-day Pingcheng District, Pingcheng Li Area, present-day Taoyuan 72 Line, along the South Ping Road), and later the security improved, taking the meaning of protecting peace, it was renamed Anping Town.
