Newborns who have not yet obtained a health insurance card, or who have subsequently been born, can still obtain a health insurance card once the policy has been implemented. It is estimated that there are around 5,000 households in the United States who use this method of self-care and self-care services. Furthermore, infants 0–6 years of age receive free five-dose family-controlled antigen rapid screening test kits, which are dispensed on a one-to-two basis based on ID numbers; one-to-one on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays; two-to-two on Tuesdays, Thursdays, and Saturdays; and all on Sundays. Parents are reminded that household rapid screening should only be used by children over the age of two, rapid screening reagents obtained from children under the age of two should be used by parents of children under the age of two, and should not be used by children under the age of two. On June 1, the "first round" 0–6 year olds (children) will receive a free five-dose household rapid screening test kit, even if they have already purchased the first round of rapid screening. On June 6, the implementation of the "second round" of home antigen rapid screening trials was introduced, increasing the number of trials from 78 to 117. On 13 June, restrictions on double purchases were lifted. On July 1, the "Third Round" of domestic antigen rapid screening reagents were put on sale under the real name system. On August 15, the "fourth round" of home antigen rapid screening trials was implemented, with the original purchase of one dose (5 doses) being increased to a maximum of two doses (10 doses), divided into one or two purchases (discountable), the price remaining at 500 yuan per dose (5 doses), informing people in need and eligible to have health insurance cards purchased/received from the health insurance bureaus and health clinics that sell real-name home antigen rapid screening trials; and the "third round" of 0–6 year olds (children) receiving one dose (5 doses) of home rapid screening trials free of charge.

The Battle of Zhengzhou was a major battle fought between the Chinese People's Liberation Army (PLA) led by the Communist Party of China (CPC) and the National Revolutionary Army (NRA) led by the National Government in Zhengzhou, Henan Province, China in 1948. During the 1948 Jinan Campaign, the army of Jinan and Xuzhou was tightened, and in late September Zhengzhou's Sun Yuanliang Corps was relocated to Xuzhou. Zhengzhou's defenses were replaced by the 106th and 268th Divisions of the National Army in Anyang and Xinxiang, and the 12th District Command of the Xinxiang National Army was moved south to Zhengzhou. Zhengzhou was then called Zheng County, and the entire county was under the jurisdiction of Vi Xin Town, Datong Town and Dehua Town, with an area of only 2.4 square kilometers. On September 24, 1948, just before the end of the Jinan Campaign, the deputy commander of the East China Field Army, Awa Yu, sent a telegram to the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and reported to the East China Bureau and the Central Plains Bureau, proposing to launch the Huaihai Campaign. In order to attract the reinforcements of Sun Yuan Liang's regiment, to cooperate with the Eastern Front of the Chinese Eastern Campaign, and to ensure the smooth conduct of the Huaihai Campaign, on October 11, the Central Military Commission sent a telegram to the Central Bureau: "Sun Yuan Liang's three divisions, Dongjin, Wang Liu, Chen, and Deng, immediately deploy to attack the Zheng Xu Line, intercept Sun's regiment. Zhengzhou is located at the junction of Longhai Railway and Beijing-Hanhai Railway, and its strategic position is extremely important. In order for the PLA to transport heavy weapons and large quantities of heavy military equipment to the Huaihai battlefield, railways were an important means of transport. After receiving the telegram, Liu Beicheng, Chen Yi, Deng Xiaoping, 1, 3, 4, 9, column commander Chen Gang, Chen Xilian, Yang Yong, Qin Qiwei, etc., in U County, in accordance with the instructions of the Central Military Commission, formulated a battle plan to attack Zhengzhou. On 13 October, the Central Military Commission gave its approval, agreeing to "attack Zhengzhou and deploy reinforcements in accordance with your timetable".

After World War II, this trend developed into a neoclassical synthesis. The problems that dominated economic hypotheses and theories at the time were becoming increasingly apparent, and John Maynard Keynes was one of the early thinkers to recognize these problems. When physics began to question the necessity of absolute time, writers began to question narrative structure, composers began to question the necessity of harmonious tonal harmony, Keynes began to question the two pillars of economics at the time: first, whether money had to have a firm foundation, usually the gold standard, and second, that if demand decreased, supply or price would decrease accordingly, thereby rebalancing. Keynes himself was closely associated with London's Bloomsbury district, and was fascinated by the atmosphere that changed people's minds. It was this experience and the signing of the Treaty of Versailles that ultimately led him to break with traditional theories. In 1920 he wrote The Economic Consequences of Peace, in which he not only elaborated on the overall economic consequences of the Treaty of Versailles as he saw it, but also established his position as an economist with practical political experience that could influence national decision-making. In the 1930s, Keynes published a series of articles on the effects of national power and overall economic trends, developed a theory that monetary policy was not just a fixed reference, and he became increasingly convinced that economic systems did not automatically follow a curve that economics called the productivity curve. But he didn't find any evidence, and he didn't find any form of expression for these ideas. In the late 1930s, the globalized economic system began to hit the United Kingdom — the central country at the time.

In order to compensate for the shortage of existing international ports, the Taiwanese government first opened Suo Port in the 1970s (under the jurisdiction of the Keelung Port Authority), then built Taipei Port (also known as Freshwater New Port; under the jurisdiction of the Keelung Port Authority) and Anping New Port (under the jurisdiction of the Kaohsiung Port Authority) in the 1990s. In 1999, the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China changed its name to the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China. Due to Taiwan's economic boom, and the rapid development of commercial ports, especially located in both the north and south of Kaohsiung and Keelung, it was the third and seventh largest container ports in the world, respectively, in its heyday, and contributed greatly to Taiwan's economy; however, since the 1990s, the rapid development of ports in mainland China and neighboring countries, which affected the competitiveness of the various commercial ports in Taiwan, passenger traffic throughput could not grow. In order to improve competitiveness, the Ministry of Transport of the Republic of China has implemented the "separation of government enterprises" measures since March 1, 2012, to incorporate the port offices and establish the Taiwan Port Authority to be responsible for the actual operation of the trading port, the original four port offices were respectively reorganized into the "port branch" of the Taiwan Port Authority, and the shipping and port supervision was established another port office as the competent authority. On the island, the Ministry of Transport commissioned the Kinmen Prefecture Government and the Linjiang Prefecture Government to set up a port authority to manage the domestic ports in the prefecture, not affected by the establishment of the Taiwan Port Authority. There are currently seven international ports in Taiwan, including four major ports and three auxiliary ports. There are five domestic merchant ports: Pubang Port in Chiayi County and Ma Kung Port in Penghu County (one of the two largest port districts in Penghu) are mainly used for offshore transportation and tourism, Shenzhen Port is mainly used for oil and gas discharge and tourism sea fishing by Taiwan Central Oil Company, while Kinmen Port (three port districts below) and Mazu Port (five port districts below) are used for direct trade with mainland China through the Small Three-way Mode, and for informal trade activities.

Admiral of the Fleet John Arbuthnot "Jacky" Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher (25 January 1841 – 10 July 1920) was a British admiral. During his 60-year career in the army, he exerted enormous influence on the Royal Navy. By the time he was commissioned, the Navy was still using pre-armored wooden sailing ships, and by the time he retired, the Navy was already using steel battlecruisers, submarines, and aircraft carriers. An argumentative, energetic, forward-thinking man, Fisher is often cited as the second most important figure in the history of the British navy after Lord Nelson. Although he had extensive combat experience, he was remembered as an innovator, strategist, and promoter of naval development, rather than a naval commander involved in major naval battles. In 1904, he was appointed First Minister of the Navy. He decommissioned the next 150 obsolete warships, and began building replacements for modern warships. Fisher felt that the navy needed to improve the range, accuracy, and speed of the guns. He was also one of the first to advocate the use of torpedoes, which he believed would eventually replace heavy artillery as the main anti-ship weapon. During his tenure as naval governor, he introduced the torpedo boat destroyer class to the navy. After serving as First Secretary of the Navy, he was responsible for the construction of the first "All-Big-Gun" in 1911, when he officially resigned from the Navy Headquarters on his 70th birthday, but he again served as First Secretary of the Navy in November 1914.

Engineering is broad in scope, and is generally subdivided into several subfields, which are different areas of engineering. Initially, engineers are trained in a particular field, but may be exposed to other fields in their careers. General engineering can be divided into four main categories: In addition, there are other engineering fields, formerly classified as mining engineering and marine engineering, and now classified as industrial engineering and materials engineering. The British Engineering Commission covers many of these areas of engineering. Occasionally, special applications integrate these traditional fields into a new one, such as Earth Systems Engineering and Management, which includes philosophy, ethics, anthropology, environmental sciences, and engineering studies. Some new fields are temporarily defined as a combination of some existing fields, so there are still many grey areas as to whether a particular application is considered a field, a major indicator being whether a major university has a department, institute, or course in the field. There is considerable overlap in these areas, especially in the applied sciences, such as mathematics, physics, and chemistry. The most critical and unique task of an engineer is to discover, understand and combine practical limitations to achieve satisfactory results. In many cases, the product doesn't just have to meet the technical requirements, it has to meet other requirements as well. These conditions include material source, physical or technological limitations, feasibility of future improvements and other factors such as cost, marketability, productivity and suitability.

Because any important resolution must be decided by more than 85 percent of the vote, a single country in the United States can veto any reform. The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank are the same organization that was decided at the Bretton Woods Conference, but they are two different organizations. The World Bank Group consists of five institutions: the term "World Bank" generally refers only to the IBRD and IDA, while the World Bank Group or WBG generally refers to all five. The World Bank Institute is the World Bank's capacity development department, providing learning and other capacity-building training to member countries. A government can decide for itself which organizations it wants to be a member of. At present, the IBRD is composed of 188 member states of the United Nations, as well as Kosovo; the other institutions have 153 to 184 members, notwithstanding that all the institutions of the World Bank Group adhere to the terms of their agreements, which form the legal and institutional basis for all their work. The World Bank is also the executing agency of the United Nations Global Environment Facility (GEF). 188 members of the United Nations and Kosovo are members of the WBG, at least in the IBRD. So far, all the members have also participated in some of the other four institutions (IDA, IFC, MIGA, ICSID). As of May 2016, according to the number of participating agencies, the WBG members: the five UN member states that have not yet joined: Andorra, Cuba, Liechtenstein, Monaco, North Korea. Since the United States is the largest shareholder in the World Bank, the President of the World Bank, also known as the "President of the World Bank," has always been an American, while the President of the International Monetary Fund is a European Union person.

According to the current hypothesis, Planet Nine orbits the Sun with a very high eccentricity and has an inclination of up to 30 degrees (6999523598775598300♠30°±10°). For observers on Earth, when Planet Nine is at its farthest point from the Sun, it will appear in either Orion or Taurus. According to Brown's conjecture, assuming the existence of Planet Nine, it would take at least 20 years to reach the planet if a spacecraft were to be launched from Earth, using the gravitational pull to navigate its orbit around the Sun. The planet's mass is estimated to be 10 times that of Earth, and its diameter is between 2 and 4 times that of Earth. Brown argues that if the ninth planet existed, its mass would be sufficient to clear its orbit of large objects within 4.6 billion years (with the possible exception of certain combinations of semi-major axes and mass) and its gravity-driven outer edge of the Solar System would be, by current definition, sufficient to make it a planet. Brown speculated that Planet Nine might be an ejected ice giant, similar in composition to Uranus and Neptune: a mixture of rock and ice and a portion of gas. In fact, if it had once flown between Jupiter and Neptune, the planet might have contained hydrogen and helium. Chad Cherkyro and Scott Shepherd were the first to describe the orbital classification of extreme trans-Neptunian objects, pointing to similarities in the orbits of asteroids 90377 and 2012 VP113. In the absence of a ninth planet, the orbits of these objects should be randomly distributed, not biased in any direction.

In 1820, under the Missouri Compromise, Maine separated from Massachusetts to become the 23rd U.S. state. In the 19th century, Massachusetts was the leader of the American Industrial Revolution, and there were a number of textile and shoe factories near Boston and Laurel, and a number of toolmaking, papermaking, and textile factories near Springfield. Although Massachusetts established its first slave colony as early as the 17th century, before the American Civil War, Massachusetts was the center of the American abolitionist and progressive movements. Thanks to the efforts of Horace Mann, the state's educational standards are among the highest in the United States. Although there was an early outcry against the abolition of slavery in Massachusetts, and even more riots against the abolition between 1835 and 1837, Massachusetts's manufacturing economy began to decline in the early 20th century as several manufacturing firms relocated. By the 1920s, with the rise of manufacturing in the Midwest and South, combined with the effects of the Great Depression, Massachusetts' textile, shoe and precision machinery industries were inevitably in decline. During World War II, Massachusetts produced 3.4 percent of all U.S. armaments, making it the 10th-largest U.S. state. In 1987, Massachusetts received federal funding for the Central artery tunnel project, the "" Big Digging "" project, the largest federal engineering project of its time. The Kennedy family played a very important role in 20th-century Massachusetts politics. U.S. President John F. Kennedy, Massachusetts Senator Ted Kennedy On May 17, 2004, Massachusetts became the first state in the United States to legalize same-sex marriage.

Hong Kong's legal system is based on the rule of law and the independence of the judiciary, along with the common law system. After the transfer of sovereignty in 1997, the Basic Law of Hong Kong was adopted as the constitutional document of the legal system. Under the principle of one country, two systems, Hong Kong's legal system was able to continue the original common law system, supplemented by the written law. Therefore, the legal system of Hong Kong is quite different from that of mainland China, and even from that of Macau. It is currently used in Hong Kong law, and is compiled in the form of written Hong Kong legislation. Currently implemented laws include: the Basic Law, other Chinese laws listed in Annex III of the Basic Law, the original laws before the transfer of sovereignty to Hong Kong (including the Common Law and the Equity Law), and laws enacted by the Hong Kong legislature. National laws of the People's Republic of China relating to defence, diplomacy and other matters outside the scope of Hong Kong autonomy must first be incorporated into Annex III of the Basic Law by the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China, and promulgated or enacted by the Chief Executive directly in Hong Kong. After the arrival of Charles I of England on Hong Kong Island in 1841, it was announced that the Chinese were still governed by local customs, and that British customary laws had been introduced. For example, for the same crime of murder, if the perpetrator was a European, he would be hanged under English law at the time, but if the perpetrator was a Chinese, he would be beheaded. In order to maintain the administrative status of the New Territories at the time and to respect the customs and interests of the New Territories residents, the Hong Kong Government decided that the New Territories would be administered by the local squires of the New Territories.

Traditional religious rituals: God the Great Secret Society: God, also known as God the Great, God the Grand Duke, God the Old, God the Goddess, God the Bodhisattva, is said to have evolved from the "wall" and "protect the city river", later evolved into the "personality god", and has the duties of a secret administrator, a magistrate. The city is named for the city walls, and God for the waterless moats of the city. The origin of the worship of the city god is said to date back to the Zhou Dynasty, when it was one of the eight gods worshipped on New Year's Eve — Sui Yong. According to the Book of Rites, the ancient gods worshipped "Water Yong" in the "Eight Waxes", interpreted as "Water God and Yong City", so it is generally believed that this is the beginning of worshipping God, but the worship of the eight waxes at this time should be performed only by the angels, and the situation of worshipping God in later times is not the same. From the Han Dynasty onwards, the worship activities of the gods continued to rise, and people everywhere honored the deceased vassals or heroes as the gods, including Kishin and Hoko. It is said that in the Three Kingdoms period, Wu Guo built the Temple of God; also in the Book of Bei Qi Muyong Yan, the Northern Qi general Muyong Yan visited the Temple of God in Yingcheng and defeated the Southern Liang enemy army, for the earliest clear description of the orthodox history. According to the Book of Sui, the Five Pilgrims: "The King of Liangwuling sacrificed to the god of the city, he cooked the ox, and suddenly there was a red snake around the ox's mouth. It is known that in the Northern and Southern Dynasties, the city gods were widely regarded as folk religions. It is believed that the temples were built to pray for rain, blessings, and disaster relief. There are many famous authors, including: Han Yu, Du Mak, and Li Shang-yin, among which the earliest is Zhang's "Sacred City God's Word" written in 717. During the Song Dynasty, the worship of the city god was included in the national rites, and the temple of the city god spread to all provinces, states, and counties.

This indicates that the inhabitants of India were also called Paladins (i.e., Brahmins) in ancient times. Some scholars have suggested that Paledi refers to the indigenous peoples of the region before the arrival of the Aryans in India, whose civilizational remains were found in Harappa and Mohenzo-Daro. There is some controversy, however, as to whether the Paladins were descendants of the King of Borodino. India existed both in the Paleolithic and the Neolithic. The ancient Indian civilization of the Indus River in Pakistan is one of the earliest ancient civilizations in the world, and at least 2500 B.C., there was an ancient Indian-created civilization in the Indus Valley in Pakistan, and because the earliest known sites of this civilization are located in what is now Pakistan's Harappa and Mohenzo-Daro, so this civilization is also called the Indus Valley civilization or the Harappa civilization. The ancient Indians established a strict social hierarchy, but the civilization collapsed suddenly around 2000 B.C., the river basin civilization collapsed, and the carrier languages and scripts of the culture collapsed, and no one understood them. The reasons for the breakdown of ancient Indian civilization are still unclear in the archaeological world. Around 1500 BC, the Aryans from northwestern India invaded the Indian and northern Ganges river basins of northwestern India, and gradually settled and engaged in agricultural activities over the following centuries. The foreign languages brought in by the Aryans replaced the local languages, culturally integrated with the locals, creating the classical Vedic culture. And this civilization is several centuries later than the Indus civilization of the Indus Valley, so relatively, it's commonly called the Ganges civilization.

For the first time, Vietnam declared a state of epidemic prevention, including the inclusion of new forms of pneumonia as a zoonotic disease. On February 3, a further 1 confirmed case was reported, bringing the total to 8 cases. A 29-year-old woman, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th by China Southern Airlines CZ8315, and three of her eight colleagues had been diagnosed with the disease. On February 4, the number of confirmed cases increased to nine. In addition, a 30-year-old man, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th by China Southern Airlines CZ8315, four of the eight colleagues with him had been diagnosed with the disease. On the same night, another confirmed case was reported, bringing the total to 10. Additionally, a woman from Yongfu Province was a relative of an infected person who had previously returned to Vietnam from Wuhan, China. On February 6, two more confirmed cases were reported, bringing the total to 12. Additionally, Vietnamese from Yongfu Province were closely associated with the previously diagnosed patients. On 7 February, the number of confirmed cases increased to 13. A 29-year-old woman, who had worked in Wuhan, China, traveled to China on the 17th on China Southern Airlines CZ8315, and five of her eight colleagues had been diagnosed with the disease. On February 11th, Vietnam added one new case, bringing the total number of confirmed cases to 15. The latest case is a three-month-old baby, infected by a grandmother, who was diagnosed with a new type of coronavirus on February 9. On February 13, the father of the fifth case was tested positive, and the number of confirmed cases in Vietnam increased to 16. On February 25th, the 16th case was released from the hospital after being negatively tested for COVID-19, which temporarily released Vietnam from the outbreak of COVID-19, and all confirmed cases have been discharged.

Idi Amin Dada (17 May 1925 – 16 August 2003) was the third President of Uganda from 1971 to 1979. In 1946, Amin joined the British colonial unit King's African Rifles and deployed to Kenya and Uganda. Following Uganda's independence, Amin was promoted to at least the rank of general in the Ugandan Army, became its commander-in-chief, and deposed Milton Obote in the January 1971 military coup d'état, seizing power. As head of state, Amin further upgraded his rank to Marshal. Human rights abuses, political persecution, ethnic persecution, summary executions, extrajudicial executions, nepotism, political corruption, and economic mismanagement under Amin's rule were all serious problems in Uganda. International observers and human rights organizations estimate the number of people killed under his rule at 100,000. Initially, Amin's policy was more pro-Western and gained support from Israel, but later shifted to Libya (Mu'anmar Gaddafi), Zaire (Mobutu Sese Seko), the Soviet Union and the East German Front. Discontent within Uganda and Amin's covetousness of the Kagera district of Tanzania led to the outbreak of the U Than War in 1978. The war ended Amin's eight-year reign, and Amin himself fled Libya, then moved to Saudi Arabia where he lived for the rest of his life, dying on 16 August 2003. Amin's year of birth is disputed: he claims to have been born in 1926 in a small village near Koboko in northwestern Uganda, but is also reported to have been born in Kampala in 1925.

On September 8, 1951, the United Kingdom signed the San Francisco Peace Treaty, which stipulated that Japan would cede Taiwan and Penghu to the United Kingdom. On 11 September 1958, during the Battle of Britain's 83rd Infantry Division, British Foreign Secretary Robert Lloyd said that the United States' cooperation in defending the Outer Islands, and even the use of tactical nuclear weapons, was clearly in danger of a chain reaction, and that Taiwan's withdrawal from the Outer Islands would strengthen its international standing. :227-236,266On May 8, 1970, the newly appointed British Consul in Taiwan, Thomas Duffy, arrived in Taiwan. On 13 March 1972, the United Kingdom formally established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China, with the removal of the Taipei Consulate. On 1 July 1994, the British Foreign Office responded to Parliament's April Report on Relations with China, stating that the United Kingdom attached great importance to Taiwan's economic interests and supported Taiwan's early accession to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), but that recognizing the position of the People's Republic of China (which claimed that Taiwan was a province of China and that the People's Republic of China was the only legitimate government of China) it was impossible to have diplomatic and political relations with Taiwan. In response, the government of the Republic of China pointed out that the British version was inconsistent with reality. On 21 September 1999, a major earthquake struck Taiwan, and the United Kingdom sent six search and rescue teams to rescue the people. In September 2003, the European Parliament and a group of MEPs from the United Kingdom, France, Germany, Italy and Spain jointly launched the Marco Polo Club.

Zhang An-Lao (Chinese: 張安樂; pinyin: Zhang An-Lao; born March 13, 1948), nicknamed "White Wolf", was born in Hongdong County, Linfen City, Shanxi Province, and moved to Taiwan with his parents as a child. He is the current Chairman of the China Unification Promotion Party and Honorary Director of the Democratic Progressive Party of China. Zhang Anlu is one of Taiwan's famous gangster bamboo gangsters. After returning to Taiwan in 2013 after being found not guilty of organized crime, he began actively engaged in political activities on both sides, and advocated the unification of the two sides, one country, two systems, etc. Born in 1948 in Nanjing City, Zhang's parents moved to Taiwan the following year when he was a baby, and as a child he and his mother lived in Taoyuan Taoyuan National Primary School, and after graduating from elementary school, moved to Zhonghe Anle Road in Taipei Prefecture. His father was a university professor, his mother was a female teacher, and when he was a junior high school student in Taipei, he attended the Taipei Provincial Taipei Jianchuan Gaku Junior High School, while in school, he contacted campus gang members, joined the local "Nankai Road Gang" and was active in Jianchuan Gaku and Taipei Botanical Garden. During his high school years, he became acquainted with Chen Kai-rei and others, and gradually became a prominent figure in the gang under the nickname "white wolf", and was arrested by the police for attempted murder and imprisoned for 28 days for allegedly shooting and wounding a police constable in Yonghe Township. After graduating from high school, he went on to study at the National Taiwan Normal University Affiliated Secondary School Day School, and after graduating from high school, he studied at the History Department of the Tanjiang College of Arts and Sciences.

Zhang Jizhong (Chinese: 張治中; 27 October 1890 – 10 April 1969) was a senior general of the National Revolutionary Army in Anhui Province, who served as the President of Hunan Province, the Minister of the Political Department of the Military Committee of the National Government and the Secretary of the Tri-Nationalist Youth League, and the Chairman of the Xinjiang Provincial Government. In 1947, he was elected as a delegate to the First National Assembly in Nesoi County, Anhui Province. He was a member of the Communist Party of China and was closely associated with the Communist Party of China. In June 1949, he announced his departure from the Kuomintang and joined the Kuomintang Revolutionary Committee, serving as vice-chairman of the Kuomintang Central Committee. The National Post Office is responsible for the formulation of postal industry policies and planning, as well as for the supervision of postal services (including express services). In 1948, the Central Committee of the People's Government of the People's Republic of China established the General Administration of Posts and Telecommunications, which was responsible for postal and telecommunications affairs. In 1949, the People's Government of the People's Republic of China reorganized the Department of Transportation of the People's Government of the People's Republic of China into the Department of Postal Administration of the People's Republic of China. On November 1, 1949, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the Central People's Government was established, and in December of the same year, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications convened the National Postal Conference, which accepted the industry of the former Postal Bureau of the Ministry of Transportation of the Republic of China, and assigned it to the People's Postal Administration; on December 27, the Ninth Meeting of the Central Postal Economic Committee decided to establish the Postal Bureau. In 1954, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China was established. In 1970, the former Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications was merged into the Ministry of Transportation of the People's Republic of China, known as the "General Administration of Posts and Telecommunications of the Ministry of Transportation". In 1973, the Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications of the People's Republic of China was restored. On March 1, 1994, the State Council approved the Ministry of Postal and Telecommunications' institutional reform program, separating the Postal General Bureau from the administrative hierarchy of institutions, becoming a professionally accounted enterprise bureau. On October 4, 1995, the Postal Bureau registered with the State Administration of Commerce and Industry of the People's Republic of China a business license as a legal entity, and the company was named "China Postal and E-mail Administration Bureau" (Chinese: 中国郵政總局).

At the beginning of the Ming Dynasty, the Yuan Dynasty still followed the provincial system, until the abolition of provincialism in 1376, the first administrative district "in line with the Song Dynasty code", the establishment of the Chen announcement ministry, the punishment according to the inspection ministry, the command ministry, the division of civil affairs, supervision, military. In the latter half of the Ming Dynasty, the power of the three departments was gradually taken over by the Chubu system, and Chubu often became the supreme commander of the unified power of the provinces. In 1376, he abolished the Bureau of Central Affairs, and instead established the Ministry of Envoys, commonly referred to as Buseishi or Hanshi, which administered local civil affairs and was directly linked to the six central ministries. On January 1, 1912, the provisional government of the Republic of China was established in Nanjing, where Sun Yat-sen was sworn in as the provisional president. After that, he abolished Jiangsu Governor's Office, established Jiangsu North Governor's Office, Xuzhou Military Governor's Office, and became the military branch of Jiangsu Governor's Office. The House of Representatives was reorganized into the House of Representatives. After the temporary government moved north, Jiangsu Governor's Office was relocated to Nanjing. On 19 November, he was appointed Governor of Guangdong Province. In December, the military and civilian governments were dissolved, and the Ministry of Administration was established. On February 15, Yuan was elected by the Senate as the Provisional President, followed by Sun Yat-sen's official announcement of his resignation as the Provisional President, the Provisional Senate's decision to move the government to Beijing, and in March, after the Provisional Government moved north, Yuan's military conference in April, formulated a national disarmament plan, demanding that the first step be to cut the national army by half. Yuan appointed Huang Xing to stay in Nanjing, the main purpose of which was to use Huang Xing to demobilize the army, but Huang thought that the time for construction had come and that the Yuan clan could be promised through democracy, so he aggressively disbanded the Jiangnan region, which was occupied by the Allied forces, such as the revolutionary army near Nanjing, in just two months' time by three divisions instead of two. Thus, by the time Yuan was preparing to kill the revolutionaries by force, the revolutionaries were in an extremely unfavorable position. Sun Yat-sen returned from Japan to Shanghai, discussed countermeasures, firmly insisted on the suppression of Yuan Shikai, but the opinion within the party was extremely unified, Huang Xing and others believed that it was militarily inadequate to counter Yuan Shikai, and therefore advocated a legal solution, only a minority of the party, including Li Rujun, supported Sun Yat-sen's opinion, and in April and May, the Kuomintang held two secret meetings in Shanghai, but failed to unite opinions and make a decision.

The Taiwanese Sociological Association (Taiwanese: 臺灣社会学会) is a social science organization in Taiwan. It was not until the 1980s that the organization began to organize regular, larger-scale academic activities. In 1995, after more than forty years of publication, the Taiwan Sociological Society changed its name to "Taiwan Sociological Society", and the institutional publication was renamed "Taiwan Sociological Journal". In 2000, the name of the society was changed again to "Taiwan Society of Social Sciences" until now. The Society's mission is to study the theory of sociology, social problems, and social administration. The main functions of the association are divided into: individual members, group members, honorary members, sponsored members. Pierre de Fermat also independently discovered this coordinate system, including the three-dimensional coordinate system, but it was not published. Both Descartes and Fermat had a single coordinate axis. When Frans van Schooten and his students translated Geometry into Latin in 1649, they introduced concepts to explain some of its ideas, including the second coordinate axis. The Cartesian coordinate system underpins the calculus invented by Isaac Newton and Gottfried Leibniz. After the Cartesian coordinate system, people created more coordinate systems, like the polar coordinate system in the plane, and the sphere coordinate system and the cylindrical coordinate system in three-dimensional space. A two-dimensional orthogonal coordinate system is usually defined by two mutually perpendicular coordinate axes, usually called the x-axis and the y-axis, respectively; the intersection of the two coordinate axes, called the origin, is usually denoted by O, both meaning "zero" and the French initial "Origine". Each axis points in a particular direction. The coordinate axis of these two different lines determines a plane, called the xy-plane, also known as the Cartesian plane. Normally, as long as the two coordinate axes are perpendicular to each other, their direction is not affected by the analytic problem, but habitually, the x-axis is horizontally pendulous, called the horizontal axis, usually pointing to the right; the y-axis is vertically pendulous, called the vertical axis, usually pointing upwards. Such a positional relationship between two coordinate axes is called a two-dimensional right-hand coordinate system, or right-hand system. If you draw this right-handed system on a transparent piece of paper, and you rotate it in the plane no matter how, the result is called the right-handed system; but if you rotate the piece of paper, the coordinate system that you see on the back is called the left-handed system.

From August 21 to October 7, 1944, representatives of the United States, the United Kingdom, the Soviet Union, and China met at the Dunbarton Oaks, an ancient manor near Washington. The meeting laid out the basic outline of the UN Charter, and resolved the main issues surrounding the establishment of the United Nations. When discussing the composition of the Security Council, the United States initially proposed four permanent and seven non-permanent members, later proposed that France be admitted as the fifth permanent member, and added that it might later propose adding a Latin American member as the sixth. When asked by the Soviet representative, the U.S. representative said that the Latin American representative was Brazil. The United States insists that Brazil's population, area, and resources give it sufficient reason to become a permanent member.

The Affiliated Senior High School of National Taiwan Normal University (HSNU) (Chinese: 国立臺灣師範大學附屬高級中學; pinyin: Zhu Zhong; pinyin: Zhu Zhong) is a full-time secondary school located in Xinyi Road, Da'an District, Taipei, Taiwan. Established in 1947, it is the oldest secondary school in Taiwan, and one of the most commonly referred to as "sub-secondary" schools. It is a traditional boys' school, and since 1980 it has been accepting girls in music classes and the newly established Kuninaku Department, and in 1983 it has been accepting a small number of girls in ordinary classes. In addition to regular classes, special classes such as science classes, mathematics classes, information science classes, language classes, music classes, and art classes are also offered. It is the largest high school in Taipei, with 84,251 square meters, and is conveniently located within the campus. As a result of the university's affiliation, it is known for its liberal arts culture, its rich community and student activities, and its students' advocacy that they can "play". Prior to the establishment of the Secondary School, on April 1, 1937, the then Governor-General of Taiwan established the Taipei State Third Secondary School on the site of the present-day Secondary School. At the end of World War II, on December 5, 1945, under the orders of the Taiwan Provincial Chief Executive Office, Taipei State Taipei Third Secondary School was renamed "Taiwan Provincial Taipei Third Secondary School".

The Nanzhuang Conference (Chinese: 城南庄会议) was an expanded meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) held in Nanzhuang, Fuping County, Hebei Province, China from April 30 to May 7, 1948. The five secretaries of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) Mao Zedong, Liu Shaochi, Zhou Enlai, Zhu De, Ren Bitian and Li Xianning, Zhang Jichun, Chen Yi, Awa Yu, Peng Zhen, Nie Rongzhen, Huang Jing, Lori Qing, Bo Wai, and others attended. It also adopted the slogan of the CPC Central Committee commemorating the "Fifty-first" Labor Day, as modified by Mao Zedong. The meeting decided to merge Jinchahe and Jinhe Luyuan into the North China Liberation Zone, establishing the Central Plains Party Military Organ. Andromeda is the northern constellation, named after the Greek mythological hero Perseus, and was one of the 48 constellations listed by the 2nd-century astronomer Claudius Ptolemy. The Milky Way's galactic plane crosses the constellation Perseus, which is the brightest of the three yellow-white supergiants at 1.79 magnitudes. Many of the surrounding stars are members of the Alpha Persei open cluster, the most famous of which is the visible eclipsing binary, Uranus, a variable star associated with a mysterious legend. There are a lot of famous objects in Perseus, X Perseus is a binary star with neutron stars, GK Perseus is a nova with an apparent magnitude of 0.2 that peaked in 1901. In ancient China, it was discovered in the constellation Andromeda that two very closely spaced open clusters formed a double cluster. The Andromeda Cluster, 250 million light-years from Earth, is a very large cluster of galaxies, named after the constellation Andromeda. The annual Perseus meteor shower is a very significant meteor shower, and the radiation point is in the constellation Perseus. According to Greek mythology, Perseus was the son of Danaeus, who was ordered by King Polytheus to take the head of Gorkon Medusa. Medusa can turn a man who looks into her eyes into a stone, Percussus cuts her head while she is asleep, and Medusa's body gives birth to Pegasus and Chrysophorus. With the acceleration of the pace of life brought about by modernization and the fusion of world cultures, today's Chinese funerals are a mixture of various religions (Buddhism, Taoism), local cultures, ethnic cultures (such as Japan), etc., the main process of traditional funeral rites has been preserved, but such traditions as funeral rites, funeral dress, filial piety, etc. have been "simplified", and the complete conformity to the old Confucian system is rarely seen. Its main processes are as follows: Funeral is a Chinese funeral form, in which a lively funeral atmosphere is used to replace the previous heavy funeral atmosphere, funerals are held for the elderly who have attained the age of eighty or more, and gongs are played to praise their longevity. The five virtues are merit, wealth, longevity, health, and good fortune. According to tradition, Han people generally allow relatives who are "one hundred years old" (one hundred years old dead) or called "high" (the "high" tradition refers to those over 90 years old, but the folk generally relax to 80 years old) to mourn, because it is believed that it is not easy to live to 80 years old (even one hundred years old) and it is worth celebrating for the deceased (there are various reasons for this, this is one), and the color of the hall and the funeral should be chosen, such as pink or pink orange, not too much white dots. The function of this mode of burial is to divert the attention of the deceased's immediate relatives from grief through elaborate ethical procedures, and to foster collective unity through community gatherings. Many owners perform funerals and burials for their animals and pets. Funeral arrangements are generally similar to those of human beings. Burial methods include soil burial, cremation, gene burial, grass burial, flower burial, water burial, celestial burial, and pet owners plasticizing their pets' bodies, or making mummies for long-term preservation, or undergoing ultra-low-temperature cryogenic preservation.

China Petroleum University (East China) is a national key university under the Ministry of Education of the People's Republic of China, is a national "211 Engineering" and "predominant academic innovation platform project" key construction institutions, is an engineering-oriented, multi-disciplinary coordinated development of teaching and research-type university, China's first established and the largest oil high school. Nowadays, it has developed into a national key university that combines engineering as the main subject and engineering management. Former predecessor of China Petroleum University Beijing Petroleum College was founded in 1953, through four important development stages of Beijing Petroleum College, East China Petroleum College, Petroleum University, and China Petroleum University, the running system was changed from industry institutions to universities directly under the Ministry of Education. In November 1951, the first National Conference of Higher Industrial Institutions was held in Beijing. The representative of the Ministry of Fuel Industry in charge of the petroleum industry attended the meeting, calling for the cultivation of petroleum technological talents, recommending learning from the experience of the Soviet Union, establishing China's petroleum education system, not only petroleum secondary technical schools, but also formal higher petroleum institutions. It's suggested that when the conditions are ripe, we organize an oil academy in time. This was the first proposal to set up an oil academy. The General Administration of Petroleum of the Ministry of Fuel Industry of the Central People's Government first established contact with Beiyang University in Tianjin. At the request of the Fuel Industry Department, the Chemistry and Geology Departments of Beiyang University were converted into the Petroleum Refining Department and the Petroleum Geology Department, with the Petroleum Mechanical Section in the Mechanical Department, and the Mining Department was essentially converted to serve the Fuel Industry Department. The Fuel Industry Department, in cooperation with Tsinghua University's Department of Chemistry, established the Tsinghua University Fuel Laboratory. In May 1951, on the basis of the Fuel Laboratory, the Petroleum Refining Group was formed.

Unlike other Eastern European socialist states influenced by Stalinism after World War II, Yugoslavia remained independent from Moscow. This was partly because of Tito's strong leadership, and partly because, when the Communist Party of Yugoslavia liberated Yugoslavia, the Red Army provided only limited assistance. All of this made Yugoslavia the only Eastern European socialist state to remain under pressure, independent of Moscow, until the late 1980s and early 1990s, when Tito made Yugoslavia proud of its independence. What the Yugoslav legislature did was a graphic decision made by the Politburo. The National Security Agency (NSA) of the Yugoslav secret police operates much more strictly than those in other parts of Eastern Europe, but is still regarded as a formidable tool of government control. The media in Yugoslavia is still severely constrained by Western standards, but it still enjoys greater freedom. Nationalist groups are a special target in the eyes of the authorities. The secret police, the National Security Agency, assassinated "enemies of the state" in exile abroad. The Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries often accused Yugoslavia of practicing Trotskyism and social democracy. At the same time, the non-aligned countries failed to form a third group, especially after the 1973 oil crisis led to a split. Despite this, the Soviet Union's attitude changed during the course of Fascism. Brezhnev cooled relations once again (though they never deteriorated to the point of conflict with Stalin). Yugoslavia supported Czechoslovak leader Alexander Dubček during the Prague Spring of 1968, and then established a special relationship (not all the time) with outspoken Romanian President Nicolae Ceausescu.

A territorial sea, also known as territorial water, is an area of water extending 3 to 12 nautical miles from the baseline of the territorial sea, that is, from the land territory of a coastal state beyond its inland waters, or from the territorial waters of an archipelago state beyond its territorial waters. However, the actual situation may differ from country to country. The sovereignty of a State over its territorial sea, its airspace and its continental shelf, as a part of its territory, is inviolable, but his State may exercise the right of passage over its territorial sea. The territorial sea was established on the basis of three principles: the state must occupy its coast for security purposes and protect its coast from offshore waters; the state must inspect and control ships in and out of its coastal harbours for commercial, financial or political purposes; and the state must possess the resources in its coastal waters in order to maintain the livelihoods of its inhabitants. The width of the territorial sea was at the heart of the controversy. From the 16th to the 17th centuries, the concepts were ambiguous. Initially, it was believed that this was due to the proximity of the sea. Later Dutch international jurists, such as Grotius, used the "cannon shot" as the area of control of the sea. Countries in the Mediterranean have also adopted the "shore range" argument. The Scandinavian countries of northern Europe define their territorial sea as a fixed distance along the coast. In the aforementioned claims, the "shore gun range" was generally accepted, and since the average 18th-century gun range did not exceed 3 nautical miles (5.6 km), some nations set their territorial sea width at 3 nautical miles. By 1945, the custom was gradually being changed to 12 miles (22 km) or even 200 miles (370 km). The 1982 United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea defined the limit as 12 nautical miles.

Between 558 and 567, the Persian Sassanid dynasty and the emerging nomadic Ancient Turkic League of Central Asia massacred the beetle empire at the Battle of Bukhara. From 648 onwards, the city was under the protection of the Tang Protectorate of Anzai, which established the city as one of the four towns of Anzai. In 651, Suleiman was once placed under the command of the Western Turks, but in 657, the Tang dynasty defeated the Western Turks and recaptured Suleiman again. In 663, the Tang dynasty began to compete with the Tibetan forces. In 670, during the Great African War, the entire Tang army was overthrown, and the sovereignty of the Suez Canal was transferred from one side to the other, until the Tang Empire finally took control of the Suez Canal in 692. In 751, the Abbasid dynasty defeated the Tang army at the Battle of Khorasan, and the entire army of the city was relocated to Han territory, while the Sumerian state became the object of a dispute between the Tibetan and Hui khanates, ultimately being controlled by the Chigils of the Qarluq tribe. Most of Kyzylorda belongs to Western Kyrgyzstan, the southern part belongs to Yugoslavia. In the early 9th century, the Turkic power on the Mongolian plateau was severely defeated by the Kyrgyz, and in 840, the Kyrgyz defeated the Mongols, the Kyrgyz migrated to the southwest, mixed with the Turks, culturally and linguistically Turkicized, and established the Karakhanate. In 915, Sultan Satuq Bughra Khan converted to Islam, and Cyrus became increasingly Islamic.

Through microgravity lenses and observations of planetary transits, it has been shown that there are many planets in the Milky Way. A 360-degree view of the Milky Way taken by the European Southern Observatory (composed from photos of Mars). The center of the galaxy is in the center of the field of view, up north of the galaxy. The Milky Way consists of a disk of gas, dust, and stars, surrounded by a central bar-like core. The galaxy's mass distribution is very similar to that of the Hubble-classified Sbc, suggesting that it is a relatively loose spiral-arc spiral galaxy, indicating that the bar at the center of the galaxy is smaller than previously predicted. The Milky Way boundary, or the fourth boundary of the Milky Way, refers to each part of the Milky Way that is divided into four circles. In actual astronomical practice, the outline of the Milky Way boundary is divided according to the galactic coordinate system: the Sun as the origin of the projection system. Use sequences to describe the boundary — for example, the "first galactic boundary." From the north pole of the Milky Way, the 0-degree meridian begins from the Sun and passes through the center of the galaxy, each boundary as follows: the Sun is about 25,000–28,000 ly (7.7–8.6 kpc) from the center of the Milky Way. This value is based on a geometric method, by measuring standard candle-like objects, and using different methods to obtain approximate but different values for these ranges. The center of the Milky Way is marked as a strong radio source called Ursa Major A* (remarkable Ursa Major A star). Centered on A* Centauri, the orbital motion of the object indicates that there is a massive dense object there.

After the March 1965 general elections, Mobutu and Casabuba returned to a political stalemate. Mobutu launched his second coup d'état in November 1965, taking control of the country. Under Mobutu, the Congo (renamed Saï in 1971) was transformed into a dictatorship until Mobutu was overthrown in 1997. Congolese colonial rule began in the late 19th century. Since Belgium's independence from the Netherlands in 1830, the kingdom's lack of international power and prestige frustrated King Leopold II of Belgium, who sought to persuade the government to support expansion around the then undeveloped colonies of the Congo Basin. The idea was so controversial with the government that Leopold eventually founded his own colony. Many supportive Western countries viewed Rio de Janeiro as an effective buffer against power struggles between the colonies, so Rio de Janeiro's private colony, the Free State of the Congo, was recognized internationally in 1885. Belgium's rule in the Congo was based on the so-called "colonial trinity" of state, missionaries and private companies. During the 1940s and 1950s, Congo experienced unprecedented levels of urbanization, and the colonial government launched various development programs aimed at making the territory a "model colony." The African nationalism movement developed in the 1950s outside of the Congo, mainly in the "évolués". The movement split several ethnically and geographically divergent political parties and groups. The greatest enemy of the Congolese national movement was the Abako League, led by Joseph Kasawubu. Despite being Africa's largest nationalist party, the National Movement has many different factions and positions on many issues.

Zhang Zhaodong (Chinese: 簡肇棟; pinyin: Zhang Zhaodong; born 18 August 1955) is a Taiwanese politician, doctor, and a member of the Democratic Progressive Party. He was elected to the Fifth Legislative Council at the end of 2001 and was re-elected at the end of 2004, but was defeated again at the beginning of 2008. He is a former member of the New York City Legislative Assembly. In September 2011, he resigned from the Legislative Council, resigned from the next Legislative Council election, and resigned from politics. On 18 December 2007, during the parliamentary elections, it was announced that Jiang was alleged to have bribed a Chinese nationalist candidate, Jiang Lianfu, during the parliamentary elections in mid-November 2007, when he visited Chen Lianji (Taiping City representative) and handed over 50,000 yuan in advance cash to Chen Lianji, asking Chen Lianji to help "pull people" and "vote" during the parliamentary elections, which was interpreted as "an attempt to tie up and solidify votes". On October 9, 2009, the Taiwan High Court of Justice ruled that Jiang's nomination was invalid, and he was re-elected by the People's Party of China. On January 9, 2010, he defeated Yu Wenqin, the current mayor of Taipei, who had been nominated by the Kuomintang, and was elected to the 7th Legislative Council. On September 11, 2011, in the middle of the night, Jin Zhao drove a car into Taichung City's Dalijiajie Road and killed a man who was drunk and fell on the road.

She said: The nomination of Comrade Li Junyi is mainly based on his extensive experience, as a member of the Legislative Council since the fifth session, he has performed very well, while in each observation, he is very explosive and combative comrade from politics, and the ability of basic integration is very strong. Among the "must vote" items in the poll, the people of Tainan County had the highest support for Lee. Since then, he has continued to rise in local support, and is often nominated for Tainan County Governor today. At the end of the same year, the Ministry of Internal Affairs announced the merger of Tainan City and the elevation of Tainan County, and the election of Tainan County Governor was cancelled at the same time. As a result, he lost the opportunity to run for governor of Tainan, and the following year, Lee was declared eligible to run for the first-ever mayoral election in Tainan. In addition to Li, the first-time mayoral candidate of Tainan, he was also a colleague of Lai Qing-de, Yee-jin, and then-Chief of Tainan, Xu Xie-fai, and then-Chief of Tainan County, Su Hwan-chi. On May 7, 2010, a press conference was held in Tainan City to announce the results of the first round of the People's Party of China (PPC) mayoral election, with the five candidates receiving 44.28%, 32.60%, 18.98%, 2.35%, and 1.79% of the votes, respectively. Lee said that he was willing to forgive the High Court Judge Chen Xiaofei, the accompanying Judge Sun Huilin and the appointed Judge Chen Yuyun, as long as they were able to apologize publicly, and if he did not apologize a week later, he would take legal action, accusing the three of misconduct.

Huang Jie (Chinese: 黃杰; November 2, 1902 – January 14, 1995) was a general, politician, and poet, who was awarded the Order of the Blue Sky, the Order of the Cloud, and other decorations.He was the Commander-in-Chief of the Army, the Chief of the Presidential Staff, the Commander-in-Chief of the Security Bureau, the President of Taiwan Province, the Minister of Defense, the Executive Council and the Strategic Advisor of the Presidential Office, the Commander-in-Chief of the Second Division of the National Army, the Commander-in-Chief of the Tax Police, the Commander-in-Chief of the Eighth Army of the National Revolutionary Army, the Director of the Chengdu Central Military School Education Department, the Director of the Sixth Branch School, the Commander-in-Chief of the Eleventh Army Group, the Director of the Central Training Group, the Commander-in-Chief of the Fifth Training Command, the Commander-in-Chief of the First Army, and the Commander-in-Chief of the Taip He graduated from Changsha High School in Hunan Province. In 1924, he entered the First Infantry Division of Huangpu Military School. In January 1925, he was appointed a lieutenant colonel of the 1st Regiment of Reconnaissance and participated in the First and Second Eastern Expeditions and the Battles of Guangzhou. In September 1926, he was promoted to commanding major of the 3rd Battalion, 1st Regiment, garrisoned in Chaozhou. Between 1927 and 1928, he participated in the Northern Expedition of the National Revolutionary Army, the Battles of Longtan, Fengyang, Bengbu, Xuzhou, Teng County and Jinan. After completing the Northern Expedition, he participated in the Western Expedition. In 1930, he participated in the Second Sino-Japanese War, serving as the brigade commander of the 2nd brigade of the 1st Division. At midnight on July 11, enemy forces broke through the line, the situation was urgent, Chiang Kai-shek insisted on commanding Yanagawa Station. Huang Jie, under Chiang Kai-shek's command, led three regiments of the Department of Light and Rapid Assault, recaptured Li Dam Shu, saved danger, and achieved great success, which is written in Chiang Kai-shek's Diary and the history of the National Revolutionary Army.

It is usually divided into "near the Qing Ming" and "near the Little Qing Ming": "The third day of the first month of March, in ancient times it was called the first day of the month, Zhangzhou people called it the third day of the month, dedicated to the ancestor's tomb." And the people of Quanzhou called the tomb of Qingming, which is called the tomb of Yeoming. The custom in Quanzhou is to sweep graves for a few days before and after the Ming Dynasty. The first tomb, called the "New Tomb," is usually laid on the second day of February. In the second and third years, the cemetery is usually cleaned for one day between the Spring Festival and the day before the Ming Dynasty. From the fourth year onwards, the cemetery can be visited on the day before or after the Ming Dynasty. According to the customs of Quanzhou, it is absolutely permissible to sweep graves on clear days, and it is not necessary to choose the day to be avoided. In Zhangzhou, more than half of the people choose to sweep graves near the small Qingming at the beginning of March, but due to the Republic of China government's designation of Qingming Festival as a national holiday, to coincide with the holiday, the day of Qingming Festival gradually became the main day of sweeping graves in southern Taiwan. It is customary in Hokkien to step on the grave of another person while walking along the way and say "borrowed" without regard to guilt. When they found the tomb, the ancestors prayed, telling the land gods and the ancestors to start sweeping the graves. It can also be used to repair the cracks in the cemetery, or to paint the gravestones, and when it is done, press grave paper on the grave, representing the repair of the ancestors' chambers. The tomb does not carry offerings, but only hammer sickles, paint, incense, paper money, and wine; if it does carry offerings, it is called a tomb; if it is a tomb, it is called a tomb; or if it has prepared boiled eggs or salted duck eggs, the ancestors of the ancestors throw egg shells on the tombstone or tomb mound, symbolizing the resurrection of the shells, the resurrection of life, other grenadier shells, clam shells, clam shells, shrimp shells, etc., for the same allegory.
